TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the thirteenth to the twenty-first reports of the Committee for 1992 relating to: development of RAAF base Scherger at Peppan, Cape York Peninsula, Queensland; construction of an Australian Embassy complex in Suva, Republic of Fiji; construction of Australian Embassy staff apartments at Attakarn Prasit, Bangkok, Thailand; redevelopment of Lavarack Army barracks in Townsville, stage 1; storage/display facility for the Australian War Memorial at Mitchell, ACT; Badgerys Creek Airport development, stage 1; development of a new international terminal complex at Brisbane Airport; York Park offices, Barton, ACT; and relocation of the Australian Hydrographic Office to Wollongong, NSW.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the House. The nine reports I have just tabled conclude an extremely busy year for the Committee, particularly in the period since August. The value of the projects in these nine reports is approximately $750m. The Public Works Committee has always prided itself on its bipartisan nature. In fact, until today, in the five years that I have been Chairman there has been only one dissenting report and that dissenting report was by two Government members. Today, we have two dissenting reports with the Committee being split on party political lines. I think it is a pity, and I hope it is not a fact, that the closer we come to an election the less bipartisan the Committee appears to become.

PARA.TAB: In the time available this morning, I do not propose to talk at length about each project but to mention a number of the more important issues which arose during the inquiries. While the Committee has recommended that the projects in both Suva and Bangkok proceed, it has reluctantly given its approval because it has been unable to carry out site inspections and therefore has been unable to properly assess each proposal. I urge the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) to give urgent consideration to the Committee's request to amend the Public Works Committee Act 1969 to remove the restrictions on the Committee meeting outside Australia and its external territories.

In relation to the Badgerys Creek Airport proposal, the Committee has recommended that the FAC stage 1 proposal not proceed but be replaced by an expanded stage 1 proposal. The expanded stage 1 proposal recommended by the Committee should include a 2,900-metre runway and not the 1,800-metre runway as proposed by the FAC.

While agreeing that there is a need for a second major airport in the Sydney basin and that Badgerys Creek is the most suitable location for such an airport, the Committee has concluded that the FAC proposal places too much emphasis on passenger demand and does not take account of the potential growth of freight services to the Asia-Pacific region or the scope for industrial growth in the western region of Sydney. However, the Committee believes that the $152m estimate provided by the FAC for a Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils type proposal is more realistic than the $42.46m estimate provided by the Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils.

As I have indicated, the Committee believes that the initial development at Badgerys Creek should include a 2,900-metre runway with the minimum associated infrastructure necessary to allow for both domestic and international operations. This should include the provision of navigational and visual aids and an instrument landing system. Essentially, after considering the evidence placed before it, the Committee has concluded that the FAC's stage 1 proposal is inadequate and unlikely to attract potential users.

In recommending that an expanded stage 1 proposal proceed, the Committee has also recommended that the FAC should seek additional Commonwealth funding. However, should the Government be unwilling to provide the necessary additional funding, a consortium, including Federal and State government bodies, local government, through the Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils, and other interested parties, should be formed to develop and operate Badgerys Creek Airport through private funding.

The seventh report I have tabled relates to the construction of a new international terminal complex at Brisbane Airport which is long overdue, I might add. The out-turn cost of the proposed work is $272m. The Committee has recommended that the work should proceed as planned. It should be remembered that the Committee, and indeed the Parliament, had already approved the preparation of the proposed site some two kilometres from the new domestic terminal in 1989. In arriving at its recommendation that construction should proceed, the Committee examined a number of important matters against the background of the Government's recently announced aviation policy reforms.

The siting of the new terminal, the capacity of the existing domestic terminal to handle international flights, two competing terminals and the views of the aviation industry were all examined by the Committee. In fact, the Committee considered the various options at great length, including the expansion of the existing domestic terminal and a stand alone international terminal.

The terminal design concept has a three-level configuration of 53,000 square metres and will provide seven aerobridge gates, four stand-off positions, four baggage reclaim units and three check-in islands. The main body of the proposed building will be designed to process 1,500 passengers per hour, although the initial capacity will be for 1,065 passengers per hour. The Federal Airports Corporation assured the Committee that additional aerobridge positions could be added quickly to cater for any increases in demand without disrupting the activity of the terminal.

The proposal for the construction of the York Park offices for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on a site in Barton, ACT, is one that has aroused considerable controversy. Indeed, the Opposition members on the Committee have dissented from the Committee's report. I must say that I was somewhat surprised to read extensive quotations from the dissenting report in yesterday's Australian. However, the Committee is satisfied that, on the evidence presented to it, the York Park proposal appears to be the most economical of the proposals considered for providing alternative accommodation for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.The Committee concluded that the Administrative Building requires extensive refurbishment to meet current standards for Commonwealth Public Service office accommodation, particularly in the areas of fire safety, building services and occupational health and safety.

In relation to the York Park site, the Committee believes that it is appropriate for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, which is a key policy department, to be located close to Parliament House. The Committee has also recommended that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade continue consultations on a regular basis with staff and staff associations during the design, development and construction of the York Park proposal and, in particular, in relation to the provision of child-care facilities. The Committee has recommended that the York Park project proceed at an estimated cost of $186.832m at April 1992 prices.

I find it somewhat amusing when politicians who occupy offices in this building refer to other buildings in Canberra as Taj Mahals. I am convinced that in the criticism of this project there is, unfortunately, an element of Canberra bashing. Also, it is interesting that my Opposition colleagues point out that public expenditure is under extreme pressure; and that is correct. They object to spending $187m on the York Park project in Canberra, but have no hesitation in agreeing to expenditure of $166m for a bare base airfield on the Cape York Peninsula.

The final report I have tabled relates to the relocation of the Australian Hydrographic Office to Wollongong at an estimated cost of $12.5m. This is also a project that has aroused some controversy, and I acknowledge that the Opposition members of the Committee have dissented from the Committee's report. The Australian Hydrographic Office is currently located in unsatisfactory accommodation in Walker Street, North Sydney, and there was general agreement that the Australian Hydrographic Office requires new accommodation.

The controversy surrounds the issue of loss of staff which may result from the transfer to Wollongong. However, the Department of Defence believes that the possible extent of staff losses will not be determined conclusively until all staff have exercised their election to relocate or not. Defence has acknowledged that the production rate of charts could slow for a period during and immediately following the move. However, Defence does not believe that safety of life at sea will be compromised.

During the public hearing, the Committee was told about the possible loss of key personnel. This argument is always presented when it is suggested that a government department or instrumentality move from a capital city to a decentralised location. It is an argument that I reject; some staff might leave, but there is always a turnover of staff in any organisation.

The work of the Australian Hydrographic Office could be carried out in almost any location with access to modern communication facilities. The Sydney site at Leichhardt, which the Committee inspected, would have a motorway three storeys high cutting through one corner of the block and be directly under the approach flight path of Sydney Airport—some location.Having considered all the evidence, the Committee is satisfied that the relocation of the Australian Hydrographic Office to Wollongong will not adversely affect its functions.

In conclusion, I want to mention briefly the reports relating to the development of RAAF base Scherger near Weipa on the Cape York Peninsula and the stage 1 redevelopment of Lavarack Army barracks at Townsville. RAAF base Scherger, which will be developed at a cost of $166.65m, is an important project as it will complete the chain of RAAF airfields across the north of Australia and provide a base for the deployment and coverage of the sea-air gap during a contingency.

The stage 1 redevelopment of the Lavarack Army barracks at Townsville at a cost of $23.433m is a topical development as Lavarack Barracks is the home of the Ready Deployment Force, elements of which it was announced yesterday will be sent to Somalia to assist with the United Nations relief mission. The Committee wishes it well on that important path. Mr Speaker, I have pleasure in commending these nine reports to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to comment on three or four of the defence related reports that the Public Works Committee has brought down today. In relation to the Royal Australian Air Force base Scherger in Queensland, we welcome this Public Works Committee report on the proposal to develop the bare base.

PARA.TAB: The coalition believes that the development of an air base on the Cape York Peninsula is an important part of any northern defence strategy. This proposal was initially put forward by the Fraser Government prior to the 1983 election. It says something about both defence budgets and the speed of defence planning as it is only now that we have really got the work approved by the Public Works Committee. In the event of a defence contingency in the Australian north, this base will play a significant role in providing a point for logistic and maintenance support as well as for tactical air operations.

With RAAF base Tindal in the Northern Territory and the bare base at Derby in Western Australia, an air base on the Cape York Peninsula will complete the chain of Air Force bases in the north. This is a worthwhile defence objective and one which signals Australia's commitment to develop a significant defence presence in the north.

I want to refer to one aspect of the Committee's work and that is the question of the location of the facility relative to the Cape York spaceport proposal. I raised this when the matter was first brought before the House. I would like to thank the Committee for addressing this issue. I note the report concludes that there is scope for cooperation between the two entities.

If it does not compromise the operation of Scherger as a RAAF base, I believe that access to the landing strip on a commercial basis may be of some value in encouraging the spaceport proposal to fruition. This still leaves open the question of the additional requirement for vital asset protection which Scherger and, if it is built, the spaceport will present. I hope that the Government will take a serious look at this issue as time goes on.

I now turn to the Public Works Committee report on the redevelopment of the Lavarack Army barracks. I do not want to take too much of the time of the House on this matter. Certainly, the coalition supports the expenditure of funds to update and modernise the facilities at Lavarack. I visited the ODF base recently. Some of the buildings are quite dilapidated and are certainly in need of replacement and upgrading. So it is not before time that the Government has correctly decided to modernise these facilities, which go back to the 1960s.

The ODF, particularly in its present circumstances, is entitled to decent facilities. As the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) pointed out, this is an appropriate time for us to discuss this issue in the House. The ODF will now get better facilities, admittedly somewhat after its return from Somalia.

On page 18 of the report, the Committee notes Defence plans for further capital facilities work at Lavarack outside the current Defence five-year plan. The five-year plan takes us to the end of 1988. So this section refers to unapproved work which might be carried on after that time. What is interesting about the Defence list of future work at Lavarack is that there is absolutely no mention of the facilities which would have to be built if the Government had any intention to relocate the School of Artillery from Holsworthy to Townsville.

The honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), who I am glad to see is in the House, made great play in the Townsville media at the time of the last Federal election of the proposed move of the Artillery School, which then Defence Minister Beazley announced when he visited the electorate of Herbert during the election campaign. This report conclusively proves that there is absolutely no intention whatsoever to relocate the Artillery School to Townsville. In fact, it is not even in the plans of the Defence Department for the turn of the century, let alone in the current five-year plan. I hope that the honourable member for Herbert is able to explain this to his constituents. If he chooses not to explain it to them, he can rest assured that we will be explaining it to them over and over again between now and the day of the next Federal election.

I turn to the controversial issue of the relocation of the Navy Hydrographic Office to Wollongong. I regret that the Labor members of the Committee have decided to support what some members of the Parliamentary Labor Party have admitted is little more than a pork-barrelling exercise. I note that there is a dissenting report signed by the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) and Senator Calvert about the relocation option. It is a tribute to the parliamentary process that some members, such as those three, are prepared to take an objective view of this matter, rather than being snowed by what could politely be described as political exigencies. Certainly nobody in the Illawarra area is in the slightest deceived by this political stunt. They know only too well that at the end of the day this will create very few jobs in the Illawarra. It is scant compensation for the number of jobs that Labor has destroyed in the Illawarra area over the last 10 years.

The dissenting report states quite correctly that the only reason for this proposal proceeding was that the Minister made a decision to relocate the Hydrographic Office for purely political reasons. Insufficient attention was given by the Government to the disruptive nature of the move or to the fact that the proposed office would be totally isolated from major naval facilities in Sydney. In addition, there remains universal opposition to the move to Wollongong from within Navy and the Hydrographic Office itself.

Overall, the coalition believes that the relocation of the office has been motivated by a shoddy attempt at pork-barrelling by the Labor Party, which is intent on trying to improve its flagging fortunes in an area that it has plunged into depression. I remind the House that when this matter was referred to the Public Works Committee I tried to table, but was not allowed to do so by the Labor Party, the Defence Department's advice to the Minister, which argued strenuously against the relocation to Leichhardt. Mr Podger, the appropriate deputy secretary from within the Department, who signed that minute, was supported all the way by the Royal Australian Navy. The documents show that Defence put Wollongong third on its list of possibilities and last in a list of three options for the relocation of the Hydrographic Office.

The coalition further believes that the proposed expenditure is unacceptable without taking a closer look at the Hydrographic Service as a whole and the full range of options which may be open to doing this essential research work in other less costly ways. In saying this, I recognise that there are deficiencies in the present Walker Street offices, which I have taken the trouble to visit. However, this accommodation will suffice for the short term until the coalition, in government, determines the future for an appropriately structured Hydrographic Office. I believe that the coalition will be able to develop a Hydrographic Service which is more efficient and cost-effective than the present organisation and which will not require a costly, disruptive and utterly unnecessarily relocation to Wollongong.

The decision to proceed with the York Park offices, at a cost of $186.2m, is in my view, as a former officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs, an absolute disgrace. I joined the Department of Foreign Affairs in 1976. From the time I joined—not because of my joining—the Administrative Building in Parkes which the Department uses was continually being refurbished. There was a constant process of refurbishment. I would like to know how much has been spent on that building since the beginning of the 1970s.

Here we have a new building at a cost of $186m in the midst of the worst recession this country has had since the Great Depression. It is in Canberra, a place which has suffered least from the recession. I think that that project is a complete disgrace. Many honourable members on the other side of the House agree with me; I know they do. It was just that little lack of courage at the end of the day that I understand persuaded the Labor members of the Public Works Committee not to support the dissenting report which would have put paid to this utterly ridiculous waste of taxpayers' money.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As a member of the Public Works Committee, I think from the outset that I should congratulate the Secretary of the Committee, Peter Roberts, and his assistants, Mike Fetter, Denise Denahy, Sue Whalan and Sophia Konti, for the excellent way in which they have been able to get these nine reports together in such a short time, so that they can be presented today. The Public Works Committee has worked assiduously to get these reports together. It has worked very constructively. I am proud to be part of that Committee. By and large, we do work very well together.

PARA.TAB: It is quite disappointing, really, when the shadow Minister for Defence, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), talks about the hydrography works being moved to Wollongong. The sad thing about politics today is that the word `decentralisation' does not exist at all. Surely there are many businesses or industries, particularly Government ones, that could be moved out of Melbourne, Sydney and Canberra and so forth to country and regional areas. That should be promoted and supported. The ironical thing about this is that Wollongong is only 80 kilometres from Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would think they were going to Darwin.

—As the Chairman quite rightly points out, anyone would think they were moving to the Northern Territory or somewhere like that. Eighty kilometres is nothing. If we can support these types of industries moving out, I think that we should be doing so. I think that it was very positive representation from the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) and the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), two members of the Committee, which played a very big part in the hydrography works moving to Wollongong.

PARA.TAB: I support wholeheartedly the Chairman's remarks regarding Fiji and Thailand building these complexes. It is very hard for the Committee to make constructive reports on these areas without having a look at them. I think that in a number of projects that we have looked at throughout Australia, we have been able to make recommendations to save taxpayers many millions of dollars, simply because of the fact that we have had practical opportunities to look at these proposals.

The fact that we were not able to look at those projects in Fiji and in Thailand I think is very disappointing indeed. It is something that should be rectified. I cannot recommend strongly enough that future Public Works Committees have the opportunity to look at projects that are going to be constructed overseas, particularly when they are going to cost so many millions of dollars. All the Committee can do is take the evidence that is supplied to it. I know that we had one report from an ambassador overseas who was highly critical of the complex that was built in an area where he was to be stationed for a couple of years. I am sure that if the Committee had had the opportunity to look at that complex, the situation would have been different.

I cannot commend highly enough the Secretary of the Committee, Peter Roberts, and his staff for the excellent job they have done in presenting the reports. I also congratulate the Committee as a whole on the very hard work it has done to bring these reports forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The old truism that if one wants something stuffed up get the Government involved was never more applicable than it has been to the provision of aviation infrastructure in Australia over the last 20 years. In this respect may I welcome the report of the Public Works Committee on the Badgerys Creek airport development stage 1 and its report on the development of a new international terminal complex for the FAC airport in Brisbane.

PARA.TAB: The Public Works Committee should be congratulated on making what I think is a rather brave report in both these instances, and in particular on its decision to reject the proposal for stage 1 of the development of Badgerys Creek. We know that a lot of politics is being played at the moment; there will always be in these matters. The reality is that the proposal for stage 1 of Badgerys Creek was never a real proposition in terms of the proper development of that particular airport.

A real difficulty we have had over the years is that there has been a number of changes in the nature of airport infrastructure administration through various changes in the Department and with the introduction of the FAC, but at the end of the day our record is really quite dreadful. The reality is, whether we like it or not, that there will have to be a second facility for Sydney by the end of this decade.

While we are now proceeding, despite the troglodytes on the other side objecting to every move, to get the third runway in place at Sydney international airport, we are facing a situation where, by the end of this decade, that second facility will be required. On the present projections of traffic inflow into Australia, we will receive something like seven million international visitors by that year, with about 60 per cent of them going through Sydney. That will mean almost a tripling of the international airline capacity coming into Australia at that time and an increase in domestic capacity of about two or 2 1/2 times. Clearly, even with the third runway and the constraints that are on Kingsford-Smith Airport, it would be very difficult for us to even remotely suggest that we could handle that sort of growth, despite the introduction of new air traffic control systems and new air traffic control facilities.

The cost of a new international airport is enormous. In the case of Badgerys Creek, I have no doubt that by the end of the day we are probably looking at a $10 billion development. Despite the controversy that has been going on about the location of Badgerys Creek, quite frankly I do not think we have many other options. I was delighted to see that the Public Works Committee in its report suggested at one stage that it should look perhaps at a joint development between private enterprise and the FAC to get this airport under way. I think that is the first step in the right direction. Obviously, from my point of view, the Government should look at the total privatisation of the Badgerys Creek airport development. It can be done.

I will give an example of what has been achieved, or what is being achieved, overseas in terms of the private development of airports. I cite the example of Denver, Colorado, where there is this huge airport for a city of about 1.5 million people. While it is a hub, and while there are greater air traffic flows in the United States, I think it is a good example of what can be done. On 1 October 1989 the airport authority, which is a private group made up of local government and others, decided to let the contracts for the development of the new Denver Airport. It is under way and will open on 1 October 1993.

Four years to build a major international airport is not too bad. It will not be finished on 1 October 1993, though, because only six runways will be operating by then. It is to have a total capacity of 15 runways and a passenger handling capacity of 200 million per year. We have taken about 25 years to make a decision on the third runway in Sydney. Getting through the environmental impact statements took longer than it took to reconstruct Kuwait Airport after the war. But Denver shows what can be achieved.

The financing of that airport was really quite interesting. In the United States there is a passenger ticket tax which is put towards the development of airports. Only half a billion dollars of the Federal ticket tax went into the development of Denver; the rest of it was raised on a public float.

The first three floats resulted in an oversubscription by the general public of the area, and the fourth float was held up for some time while the situation regarding Continental Airlines was sorted out. It has now gone on and that airport is completely funded. I believe that the establishment of a private consortium to develop Badgerys Creek is probably the way to go so that we can get it off the ground by the end of this decade.

We should also be aware that the position overseas now is that airports are developed further from the inner city. In the case of Denver the airport is about 35 miles from the centre of town. Another interesting one is Stansted in the United Kingdom, which is the third airport for London, which is exactly the same distance from the centre of London as is Badgerys Creek from the centre of Sydney.

While we can talk about this private development of Badgerys Creek—and that is the way we should go—we have to realise that an awful lot of public infrastructure will have to be put in. High speed rail links, water supply and sewerage systems, oil and fuel supplies are going to amount to a lot of money. If we are going to be serious about the development of these airports, obviously there will still be a role for government to play in that regard, but the principle of getting it out for private tender as soon as possible will be very much at the forefront of the Federal coalition's agenda.

I wish to comment briefly on the decision of the Committee to go ahead with the development of the new international terminal complex at Brisbane International Airport. I do not know how many times over the years I have risen in this place to talk about the disaster that is Brisbane International Airport, and particularly the terminal. Obviously the Public Works Committee had a very difficult role to play in relation to that airport, especially with the changes of policy. At the end of the day, it has probably come down with the right decision.

The real difficulty regarding that international terminal probably goes back to a previous Public Works decision of the early 1980s, when it was decided not to proceed with the development of the international terminal, which originally was to be part of the major terminal complex. It is obvious now that we are going to have a terminal one, terminal two situation in Brisbane, with all the difficulties and inconveniences that that causes with people having to ply between the different terminals to make connections with the flights. But as so much money was invested, against my better judgment, I must say, in the provision of the sandfill at the Brisbane airport and the fact that something has to be done in Brisbane in a hurry and that there is room to expand, the decision is probably the right one.

I put governments of the future on notice in light of the fact that one of the things we have not been very good at in the past is being able to project the possible traffic growth. The reason that the new terminal in Brisbane did not go ahead in the early 1980s was that they could not see any traffic requirement until 1993. It looks as though we are going to go to 1995 or 1996 at best to get it on line. No consideration was taken as to the effect of the Commonwealth Games and, of course, Expo, and the growth in tourism. Therefore, I put future governments on notice with this prediction. I am not being big headed about it, but some of my predictions might have been a bit closer to the mark than those of some of the powers that be in the past.

The reality is that Brisbane is going to become the number two airport to Sydney by the turn of this century. I would not be at all surprised, when the present growth patterns are studied, if we actually reach that by about 1998. When we look at the decision of Air New Zealand to put a hub in over Brisbane, with 58 flights a week from that airline alone going through the place within the next two or three years; when we look at the tremendous expansion of the Japanese market and what Qantas is doing by introducing direct flights; when we look at the applications from companies such as North-West Airlines and the fact that United is coming on stream into Brisbane with more and more flights, it is pretty obvious that the major growth in international traffic is going to happen in Brisbane.

I was pleased to see in that report that, while a reference was made to the seven air bridges and the 11 hard standing areas, the Committee acknowledged that there may be a need for some very rapid expansion of the Brisbane terminal. I hope that governments of the future do take that into consideration too, because the last thing that we would want to happen in an airport such as Brisbane is the disaster with the delays that have happened in Sydney. To that extent, I extend my congratulations to the Committee, its Chairman and members and, indeed, the secretariat, for what I think were very well considered and vitally important decisions on these two aspects of the provision of aviation infrastructure.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—One of the ironic things that members of this House see, when reports of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works are presented, is members of the Opposition coming in here and talking to those reports and supporting them in the main, against the background of their own policy which calls for cuts in public expenditure of $10 billion. I know that, if there is a change of government at the next election and we are on the other side of the House, Public Works Committee reports on major capital works projects undertaken by the Commonwealth will be few and far between. I will say something about those issues in a minute.

PARA.TAB: First of all, I wish to refer to the report on the development of the RAAF base Scherger at Peppan, Cape York Peninsula. This is a very important recommendation by the Public Works Committee for, upon completion of that air base, it will complete an arc of air bases extending from Learmonth, Curtin, Tindal, Darwin, Scherger and Townsville, to give us the capability of deploying aircraft and other elements of the Australian Defence Force to conduct operations. It is long overdue and I take personal delight in seeing the recommendation being adopted by the House today.

The development will have further significance. The base will be able to be used by United States forces deploying to Australia for training purposes, or places from which they can conduct joint operations with the Australian Defence Force. Thirdly, the air base could be used for any activity that might come from the proposal to develop a space port in Cape York Peninsula. So the development of RAAF base Scherger is fundamentally important not only to the Defence Force of Australia but also to our economy and to uplifting the eyes of all Australians so they realise that enormous opportunities exist with the development of this base.

The redevelopment of Lavarack barracks is also an important initiative by the Government. It is a project that will cost $23.45m and involve construction of purpose built accommodation for 3rd Brigade Administrative Support Battalion and 162 Reconnaissance Squadron, a barracks sick quarters and an area curbside refuelling facility for Townsville logistic company.

Lavarack barracks is nearly 30 years old. There have been many ongoing improvements over that period. But it is now in urgent need of extensive upgrading and refurbishment of many of the facilities. This is long overdue. Indeed, this work is additional to work that has been carried out at the base over the last few years to upgrade accommodation for single soldiers, mess accommodation and so forth, costing nearly $27m. Altogether 36 buildings have been involved in that upgrade, and that is also long overdue.

I take advantage of the opportunity this morning while dealing with Lavarack barracks to wish the First Battalion Royal Australian Regiment every success in its deployment to Somalia as part of the United Nations force to assist in the pacification and the provision of humanitarian aid to the people of that unfortunate and tragic country. I know that the 1st Battalion Royal Australian Regiment, which has one of the most distinguished records of any battalion in the Australian Army, will perform its duties in the highest traditions of the Australian Defence Force. It goes with the good wishes of the Townsville community. I know that the families of the soldiers of the First Battalion are absolutely supportive of their spouses, their folk, in this very important deployment.

I must say that there was a sour note associated with some of the press releases yesterday. To the credit of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), he gave unequivocal support to the deployment of these Defence Force personnel to Somalia. But it was the shadow Minister for defence, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), who was reported as putting a slight snide caveat on the deployment by suggesting that somehow or other it would leave Australia's domestic defence capabilities `dangerously thin'. I know that soldiers in the 6th Brigade and 1 Brigade reading that waffle would take serious umbrage at that statement that taking 900 soldiers from the Australian Defence Force, capable as they are, will leave this country's defences dangerously thin to conduct necessary operations in our region. I am very disappointed in the shadow Minister for defence.

His snide remarks this morning about the School of Artillery announced by one of Australia's outstanding Ministers for Defence, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), before the last Federal election deserve some comment. It so happens that the Department has acquired a major property in Townsville called Dotswood for the purposes, as I understand it, of the location of a range for the School of Artillery. At great expense, an environmental impact study has been carried out, costing nearly $1m. That property is now owned by the Department of Defence and all the necessary environmental requirements have been completed satisfactorily.

The announcement by the honourable member for Swan was in line with the shift to the north of our defence capability that has been going on unabated since 1983. His statements about a so-called report containing no reference to the Government's future intentions with respect to what will happen to the School of Artillery are meaningless. Bureaucrats do not decide government policy with respect to defence or anything else. That decision will be taken by the Government at the appropriate time.

The snide comment by the shadow Minister for defence with respect to this issue does not go over very well in the Townsville community, where copies of the Department of Defence's review of the Opposition's defence policy have received wide circulation in the defence community. The Department of Defence has estimated that, with the full Fightback proposals implemented with respect to the Department of Defence, between 1993 and 1996 there will be a shortfall of between $850m and $950m in defence expenditure.

There are capable people in the Opposition who are well able to perform the very responsible duties of shadow Minister for defence. The honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) is one of them. The very able Senator David MacGibbon, the Deputy Chairman of the Defence Subcommittee, is another. It is a great pity that the Opposition spokesman on defence, as a person who should have a great commitment to the defence of Australia, is the facile honourable member for Mayo.

He also made snide comments about the relocation of the Hydrographic Office to the Illawarra. I just cannot understand the import of his comments. Is he suggesting that somehow or other this is another sleazy piece of pork-barrelling? Is that what he is suggesting that the Department of Defence is involved in? Nobody believes that. I would find it outrageous if I were a senior defence bureaucrat listening to someone mouthing off that rubbish in this chamber. That is not the sort of statement I expect from a responsible shadow Minister for defence. Every time I come into this chamber and listen to that drivel, I expect not only Government members but also Opposition members to stand up and correct it.

I would like formally to thank members of the Department of Administrative Services and the Australian Construction Service representatives who have been involved with the Public Works Committee for ensuring that these projects were documented and supported to the extent that these reports could be brought into the Parliament. I believe that, in my experience with both of those organisations, they perform their duties in a most professional way and are of great assistance not only to the Department of Defence but also to the Australian Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to say a few words about the reports by the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works on Badgerys Creek and the Brisbane Airport terminal. Those words relate to the processes that will be involved in the privatisation of those operations. I note that the Committee, in its report on Badgerys Creek, has been—not to put too fine a point on it—a little critical of the operations of the Federal Airports Corporation. As the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) said in his remarks a few moments ago, if the Federal Airports Corporation's approach remains inadequate, then the Government should be encouraging Federal, State and local governments to get together with other interested parties in order to arrange private funding of the operations of Badgerys Creek.

PARA.TAB: We have had some things to say about the operations of the Federal Airports Corporation over time. It is a government owned, Sydney based bureaucracy. It is hard to see how the Federal Airports Corporation can take into account fully the wishes of the travellers in distant places around Australia. For that reason, the coalition has been urging the Government to look closely at the possibility of privatising the Federal Airports Corporation airports. That is our policy.
I want to make a few more remarks about this, but I want to lead into them by quoting from an article on the privatisation of Qantas from the Business Review Weekly of 11 December this year. It said:

The Qantas trade sale campaign, in which a share in Qantas is being discussed with other international operators, is proving a tortuous and confused process. It has been . . . described by one of the potential buyers as "a bunch of rank amateurs . . .

SPEECH.PARA: The `bunch of rank amateurs' is the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), and the former Minister for Transport and Communications, now Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley), who, over a period of years now, have brought Qantas through this tortuous and confused process and are behaving like a bunch of rank amateurs. I cannot put Senator Collins completely in this class; he has just fallen into bad company. I want to quote what Senator Collins had to say in respect of privatisation. In the Senate on 7 December during the second reading debate on the Qantas Sale Bill, he said:

PARA.TAB: The same applies to our airports. I am not suggesting that some airports may not at some future time be improved by sale. For example, at some future time when the second Sydney airport is truly competitive with the existing airport in Sydney, it may well be in the national interest to sell both airports.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins is signalling that the Government will change its mind about airports in the same way as it has changed its mind about most of the privatisations that it has started to undertake. I say to Senator Collins that the condition precedent for privatising does not have to be a competitive market; it can also be a contestable market. As a result of this report by the Public Works Committee, we now have a contestable market emerging in Sydney. In those circumstances there is no reason why the Government should not proceed to the privatisation not only of Badgerys Creek, but also the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

PARA.TAB: We have to understand that airports are really only pieces of real estate. It is true that they can exercise a monopoly position with regard to the provision of aviation services. No government would allow them to abuse that monopoly position. Any part of the operations of a government business enterprise that could exercise monopoly powers would necessarily require, as part of the privatisation, some form of cap on the charges in order to protect the public against abuse of those monopoly powers. But there are no monopoly operations with regard to businesses that might be set up in and around airports, wholesale and retail operations in airports, and education and training. None of these situations are monopoly situations. Under those circumstances, provided there is appropriate protection for the travelling public against the monopoly situation with regard to aviation services, there is no reason at all why the Government should not take advantage of the trigger provided by this report and move to the privatisation of the Federal Airports Corporation airports.

In that respect, we would prefer to see the $270m being spent by the private sector in the Brisbane international terminal. There will be a need to dovetail that in, with the eventual privatisation of Brisbane Airport, where there is some competition at the margin, perhaps with the Coolangatta Airport. We would prefer to see the construction, ownership, control and operations of that terminal also being in the hands of the private sector.

For some time now, the Committee for Melbourne, whose members include Senator Button, the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) and Bill Kelty of the ACTU, has been pressing the Government and, ironically, Senator Collins to move towards transferring the ownership of Melbourne Airport out of the hands of the Federal Airports Corporation, which as I have said is a Sydney based bureaucracy, into the hands of Melbourne interests. Bill Kelty said to Senator Collins, `Just give us our airport'. Why? Because he, the Committee and others in Melbourne are convinced that the best interests of Melbourne and the State of Victoria will be served by having the ownership and control of Tullamarine Airport in the hands of local interests and, we would say, private interests.

I join my colleagues in commending the Public Works Committee for its reports on Badgerys Creek and the international terminal complex at Brisbane. I also join my colleagues in thanking all the members of the Committee and the staff associated with it for the job that they have done.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PRICE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As a western suburbs member who has taken a keen interest in Badgerys Creek, I could not resist the opportunity to make a small contribution this morning. Frankly, I say to the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) that his report on Badgerys Creek certainly exceeded my expectations. I particularly believe that it will be well received by the people of western Sydney.

PARA.TAB: I do not think it is useful going over old coals, except that I would like to make a couple of points. One could be forgiven, sitting here on the Government side, for believing that, in terms of aviation policy, it was this Government that has held everything up and that it was the Opposition that was all gung ho when in office previously and is now.

TALK.START.PARA: —The third runway?

—Of course, nothing could be further from the truth. Indeed, some of the opportunities that Australia is realising through tourism are because of this Government's deliberate policy to deregulate civil aviation, both domestically and internationally. I think it is true to say that we are yet to reap the full benefits of that deregulation.

PARA.TAB: The shadow Minister for privatisation, the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Beale), says, `What about the third runway?'. I make no secret of the fact that I am disappointed that the third runway went ahead. People like to give examples of overseas countries—I am afraid I am not as well travelled as some of my Opposition colleagues—and it is a fact that a lot of money is being spent on enormous airports in our region as countries see the benefit of tourism. It has always been a disappointment to me that we did not decide to put a massive airport in initially at Badgerys Creek, capable of taking us into the twenty-first century and beyond. But we have to move on; the third runway decision has been taken. One cannot say it was with a very fulsome public discussion and involvement process, but that decision has passed us.

We now turn to Badgerys Creek. I think I reflect some of the pleasure of the people in the western suburbs when I endorse the Committee's report by saying that what we really need for Sydney and tourism is a robust competition policy in relation to Badgerys Creek. For that, we need a couple of things. Firstly, we do not need both airports being run by one organisation. In that regard, the FAC will always seek to recoup its sunk investment in Kingsford-Smith Airport. We will never be free of the suspicion that it would wish to hold back the development of Badgerys Creek.

The Committee has recommended that stage one at Badgerys Creek be deferred and that we go for a larger runway at Kingsford-Smith capable of taking both domestic and international traffic, and that the FAC approach the Government for the money. In the current budgetary circumstances that is going to be difficult, but the report provides the fall-back option of seeking private involvement in Badgerys Creek, something I am on the public record as having advocated.

I particularly welcome the report. I certainly hope the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) and the Cabinet will give it the full consideration that it so richly deserves. I am sure it is going to lead to a lot of discussion and involvement by the people of western Sydney, who realise that, given a chance, we will be able to see a more rapid development than possibly officials from DOTAC have to date envisaged. I support the remarks of the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) about the estimates of traffic. Whatever the potential for attracting additional airline traffic into Sydney, it will be maximised only if we have a robust, competitive policy which allows Badgerys Creek to compete, as it will, with Kingsford-Smith. That requires a runway which will take both domestic and international traffic and be managed by an organisation other than the FAC. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to confine my remarks to the York Park proposal, which the Opposition opposes, for an expenditure of some $186.8m, plus the $80m-odd that will be required to upgrade the existing building. The proposal is for a new building containing 46,000 square metres of useable floor area. Of that amount, 41,000 square metres will be allocated to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, with an additional amount of 5,300-odd square metres to be taken up by Austrade. The report of the Public Works Committee said that the 7,000 square metres required by AIDAB could not be accommodated in this proposal.

PARA.TAB: The minority report put down by my colleagues the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) and Senator Paul Calvert, senator for Tasmania, pointed out that the proposal for the construction of a high security annex, which they have suggested should be fully investigated, was at a far lower cost of $102m all-up. The advantages of this proposal are that there would be a substantially lower cost and that it would provide an additional 14,000 square metres of floor area, plus 240 additional car parking spaces. The cost of the Government's proposal—$187m, or all-up $267m—is excessive and exorbitant, particularly in these very difficult times. The new proposal for York Park has been described by some as `Gareth's Gazebo'. It is totally inappropriate in these times.

The significant point to be raised with regard to the York Park development is that, while it is a substantially bigger building, it provides the same net useable floor area. That would seem to be a complete waste of money. I have expressed my concerns in this chamber before about the lack of involvement, consultation and use of expertise in the private sector with regard to this proposal. That point was also highlighted in my colleagues' minority report, which said:

SPEECH.PARA: Another dimension to the York Park proposal is that private enterprise has not been given the opportunity to compete for the right to design and develop a building able to meet the accommodations needs . . .

My colleagues went on to point out that those accommodation needs could be met far more competitively in the proposal they put forward. That is a view which the Opposition supports. We consider that the annex building should be fully investigated because it is far more cost-efficient and it would provide an additional 14,000 square metres of floor area, plus an additional 240 car parking spaces.

PARA.TAB: Our major concern is that the York Park proposal, as submitted by the Committee, is for an all-up expenditure of $267m for a building that is larger while only providing the same net lettable floor area as the present building—a building that the Department is saying is inadequate, does not provide the accommodation space that people working in the building require and is cramped because of insufficient space. We would have to ask the question: why build a building at such enormous cost and of such large proportions that does not meet the needs of the clients for additional floor area? For that reason, the Opposition opposes this expenditure.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would like to associate myself with the report of the Public Works Committee relating to the relocation of the Australian Hydrographic Office to Wollongong, New South Wales—a relocation which I was at the forefront in pursuing when it came to my knowledge some 12 months ago that the Navy was planning to move from North Sydney. This matter was drawn to my attention by the news editor of one of Wollongong's television stations. He had heard it at a private party and suggested that, given the state of the economy and the depths of the recession in the Illawarra region, as an employment generating proposition this proposal may be pursued.

PARA.TAB: The news editor was somewhat taken aback when I decided that he was absolutely right and that the proposal to decentralise this particular operation—and, indeed, any other Commonwealth operation—out of a major city was a proposal which I had personally been supporting for quite a number of years.

The history books will show that, as a result of intensive lobbying—and I make no apology for that as the local member representing Wollongong—and that as a result of a consistent effort by Wollongong City Council to meet the needs expressed in the brief put forward by the Department of Defence in respect of the requirements of the Hydrographic Office in Wollongong and in response to a demonstrated need in an economic and social sense for this particular project to proceed, we were successful. We were successful in that today the Public Works Committee has brought down a report which recommends for good, strong, economic and social reasons that the Hydrographic Office be relocated to Wollongong.

Some three years ago, an organisation called the Illawarra Regional Consultative Council was formed in Wollongong. This council brought together representatives of the local community—representatives of business, trade unions and government. It was chaired by me under the auspices of the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. The idea was to develop an economic strategy for the Illawarra region which would be a guide to government, to business, to the trade union movement and to the community of the Illawarra in an effort to bring together those major players to ensure that we could get on the road to economic recovery.

One of the recommendations in that strategy report went to this particular issue of the decentralisation of Federal Government offices out of Sydney and attracting them to regional cities such as Wollongong. Specifically, the Australian Taxation Office was mentioned in that report. I am pleased to say in passing that that proposal was supported by the Government and construction is at present under way in Wollongong just around the corner from the proposed location of the Hydrographic Office that we are debating here this morning.

That decentralisation policy could be extended to embrace any government entity. When we consider issues of this nature, it is important that we do not simply look at the dollars and cents; we need to give consideration to other factors such as the economic and social conditions prevailing in different parts of Australia and whether or not it is the responsibility of government to take those factors into consideration when making a location decision. I am pleased to say that those factors obviously have been taken into consideration in this case.

I mentioned earlier that the Illawarra is a region which has suffered considerably because of the industrial restructuring that is taking place in Australia. In Wollongong private enterprise has implemented policies to make major industries more efficient, to work smarter and to become technologically advanced but with the unfortunate consequence of reduced employment opportunities. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), in his contribution as shadow spokesman on defence issues, talked about the Navy's relocation proposal for the Hydrographic Office using terms such as `pork-barrelling' and `a political stunt'. He said that few jobs would be created and that this would add to the miserable record of Labor, which has destroyed jobs in the Illawarra in the past 10 years.

As a long term resident of Wollongong and as the local member who represents that city in this Parliament, I am offended by those remarks. It was not the Labor Government that decided in 1983 to slash the work force at BHP from 23,000 to a present day total of fewer than 7,000 employees; it was the company that made that decision. It was also the company's decision, through the steel industry plan which this Government put in place and which in fact saved the steel industry in this country, to invest $1.8 billion to re-equip its plant. This necessarily led to fewer job opportunities through a massive restructuring and downsizing of the work force.

Rather than criticising the Labor Government for causing job losses in that industry in the past 10 years, I think people should reflect that if there had not been a steel industry plan we would not be talking about a steel industry in this country at all. It was not the Labor Government which saw massive restructuring in our other main industry in the Illawarra, the coal industry, which saw 3 1/2 thousand coalminers' jobs lost in the last eight years or so because of efficiency drives, the fact that geological conditions underground meant that coal seams were no longer workable and so on. It is absolute arrant nonsense to suggest that it was and that it is Labor which has destroyed jobs in Wollongong. It is a simple fact that a major industrial city and complex—that is, Wollongong, Port Kembla and the Illawarra region in general—have undergone major industrial restructuring and micro-economic reform that we hear about so often which has resulted in much of the rise in unemployment in that area.

I think it is also quite nonsensical for the honourable member for Mayo to suggest that this decision produced an outcome whereby a naval facility was isolated from other naval facilities in the immediate area. As has been stated by the Chairman of the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works and other honourable members in discussions this morning, Wollongong is in fact 80 kilometres from Sydney and the existing major naval facility in Sydney Harbour. It is a little more than 80 kilometres from another major naval facility at Jervis Bay. How then can it be isolated?

It is also located adjacent to a major technological area of BHP's operations. This was a major selling point for Wollongong in attracting this facility to our region. There is also a major university which is at the forefront of technology encompassing a lot of the work that would be necessary in order for the Hydrographic Office to operate. It is absolute nonsense to say that there would be massive dislocation.

Some Opposition members have submitted a dissenting report and referred to the fact that the Wollongong option would be disruptive and would have an adverse effect on the morale of key technical staff. So what? If the decision is taken to decentralise a facility of this nature people will have to move out of Sydney to the south coast which has a far better environment than Sydney. It is cheaper to live; the cost of living is a lot less, in terms of housing and other matters. But people are complaining about that. I do not know what they want, quite frankly. Rather than being, as is described by the honourable member for Mayo, pork-barrelling and a political stunt with few job creation opportunities, in fact this decision is an act of a caring, compassionate government which is in tune with the specific needs of a local region.

The $12.5m that will be invested in the building of the new facility will have an enormous multiplier effect in the Illawarra region. The 100 jobs that will be created when the building is completed—most of the people will be transferred from Sydney; but, if we are to believe those on the other side, this is not the case—will open up opportunities for Wollongong based people. I think that should be applauded rather than denigrated.

If nothing else, the fact that the honourable member for Mayo and the shadow spokesman for sport, Senator Michael Baume, have come out and publicly opposed Wollongong as an option demonstrates what the Liberals have always thought of regions like the Illawarra and cities like Wollongong: they could not care less.

They could not care less that the unemployment rate at the moment is about 13.8 per cent, marginally above the national average. They could not care less that industrial restructuring has gone on in that part of the world and that this is an opportunity to generate meaningful employment through construction which will have an enormous multiplier effect by that amount of money being generated in the local community.

Finally, I turn to those people both on the other side of this House and indeed in the local Illawarra community who have chips on their shoulders. An issue which is often reflected in respect of previous State Labor Governments is that Wollongong never gets anything. Here is tangible proof that Wollongong does get something from Labor. If we add to that the $20m worth of building, the 275-plus jobs that will be created in the regional office of the Australian Taxation Office building which is under construction at the moment, the Commonwealth office block, the grain handling facility, the steel industry plan, all the sporting facilities that have been created through Federal Government assistance, and all the other things that have come from the Federal Labor Government, I would just ask those cynical people in Wollongong to have a second thought. This is a proposal which is welcomed by the people of the Illawarra, by the people of Wollongong. It is something which we desperately need. We look forward to its approval here in the Parliament later today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the amendments to the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 sets out to reduce the amount of information which banks must provide about unclaimed moneys under the Banking Act. The amendment reflects the Government's experience that the name and address of a solicitor acting on behalf of an estate of a deceased person is not necessary, since the banks are already responsible for checking the bona fides of any claimants.

PARA.TAB: The other significant amendment serves to add the names `Commonwealth Savings Bank', `Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia' and `CSB' to the list of names protected under the 1959 Commonwealth Banks Act. This amendment is designed to prevent these names being appropriated for the purposes of soliciting money, in the process taking advantage of the goodwill associated with those names.

Because the word `Commonwealth' appears to be implicit in these titles, the banks to be named would otherwise be unable to obtain the same degree of protection that is available to other banks. The Ministerial Council for Corporations has reportedly considered this matter and the States and Territories have accordingly agreed to this proposal. The only other amendment concerns a name change to one of the banks listed in the schedule to the Bill.

It should be pointed out that many of the concerns raised by me on behalf of the coalition when this Bill was originally debated in the House remain pertinent. When the Bill was debated on 4 November, I made the point that many of the taxation issues with implications for further foreign bank entry into Australia had yet to be resolved. This is despite the fact that these matters have been under active consideration for some time now.

Although the offshore banking unit legislation has all but been passed by the Parliament, there is still more legislation required to facilitate the entry of foreign banks into Australia. Foreign banks are potentially at a disadvantage when converting existing subsidiaries in Australia into branches, because the existing law does not allow them to carry forward their losses. Some $2 billion in accumulated losses has been notched up over the past three years or so by foreign banks in Australia, and so taxation and other legislation to facilitate the conversion of those losses to operations with branch status is of great importance to the future of these banks. I am sure that the Government recognises that very pertinent fact. In fact, the Government signalled as early as June this year that the necessary legislation would be forthcoming.

When this Bill was first debated, I noted that there was still no sign of this facility and that any such legislation risked being caught up in the calling of the next Federal election. Since then, my attention has been drawn to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 8 December headed `Foreign Bank Tax Talks Stall'. The article begins by noting:

SPEECH.PARA: A crucial meeting held yesterday involving Federal Government and industry representatives failed to reach agreement on key taxation issues affecting foreign banks.

The haggling, it would seem, is still going on. We have reached the end of the sittings for the year with no sign of the legislation that the Government said would be forthcoming as early as June this year. It is now quite likely that the Parliament will be dissolved before the next scheduled sitting in February next year, so these problems will remain unlegislated for some time. Although the Government might—and I emphasise `might'—be in a position to make an announcement about its policy before such legislation is proposed and passed, this is a very complicated area of tax law and there are grave dangers in legislating by press release, particularly given the strong possibility of a change of Government early next year.

PARA.TAB: The point of all this is that despite Labor's high flying rhetoric about turning Australia into a major regional financial centre—a worthy goal which we all support—the Government has failed in its duty to provide the necessary legislative framework for that goal to be realised. The problem is that Labor spends a lot of its time talking before it gets around to acting and then fails to give appropriate priority to its actions when it has finally stopped talking and decided to do something. With those few remarks, I commend the amendments to the Committee and say that the coalition in Government looks forward to picking up where Labor has left off on this issue.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments to the Qantas Sale Bill 1992 go to the heart of the Government's policy in regard to the extent of overseas ownership in Qantas. In considering these amendments, it is important that we should understand how we got to this point. To start, I will quote from an article in the Business Review Weekly of 11 December on the privatisation of Qantas and the extent of foreign ownership. The article says that the privatisation exercise is:

SPEECH.PARA: fraught with financial danger because it could blow up and jeopardise the goodwill of its newest clients: the passengers . . .
It continues:
From early this year, the problems of privatising Qantas became perceptible.
The Chairman of Qantas, Mr Dix, is reported to have said recently:

. . . negotiations over Qantas are "very transparent" to the public and nobody could afford to sell Qantas out of "desperation for funds." He says: "The Australian public would never forgive the Government if it gave away the airline at less than the full price.

The Qantas trade sale campaign, in which a share in Qantas is being discussed with other international operators, is proving a tortuous and confused process. It is presided over by . . . "a bunch of rank amateurs—

Now that the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) is in the chamber, I have to say that when the Business Review Weekly article refers to `a bunch of rank amateurs', it is referring to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley), formerly the Minister for Transport and Communications.

PARA.TAB: Under the Hawke and Keating governments, both Qantas and Australian Airlines have suffered crippling debt-equity ratios. Qantas has been allowed to remain scandalously undercapitalised by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. The constant changes to the rules and timetables in the Qantas sale have frightened off potential investors.

The field has narrowed to two overseas bidders, which is the reason for these amendments, but the Government is too worried about the content of the bids to make them public. The Parliament and the public have the right to know what the bids are so that public opinion can prevent a fire sale of a great national asset. We cannot trust Labor governments with our money or our assets.

I remind the Minister for Finance that he is on the record consistently as saying that a trade sale bidder would have to pay a premium for entry into Qantas. Paying a premium does not mean paying a premium over the float price; it means paying a premium over the price after it had consolidated following the float. The Minister told Federal Parliament in October that the Government was not locked into a trade sale. He said that, if the bids are not good enough, we can reject all of them and make the whole sale through a float.

The article in the Business Review Weekly and discussions with British Airways and Singapore Airlines indicate quite clearly that neither of those international carriers is prepared to pay a premium for entry into Qantas. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: "BA—
that is, British Airways—
will not pay a premium under any circumstances.

I think it is now incumbent on the Minister to make public the details of the two bids. The Australian public wants to know what the bids are; how they compare with a straight public float; who is giving the Minister advice on it; what deals the Government has done with one or both of the contenders on the side; and by what criteria the bids are to be decided. Will the Minister decide the criteria?

PARA.TAB: The sale of Qantas will go down as one of the greatest botch-ups of the Keating and Hawke years. The public has a right to know what the bids are. These things will eventually become public. The Minister for Finance and the Government should tell the Australian people what those bids are so that an assessment can be made by the Parliament and the people as to whether the Government is just giving Qantas away or whether, for the sake of the Government's budgetary difficulties, it is simply disposing of Qantas in a fire sale.

I said at the outset that these amendments go to the heart of the Government's policy to sell off 35 per cent of Qantas to overseas interests and no more than 25 per cent to one buyer. They adjust the situation in regard to the relevant interest of an overseas owner in Qantas and, for that reason, the Opposition will not oppose it.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take the Committee's time for a few minutes to comment, firstly, on the amendments made by the Senate to the Qantas Sale Bill 1992 and, secondly, to address a couple of remarks made by the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Beale). The amendments made by the Senate, which are now before the Committee, are of a technical nature and relate to the definition of the term `relevant interest'. The Bill seeks to use the concept of relevant interest from the Corporations Law to trace foreign ownership and control through company chains. Thus Qantas shares would be classified as foreign if foreigners, either directly or indirectly, have control over the voting rights of those shares or the power to dispose of them. The relevant interest concept could be used to determine the level of foreign ownership and to ensure that it stays within the limits imposed by the Bill.

PARA.TAB: However, section 33 of the Corporations Law could result in a foreigner being deemed as having a relevant interest in Qantas shares held by a subsidiary of Qantas, including a subsidiary established to conduct an employee share ownership scheme. This would have had the unintended effect of adding those shares held by Qantas subsidiaries to the relevant interests of foreigners, plus inappropriately restricting the level of foreign ownership beyond that intended by the Bill.

It is therefore proposed that section 33 of the Corporations Law be ignored when determining the extent of a foreigner's relevant interest in Qantas shares. These amendments, passed by the Senate and before us now, will not affect the required tracing of foreign control over voting rights through company chains. So the proposals that have come from the Senate and that were moved by the Government in the Senate are essential to overcome what would have been unintended consequences of the original legislation.

The Opposition spokesman made somewhat ludicrous comments about the sale of Qantas. We are in the final stages of that trade sale process. We have bids before us from two of the three short listed bidders. Both British Airways and Singapore Airlines have submitted bids to us. The Opposition spokesman referred to us as rank amateurs and then said that we should reveal the bids. This certainly demonstrates the rank amateurish nature of the Opposition when it thinks that in a commercially sensitive situation such as this we could reveal the bids. These are very commercial, in-confidence bids and are not to be revealed to anyone whilst discussions and negotiations are going on between the Government and the bidders. We are in that process at the present time. It would be the greatest absurdity of all time for us to reveal those now. It would probably mean that both the bidders would walk away.

So it is just a nonsense, a demonstration of the rank amateur knowledge of the circumstances, if the Opposition thinks we should be revealing the bids in these circumstances. I simply say to the Committee that we hope to have consideration of the bids sorted out in the very near future and to be able to announce to the nation the outcome of the trade sale process.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has made a number of amendments to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992 dealing with the taxation arrangements for offshore banking units or, as they are commonly known, OBUs. These amendments are designed to ensure that deemed interest income can arise only where paid up capital provided by an Australian parent company is used by the subsidiary in the performance of offshore banking activities. Without amendments to the original Bill now proposed, if an OBU subsidiary were engaged in both domestic and offshore banking activities, the deeming provision would have the unintended consequence of resulting in a stream of interest being imputed on the funds used in the domestic part of the business.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has no objections to these amendments. I would, however, take issue with some of the comments made by Senator McMullan when he moved these amendments on behalf of the Government in the other place. Senator McMullan said:

These amendments are another example of the Government's willingness to swiftly respond to legitimate industry concerns which are brought to its notice so that we can all get on with the job of establishing Australia as a viable offshore banking centre.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be obvious to anyone with a passing familiarity with the history of this legislation that the Government has not been particularly swift or assiduous in responding to industry concerns. Indeed, to a great extent, the Government has ignored these concerns entirely and pressed on regardless of what industry wanted, thereby forcing the industry to accommodate itself to the Government's position. With this in mind, the coalition moved a whole series of amendments to this legislation in the Senate, based for the most part on industry concerns.

PARA.TAB: The Government rejected our amendments with virtually no discussion or explanation from Senator McMullan about the merits of those amendments. We should also remember that this offshore banking unit legislation is only one of several measures required to establish Australia as a major regional financial centre and not just a centre for offshore banking activities. A notable example is the legislation required to facilitate further foreign bank entry into Australia, which I spoke to a little while ago.

Apart from specific measures designed to assist Australia's development as a regional financial centre, we need to pay attention to the full range of tax reform issues if Australian financial services are to be internationally competitive. Tax reform is as crucial to financial services and the financial services industry as it is to the rest of the economy. Clearly, until we have addressed the full range of tax reform issues in this country, we will not be able to fulfil our aspirations to become a regional financial centre, or anything else of note for that matter.

It is worth recalling what Mr Geoff Lehmann of Price Waterhouse had to say on this subject. After noting that the Tax Office has for many years argued against Australia trying to compete against Singapore in the taxation of financial services, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: During the past decade, they (the Tax Office) have done Australia a disservice, by arguing for new tax laws that have given us the world's second most complex tax system after the United States.
He went on to say:
London's international pre-eminence as a financial centre is the result of many factors. But it would not have retained that pre-eminence if Canberra bureaucrats had been running the inland revenue.

That about says it all. The point here is that the Government is far too complacent and shallow in its approach to these issues. The comments by Senator McMullan that I have referred to here and earlier today typify this complacency and go a long way to explaining why this country is falling behind the pace in so many ways under this Labor Government.
