TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be laid aside.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government proposal was the alternative but less preferred option of the PJC report Who is to guard the guards? that the PJC would have access to all NCA information that was relevant to the PJC's duties, with the exception of sensitive information. The scheme was set out in the Bill that would allow the PJC to seek the Minister's ruling on whether or not the information sought was in fact sensitive if the NCA refused to provide information on the basis that it came within the definition of sensitive information. The Minister was given the discretion to obtain the non-binding advice of the Inspector-General of the NCA before finally determining the matter.

PARA.TAB: I move to the Opposition's amendments. The amendments related to the vexed issue of the PJC's access to information following the recommendations of Who is to guard the guards?. The key provisions were: new subsection 51(3B) to expressly provide that section 51, the secrecy provision, does not prevent NCA members and members of staff from providing evidence and documents to the PJC and that to do so would not be in breach of the obligation of secrecy. New subsections (3) to (13) of section 55 and some other related consequential amendments provide an alternative scheme to governments in which the NCA is obliged to provide all information sought by the PJC—limited only by the relevance to the PJC's duties—subject only to a prohibition on disclosure beyond the PJC if the information is sensitive.

Should the chairperson of the NCA claim that the information is sensitive, the PJC may not publish that information beyond the PJC, but the PJC or an individual member of the PJC may seek the Minister's final decision as to whether the information is sensitive and has 14 days to do so. The Minister may obtain the advice of the Inspector-General, but the Minister is not bound to follow it. This is very similar to the Government's scheme, but for the crucial difference that the PJC obtains the sensitive information in the first place. Under both the Government and Opposition model, in theory no sensitive information goes beyond the PJC. That is in theory. The Australian Democrats supported the Opposition's amendments, although the Democrats would have preferred their own model of a Federal Court judge in place of the Minister deciding the matter, with no role for the Inspector-General of the NCA.

The Government does not accept the Opposition or Democrats' line for the following reasons: the NCA is a joint Commonwealth, State, Northern Territory and ACT body that requires the agreement of those governments to continue to exist and operate. Each State and every one of the governments were consulted and agreed to the amendments proposed in the Government's Bill. All the participating State and Territory governments have refused to agree to the Opposition-Democrats amendments. The intergovernmental committee, at its last meeting on 20 November 1992, passed unanimously a resolution that the IGC, firstly, supported the provisions of the Government Bill, which would prevent access by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the NCA to sensitive information and would ensure that disputes as to whether particular information is sensitive are resolvable by inquiry by the Inspector-General of the NCA and determination by the Minister, and, secondly, opposed any amendment to the Bill which would have the effect of granting the Parliamentary Joint Committee unfettered access to NCA sensitive information.

By a long-standing convention applied in most, if not all, Commonwealth countries and Australian jurisdictions, by law in some, the legislature and Executive are not generally privy to operational details of police and other like bodies, such as the NCA. For example, section 13 of the Australian Federal Police Act vests control of operations of the AFP in the Commissioner and limits the Minister to giving directions as to general policy. Section 58(5) of the National Crime Authority Act precludes the NCA from furnishing to the IGC `any matter the disclosure of which to members of the public could prejudice the safety or reputation of persons or the operations of law enforcement agencies', except where the information is included in the findings of the NCA, and in such cases the NCA is only authorised to report to the Minister or Ministers who gave the reference.

The Government cannot agree to the argument that the PJC should have access to information which is generally not available to the intergovernmental committee. Under subsections 59(1), (1A) and (2), the NCA is only obliged to furnish information concerning a specific matter relating to operations under its special or general powers to Ministers within the jurisdiction in which the operations were conducted. There is no general power for the IGC Ministers as a group to obtain such specific information.

The provision of information only to the Minister or Ministers within whose jurisdiction operations are undertaken is consistent with the principle of ministerial responsibility. The risk of inappropriate disclosure of sensitive information increases with the number of people who know of that sensitive information. Providing such information to members of the PJC would be a source of increased risk. Access to operational information is not a necessary element for the PJC to evaluate the performance of the NCA.

This was not some theoretical concern of the IGC about disclosure of sensitive information. I remind the House that on 17 October 1990 Senator Amanda Vanstone, then a member of the PJC, tabled in the Senate a report of the PJC together with what amounted to a dissenting report that had attached to it evidence that had been given to the PJC in camera. I said then, and I repeat it now: how are we going to have people giving evidence in camera if in fact the next thing it is all over the place?

The Opposition has chosen a path that has led inevitably to the demise of the National Crime Authority Amendment (No. 2) Bill. It is not an option that the Government relishes. There will be no Inspector-General of the NCA, nor indeed will any of those other legislative changes be made, with which the Government was in agreement, that the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the NCA had recommended in its report Who is to guard the guards?. The Government had in a timely manner considered and agreed to implement many of the recommendations of the PJC report, which is now not to be.

I remind the Opposition that the intergovernmental committee includes a ministerial representative of each State and of the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory. These jurisdictions are not compelled to participate in this truly cooperative NCA structure. Each and every State could, of its own free will, cut itself from any involvement in the NCA. I would further remind the Opposition that four of the eight State and Territory governments are governed by coalition parties. Yet there is bipartisan support on the IGC for the Government's position in refusing to buckle to the Opposition's unrealistic and ill-considered approach to the provision of sensitive information to the PJC. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) has been unwilling, or unable, to impress upon his colleagues in the party room the consequences of the course of action upon which they have embarked.

I take no pleasure in the action that I have been forced to take. Given the role of the IGC, I believe that the Government had achieved a successful compromise that allowed the PJC to play a significant role in the fight against crime without compromising the operational integrity of the NCA. The IGC has functioned efficiently in its efforts to ensure a national approach to the fight against organised crime. Despite political differences, the IGC has operated in a truly national spirit. Yet, despite the wishes of the States and Territories, the honourable member for Higgins—perhaps he believes he is the repository of all wisdom and knowledge in this area—has thwarted those wishes.

I should mention that I understand that not since 1913 has a Minister pulled a Bill in the manner I have chosen. I am compelled to take this unusual course because of the seriousness of the situation that has arisen. The Federal Government, with the advice and consent of the governments of eight Australian States and Territories, passed legislation in this House, the people's House, which was amended by the Senate on the advice of the honourable member for Higgins, a member of this House. I cannot see what the purpose is here. The Senate is prepared to dismiss the wishes of not one but eight State and Territory governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) had a nice try, but he does not deal with the facts. He comes in here and, with all of the gravitas he can muster, tells us that he is taking this unusual and unprecedented step not to proceed with his own Bill because the Senate has amended it. The fact is that, when two Houses comprise a parliament, we do not always get legislation through in the manner in which we wish. The Attorney may take the view that the Parliament is some kind of accoutrement to legislation that is prepared by him as a Minister or by his public servants and that, if he does not get the legislation he requires, the Parliament is somehow standing in the way of the functioning of government. But the fact is that it is the Parliament that passes legislation in this country.

PARA.TAB: The Senate made an improvement to the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2). He could accept that improvement and allow this Bill to go ahead. I do not think that we ought to be setting aside this Bill as amended by the Senate now. We ought to be adopting the amendments and passing it. Some very good things were proposed in this Bill that we should not walk away from, such as the provision for an Inspector-General. The Government is walking away from it. It is saying that it did not like the ball that came down, so the wickets, the bat, the ball and everything else are just picked up and taken home. There are some good things in this Bill that ought to go through, and some improvements were made in the Senate that ought to be recognised and adopted. To say that the amendments that the Opposition has moved are unusual and somehow unwarranted ignores the whole history.

The whole history of this Bill comes from the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. The Joint Committee recommended that it have access to information. The amendments that I moved, which were rejected in here but accepted in the Senate, were not just my amendments, just the Liberal Party's amendments, just the coalition's amendments or even just the coalition's and the Democrats' amendments; they were approved by a parliamentary joint committee on which members of the Labor Party sat, chaired by a member of the Labor Party. That Committee—with Labor, Liberal, National and Democrats representation—came to this recommendation and recommended a first best option. The Government chose not to accept it. When we put it to the Parliament, it was accepted in the Senate. So the Attorney-General should not try to make out that something unusual has gone on. We have adopted and endorsed a bipartisan recommendation.

It is true, as the Attorney-General said, that the Inter-governmental Committee looked at this matter. I suppose, on a motion moved by the Attorney, it passed a resolution back on 20 November that it did not want any amendments. Did anyone put the case to the Committee why the amendments were required? Did anybody explain to it the case? Was there anybody in that meeting who was making sure that there were full and frank facts? Anybody can get a resolution out of a committee if it hears only one side. That is not a major turn in relation to this particular Bill.

Indeed, let us consider it from the other perspective. Were these recommendations that came forward recommendations of the Inter-governmental Committee? Did it start this? Was it that Committee that was concerned about the accountability of the National Crime Authority? No, it was the Parliamentary Joint Committee. It thought that there had to be greater accountability. It proposed a model. It was bipartisan. It has been adopted by the Senate. It went off to the IGC, which was never involved in this—it did not see the necessity for that in the first place, it did not do a report, it did not make the recommendations—and the Government decided against the proposal. It may have had some greater moral suasion if the IGC had shown a great interest and come forward with the proposal, but it did not; it was the Parliamentary Joint Committee.

The Government went on to say, `Well, the IGC does not have this kind of information; therefore the Parliamentary Joint Committee cannot. I would have thought entirely the reverse. If the IGC is not interested and is not exercising that kind of supervision, is it not therefore a stronger case that a parliamentary joint committee, a committee of this House, should do that? Rather than to say that one committee has chosen, as it were, not to seek this kind of information and that therefore nobody should, should not one say, `Well, there is a committee. It is a parliamentary committee, it is interested, it does have a statutory role and it will exercise that role of accountability.'?

Let us not put this in too precious a sense. A parliamentary joint committee is a committee of parliamentarians, elected by the people of Australia. They are the people that the people of Australia entrust to pass legislation. Yet they are not entitled to have information in relation to an agency that they are able to set up; is that the proposition? They are able to set it up and fund it, but they are not allowed to know what is going on. What an absurd proposition! If we are to have a parliamentary committee and give it accountability and a role, it has to be entitled to the information.

Let me come back to what I believe is the real problem. The real problem with the model that was put forward by the Government is this definition of sensitive information. I said this in my speech during the second reading debate. What the Government was trying to keep from the Parliamentary Joint Committee was sensitive information which, as defined, might prejudice the reputation of a person. So it would be conceivably open to the NCA to say, `Look, we cannot give you that information; that would disclose that we have been doing something we should not have. That would prejudice the reputation of one of our commissioners, or our chairman, or one of our officers. That would prejudice that person's reputation. You cannot have that kind of information'. That is the very kind of information that the Parliamentary Joint Committee should be interested in. It is not a mere academic point. This point has come up in relation to the NCA. The Attorney-General would be aware, and the public is aware, that there was a very strange incident in relation to a previous Chairman of the NCA. That might be a matter that was within the province of the Parliamentary Joint Committee.

The basic problem that I have with the Government's proposition is that, by enacting its proposition, the Parliament would effectively be saying, `We do not trust ourselves with information'. How can a parliament ever say, `We cannot trust ourself with information.'? As we have reiterated time and again, there is a difference between access to information and disclosure. What we have said is that, if responsible parliamentarians who are charged with the legislative responsibility of ensuring accountability of a body believe that they need particular information, they should be entitled to have it. But that does not mean they can broadcast it to the world.

As the Attorney-General described in his speech, there were very precise mechanisms ultimately which gave the discretion to the Minister or to the Inspector-General that provided that such material, sensitive information as defined, would not be disclosed—that is, disclosed to the world or the Parliament or put out. But there is an enormous difference between having access and disclosure. It is a difference that the Parliamentary Joint Committee was able to understand and take into account in its recommendations. It is a difference that the Senate was able to understand and take into account in moving its amendments. It is a responsible difference that I believe this House ought to be able to understand. I believe it is a matter of deep regret that, because the Attorney does not understand or accept that proposition, all of the good reforms and changes that were provided in this Bill will now lapse and this proposal will have to be taken up—and it will be taken up—and fixed by the next government.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUFFY
TALKER.ROLE: Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) referred to the fact that this is an unusual and unprecedented step. I agree with that; I said that. He said that, with two Houses of Parliament, we do not always get the legislation we want. We know that only too well. He also said that there were some good things in this legislation—the establishment of the Inspector-General and other matters which were put forward by the PJC. I also agree with that.

PARA.TAB: But to suggest that a meeting of the IGC—that is, the Commonwealth, all of the States, the Northern Territory and the ACT—knocked back the proposal because in some way it was conned, that no other point of view was put and that I just walked in there and told the IGC some fairy story is quite an extraordinary slur to place on the Attorney-General of New South Wales, a Liberal; the Minister from Tasmania, a Liberal; the Northern Territory Minister; the new Minister for Police and Emergency Services in Victoria, Mr McNamara; and all of the other people the honourable member obviously considers are pretty stupid. It was a matter which was debated for a long while. Then the honourable member asks me here what happened at that meeting. Why did he not ask them?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you invite me?

—The meetings are difficult enough without having the honourable member there. The fact of the matter is that he could have found out exactly what took place at the meeting by picking up the phone, talking to them, and asking them what happened. It is worth noting that some time ago, before this issue was faced directly, the IGC met with the full parliamentary committee, discussed this whole matter for almost a whole afternoon, and made its position absolutely clear. What the IGC unanimously agreed—and what we are not prepared to do—is that it is not going to have a risk of the inappropriate disclosure of sensitive information. It is not a matter, as the honourable member said, of who stops people from doing things that can happen on either side of the House. Whoever is in opposition can use this sort of information. Either side of politics, when in opposition, can use this information in a way which might suit it politically. It is not good enough, and it has happened during this Parliament—
—Don't go into that again.

—It is not a matter of not going into it again; it has happened. The honourable member might not like the fact that it has happened, but it has. We had the ludicrous position where it was thought that somebody was giving in camera evidence and then the evidence was tabled in the Parliament. The IGC—not this Government—which this Government depends on totally for a cooperative arrangement for the NCA to operate, is not going to take that risk. Those opposite have been so belligerent about it and are so absolutely determined that they are going to allow people to receive information and then, if they decide for political purposes to use it, so be it. Tragically, this means that a lot of the good reforms in this legislation—and I agree with the honourable member that they are good—are going to go by the board. What will happen is that this Bill will be laid aside.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill represents a further step towards the rationalisation of the institutional arrangements for the coal mining industry. The Bill provides for amendments to the Coal Industry Act 1946 and the Industrial Relations Act 1988 in order to transfer the function of providing administrative support for the Coal Industry Tribunal from the Joint Coal Board to the Australian Industrial Registry. The Bill also amends the audit provisions of the Coal Industry Act 1946 to bring the audit arrangements for the Joint Coal Board into line with current practice. The New South Wales Government has made the necessary complementary amendments to the Coal Industry Act 1946 of New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: The amendments concerning administrative support for the Tribunal are concerned solely with that subject and do not in any way alter the Tribunal's industrial relations powers and functions. Some coalmining industry parties have advocated changes to those powers and functions. It has become apparent in the course of discussions that the responsible Minister, Senator Cook, has already held with the parties that there is a range of strongly held and widely divergent views about that. Any change to the Tribunal's powers and functions will only be made after full consultation and discussion with all parties. This process of consultation has commenced.

At present, the Coal Industry Act 1946 establishes that the Joint Coal Board is responsible for providing administrative assistance to the Tribunal. The Board employs the staff who provide that assistance. The Tribunal is funded, through the Joint Coal Board, on a 50-50 basis by the Commonwealth and New South Wales governments. Recent amendments to the Coal Industry Act 1946 of the Commonwealth and the Coal Industry Act 1946 of New South Wales have redefined the role of the Board by providing that it will in future focus on workers compensation and miners health and welfare, and that it will become self-financing.

It is inconsistent with this redefined role that the Board should continue to provide administrative support for the CIT. This Bill amends the Industrial Relations Act 1988 and the Coal Industry Act 1946 so that the Australian Industrial Registry will be responsible for providing administrative support for the Tribunal. This will include the provision of administrative staff.

In making these administrative changes, it is not the intention of the government to alter the level of administrative support provided to the Tribunal. The New South Wales Government will continue to make its contribution to the funding of the Tribunal under the new arrangements.

The amendments concerning the audit provisions specify the matters which must be incorporated in the Joint Coal Board's annual report, including its financial statements. The Board will be required to submit its financial statements to the Auditor-General for report to Ministers before submitting its annual report to the Commonwealth Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the State Minister for tabling in the Commonwealth and New South Wales parliaments.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be opposing this measure. In those circumstances, I will not delay the House any further. I have plenty to say on other industrial relations matters, but it is more appropriate to keep those comments for another time.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL CHEMICALS (NOTIFICATION AND ASSESSMENT) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ROBERT BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989 establishes the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme. This scheme provides a national system of notification and assessment of industrial chemicals which, among other things, aids in the protection of the Australian people and the environment.

PARA.TAB: When the scheme was introduced in 1990, the Government decided that the regulatory impact on industry would be reviewed after two years of operation. This review has now been completed. The recommendations arising from this review have led to the amendments proposed in the Bill which will remove impediments to product innovation within the chemical industry.

These amendments are a further indication of the commitment of the Government to ensuring a workable and effective scheme. It meets the objectives of protecting the Australian people and the environment, while reducing the regulatory burden on industry. The Bill allows for the introduction of three new notification categories: `eligible' chemicals, low volume chemicals, and synthetic polymers of low concern.

An amnesty period will be introduced for eligible chemicals to assist industry to comply with the Act. While companies have had the opportunity of nominating chemicals to the Australian Inventory of Chemical Substances from 1 January 1977 to 16 July 1990, some companies have neglected to nominate some chemicals. As the legislation currently stands, such companies would be in technical breach of the Act and liable to severe penalties. During the amnesty period such penalties will be waived but, as a safeguard, companies will be required to submit some basic information about each chemical. The director will have the power to refuse the application if the chemical presents a significant hazard to human health or the environment.

The Bill provides for a two-year amnesty period. The Government considers that this period, which will commence on the date the Bill comes into effect, will be sufficient for companies to come forward, especially when coupled with the planned intensive promotional campaign.

For low volume chemicals, that is chemicals which it is proposed be introduced in quantities of up to 100 kilograms per year, the notification and assessment requirements will be reduced. The 100-kilogram limit will be an Australia-wide total and not a limit per applicant. Adequate safeguards will be in place to ensure the integrity of the scheme is not compromised. A list of chemicals accepted under this category will be published at least on an annual basis in the Chemical Gazette.

Previously, companies were required to supply a full data package and a full application fee for these chemicals. Under these new arrangements both the data requirements and the application fee will be significantly reduced. The 100-kilogram threshold will be reviewed after two years. This review will also examine the possibility of a lower threshold where no assessment will be required.

The Government believes these arrangements will be particularly beneficial to innovation in the chemical industry. This initiative is in line with overseas schemes which also have arrangements for low volume chemicals and demonstrates the Government's commitment to ensuring that our scheme is in harmony with comparable schemes administered by our overseas trading partners.

Polymers of low concern are a class of chemicals which inherently pose little risk to human health or the environment. For polymers which meet prescribed criteria the Bill proposes that the notification and assessment requirements be streamlined. Companies will be required to supply the relevant information on a form and will not be required to submit raw data. For these chemicals, a copy of the full public report will be published in the Chemical Gazette.

The changes being proposed in relation to this category, therefore, further demonstrate a commitment to streamline procedures. In order to make the decision making process for all the new categories introduced by these amendments as transparent and easily understood as possible, guidelines will be developed in consultation with government agencies, unions and industry.

The principal Act will also be amended to require that all assessment reports include a material safety data sheet. The MSDS is an important vehicle for communicating safety and handling information to supervisors and workers. This amendment will ensure greater availability of the MSDS in the workplace and will assist the States and Territories in the operation of their occupational health and safety legislation.

The Bill includes a new provision which will enable the Commonwealth Government to make regulations to prohibit or restrict the introduction and export of chemicals that are the subject of prescribed international agreements. Such power is fundamental to meeting international obligations with respect to certain chemicals and follows significant advances internationally, especially within the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation and the United Nations environment program.

`Prior informed consent' is one international scheme to which the provisions of the amendment could be applied. This scheme is based upon the principle that the export of a chemical which is banned, severely restricted or withdrawn from use in order to protect human health or the environment should not proceed without the consent of the importing country.

The Government intends, in circumstances where a chemical is to be banned or severely restricted, that thorough consultations occur with relevant government agencies and industry prior to a regulation being made. Administrative arrangements for international coordination on these chemicals will be developed in collaboration with relevant authorities. The Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency is the designated national authority for `prior informed consent' and will consult at an international level.

Finally, the Bill also contains some minor amendments of the principal Act to simplify and to remove redundant sections. The passage of the Bill will show the strength of the Government's commitment to reducing the regulatory burden on industry, while maintaining adequate safeguards for the Australian community and the environment. The Government is determined to create a regulatory climate which will foster industry development and thereby assist in achieving the Government's micro-economic reform objectives. The Bill will also ensure that assessment effort is consistent with the level of risk posed by chemicals and will result in the redirection of assessment effort to more needed areas.

Worksafe Australia has been instrumental in assessing the needs of the chemical industry and formulating these changes after extensive rounds of consultation with all the stakeholders. It has consulted with relevant Commonwealth, State and Territory agencies. Industry bodies consulted were the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Chemical Confederation of Australia, the Australian Chemical Industry Council and their affiliates. Discussion with other industry bodies not affiliated with these peak organisations has also taken place. In addition, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and interested non-government organisations were included in the consultation process. There is therefore widespread support for these amendments. I commend the Bill to the House and, on behalf of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. Obviously, any measure of the Government that seeks to achieve a sensible balance between freeing business from regulatory burdens and providing adequate safeguards in relation to notification of potentially dangerous substances is a measure we ought to support.

PARA.TAB: I have two comments to make. We have some worry about the effectiveness of the amnesty proposal and the cost of the associated publicity campaign as a remedy for non-compliance. The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), who is well versed in these matters, might canvass that when he replies, but I will leave that up to him. Generally speaking, we support the Bill. I do not want to delay the House. The speech of the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) was so compelling that I am left uncustomarily speechless.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989 establishes the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme. This scheme provides a national system of notification and assessment of industrial chemicals which, among other things, aids in the protection of the Australian people and the environment. The Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 allows for the introduction of three new notification categories: eligible chemicals, low volume chemicals and synthetic polymers of low concern.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has mentioned, an amnesty period will be introduced for eligible chemicals to assist industry to comply with the Act. While companies have had the opportunity of nominating chemicals to the Australian Inventory of Chemical Substances from 1 January 1977 to 16 July 1990, some companies have neglected to nominate some chemicals. As the legislation currently stands, such companies would be in technical breach of the Act and liable to severe penalties. During the amnesty period such penalties will be waived but, as a safeguard, companies will be required to submit some basic information about each chemical.I am pleased that, as the honourable member for Bennelong has noted, it frees business of some regulations. That is to be welcomed. I am very pleased that the Opposition is also supporting this Bill. I concur with the honourable member for Bennelong that the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Bob Brown), who is at the table, has very comprehensively covered this Bill.

I would like to pay tribute to the industrial chemical industry in this country. We need to have the best safeguards in standards and requirements. Chemicals are a necessary part of industry and development. I guess that is brought home to me, more than most other people. I am very pleased to be able to say that I have a growing chemical industry in my electorate, particularly in the city of Gladstone, where both ICI and Minproc Chemical Co. Pty Ltd have established chemical industries.

A few years ago, the Brisbane City Council, under the former Lord Mayor, Sallyanne Atkinson, made it clear that the people of Brisbane did not want ICI establishing a sodium cyanide plant at Lytton. Mayor Col Brown of Gladstone and I invited ICI to come to Gladstone to see what facilities we had to develop sensibly, in a sound environment, a chemical industry. Through the State Department of Industrial Development, we now have 1,500 hectares. The Yarwun industrial estate is set aside on 50-hectare lots. The Minister for Land Transport has on two occasions inspected that industrial development and the potential land that can be used for safely developing industries such as the chemical industry.

It is now history that ICI came to Gladstone, met with the Gladstone task force, the Gladstone councils and the port authority and established a sodium cyanide plant in Gladstone. ICI is now in the final construction stages of an ammonium nitrate plant, which will add value to that chemical industry and ICI's plant, and quite a number of permanent jobs have been created as a consequence.

Again ICI, in conjunction with the trade union movement, has been a pathfinder in setting up an industrial agreement, a greenfields agreement, that has been ratified by the ACTU. ICI can be complimented for being the pacesetter. Something like 1,000 industrial agreements have now been ratified by the ACTU, the Commission and employers in this country. That demonstrates the way to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you can be complimented for your outstanding efforts in attracting industrial development in that area.

—I welcome the interjection from the Minister. I compliment the Minister at the table for supporting me and David Hamill, who is the State Minister for Transport, for putting in the extension of the railway line, which now allows sodium cyanide to be carried by rail. This is a much safer mode of transport. Instead of using road transport, we are utilising rail facilities; we are interfacing road and rail. I am on the record as saying that I would like to see that extension go down to Queensland Cement and Lime eventually, so that we can utilise the clinker plant and the facilities that it has.

PARA.TAB: I compliment the Minister for supporting that expansion and adding infrastructure that then benefits the industrial development of cities such as Gladstone. Bob Hindley is the manager of the plant, and he does a great job. Ross McCann, who was involved in the construction stage of ICI, is a personal friend and should be complimented for the amount of work that he put in, in setting up the ICI chemical plant in Gladstone. I hope that over time we see more expansion of and value added to those plants and facilities. Once we have one chemical plant, it adds value. The by-products and so on are added value too, and other plants come as a consequence.

A company called Minproc is also established in Gladstone, and it produces sodium cyanide. I compliment that company. Russ Connor, Tom Hunter and Martin Ackland, who were involved at the establishment of that chemical plant, have been able to create jobs for our district as well as produce import replacement goods, which I think is vital. Minproc's sodium cyanide is now replacing imported products.

We have witnessed tough competition between the domestic products from ICI and Minproc and imported products from companies such as Dupont. Anti-dumping applications have been lodged, and the cases against some companies, but not all, have been successful. It is important to recognise that Customs and the Anti-Dumping Authority do a great job. They are able to indicate when companies do the wrong thing and dump into Australia, and also highlight when it is simply tough competition. That is the way it ought to be. Customs and the Anti-Dumping Authority are GATT related, and it is through those processes that we get sensible trade in the world.

I compliment both companies, ICI and Minproc, for the contributions that they are making to central Queensland—particularly Gladstone—by providing job opportunities. The industrial chemical industry is of great importance to Australia. I know that the Deputy Speaker is fully aware of the importance of chemicals in agriculture. Good, safe chemicals used properly can increase our productivity and our quality of product. Once the emotion is taken out of the subject, chemicals used sensibly are a necessary tool in both primary and secondary industry. Amendments such as the one we are speaking on not only go a long way towards providing the safeguards that are necessary and giving confidence to the community but also, importantly, give confidence to the industries that produce these necessary products such as industrial chemicals. I am pleased to support the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KEATING

Under the Prime Minister's policies, how many more Christmases have to pass before these people and millions of other victims of his deliberate recession will not have to queue and show their poverty to the populace of this country because of his policy failures? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does the Government stand by its decision not to introduce a broad-based goods and services tax? Have recent reports regarding modifications to the GST proposal caused the Government to rethink its position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports of altered proposals around the community about the imposition of a goods and services tax. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Under standing order 142, a question should relate to a matter with which the Minister is officially connected, to proceedings pending, or to matters of administration for which he is responsible. The question asked about the GST. The Prime Minister is not officially connected, there are no proceedings pending and he is not responsible for its administration.

—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell might resume his seat. The Prime Minister was asked the question: does the Government stand by its policy not to introduce a GST and have there been any recent reports or matters that would cause the Government to change its mind? The Prime Minister is in order.

—The Government is not changing its mind. After telling us that Fightback took a year to prepare, a year following its introduction and after a year of telling us it was right, the Leader of the Opposition has now told us that Fightback was not right and he has to change it. The first whiff of grapeshot and up goes the white flag. The Leader of the Opposition has said, `We'll dissemble on the beaches, we'll dissemble in the streets, we'll dissemble in the churches, we will abjectly surrender'.

PARA.TAB: The biggest whopper of course is how he is not poll driven. After he said that the whole country blushed. Fightback mark 2 is coming up and Fightback mark 2 is basically Andrew Peacock mark 2—but, as I remarked the other day to the honourable member for Kooyong, without the good nature and the good humour he brought to it.

In the contest for ideas in the Australian political system the Leader of the Opposition has retired hurt. He has retired hurt from a policy which he said was abjectly necessary for Australia, but which he now says he will have to amend to make politically acceptable. The fact is the only party in this Parliament with a policy construction that can last the distance is the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about One Nation?
—Order! The honourable member for Bendigo!

—This has been proven again by the events of the last days. We will not be changing our policy about a GST. Australia does not need one, it should not get one, and we are determined it will never have one.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister who has lost the real plot.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting.

—Does the fact that almost 80,000 people lost their jobs last month indicate that the recession that you engineered is lasting longer and hurting more than even you planned? Will you now admit that your previous statement that the recession was over long ago was grossly misleading, given the continuing hardship and misery that millions of Australian families are facing this Christmas solely as a result of your inadequate policies? Is it not a fact that things are far worse that you thought they would ever be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has believed that there is a role for government in inducing a recovery in this country and lowering the level of unemployment. You have said that there is no role for government; you have said that government should withdraw. You have said that we should cut $7 billion out of the Budget. You have said that we should have a contractionary policy. In fact, in a question to me on 24 November, the Leader of the Opposition said that I had:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . sought to argue a case for stimulatory economic policies.
He went on:

I therefore ask the Prime Minister: given that the 1991-92 Budget was stimulatory, given that the One Nation statement was stimulatory, and given that the 1992-93 Budget was stimulatory . . . Surely stimulatory economic policies do not work and an alternative approach is called for.

The Leader of the Opposition said that. In other words, he referred to the policies of engagement of the economy, of adding to public infrastructure, of adding to public spending, which are now turning around our national accounts. A week ago we saw that two-thirds of the growth was coming from the public sector, from public demand. Your Leader told me how wrong-headed stimulatory policy was, and urged upon us, in the throwaway speech he made after the Budget, that we should cut 2 per cent of GDP out of the deficit, that we should cut it back by $7 billion.

PARA.TAB: This week I see that all the newspapers are carrying this statement: `We have got to kick start the economy', says Hewson, `We have got to take on stimulatory policies'. He says that he is now listening. About all he is listening to is Andrew Robb and his pollster; that is all he is listening to. I guarantee, Mr Speaker, that in one press statement he had the word `listening' 23 times. He is listening everywhere—cooee! cooee!—hearing voices. We know whose voices they are. They are his pollster's voice and his Federal Director's voice. They are the voices he is listening to. He is now basically saying that he thinks he can deliver the Government's policies better. He is saying, `The stimulatory policies of the Government can be delivered better by us'. He is into camouflage politics.

It is like the Labor Party in the sixties. It went around with a policy for massive government involvement in the economy, and at the same time it said, `But we still believe in the private sector and private business'. Everyone said `Sure you do, sure you do', but nobody believed it. You are doing the same now. You are saying, `Look, we believe now in stimulatory policies; we believe in putting our arm out to help people; we believe in giving people a fair go'. People are saying, `Sure you do, sure you do'.

The truth is that, if the Leader of the Opposition has to move to the Government's policies, I say to the Australian public: let the party that believes in those policies put them in and keep them in action; do not take some shabby alternative that does not believe in them, that wants to pick up lines from the Government about stimulatory policies, about caring, about listening to people, when it is prepared to throw people off unemployment benefits after nine months; when the shadow spokesman for social security calls the unemployed riffraff; and when the honourable member for Mayo talks about leaning out a caring arm when there has been no care or compassion in him over the last year since the presentation of Fightback.

The fact of the matter is that if the people of this country want policies of engagement, policies of inclusion, policies of compassion, policies of stimulation, they will get them from the Government. They should not go to this puny alternative, who now seeks to introduce the Government's policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon members of a delegation from the Parliament of Fiji. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer inform the House whether a broad-based consumption tax on goods and services, but not on food, offers any significant advantages over the current system? If not, why not?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The particular construction of that question clearly offends standing order 144, especially in relation to seeking an absolute opinion, quite apart from Opposition policy. In that context you should ask that the question be reworded or ruled out of order.
—Order! The honourable member had a preamble and asked the Treasurer whether the Government intended to change its mind. The question is in order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be changing its mind on this issue. There is a very simple explanation, and that is that a goods and services tax is inherently unfair. That, of course, is the point of this debate at the moment. The honourable member asks, `Can you make it more fair by excluding certain items from it, particularly food?'. I refer to a remark that was made just a couple of months ago by the Leader of the Opposition. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The argument that food should not be taxed simply does not stand up.
He gives three arguments, and then he gives a fourth. He said:
Excluding food would mean raising the GST on all other products in order to maintain the revenue.

Here you have it: the GST is inherently unfair and, then, if you exclude some of it, you have to load up the rest of it. Of course, the rest of it that you would load up presumably would be that relating to services.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has an intriguing argument in relation to the taxation of services. It says that services are consumed—and this is in Fightback mark 1; God knows what will be in Fightback mark 2, but it will be just as erroneous—disproportionately by the well off. So here we have the rich drinking more water than the poor. Is that what happens? So you tax the water, and this is somehow fair, because you are taxing the rich more than you are taxing the poor.

This is obviously rubbish. It is true wherever you look in the area of services. Who is it that goes on public transport and will be taxed as a result of the imposition of the GST on bus fares? Who is it? Is it the wealthy who are jumping on the bus in order to go from A to B? Is it the wealthy who are taking their shoes along to have them resoled or repaired and being taxed for the privilege?

Is it the case that the rich pay more for having their rubbish collected than do the poor, when they are living side by side in the same municipality? This is so obviously wrong, that services are consumed disproportionately by the well off, as the Leader of the Opposition says. But no doubt we will have some fantastic explanation provided for us on Friday.

Of course, the policy gymnastics of the Leader of the Opposition know no bounds. As the Prime Minister has pointed out, here we had him clutching this policy for a year—a year in gestation, a year being clutched to his breast, a year being forced down the neck of anyone who would be prepared to listen to him. Only two months ago—less than that, on 24 October—the Leader of the Opposition said that Fightback was as near as perfect as you could get in terms of a policy response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Mr Speaker, I presume you have been listening to the Treasurer. My point of order relates to standing order 142. Could you please explain to me how much of what he is saying is relevant to the fact that questions may be put to a Minister relating to public affairs with which he is officially connected, to proceedings pending in the House, or to any matter of administration for which he is responsible? Would you tell me, because I cannot understand it.

—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. The honourable member for O'Connor often has trouble understanding the Standing Orders. The Minister was asked a question about why the Government did or did not intend to proceed with a matter. The Minister is illustrating his answer. The Minister is in order.

—The honourable member for O'Connor understood one thing, and that was that the GST was unsaleable. He said it a couple of years ago and nobody listened. Why are you not basking, Wilson, in the fact that finally they have come to your point of view? Is it not interesting, Wilson, that you spent a year telling us how—
—The Minister will refer to the honourable member by his title.

—I raise a point of order. Under standing order 145, the comments being made are directly reflecting on a member of this House and have absolutely no relevance to the question that was asked of the Minister.
—The honourable member for Isaacs will resume his seat.
—I would ask you to get him back to the point.
—If the honourable member for Isaacs takes a point of order like that again, I will deal with him.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the honourable member for O'Connor would never reflect on anybody about anything; never.

PARA.TAB: An Opposition member interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I had a few to say about you, too, if you will recall.
—Order! The Minister will answer the question.

—Why is it that the honourable member for O'Connor went around for a year telling everyone how terrific Fightback was when he did not believe it? It was perfectly obvious. The reason why the Government will not reconsider its opposition to a GST is that we know of its imperfections, unlike the Leader of the Opposition who only six weeks ago was saying it is perfect. Believe it or not, he still believes it is perfect, although it is not what he says. He actually believes it is perfect when indeed he is now saying other things about this policy.

PARA.TAB: The GST is inherently unfair. It is inherently unfair in relation to food. It is inherently unfair in relation to the way it taxes services. That is why the Government will have nothing whatever to do with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, my question—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my right!

PARA.TAB: Mr Harry Woods interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Page will cease interjecting.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. The Treasurer would be aware that the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has just cut back its growth forecast from 3 per cent to 2 1/2 per cent for this year. I ask the Treasurer: what is the growth forecast from the Joint Economic Forecasting Group, the Government's peak forecasting body? Is it not a fact that things are far worse than he thought they would be?

—I take it from this that the shadow Treasurer has been put in a cupboard and told not to emerge. He is, of course, busily being reprogrammed. Those opposite put such a lot of effort into programming him for a year.
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: the Treasurer is not answering the question. I expect an answer.
—Order! The Deputy Leader will not just jump to his feet without getting the call.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting.
—Mr Speaker, I was absolutely unaware of the fascination of the Deputy Leader of the National Party for growth forecasts.
—You should read ABARE.
—If you read ABARE you would have understood that it was not a forecast; it was an assumption. There is a difference.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting. The House will come to order.

PARA.TAB: Mr Carlton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mackellar!

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer might resume his seat. The House will come to order. Honourable members on my left!
—ABARE's last published assumption was what? Its last assumption was 3.5 per cent.
—I have got it here.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the National Party will resume his seat.
—Its last assumption was 3.5 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Mr Lloyd interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Was the Deputy Leader of the National Party up here saying, `Oh, the Government has got it wrong. ABARE says it is 3.5 per cent.'? Was he up here saying that? Of course he was not, because he, like the others, will grasp only on those little scintillas of pessimism that he can find around the place. He has caught the Hewson disease of talking the country down and, whenever he finds something which he thinks supports his pessimism, he will grab it.

PARA.TAB: Let me just give the honourable member some other views of what is happening to growth here and in the world. On 1 December the International Consensus of Forecasts was published, which showed that Australia would achieve economic growth of 3.5 per cent in 1993 compared with world growth of 2.3 per cent.

What do you think of that as a forecast? Is that a bit high or a bit low? What do you think about that? Late tonight the OECD will publish its most recent assessment of world growth. What it will show is that for 1993 the forecast will be around 3 per cent, whilst the OECD area will be just 2 per cent for 1993 and 3 per cent for 1994. What this demonstrates is that both consensus and the OECD have Australia growing either the fastest among the major OECD countries or the second or third fastest of the major OECD countries.

The process of remaking our forecasts is under way. It is a process which takes into account what is happening in the world, particularly as reported by the OECD. I am not suggesting that we should put any particular weight on any of these forecasts to which I have referred. I am simply saying that there are these forecasts which are out by internationally reputable forecasters based on their assessment of policy in Australia and their assessment of what is happening in the rest of the world. That is proceeding with our own processes and at some time in the future we may let you know what they say.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and relates to the Government's commitment to research. Can the Minister inform the House about the benefits to the rural sector that will flow from the latest round of cooperative research centres announced this week? Can he also advise whether or not the commitment to the rural sector is secure?

—The simple answer is that, under us, the commitment to rural research and development is secure. The recent announcements in relation to the cooperative research centres saw six cooperative research centres relating to agriculture and rural based manufacturing—the value added dimension of it—awarded; that is, six out of the 18. They covered wool, cattle and beef, aquiculture, cotton, floriculture and food.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bennelong!

—This takes to 13 the number of cooperative research centres that have been awarded to areas affecting agriculture and related production, a commitment of $160m over the remainder of this decade. That is on top of the four land, soil and water related cooperative research centres which themselves total $55m over the same period.

PARA.TAB: On top of that commitment, the matching funding that this Government recommitted itself to in the recent Budget has seen our contribution to rural research and development increase by 8 per cent this year. Coupled with the research and development corporations, we have seen a trebling of rural research and development since 1985. That is not to mention the commitments that are there in terms of CSIRO and the universities.

This reflects the recognition on this side of the House of the importance of research and development and innovation as a building block for sustainable agriculture, but more value added agriculture. I have talked to the National Farmers Federation today. It sees this as a crucial commitment from both side of the House in relation to the `New Horizons' package.

I simply make the point to the House that, under us, the commitment to rural research and development is secure. Where it is not secure is under Fightback. Under Fightback there is not one commitment made to the continuation of rural research and development. Fightback is silent in this area, just as the coalition parties in Victoria and Tasmania were silent on this issue before they went to the polls.

What did they do when they got to power? Tasmania cut the rural research and development budget by $2.5m. Some 45 research positions went; they were cut away. There was no mention of it before the election. In relation to Victoria, the Agriculture Department's budget has been cut by $6.2m; some 200 jobs have gone, many of them in the area of research. That is significantly more than the across-the-board 2 per cent cut previously indicated. No wonder they were silent.

The last time I got up in the House on this point, the Deputy Leader of the National Party said that it was not true that Victoria was going to cut rural research and development. Well, it has done so, and it has done so in massive swathes. Not only is Fightback silent; we also cannot trust the coalition in office. It will not tell us the full extent of its programs. As the examples of Victoria and Tasmania have demonstrated, it will cut in the areas that are needed most.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you supporting Joan Kirner, Simon?
—Order! The honourable member for Corinella!

—I would like to know how members of the National Party are going to go out and explain this to their constituency. The funding gap that is there in Fightback already, let alone after the changes on Friday, simply means that there have to be massive cuts to expenditures and, in particular, to these very important programs.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: rural research is guaranteed through Fightback and the coalition.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I remind the House that it is not even mentioned in Fightback. It is silent. At least the honourable member for Barker is prepared to be honest with the constituency he hopes to take over in terms of the industry portfolio. He has gone over and told the Department that many of the programs will be not only looked at but significantly curtailed. That is the coalition's approach to helping industries get along in this country, to take advantage of the resource base to do more with the commodities before they leave the country. The coalition would cut the very programs that support them.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, the commitment of this Government to research and development is on the board. The track record is there. We have not only maintained but also significantly increased expenditures. The coalition is silent, and its partners in two States have made significant cuts. That is what would happen if it were elected to government.
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members on my right will cease interjecting.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Mr Brereton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Kingsford-Smith will cease interjecting.
—I refer the Prime Minister to his statement of six days ago, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Growth of around 4% or so will bring down unemployment. It is also quite achievable.
I also refer him to his statement:
I have said on a number of occasions, if we cannot make 4% growth a year, the whole lot of us ought to give it away.
Finally, I refer him to the remarks of his good mate, the never-in-the-Senate Senator Richardson, who said three days ago:
Well, anyone who made a prediction of 4% growth in the immediate future would, I think, be joking.
Is the Prime Minister joking when he predicts 4 per cent, or is he going to give the game away? Is it not a fact that things are far worse than even he believed they would be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has taken the Deputy Leader a while to get to his feet. The Treasurer is right: they have had to reprogram him over there from the things he normally says. I do not get bilious too often, but when I saw him on the television the other day saying that he had to take money off the wealthy to give it to the poor, it was nearly too much for me. I just made it; I just held it together. Fightback was right. He used to go to a doorstop—
—You won't be able to keep your Christmas lunch down this year.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—When a journalist dared asked, `But Mr Reith, what about this?', he would say, `It is in Fightback. Go and read it. It is all there; it has all been done. We have put the research in and the time in. It has all been costed; it is there—every i dotted and every t crossed. Go and read it'. He has a different tune today. He is not so cocky today. It is very interesting, is it not, when the coalition is talking about growth? As late as 24 November, the Leader of the Opposition put out press statements saying:

ANSWER.PARA: Fightback is the best stimulus. The Government is running a ridiculous argument that Fightback would not stimulate the economy.
It seems the Government is right, and now what those opposite have to do is to embrace the Government's policy and try to stimulate the economy. He said:
Fightback! is not contractionary.
They only want to cut $7 billion out of spending. It is not contractionary. He went on:
. . . will release of resources for use in the private sector. . .
He goes on:
Mr Keating's policy of fiscal stimulus is becoming increasingly reckless.
Now the Deputy Leader is complaining about the growth rate. The Leader of the Opposition went on:
The jobs he intends to buy today with taxpayers' money are nothing more than a cruel hoax on the growing ranks of the unemployed—and he knows it.

That was on 24 November. But we had, as I said, the beach side conversion. Now we are into stimulatory policies. They are now pretending that they can deliver a bit of the Government's agenda—a positive stimulus, a bigger role for government, caring for people and higher growth. I repeat what I said earlier. If that is what the nation needs, let the party that believes in these policies deliver them—and that, of course, is the Government.

PARA.TAB: I have said, and I will say it again, that Australia must be able to sustain at least 4 per cent growth rates into the future, because if we cannot sustain them unemployment in this country will not fall over the long term. It is a matter of shame for the coalition that, after 30 years of almost continuous office, the greatest growth that Australia could have in the 1980s—the best those opposite could do with a capital stock after 30 years—was only 4 per cent without the demand spilling into imports. What we saw in 1988-89 and 1989-90 was that, with 9 per cent growth in demand, only 4 to 4 1/2 per cent was being settled by domestic production. In other words, while all the economies to our near north were doing sixes, sevens and eights, the best we could do, after you turkeys being around for 30 years, was 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.

What I am saying is simply this: the notion that we should ask the central bank to sit on the economy, removing the employment objective from its policy, and to depress the economy with the same stupid wilfulness that the Leader of the Opposition has talked of in the past, so that we are sitting on 2 per cent growth rates, where we are not seeing a rapid decline in unemployment, is an unacceptable policy—
Mr Ruddock interjecting—

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Bob Woods interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Dundas and the honourable member for Lowe will cease interjecting.
—In this country the central bank has a commitment to full employment and to price stability, and the Government has a similar commitment to full employment and to price stability.

PARA.TAB: Mr Cadman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mitchell will cease interjecting.

—The only way we will get it is not by employing the Reserve Bank to put a flamethrower on the economy, as those opposite wish to do, with its supposedly being independent from the legislature and the community, but by putting the capital stock into place to grow the economy at 4 per cent plus. The Leader of the Opposition wants to indicate that he does not seem to know the difference between the growth rate now and the sustainable growth objectives over the long term. The growth rate now is about 2 per cent—
—Tell that to the unemployed.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—It happens to be the fastest rate of growth of any OECD country, but it is not enough. In the future we will have to grow at around 4 per cent. Our contention is that the only way we can grow around 4 per cent without the growth spilling into inflation is not with a draconian monetary policy but with an incomes policy. Guess which is the only party in this Parliament with an incomes policy? It is us, the Government.

PARA.TAB: Mr Cadman interjecting—
Mr Reid interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mitchell and the honourable member for Bendigo will cease interjecting.

—In other words, the only model which exists in Australian public policy which will let the economy grow, but not see the growth frittered away in a price and wage round with higher inflation, is an incomes policy under the Government's policy. We are the only party with the policy structure to handle 4 per cent growth rates or better; that is the point I am making. But 4 per cent we must do over the medium to long term. We have got to get back there. We are getting back there now with a 2 per cent growth rate. As I indicated to the House a week ago, the Economist magazine has Australia at the top of the poll of forecasters for growth through 1992 at 2.1 per cent. It is 1.5 per cent for Belgium, 1.3 per cent for Canada, 1.8 per cent for France, 1.1 per cent for Germany, 1.4 per cent for Holland—

PARA.TAB: Mr Tuckey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.

—It is 1.2 per cent for Italy, 1.8 per cent for Japan, 1.5 per cent for Spain, minus 1.3 per cent for Sweden, 0.2 per cent for Switzerland, minus 0.9 per cent for the UK and 1.7 per cent for the USA. For the following year, 1993, it has Australia at the top again.

PARA.TAB: So, the Government's policy is inducing a recovery—but only the Government's policy can induce a growth rate in the 4 per cent area with low inflation without the central bank needing to burn the economy with the flamethrower of a brutal monetary policy, a la the Hewson prescription. That is why the 4 per cent rankles you—because you know you could not get near it. Let us not have the duplicity, the deceit and the confusion which the Leader of the Opposition is seeking to imply in the question. The fact is that 4 per cent is a medium to long term growth rate which Australia should have. The current growth rate is what we have got, and it is the fastest in the OECD.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Bass!
—I warn the honourable member for Bass.

—I suppose we should say that imitation is the greatest form of flattery, and the Leader of the Opposition is now coming to tell us that he did not really believe it when he said Fightback was the best stimulus; he did not really believe it when he said the Government is running a ridiculous argument about Fightback not stimulating the economy; and he did not really believe it when he said he thought that the Government's policy was becoming increasingly reckless. I suppose it is better that you have recanted, even if it is late. But let us not pretend that you can deliver parts of the Government's policies better than the Party that believes in and has constructed those policies in the first place. The only Party that can deliver stimulatory policies to this economy and not blow the inflation rate is the Australian Labor Party, and I am afraid that is it for the Opposition.

—I ask the Minister for Employment, Education and Training: what progress is being made to increase employment and training opportunities, especially for young people and the long term unemployed? Where is the main progress occurring, and are there any obstacles to further progress in the short to medium term?

—I was delighted today to participate, with the head of the Master Builders Association, the trade union most concerned with the construction industry, and the President of the ACTU, in the announcement of the Build a Job program for some 4,000 young people to participate in training opportunities in the building industry. I note in passing the comments of Mr Stewart, the President of the Master Builders Association. He said that the objective of the Association and the representatives of the employees was to seek improvements not through lower wages but through the better skilling of our work force. That was his fundamental point. He went on to say how important this was in trialing the vocational certificate that the Government has announced and is working towards.

PARA.TAB: In April of 1983 there were some 158,000 full time unemployed young people in Australia—12.4 per cent of the age cohort. The November figures, disappointing as they are, showed that there were 123,000 full time unemployed amongst 15- to 19-year-olds—some 9.4 per cent of the age cohort, and 35,000 below the figure when this Government came into office. That is because of the training programs we have been putting into place since the One Nation statement, since the youth package, was announced.

I have already had occasion to refer to the fact that apprenticeships were up some 18 per cent for the September quarter over the corresponding period in 1991. Between July and November this year the figures for trainee commencements present a dramatic turnaround. Traineeship intakes are up 138 per cent on the corresponding period for last year, demonstrating the considerable impact of our various policy statements during the course of this year.

I now turn to the position of the long term unemployed. There are various leaks in the press, of course—most of them inspired by the Leader of the Opposition who, despite trying to maintain a cheerful demeanour in the public forum, has sat here with a face like thunder staring at the desk for the entirety of this Question Time, with no animation at all. Despite what he has had to say about the fact that he is reconsidering the Opposition's totally heartless policy of tossing people off unemployment benefits after nine months, he has not told us what they are going to do for long term unemployed people; what they are going to reverse in the rest of the policies which are central to their position.

This fact needs to be understood and put firmly in the public's mind: some 61 per cent of labour programs now go to long term unemployed people. They are a saving in Fightback and a saving in the reduction of $7 billion that honourable members opposite have been talking about in their opposition to the Budget that we have put forward. That is what gives people who have been out of work for 12 months a chance to work again; not simply paying them—that is important, but it is not sufficient. It gives them a chance to work again. Likewise, of the 119,000 people that the CES placed in the September quarter, some 27 per cent had been out of work for a year or more.

It is important to understand these things about Opposition policy: firstly, Opposition members stand for the abolition of the CES and the palming out into sectors of private employment—which have never had to handle massive labour market programs, although most of them cease to exist, so that is not quite the problem it would be if you were actually dealing with our programs—plus any placement opportunities that people obtain in industry. What that means, of course, is that, with the abolition of those functions of the CES, they will get absolutely nowhere. The long term unemployed will not be given those opportunities to get back into the work force.

Then there is the question of the GST itself, which Dr Murphy, their modeller, has estimated would add between 0.2 per cent and 0.5 per cent to the unemployment rate by its second year of operation. That is some 50,000 people. We are not talking about unemployment in greengrocer shops; we are talking about unemployment in the area where there has been the greatest job creation over the last few years, and that is in small business. Basically, small businesses are service providers. That is where employment generation has been—not people paying payroll tax, not people providing the community with food; but people providing the community with their services. As far as anything that has leaked so far from the Opposition's intentions is concerned, there is no intention to deal with the problems that they pose.

Then there is the question of the policy of the Reserve Bank. Is it to be assumed that, as the Reserve Bank has been given a charter which has its unemployment objectives removed from it, you are going to get the stimulatory policies which will deal with the question of the long term unemployed?
Mr Costello interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Higgins!
—You are now, as you meander through your policy vacuum—
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Higgins.

—As you meander through your policy vacuum, you are trying to work out what it is that you can pick up from the Government's position and implement. What you cannot pick up is an attitude of mind which stresses that the most significant issue in this country as far as employment is concerned is skilling people and providing to people who have lost their capacity to find work—to relate to the work force by virtue of the fact that they have been unemployed for a lengthy period—the opportunity that will enable them to get back into the work force, to encourage them back into the work force. It is only those labour market programs and training programs that do it.

PARA.TAB: I emphasise this point again in conclusion: if you are long term unemployed and you are the beneficiary of one of these labour market programs which the Opposition has said it will cut, you are seven times more likely to find yourself a place in the work force than if you are a long term unemployed person without those benefits.
