—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I remind him of his promise when he took the job of Prime Minister just on a year ago now—

PARA.TAB: Government members—Promises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the one that he would tell the truth; the one that he would reduce unemployment. Is it not a fact that the only reason why the latest unemployment rate was not 12.2 per cent was that 82,000 gave up looking for work last month? As this is probably the last Question Time before the next election, is the Prime Minister prepared to assure the people of Australia that unemployment will not be nudging 12 per cent and will not exceed one million people by early next year, as the school leavers come onto the job market? Is it not a fact that things are much worse than the Prime Minister thought they were and that he has absolutely no plan to create jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should have thought that the Leader of the Opposition would have focused on participation rates, because if we had the same participation rate today as we had when he was advising the honourable member for Bennelong, we would have unemployment at between 7 and 8 per cent at this very minute. The Leader of the Opposition wants to direct a question to me based on the very high participation rates in the economy, engendered only by the high growth of employment in the 1980s, when Australians believed they could go and look for work. But after nearly a decade with you in office there was such a low participation rate that, by today's measures, unemployment would have been 7 to 8 per cent. The Governor of the Reserve Bank recently made what I think is a relevant point when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Certainly opponents of the monetary and fiscal policy easings have no right to be in the vanguard of those now voicing concerns about unemployment.

In other words, here is the person most highly placed in the bureaucracy basically saying to the Liberal Party, `All of you who have opposed the reductions in interest rates'—and you did; you called them political—`which have eased fiscal policy and made it stimulatory', as we did, and you attacked us for it, as in the question I read earlier, `and all opponents of monetary and fiscal easings have no right to be in the vanguard of those voicing concerns about unemployment'.

PARA.TAB: You attacked every policy of the Government that was aimed at creating more growth in the economy and higher levels of employment. In a recent press statement, you told me that our policy of fiscal stimulus was `increasingly reckless'. You tried to deride the employment the Government created by saying:

ANSWER.PARA: The jobs he intended to buy with taxpayers' money are nothing more than a cruel hoax.

What sort of duplicity is it to make statements such as this and then ask me about unemployment and about the same unemployed people that you say you will put off unemployment benefits after nine months; the same unemployed persons you will throw onto the streets without the support of the national income support system, the social security system, after nine months; the same people you would send to the voluntary agencies; the same people the shadow Minister for social security refers to as riffraff; the same people you said—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—
—You do not like the answer.
—You will not give us an answer; that is your problem. Now sit down.
—Order! The Prime Minister will resume his seat.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under the standing order relating to relevance. The Prime Minister was asked whether or not unemployment would go over 12 per cent. He ought to answer the question instead of attacking the Opposition. So stand up and answer the question for a change.

—In that cheap, thoughtless Budget reply of the Leader of the Opposition, he said to me:

ANSWER.PARA: I remember you—
pointing to me—
saying not long ago that when they fall off the pace you will reach back and pull them up—
that is, the unemployed—
What you mean is you will pull everyone else down to the lowest common denominator.
And I am supposed to give you a serious reply? You humbug. In the family summit speech, he said:
Giving people choice is the compassion that liberates; just giving is the compassion that suffocates.

That is what Dr Hewson thinks about Australians who are not well off. He then derides us in the Parliament about fiscal expansion. Let us make this clear: Dr Hewson is now pretending that he can deliver on the Government's agenda of a stimulatory policy leading to higher employment. He is pretending that there will be a positive stimulus, a role for government in getting Australia out of recession and the Government looking after people.

PARA.TAB: I will repeat what I said earlier: if the Australian people believe that is what they need delivered to them, it should be delivered by the Party that believes in the policies and constructed the policies and not in a policy which is constructed by him. In respect of food, which is an example of where the Leader of the Opposition is coming from, he said this on 11 December—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order under standing order 145: the question that was specifically put to the Prime Minister related—

—In the cast of policy adopted by the Government, we have seen the Government of Japan adopt a highly stimulatory fiscal package. We are now seeing the American President talking about a stimulatory fiscal package, and we have seen the OECD Secretariat address member states urging them to adopt a fiscal stimulus, as this Government has adopted. For our trouble, all we ever got in Australia from the Leader of the Opposition were claims of recklessness and claims of buying jobs. In other words, he did not want to participate whatsoever in the international consensus, which said that, at a time of low private sector investment, now is the time to lift public sector spending, particularly to cushion the effects on those who are affected by the recession and unemployment worldwide.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition rejected all those philosophies. He said that Fightback was right and did not need to be changed, that Fightback was already the right stimulus. Now he is saying to the Government, which has done everything to induce a recovery, higher employment and lower interest rates—
Opposition members interjecting—

ANSWER.PARA: . . . opponents of the monetary and fiscal easings have no right to be in the vanguard of those now voicing concerns about unemployment.

The fact is that the Opposition is poll driven. It has now found that its heartless policies are not washing with the Australian people. Now with this sort of deathbed repentance, we see that he wants to change to more stimulatory policies. We are supposed to say, `That is okay, John. —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister inform the House of progress on negotiations for a major expansion by Riverina Wool Combing Pty Ltd of its plant at Wagga Wagga and any implications that this may have for Australian industry and exports?

—I am delighted to be able to tell the House that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has announced today that an agreement has been concluded for the Chargeurs company, one of the world's major wool processors, to produce superfine wool tops at its Wagga plant.

PARA.TAB: The announcement of a major expansion of the Chargeurs wool tops plant at Wagga Wagga is greatly encouraging news for the Riverina region of New South Wales and for the wool industry in general. Processing adds about 35 per cent to the value of wool, and this will be the first plant in Australia to process superfine wool tops. Downstream value adding is, of course, vital to the development of the nation as a trading nation, but it is particularly vital to the primary industries of this country and to rural Australia.

The expansion of the Chargeurs plant will mean $62m in new capital expenditure, an extra $120m a year in export earnings for Australia, 90 more jobs at the plant itself, 50 jobs in the building of it, and a boost of $340m to the economy of New South Wales. We are very pleased that the board of Chargeurs has chosen the Riverina as the place for its development.

Let me say that this expansion would not have gone ahead without the TCFDA—the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority—contributing in a material way to its success with funding. Along with most honourable members, I am sure it is very clear to the House that the Liberal Party voted against support coming through the TCFDA to the textile, clothing and footwear industries. In fact, the honourable member for Curtin and the honourable member for Maranoa made cynical, dog in the manger speeches against the TCFDA funding when it was introduced in the House. Of course, the honourable member for Hume was sidelined or not supported by the Leader of the Opposition because of a challenge from the National Party in the seat of Hume.

We have seen again, as always, that it takes a Labor government to represent rural Australia. Only the efforts of this Government—and I might mention the efforts of the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith, my Parliamentary Secretary—and the efforts of the New South Wales Government have produced a benefit for workers and the wool producers of the Riverina.

I have a copy of a letter here from the Managing Director of Chargeurs, Mr Giraud, in which he describes as essential the assistance available from the TCFDA and the Australian Development Assistance Agency. This is another example of the role government can play in making Australia better, in inducing new industries, in making Australia more relevant in the world, in adding value, in doing the things which the National Party and the Liberal Party were never able to do. The Leader of the Opposition had his Party oppose in the Parliament funding for this particular plant.

This again makes the point that it is now the Liberal Party which is trying to change its spots. It is saying, `We believe at the eleventh hour that there is a role for government. We believe there is a role for us in stimulating the economy. Just disregard all that rhetoric we have been putting to you all year about how Fightback is the answer'. It was saying, `You ought to be contracting fiscal policy. Stop trying to buy employment. Stop trying to help industries. That is the compassion that suffocates people. There is no role for government. Government, get out of the way'.

This is another example where government has produced, as we saw BWK at Geelong, another state of the art, tops, making plant. Now with Chargeurs at Wagga, we are seeing the renaissance of the Australian wool industry in terms of added value and higher levels of production, delivered by a Labor government with policies of inclusion, with policies of a role for government, with policies of government getting involved and Australians moving together, not creating an underclass, not leaving people behind and not saying, `If you try to bring them up you will drag the rest of us down'.

This decision is right on the beam for the policies that provide the best things to Australia. We can see innovation, change, added value and employment in one of the provincial centres of Australia, and it is delivered, as always, with the wit, inventiveness and good spiritedness of a Labor government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that the expense involved in conducting a by-election would be in the order of $400,000. Furthermore, the earliest practical date to hold a by-election would be in February 1993. Honourable members would be aware that, when a general election is held, the House is dissolved at least 30 days prior to election day. With a general election expected in the first half of 1993, it is likely that, if a by-election were held in February, the honourable member might hold office for only a few weeks before the dissolution of the House. I have been informed that, if a by-election is not held, the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) will endeavour to maintain the services of the Wills electorate office until the general election. Therefore, I have decided not to issue a writ for the by-election for the division of Wills.

DEBATE.TITLE: PUBLIC SERVICE (ABOLITION OF COMPULSORY RETIREMENT AGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table a private member's Bill, which abolishes compulsory retirement in the public sector, to allow for comment and for suggestions from interested parties while the Bill is before the House.

PARA.TAB: The Bill has two objectives: firstly, to allow the recruitment of officers after the age of 65; and, secondly, to allow people to work beyond retirement age. That age alone should not be a bar to employment has been a key policy of the Opposition since 1988 and is an important component in our Fightback plan as it will help to change community attitudes towards older workers and overcome the age stereotypes which have actively discriminated against older workers for far too long.

The Bill therefore addresses two issues. Firstly, middle aged people are finding it increasingly difficult to get work after being retrenched because of public perceptions that after 45 people are too old. A study by V. Maxwell of Monash University has found that this is due to an attitude among employers that older workers are inflexible, complacent, have more health problems and are unwilling to retrain.

Middle-aged people make up the majority of the long term unemployed. The national average duration of unemployment for men aged between 35 and 54 years is 63.7 weeks. Out of every 10 jobs, only three go to people who have been unemployed for over 12 months. The current high level of redundancies also guarantees that this trend will continue unless there is a fundamental change in national policy, as proposed by the coalition.

The second issue is the growing trend to early retirement in Australia. Indeed, some companies in the process of restructuring are influencing staff to retire as early as age 50. The national interest makes it essential that our mature and skilled work force be productively employed for as long as possible. Thus, it is essential that governments lead the way in giving older people a fairer go.

There is a role for government in establishing the retirement parameters of its own public service and setting an example for the private sector. The purpose of this legislation is therefore to give the community at large the opportunity to comment on the Bill, and act as a further encouragement to State governments which have not yet gone in this direction—notably, at this stage, Victoria and Tasmania—as well as the private sector across Australia.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF THE PARLIAMENTARY REPORTING STAFF

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—On behalf of Mr Speaker, pursuant to section 9B of the Public Service Act 1922, I present the annual report of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff for 1991-92.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Mr Speaker, pursuant to section 9B of the Public Service Act 1922, I present the annual report of the Department of the Parliamentary Library for 1991-92.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—During Question Time, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) claimed that I was opposed to the Fightback GST policy. It is true that I opposed any proposal that introduced a GST as a replacement for the wholesale sales tax, as proposed by Treasurer Keating in 1985. However, I have always supported the coalition concept, which I know to be in the community interest, of a GST as a replacement for sales tax, payroll tax, the fuel excise, and tax cuts.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member for Franklin claim to have been misrepresented?

—I do. Recently, on 12 December, I announced that, regrettably, I would not be standing at the next election. I subsequently held a very small press conference. I said quite distinctly at that press conference—
—`I am the chicken'.

—No. I did say that, too. I said that I was retiring because of ill health. I was asked the question whether it was because of the GST. I looked bewilderedly at the journalist. I said, `What do you mean?' I said, `I am retiring because of ill health'.

PARA.TAB: The next day in the media, the matter was stimulated again. The same thing was said again. It is completely untrue. The endorsed Labor candidate—I do not want to run him down now—mentioned that I was a victim of the GST. That is completely untrue. It is unfair to my colleagues. It has nothing to do with my retirement. I had a slight hiccup, which I hope I will get over, but it is nothing to do with the GST or anything else. It is because of ill health.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that other honourable members wish the honourable member for Franklin good health.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—During Question Time, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) accused me of calling the unemployed riffraff. Unlike the Prime Minister, I have not caused the unemployment of a single Australian.
—I ask the honourable member to get to the heart of the matter.
—Having said that, I want to place on the record the background to this situation.
—Oh, no! Hang on!
—I am clarifying what is a very serious aspersion on my name.
—I will hear the honourable member for Bradfield. He needs to get right to the heart of the matter immediately.
—This matter arose in an interview with Karen Middleton of the Age on 19 October this year. I want to quote the comment out of which this allegation has arisen. The article said:

SPEECH.PARA: He said some age pensioners objected to lining up with what they described as `the riffraff' receiving other benefits.

That is what I said. That is what other people have said to me. The reason I gave the interview is that I take the view that it is important that retired people should have special facilities in the offices of the Department of Social Security to avoid the problems that they obviously face.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the honourable member for Bradfield concluding his remarks?
—I am in the process of doing so, yes. This is a very important matter to me personally.
—I think you have just about clarified it.
—With respect, sir, I believe it is a very important matter.
—Please proceed.
—This is not the sort of language I am accustomed to being accused of using. It is certainly not my personal view and was never expressed as my personal view.
—Of course it was.

—The Prime Minister has deliberately misused this expression. The material is there; it is on the public record. On the following day, 20 October, in another article by Bernard Lagan in the Sydney Morning Herald he referred to the comments I had made again. He went further and said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Connolly said later yesterday he had used the language of those beneficiaries who had complained to him.
I went on to say:
"If by using that term I have contributed to developing the various stereotypes that I am trying to break down, then I regret it. It's certainly not my view.
I want to place that clearly before the House. It is certainly the continuation of my position.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member has concluded his personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the House was simply challenging the question of whether or not the honourable member was within Standing Orders. The Chair determined that he was within Standing Orders, so the matter does not need to proceed any further.

DEBATE.TITLE: DISCUSSION OF MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The need for the Treasurer to release the Treasury's latest revised estimates of economic growth.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to start my remarks today by saying that history often repeats itself, although given the happenings at the end of Question Time today, it is the first time I have ever heard of a Speaker getting $65,000 for falling off his bike.
—Order! The honourable member should return to the question and not reflect upon the Speaker.
—It illustrates my point. I suppose that is an exception to the rule. It is a lot of money. Perhaps he did more than break an arm.
—Order! The Deputy Leader has a matter before the House and he should address it.

—In politics history does have a way of repeating itself. As I listened to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) today, he took me back to the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s. When he was asked whether unemployment would go over 12 per cent, he was actually saying that it was all the fault of the Menzies Government and the Fraser Government. That took me back 10 years. There is a sense of history repeating itself.

PARA.TAB: Ten years ago Malcolm Fraser was on his back in the Freemason's Hospital in Melbourne and the Australian economy was on its back in the 1981-82 recession. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who was then acting Leader, came down on a train—because he had an ear infection—from Sydney to Melbourne to open the by-election campaign in Flinders. The parallel with then and today is that as the Government that year—

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't get paid to open it though.
—If he had fallen off the train at Flinders Street he might have.
—I fell on my ear instead. Think of the compo I missed.
—If there were a compo claim for sore ears after Question Time we would all be lining up. If there is a parallel, it is this: after we won that famous by-election in December 1982—
—A great candidate.

—We ran a very strong campaign. The interesting thing was that politically those in the coalition government then basically sat down for Christmas lunch feeling a bit better than they had for some time. Most people would recognise that. The truth is that in September 1982, with the benefit of hindsight, the members of the conservative coalition, the Liberal-National Party coalition, were the walking, talking political dead.
—You speak for yourself.

—The fact is that we had had it. The truth is that as we go into Christmas 1992, after a decade of Labor, the current Labor Government is politically dead; it is finished; it is absolutely done and over. The person who knows that most—and I see a smile of encouragement and endorsement from the honourable member from Macarthur (Mr Martin). Is it Macarthur?
—At the moment.

—That is right. The Prime Minister knows it himself. What will happen in 1993 is that we will put this carcass finally down. It will be dead and buried and we will start afresh with a new government. I do not know when the next election will be held. The Prime Minister is now hanging on. He is the Joan Kirner or the Barrie Unsworth of Federal politics. He would not know when the next election is to be held. I think it would be a fair political assessment to say that his best chance, although he would not have won an election—even he himself knows that he would not have won it, which is the reason we did not have it—was last weekend. That opportunity has gone and the Prime Minister will face the end of a decade of Labor whenever the election is held, whether it is held in March, April or May next year.

PARA.TAB: When that election is held, the queues of people who stand outside that rare business that has a vacancy sign—there are very few of those—looking for a job will be the same queues standing outside the polling booths who will vote Labor out at the next Federal election. They will throw Labor out because Labor caused this recession. It deliberately engineered it. Today it does not have the vaguest idea of how to get us out of this recession. It simply will not tell people the truth about the Australian economy.

Members of the Australian Labor Party have absolutely no credibility. No-one in his right mind would believe a Labor Prime Minister, a Labor Treasurer and a Labor Party that for years have been distorting the truth. The truth is that they lie through their teeth. They will do so between now and the next election for only one reason. It is not because they give a damn about the people who are unemployed; it is because they are interested in only one job, or one set of jobs, and that happens to be their own jobs. They do not tell the truth. Furthermore, whenever they get a chance, they try to hide the truth as well.

We saw examples of that in the scandalous Victorian loans affair when they knew that the figures they put into the Budget this year were wrong. Basically they conspired with the Victorian Government. This has seen the Victorian people saddled with a massive debt as a result of Labor incompetence over the years. Recently we saw another example of Labor Party members suppressing the truth. They sent some Treasury officers over to New Zealand to find out about the GST. When they came back they wrote a report saying basically that the GST is a great idea and if anybody goes to New Zealand, as they did, people there will tell them that it is a fairer system, people pay a lot less income tax and those in the black economy pay their fair share of tax. When they were asked to produce the report, those opposite basically censored it and were not prepared to tell people the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can see the report now.

—The smart alec opposite has got all his files here. If the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) is fair dinkum, when I sit down and he stands up, he will gives us the report. Why does he not, just for once in his parliamentary career as Treasurer, actually have the decency to give us the honest truth about the state of our circumstances?

PARA.TAB: That is not the only report the Government has had. It also sent people to New Zealand to look at industrial relations. I will tell the Treasurer how I know about that. When 10 of us were in New Zealand during the year we met a number of people who had spoken to the very Treasury people that he had sent to New Zealand. I know what they were told. They were told that the industrial relations reforms in New Zealand have been a great success and that the average working person has had a very good deal. The vast majority—about 90 per cent—have got either the same wage or an increase in wage and, of those, half have had an increase above the rate of inflation. For all the Government's silly scare campaigns, the truth is that in New Zealand people are actually better off. Government members do not have the guts to stand up and state the truth about what is happening in New Zealand, let alone what is happening in Australia.

I want to say by way of passing reference that it is hard to suppress the truth on a permanent basis. The Treasury Secretary has been told that he is not to say in public that he supports the GST, but we all know that he does. We have to give him this much—at least he goes around saying it privately. The other day someone who was in one of his private meetings actually told somebody writing for the newspaper what he had been saying about how good the GST was. The article is headed, `Treasury blow to PM', because Treasury, of course, thinks it is a great idea as well.

I ask a very simple question: where is this Government's economic credibility? Does it lie in the worst recession for 60 years? Does it lie in the One Nation statement that he proudly proclaimed last February, which is now shown to be a complete sham, an absolute shambles and, in fact, a living lie? Or does it lie in the smart one-liners we get from people such as the Prime Minister? The Prime Minister actually had a meeting of his troops in the alcove before Question Time to rev them up to disrupt Question Time. He is that desperate and worried about his own circumstances. It is the typical sort of trickery that we have from this person. Or does his credibility lie in the fact that unemployment is now at 11.4 per cent? The answer is very simple, and that is that these people do not have a credible economic leg to stand on. I think most Australians now appreciate that fact.

Let us look at the Government's record in terms of its statements to the public. I pulled out the Hansard of the debate on the economic situation at this time last year. Every year before Christmas the Government says that things will be better after Christmas. That is what this Treasurer will say when I sit down. Just before Christmas last year, the Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: I say now, quite dogmatically, that 1992 will be much better than 1991.
Members of the Government say it every Christmas. There it is in black and white. The Treasurer will say it, and we all know it is yet another lie.

PARA.TAB: Throughout the year members of the Government have been saying that the recovery is coming through. We can go back as far as we like; it does not matter. I will not read them, but I have here a quote for every month this year from Government members saying that the recession is over, that the recovery is coming through and that we will have 3 or 4 per cent growth. That is the magical figure. Members of the Government themselves have said, `If we cannot get 3 or 4 per cent growth, then our unemployment situation is actually going to get worse'. Instead of things being better next year, on the Government's calculations, if we do not get to 3 or 4 per cent growth—I say 4 per cent because the Prime Minister said in Question Time today that it is Labor's plan to get us up to this 4 per cent—the two plus two conclusion is that unemployment will actually get worse.

TALK.START.PARA: —And his pigs will fly before Labor gets into office.

—Pigs will fly, says the Deputy Leader of the National Party. I am very pleased that he is supporting my matter of public importance. So here we are before Christmas and the Government is saying that things will be better next year. The truth is that the Government has said that every year, and in fact in the last few years things have got a lot worse.

PARA.TAB: The figures in this country are absolutely dreadful. The latest national account figures tell us how big the cake is and whether it is growing or not. If we take into account the size of the population, in the last year we have had 0.2 per cent GDP growth per capita. Basically the place is as flat a landscape as we can get in terms of growth. If we look at the ANZ job ads figures, we see that the figure for November was 0.6 per cent. That basically is as flat as a tack. If we look at the graph, we see nothing there. The recession continues. Bankruptcies are 22.05 per cent on the latest annual figures.

Let us look at the national account figures again and at the private capital expenditure. This is the critical thing. If we are to get out of the recession, people have to start investing. It is pretty simple. People have to start building up their businesses to create jobs, to get production going, to start to lift our living standards. In the last figure, private gross fixed capital expenditure fell by 2.1 per cent. We are going backwards on that number. If we look at our other big problem in Australia, and that is the fact that we have this huge debt to the rest of the world, on the latest national quarterly accounts, that is, for a three-month period, our exports fell by 1.1 per cent and our imports went up by 2.4 per cent.

Ladies and gentlemen, we are going the wrong way. Wake up Australia! We are going backwards. We are not going to some better tomorrow where people have got a chance of a job. Tomorrow, 1993, under Labor, the way we are going, it is actually going to be worse. The other day our debt went for the first time through the $200 billion mark. For heaven's sake, that is $12,000 per head for every man, woman and child in the country. We have massive problems. The Opposition's policy is Fightback. We say, `Look, this is a fantastic country. We have great people, tremendous resources, and one of the world's great democracies. If we can gather the people up together, gather that constituency for change, Australia's future is fantastic; there is no doubt about it'. What is the Government's policy? It is `Sitback'. Those opposite say, `We have done all that we have to do'.

The Prime Minister on television the other day, when asked about micro-economic reform, said he had done it; tax reform, he had done it. With fiscal policy, `Forget fiscal policy'—that is basically what he said the other night. Those opposite reckon that they have put things in place for this country to grow in 1993. That is simply not the case. We have the only viable plan that is going to get this country out of the mess that those opposite have put it in.
Mr Martin interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Macarthur will cease interjecting.

—This is probably the last MPI before the next Federal election. I conclude by saying that we have highlighted the problem, and on many occasions in the Parliament we have established what clearly needs to be done in Australia to get us out of the problem. I say to my colleagues and to the Australian public: in 1993 we have to start changing Australia for the better. There is one change we have to start with—we must change the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think anybody has told the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) that those opposite do not have a plan. They had a plan but they no longer have a plan. He was similarly caught out on the day that `Flipback' was announced by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), when his office staff said they did not know anything about it. He finally caught up with it and said on the radio that of course he knew about it. But he did not know about it then and he does even not know about it now. So that reprogramming I talked about has not been successful—
—Personal abuse.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Order! The honourable member for Flinders!

TALK.START.PARA: —Personal abuse? The old dalek from Flinders has been only half-wound up again. He was sent in here today and those opposite said, `Don't mention the GST. Talk about growth, talk about unemployment, but don't mention the GST'. But he could not keep to that simple instruction; he had to stray into this area. He had to talk about a plan—a plan the Opposition does not have, a plan he does not know about, a plan that is in the bin, a plan that is in the state of being massively revised. Does he know what is happening to the Opposition's plan? It is being made like ours because those opposite have discovered that a bit of fiscal stimulus is not a bad idea, and they are a bit worried about the fairness issue, which they have suddenly discovered. Whereas before they thought fairness did not matter, they are now discovering that the people of Australia care very much about fairness.

PARA.TAB: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition may not care about fairness, and the Leader of the Opposition does not care about fairness, but the people of Australia do. So reluctantly they have had to do something to appear as though they are fairer than they used to be, but they will deceive no-one, and plan B will be just as inappropriate, just as much rubbish, as was plan A. Even the Deputy Leader of the Opposition will discover that at some point. There was a very interesting observation by Mr Chalmers about the honourable member for Flinders, and I can see that he has read it. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Having conceded that "Fightback!" needs changing, one assumes we will hear less of Dr Hewson explaining how hard it is to sell "Fightback!". But if blame is to be allocated on the failure to sell, then apart from John Hewson, the next to shoulder the blame for the failure to sell should be the Shadow Treasurer, and Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Peter Reith. Should Dr Hewson win the election, he must surely have grave doubts about the capacity of Peter Reith to fill the Treasurer's role, if for no other reason than Mr. Reith's political credibility has been so tarnished.

Of course it has been so tarnished, because only a little while ago this year he said to Laurie Oakes, `We are not budging an inch, Laurie, on this proposal, or the other proposals contained in Fightback'. He has been running around Australia—programmed, wound up and sent in a particular direction like some deranged automaton—telling the people of Australia what he has been told to say. He never thinks about it—he does not understand it too well—he just spouts what he has been told to say. Now he finds himself in this terrible position of having to relearn it all, to be recast and to be relaunched in order that he can now start spouting whatever is the new Opposition line which emerges on Friday.

PARA.TAB: What a cheek for the Deputy Leader to come in here and talk about growth when the Opposition has a policy—to the extent that it has a policy—about contraction. Opposition members stood up here after the Budget was delivered and said that it was reckless because it was too stimulatory. What was their solution? Their solution was to rip about $7 billion out of the Federal Budget. That was what the Opposition Leader said a couple of nights after the Budget was brought down. He said, `We would reduce the size of the Commonwealth Budget by $6 billion to $7 billion'. As if that would not have an effect on growth. As if that would not have an effect on unemployment. Even a cautious assumption about what would happen to unemployment as a result of that is that we would see an additional 120,000 or 130,000 people unemployed. Not only does he not understand this policy; he does not understand its implications for this issue which he raises today in his MPI.

Of course it is true that we would like to see the economy growing faster than it is at the moment, but the question is how we do that and what policies will ensure that the economy grows faster. All the Opposition has been able to talk about in this monomania which it has developed over the last year is taxation, as if some big tax shift will make a jot of difference to employment in Australia. Of course it will not. Opposition members have come to that realisation now only because they have failed to convince the people of Australia. As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has said, it is not because they have changed their minds. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, to the extent that he has a view on these things, has not changed that view; he has realised that that view will not wash and, therefore, he has to go through the cosmetic exercise of changing the policy even though Opposition members will not believe in the new policy which they will bring down on Friday.

Let us examine what is happening to Australia in the context of the rest of the world. It is impossible to imagine that the economy of a country such as Australia, particularly as a major commodity provider to the developed world—especially to Japan but also to other countries in the developed world—and a major exporter of agricultural and mineral commodities, can be considered in isolation from the rest of the world. What we said, and will continue to say, is that Australia is in a more privileged position than many other developed countries because we have developed our trading links with some of the more rapidly growing countries, particularly in the Asian area—northern Asia, north-eastern Asia and South East Asia.

There has been a huge shift in the way in which Australia trades with the rest of the world, which has meant that we are to some extent cushioned from what is happening in other parts of the developed world in North America and Europe. It is for that reason that some of the economic forecasts, particularly the one produced on 1 December by London based Consensus Economics, say that, of the major OECD countries, the forecast for Australian growth is higher than that for any other major developed country.

The forecast for Australia in 1993 is 3.5 per cent. That is not our forecast; it is not a forecast to which we give any more prominence than any other. This is what this organisation says about Australia's growth. It forecasts 2 per cent for Belgium, 3.1 per cent for Canada, 1.6 per cent for France, 0.3 per cent for Germany, 0.9 per cent for Italy, 2.3 per cent for Japan, 1.5 per cent for the Netherlands, 1.1 per cent for Spain, minus 0.2 per cent for Sweden, one per cent for the United Kingdom, 2.7 per cent for the United States, 2.8 per cent for North America, just one per cent for Europe and 3.5 per cent for Australia, which is much closer to the Asia-Pacific OECD countries. What we are seeing, in the face of this criticism from the Opposition, is that Australia is forecast by this organisation to do better than any of the other major developed countries—that is, the major members of the OECD.

Would honourable members not think that was a matter for some pride? Would they not imagine that that was something about which the Opposition would say, `Okay, perhaps things are not going as well as we would like to see them, or the Government would like to see them, but at least we are doing better than most.'? Indeed, according to these forecasters, we will do better than any of the major developed countries with which we compare ourselves. But there is not a bit of it. All we have is this carping, haranguing style of Opposition members as they look for various pieces of bad news. They have become experts on identifying bits of bad news. They have a total aversion to finding anything which might be remotely positive about Australia's performance.

The papers tomorrow will publish the OECD's economic outlook No. 52, which is the OECD's assessment of what is happening to the world and to the member countries of the OECD. Again we will find an estimate of Australia's growth rate for 1993, which as I said in Question Time is around 3 per cent. It will grow more rapidly in 1994. In that context, we will find ourselves behind only one of the major OECD countries. I would have thought that if the Opposition were really concerned about this country it would have been prepared to talk up that issue rather than to continue its relentless efforts to talk down the Australian economy. Some other goods news came out overnight in relation to the performance of 700 Australian manufacturing companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—`Hear, hear!' says the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs, because it is his Department which, through the Australian Manufacturing Council, has been responsible for commissioning this report. It reveals that these 700 firms are high value added manufacturing companies, each with exports of between $2m and $50m a year and growth rates of over 13 per cent a year. It says that 40 per cent of these firms began exporting only in the last 10 years and that another 30 such companies join their ranks each year.

PARA.TAB: Total exports of just these 700 firms were over $8 billion in 1992 and are expected to grow to almost $16 billion by 1997—that is, double in the next five years. Surely even the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd) would think that that was a pretty good prospect for any firm. Surely even he is prepared to acknowledge that to have this as the prospect for 700 firms, lifting Australian exports of manufactured goods by $8 billion, is something for us as Australians to be very proud of. The AMC study suggests that in 20 years it is possible that these firms and others like them could be exporting $70 billion worth of products each year. This is an amazing transformation.

The important point is that this amount is coming from a large number of smallish firms. It is not the result of huge investments by the BHPs, the CRAs and so on of Australia—in other words, the traditional kind of resource development—it is the result of applying Australian labour, Australian imagination and Australian skill to the process of manufacturing. These results reveal that, with the kinds of export performances and export successes which these companies have already turned in and look like turning in in the future, Australia can be very competitive.

These results come from a diverse array of sectors which include the food, beverages and tobacco sector, the industrial machinery and equipment sector, the chemicals and petroleum sector and the motor vehicle parts sector. Yet, on the day that this report is published and reported on in the press, do we hear any hint of congratulations coming from the Opposition? Not a bit of it. All we have is the usual derision and the usual claim that Australia is hopeless.

We had the claim by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that Australia was moving in the wrong direction. He says that we are going backwards at a time when we are having this kind of performance, which can only be described as spectacular. I do not think there would be another country in the world which could make this kind of boast about the transformation of its manufacturing sector in such a short space of time. Yet, in the face of this evidence—which has not been conjured up by the Government but which comes from a highly reputable, independent organisation—those opposite say that these kinds of results have occurred and these kinds of prospects are in line for Australia. How about just for once giving a big hoorah for manufacturing in Australia? (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), in his rather irrelevant response to this matter of public importance, first of all made some allegations about fairness. I put it to him directly: what is fair about unemployment that is heading fast for a rate of 12 per cent, the highest since the Great Depression? What is fair about that for all unemployed Australians? What is fair about a foreign debt that is now $200 billion and has to be paid back by the next generation of Australians? On a personal note, what is fair about a Prime Minister who invests $430,000 in a piggery and sees it change to over $4m in the space of a couple of months?
—That is pork-barrelling.

—It is pork-barrelling at its worst. The second point that the Treasurer tried to make was that somehow or other it was an outrage for the coalition to update Fightback. Let us remember what happened 12 months ago when the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) became Prime Minister and said that there was going to be at least 4 per cent growth. On the Prime Minister's own words, there has to be 4 per cent growth if unemployment is to stabilise and start to fall.

PARA.TAB: We had the One Nation statement earlier this year. Does anybody still hear about One Nation? The growth forecast is still 4 per cent but the Budget sank like a stone, even after throwing in $800m to try to create those jobs. One Nation was derailed with the failure to spend some of the money. In the Budget we are down to 3 per cent growth. What is next?

The crux of this matter of public importance is that it is time that the Treasurer released Treasury's latest revised estimates of economic growth. How much lower than 3 per cent is the figure now, which was Treasury's changed figure in the Budget? The release of these estimates is made more imperative because this month's Agriculture and Resource Quarterly, released a few days ago by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics—one of the officially recognised forecasters—has indicated that Australia's growth for this financial year will be 2 1/2 per cent. That forecast is closer to home and shoots down all of the rosy and inaccurate international forecasts that the Treasurer has been trotting out.It means that even the Government's Budget forecast is not real. It means that unemployment must increase. It means that the Budget deficit must increase. What is the Government's response? That is what this matter of public importance is about.

If we look at those ABARE forecasts we see that the figure of 2 1/2 per cent is still too high, because on the annualised growth rate in the last 12 months we are down to 2.1 per cent. As I will indicate later, the Business Council of Australia and other employers have indicated the job shedding that will continue in the new year. The Government should not take any sort of comfort from ABARE's long term forecasts—even though that December edition states that in the next financial year growth will be 4 per cent and in the following year 4 1/2 per cent—because ABARE's track record on long term forecasting is pretty poor.

For example, in December 1990, ABARE predicted that for 1990-91 there would be a 0.5 per cent increase in growth, whereas the actual was minus 0.5 and so it was one per cent too optimistic. ABARE also predicted that for 1991-92 there would be 3 1/2 per cent growth when the real growth is 0.2 per cent, so it was over 3 per cent too optimistic there. In its December 1991 forecast, ABARE predicted that for 1991-92, the current year then, there would be a 1.5 per cent growth whereas the actual growth was only 0.2 per cent. Again, the prediction was well over and ABARE was too optimistic. For this year the growth was going to be 4 per cent but we are now down to 2.5 per cent. There is no comfort for the Government in any of the longer term projections of ABARE.

The Business Council of Australia has just released a report which indicated that, of 43 out of the 82 largest companies, and therefore the largest employers—this is significant—24 said that they would be cutting their employment by 5 per cent in the new year. On those figures, there will be a 2 per cent overall reduction in employment. That is a terrible situation facing this country in the new year.

The New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures says that 8,000 jobs will be lost in small and medium manufacturing in the new year. When it comes to rural Australia, ABARE indicates that this year the net value of farm production will be up to $1.8 billion from $1.2 billion last year. However, in the 1980s the average net farm income was $4 billion. That is a terrible reduction in farm income. We can go on and look at the average over three years where broad acre farming will have an accumulated loss of minus $57,848, the worst being the sheep farmers who are over $100,000 in the red over three years. That is why rural debt has increased from under $10,000m to over $14,000m in that same time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the social justice in that?

—There is none, and the Government is doing nothing about it. But what is even more significant is ABARE's medium term projection for the future to 1998, where it says that the range of net farm income will be between $1.7 billion and $2 billion. This means that, 10 years after average net farm income was $4 billion, it will be under half of that amount over the next few years. If anybody in this country needs Fightback it is the rural sector because, according to Treasury the cost savings alone under Fightback will be $1 billion a year, or basically 50 per cent additional net farm income.

PARA.TAB: Let us turn to unemployment. The Department of Employment, Education and Training produced some very interesting figures on unemployment in its June quarter report Small area labour markets, which was released in late August. For example, for the June quarter unemployment in the Prime Minister's electorate was 13.5 per cent; in the electorate of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) it was 18.9 per cent; 14.8 per cent in the Treasurer's electorate; and in the electorate of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), 16.3 per cent. Of course, all of those rates have got worse since then.

What is really curious is that the September quarter figures should have been released late last month. They would have showed a further deterioration in the employment rate of these electorates. We have been told that we are not likely to see the figures before Christmas. Here is another series of figures that the Government is hiding from the people of Australia.

We can go further. In regional Australia youth unemployment was a staggering 32.4 per cent for the June quarter—and that is before the school leavers are taken into account. Australia already has the worst record—and has had for the last two years—of the 10 leading Western economies on job losses.

We have reached the sad anniversary of the Prime Minister's accession to the Prime Ministership of this country. Upon his accession he made some pledges. He said that he would deal honestly with the people of Australia. That is a laugh by itself. But he then said that his aim was economic recovery and reduced unemployment. What do we have? One year later, unemployment has increased by more than one per cent. Since his famous One Nation statement there have been nine jobs lost for every job created in this country. Our foreign debt is almost 20 per cent higher than it was when he came to the Prime Ministership 12 months ago.

This returns us to the basic question of this matter of public importance. We do not want to hear, as the Treasurer has been telling us, what the OECD says about Australia. We do not want to hear what some international forecaster, well removed from Australia, said about Australia some time ago. We want to hear what the Government's own forecasting body says is its obviously revised downward economic growth projection for this financial year because it means that it must be lower than 3 per cent. That means there will be more unemployment; shooting towards 12 per cent—even without the school leavers and the job shedding which I referred to earlier. It means that the Budget deficit is worse. More than ever, we are heading for the worst depression since the 1930s. We need a new government; we need a fresh start. The last thing Australians want is 12 per cent unemployment and more under this Government.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Both of the Opposition spokesmen during the discussion of the matter of public importance today have concentrated on two specific themes: firstly, the question of growth; and, secondly, what that means as far as employment is concerned. We constantly hear the plea for a bit of honesty in debate. We constantly hear the suggestion that a policy prescription is required which will see this growth improve and, as a consequence, again generate employment.

PARA.TAB: Let us try to inject a bit of honesty into the debate today. Most of the areas to which the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd) referred in a breakdown of unemployment figures on a regional basis are manufacturing areas, or have as their base some form of manufacturing or small business. I represent such an area in this Parliament. In the last 10 or 12 years I have seen what industry, business and manufacturing have been doing in an endeavour to do something which people in the media, the economic forecasters and certainly those on the other side of this House called for two years ago: micro-economic reform and industrial restructuring.

If we want a bit of honesty in the debate I ask those honourable members opposite to stop and think for a moment. If they were those people in small- to medium-sized businesses, or indeed large businesses, and they were endeavouring to work smarter and more efficiently and bring in micro-economic reforms to their businesses, what would they do? They would cut costs. What is the first cost that most businesses will endeavour to cut? Businesses will endeavour to shed labour.

The second thing businesses will do is introduce technology. In the last 10 years there has been an explosion in the use of technology in all forms of business in this country. It has replaced the need for manpower or womenpower in many of those businesses. To constantly harp that that factor should not be taken into consideration I think is abrogating some of the debate.

Another matter is worthy of comment. We have heard a lot about the stimulatory processes of this Government through the One Nation statement, the Budget and other announcements which have been made. We heard cries of `What about the rail system?' and so on. I am reliably informed that in the electorate of the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) the Brisbane to Gold Coast rail link, which was part of the One Nation statement, is proceeding at quite a considerable pace.

I am also informed by my colleague the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) that in the case of small business—which the Deputy Leader of the National Party referred to, saying that there were sackings and that small business opportunities were reducing—between April and December 1991, in the depths of the recession, 60,000 new jobs were created. That is based on BIE estimates and figures. It is a fact; we cannot escape it.

The other issue raised in the course of this debate related to forecasts. How many people in the public and private sectors in Australia, the United States, the UK, France and all of the OECD countries are now prepared to put up their hands and say that they got the forecasts about economic conditions in Australia, the US, the UK, France and all OECD countries right for the last one, two, four or five years? I think very few would do that.

Those figures are simply forecasts based on the best available information provided by well qualified and well equipped people from the public and private sectors. The difference here is that the Government is prepared to suggest—and it has been said on a number of occasions—that those particular forecasts understated the extent to which the recession was both deeper and longer than anyone was able to predict. We have said that.

But there is no point dwelling on the past. It is a fact that there has been successive growth, albeit modest—and the Government has said that it is modest and we want more—for more than 12 months. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have said—and it is certainly true in terms of the statistics which are available and which have been derided by those opposite in their contributions this afternoon—that that growth demonstrates clearly that we are way in front of OECD countries with regard to that process. Those opposite cannot have it both ways.

The issue of unemployment always arouses the emotions of honourable members in debate and, to some extent, this takes away some of the rationality as well. I thought it was rather intriguing that the day after the unemployment figures were announced nationally as 11.3 per cent, the New South Wales Liberal Government, in one of the most cynical exercises I can recall, decided to sack thousands of workers in the State Rail Authority.

In Victoria we have seen the effect of industrial relations policies as well. Yet those honourable members on the other side who give comfort to the policy prescriptions of their Liberal counterparts at the State level are prepared to turn a blind eye to that. Teachers will be sacked; public servants will be sacked. That is the grand plan which has been advanced in Victoria. As I have indicated, the same process is under way in New South Wales.

Are those opposite prepared to say, `We don't believe in any of that. We're not going to do that.'? Will they distance themselves from that? Will they take a different policy prescription? As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) said during his dissertation this afternoon, `We've got a plan'. Will plan mark 2, Friday, contain this sort of nonsense or will it repudiate the industrial relations policies and the unemployment consequences of their State colleagues? We wait, eagerly in fact, to see whether Fightback mark 2, or whatever it will be called—

TALK.START.PARA: —`Flipback'.
—`Flipback', and so on
—`Backdown'.

—Or `Backdown'. A number of names have been thought up in readiness for Friday so that there is a headline for Saturday's newspapers. It is absolutely and patently obvious that the questions of unemployment and growth must be very carefully considered and debated. As the Prime Minister said today, the 4 per cent growth target for sustainable job generation is a medium to long term goal of this Government. The present growth rate of a little over 2 per cent in the meantime will provide the basis for that growth to 4 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The issue of public or private investment was glossed over somewhat. I think it is readily apparent to anyone who looks at this issue that private investment is important. We have often heard people suggest that private investment is the way to achieve sustainable economic recovery and job generation. It is said that we need to get inflation under control and interest rates down. In Australia we now have a 0.8 per cent inflation rate, the lowest in the OECD by a country mile. The overnight bond rates are at 6.5 per cent.

The environment is there for public and private investment. But where is it? That is a good question. Why is it then, particularly in the private sector, that there is not the preparedness to support Australia at this point in time? One has to ask oneself whether there is some other underlying message written into that.

The MPI today was just dreamed up out of the air. This is something which the Government believes has been addressed by both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, and we should condemn those opposite for this cynical exercise. (Time expired)

2MR SNOW: To move—That this House:

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the ordinary business for Thursday, 17 December 1992, unless otherwise ordered, being proceeded with as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Presentation of petitions.
2.Presentation of, and statements on, reports from parliamentary committees and delegations.
3.Orders of the day for the resumption of debate on motions moved in connection with committee and delegation reports (debate concluding no later than 11 a.m.).
4.Private Members' business (commencing no later than 11 a.m., debate concluding no later than 12.30 p.m.).
5.Grievance debate.
6.Members' statements (at approximately 1.45 p.m.).
7.Presentation of papers (at 2 p.m.).
8.Notices and orders of the day.

This proposition is in line with the conduct of business generally at this time of the year. We generally come back for two days of sittings to clean up what is usually a plethora of business—and this case is no exception—which is returned to us from the Senate amending a vast array of Bills that we have put before it.

PARA.TAB: There is an added twist this time in that we also have to consider a major amount of legislation from the Senate itself. As honourable members will have noted from today's Notice Paper, a considerable amount of material is to be debated today under that particular heading, and the situation tomorrow will be no different. There is an extraordinary amount of legislation to finalise.

All honourable members will be as aware as I am of the importance at this time of the year of being in our constituencies so that we may take the opportunities that are presented to us to talk about policy and about the issues which are—

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better be back in Swan.

—It is going pretty well in Swan, thanks very much, since the honourable member has inquired. It is going extra well, as the honourable member well knows. Things have changed a bit of late, even on the surveys by those opposite in Western Australia, as they well know.

PARA.TAB: Mr Prosser interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No. It has turned around in mine as well. So from my point of view this gives a real opportunity to get back there to chat with our supporters. That is not the only thing that we have to consider. Also, we have to look at the program for tomorrow. As always, the program contains protection of the rights of private members. In our proposal we have allowed a situation to emerge in the Standing Orders for tomorrow whereby full weight is given to the normal conduct of business by private members in the House up until 2 o'clock. This means that there will be an opportunity for private members to make their statements and to state their grievances, and for Committee reports and the like to be considered.

PARA.TAB: From that point on there is so much business to be conducted that it needs to be conducted purely under the banner of government business. There is no time for the normal practice of Question Time. There is always the chance that we will be engaged, too, as the night wears on, by the requirement to play some sort of legislative ping-pong with the Senate, which we also tend to do at this time of year. All of those considerations take into account that the Government will require, from 2 o'clock tomorrow, maximum flexibility for the consideration of its business, hence the decision to put to the House for its consideration the change in Standing Orders for tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition rejects this motion as yet again an outrageous demonstration of the lack of management of the Government's business. More importantly, we often have motions imposing the guillotine to facilitate government business through this place at the end of the year, but very seldom do we get to the position where Question Time is actually denied the Parliament. Tomorrow we will not have any Question Time, and I think that is outrageous.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, as we have seen during the course of the year, the number of Bills subject to the guillotine has increased alarmingly. We are well up in the hundreds now in terms of Bills that have been subject to the guillotine. This denies honourable members in this place the opportunity to speak and to argue their case with regard to particular Bills, and it also denies honourable members a proper committee stage in this place. The committee stage is where, clause by clause, a particular piece of legislation can be dealt with. That really is the way the legislature should work.

Increasingly we are seeing a tendency for this Parliament to respond to the demands of the Executive which means not only is the Opposition denied the opportunity to speak but, more importantly perhaps from the point of view of Government backbenchers, there is no opportunity for them to speak either. I find it amazing that Government backbenchers continue to agree with the Executive of their own Party trammelling upon their rights as private members in this place.

Some comment also has to be made about the difficulties we are experiencing with the amount and complexity of legislation. In an earlier debate I referred to an occasion when we had some new sales tax legislation and how that was actually guillotined through the Parliament. In the recent past we have also had dealings with a whole range of broadcasting and telecommunications legislation which I know the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) is quite familiar with.

It seems to me that the more contentious pieces of legislation, which would benefit from a detailed scrutiny by the Parliament, are being made subject to a Senate timetable. The Senate timetable and the mysteries of the way in which the Senate works continue to astound me. The time that it spends dealing with some of the matters which, in my view, do not deserve the weighty time that is given to them is quite amazing. This place is now being pushed considerably by the Senate's lack of timetabling or prioritising of its own arrangements. That is regrettable. That ought not be a reflection on my colleagues in the Senate. When I was at the Senate the other evening, they told me that the management of the Senate is the worst that many of them have seen in the number of years that they have been there.

That is also part of the problem that we have to deal with on this side of the chamber and is part of the difficulties faced by the Leader of the House. But in any event, we are faced yet again with a denial of Question Time. We are faced again with the prospect of working right through Thursday and well into Friday morning, finishing at some early hour of the morning. When I said `early hour of the morning', my colleagues should be thinking of about 5 a.m.—rather than 1 a.m., and perhaps even later than 5 a.m.—or 6 a.m. But we are hoping that they will get to the airport and get home on Friday.

I guess there will be an opportunity for some comment later, but this may well be the last motion by the Leader of the House in this place if this week is the last time that this Parliament meets. I notice that Senator Richardson is now on his side. I do not know whether that should give the Leader of the House comfort or whether it should scare him. In any event, we watch with interest. We find it interesting that the Government has chosen to conform to its practice of the last several years of denying honourable members, by not managing the business of this place in a constructive way, the opportunity to debate issues. It is regrettable and reflects on the Government very adversely.

It means that the centrepiece of democracy, which is seen by most people in this place as being important—that is, Question Time—will be denied yet again, although Question Time itself has developed into somewhat of a farce. But that is a debate for another day. All of us hope that the current Speaker is able to, if there is another Question Time—and there may not now be another Question Time under this Speaker—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a blessing.

—The honourable member for Mackellar said that that is a blessing. I do not want to reflect on the Speaker. The Government will not remove the Speaker now because there may not be another Question Time.
—Take his bike away.

—He has lost his seat and got another one. He has fallen off his bike. We do not know what will happen next. In any event, Question Time has developed into somewhat of a farce in this place. It has been a matter of broad public comment and concern and is certainly of concern to our side of the chamber. As I have said before, if the current Speaker is to sit in judgment of us all at another Question Time—or whoever the Speaker might be—there has to be a better way of responding by, and getting information out of, the Executive than under the current arrangements. All of us need to consider that in some detail.

PARA.TAB: I say to the Leader of House: I am appalled that this course is being proposed. As the Government would expect from those on this side who defend the fundamentals of democracy, we will vote against this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been the wont of the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), when matters come up relating to parliamentary procedures, to tip a bucket on the Senate. As one of a number of members of this House who have served in the Senate, I want to put a couple of matters on the record for the benefit of a few people and not let it go over the shoulder yet again.

PARA.TAB: I was a member of the Senate at a time when it did not sit until Christmas, the reason being that in those days this Government used to rush in its Bills at the end of session and say, `These are urgent; we have got to have them'. There would be a wish for a debate and maybe for some amendments in the Senate, but everyone would say, `It is too great a cost to bring back the House of Representatives'.

It became the practice of the Government to bring in at the end of each session, not just at the end of the year, urgent Bills and Bills critical to the public. The Government assumed that it could guillotine the Bills in the House of Representatives after about two members had debated them, and put the same sort of pressure on the senators. A little while ago the Senate jacked up on that—not before time—and passed the Macklin amendment, insisting that it was going to debate Bills. I do not think there has ever been a better example than this session of how important that Macklin amendment was. This chamber received 70 new Bills in two days, and we had to put them through in a couple of weeks. We had no forewarning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Worst ever.

—Absolutely the worst ever. The Government is going from bad to worse. We have not had the opportunity to debate things that are of critical importance to our constituents and to this nation. That has been a deliberate decision by the Government. We talk about the management of Government business in the Senate, but I have a little sympathy for the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan) because of the number of Bills that the Leader of the House piles onto him. He knows he has to cope with that number of Bills in such a period of time.

PARA.TAB: At least senators are trying to make their chamber act like a House of Parliament. This place has become an absolute farce from beginning to end. One of the reasons we are held in such appallingly low esteem, indeed outright disgust, by so many Australians is the way the House of Representatives is being run by the Government. At least the Senate is trying. It is about time that the Government took on board the fact that it cannot bring in a swag of Bills and not expect the Senate to have its go at examining them—and properly so. It is now only in the Senate that many people's concerns about Government activities and Government legislation are expressed.

It is a poor excuse for bringing us back for two days this week to say that we have to put all this legislation through. There are more than two days in a week. We could have come back for Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. It has transpired that the only glimpse of a chance that the Opposition has to put the Executive Government under scrutiny in this chamber is during Question Time. It is a fleeting glimpse these days, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) gives us 10 minutes of his theatricals and nothing on policy in answers to each of the questions asked of him.
I put on record that the Senate should not be any more denigrated in this Parliament. It is trying to do what parliament is about—namely, to debate legislation, to look at legislation and reports—

TALK.START.PARA: —You're an ex-senator.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Order! The Parliamentary Secretary will cease interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Chifley can sit there and scoff. Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not need protection from the honourable member. He is a perfectly pleasant guy, but he should stick to the subjects that he knows something about. He clearly has no expertise on the running of parliament because he has only ever seen the House operate under a Labor government.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Mr Beazley's) be agreed to.
