TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill contains a number of proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 and the Freedom of Information Act 1982, which are necessary in order to respond to certain recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, and to resolve various practical problems which have arisen in the course of electoral administration.

PARA.TAB: The Bill will also repeal the requirement that documents containing information about candidates and their policies be delivered to all households prior to the next election. Section 386A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act was inserted last year as a result of an amendment moved by the Australian Democrats during debate on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. The Government supported the amendment because it formed a part of what was seen as a package of measures, which included free time broadcasts, designed to ensure that the electorate was informed in the absence of political advertising of candidates' policies in the election. With the disallowance by the High Court of the legislation to ban political advertising, the case for the candidate booklet no longer exists.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act already provides for a free issue of the electoral roll, in computer format if required, to senators, members, registered political parties, and other persons and organisations deemed appropriate by the Electoral Commission, after each general election. This Bill will allow for the free, regular provision of supplements to the roll, in computer format, to all senators, members, and registered political parties which have parliamentary representation. Other groups will be able to obtain these supplements at cost. Habitation indexes are already issued free of charge by the Electoral Commission to registered political parties once in the life of a parliament. The Bill will allow for additional issues of the habitation index to registered political parties at cost.

In response to current concerns about privacy issues, this Bill will also provide that where computerised roll information on names and addresses is provided by the Electoral Commission to senators, members, registered political parties and other persons and organisations, that information must only be used for purposes related to enrolment and to elections and referendums, or in the case of other persons and organisations, purposes permitted by the regulations. Penalties are provided for the misuse of the information. In addition, personal electoral roll information will no longer be generally available under the Freedom of Information Act.

In its interim report on counting the vote on election night, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters recommended that Electoral Commission officers conduct an indicative distribution of second and later preference votes for the House of Representatives on election night. This will provide the public on that night with an early indication of the two-candidate preferred result in most electorates. This legislation will require the Australian Electoral Commission to conduct such an indicative distribution of preferences. The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters also recommended that scrutineers be given an explicit right to examine preferences on ballot papers. This legislation will give scrutineers the right to observe preferences so long as they do not unreasonably delay the scrutiny.

In its report on the 1990 election, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters recommended a prohibition on the distribution of material which discourages electors from numbering their ballot papers consecutively and fully. This legislation will make it an offence to intentionally encourage electors to mark their ballot papers in any way other than consecutively and fully.

In its May 1991 report entitled United Nations peacekeeping and Australia, the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade recommended that an explicit function be conferred on the Australian Electoral Commission to provide assistance to foreign countries and international organisations in the conduct of elections and referendums in cases where such assistance is approved by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans). The Bill will confer such a function.

The Bill will also empower the Australian Electoral Commission to provide goods and services to members of the public and organisations in a manner not inconsistent with the performance of its primary functions. Such goods might include the provision of public roll information, and such services might include providing a roll scanning service to State electoral authorities. In the light of the recent report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which recommended greater cooperation between Federal, State and Territory electoral authorities, legislation to permit the Electoral Commission to provide goods and services to those State and Territory electoral authorities is desirable.

In accordance with the Government's commitment to the user pays principle, the Bill will also empower the Australian Electoral Commission to impose charges for the provision of goods and services. The Bill also provides for a new system of automatic enrolment of new citizens. At the time of applying for citizenship, a person will be able to make a provisional claim for electoral enrolment. The provisional claim for enrolment will be activated once the person concerned has been granted citizenship.

Finally, the Bill includes a number of proposed minor amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act to improve the efficiency of the electoral process and to resolve certain practical difficulties in electoral administration. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill contains a number of amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984. Some of these amendments result from recommendations made by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. The Government asserts that others are designed to `resolve various practical problems which have arisen in the course of electoral administration'. Most importantly, the Bill repeals the requirement for biographical details of candidates to be distributed to each household in the lead-up to the next general election.

PARA.TAB: This particular measure was introduced last year in the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Act 1992. Indeed, this section of the Commonwealth Electoral Act was inserted as a result of an amendment moved by the Australian Democrats during debate on the Political Broadcasts Bill. In reality, the Government's agreement to this provision was part of the pay-off to the Democrats for supporting the ban on all political advertising.

The coalition felt that this ban on political advertising was one of the most appalling attacks on the freedom of speech and political expression in this country. The ban scaled new heights even for this Labor Government, which seems to thrive on social engineering. As the House would be aware, we vigorously campaigned against the ban.

As I mentioned earlier, the introduction of the brochure was a political pay-back to the Democrats in return for their support for the advertising blackout. However, following the High Court's decision that the advertising ban was, in fact, unconstitutional and a gross attack on the freedom of speech of ordinary Australians, the Government is killing off the whole concept of introductory brochures. What this amounts to is a huge back flip by the Government. It did not get its own way in the advertising ban, so there is no way it is going to honour its commitment to the Democrats.The coalition welcomes this decision, not only because of the opportunism which this Bill offered to enterprising businesses but also because of the very significant savings it will generate.

The Democrats' amendment created a bizarre opportunity for local tradesmen and businesses to register and run for a House of Representatives seat. By virtue of this introductory brochure the particular tradesman or business would gain free advertising, reaching every person in the local region. I have no problem with businesses being that enterprising—certainly in these times of recession they need all the help they can get just to survive—but this loophole demonstrates the absolute stupidity of the Democrats' proposal.

According to a Senate Estimates committee, repealing this amendment will save the taxpayer some $3m. My colleague Senator Parer, the shadow Minister for administrative services, has calculated that the savings are more likely to be in the vicinity of $5m to $10m.

The Bill makes a number of other amendments, some of which I would like briefly to comment upon. Clause 4 of the Bill results from recommendation 13 of the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.The report, titled United Nations peacekeeping and Australia, states:

The Committee recommends that steps be taken to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, or any other relevant regulatory change be made, to give the Australian Electoral Commission the function of providing assistance in the form of the secondment of personnel, or the supply or loan of material to a foreign government or to an international organisation in connection with the preparation for or the conduct of an overseas election or referendum as approved by the Australian Government.
This function should be reflected in the organisational structure of the Commission'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission has already made its expertise available for the United Nations peacekeeping operations in Namibia; the proposal to install a United Nations administration which would organise and conduct free elections in Cambodia; and preparatory work in connection with the proposed referendum to be held in Western Sahara to give the people of the Territory a choice between independence and integration with Morocco.

PARA.TAB: In addition, the Bill allows the Australian Electoral Commission to provide goods and services to other organisations or individuals—for example, a scanning service for assistance in the conduct of elections to the States. Importantly, and according to the user-pays principle, the Bill provides for the Electoral Commission to charge a fair and reasonable fee for these services. Clause 6 ensures that the Australian Electoral Commission lists the names of people who are required or may be required to provide a return showing donations to candidates or political parties in its report to the Minister. This measure arises from amendments made to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 following debate on the political broadcasts and political disclosures legislation last year.

The Australian Electoral Commission will be allowed to employ temporary staff and consultants to enhance public awareness of electoral and parliamentary matters under new provisions introduced in this Bill. Similarly, the Commission will also be obliged to regularly provide—free of charge—supplements to the electoral roll in computer format to all senators, members and registered political parties which have parliamentary representation. Other groups in the community will be able to purchase these supplements at some cost. In addition, the amendment allows registered political parties which presently receive habitation indexes from the Australian Electoral Commission to obtain extra copies at some cost. Clause 11 of the Bill tightens the copyright relating to the use of information contained on the electoral roll and habitation index. As such, tape and disk copies are now protected in a similar manner to the hard copies.

A new system of automatic enrolment of new citizens is introduced in this Bill. Under the new arrangements, those applying for citizenship may, at the same time, make a provisional claim for electoral enrolment, which would be activated when citizenship is granted. The Bill eliminates the need for the Australian Electoral Commission to advertise the receipt of an application for the registration of a political party. However, this is largely confined to cases where the Commission concludes in its initial consideration of the application that it is required to refuse the application, and where the applicant declines to vary the application to remedy its defects. On the other hand, if the applicant is prepared to vary the application in accordance with the Australian Electoral Commission's suggestion, the varied application is treated as the new application and an advertisement is required.

Clause 20 of the Bill eliminates the restriction of the Australian Electoral Commission to appoint a deputy presiding officer for a polling place where there will be fewer than six issuing points at any time during the hours of polling on polling day. This amendment results from a recommendation of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and is designed to increase flexibility in staffing arrangements.

Clause 22 provides for an Australian electoral officer in a given State or Territory to direct an indicative distribution of second and late preference votes at a House of Representatives election for any division in that State on polling night. The Australian Electoral Commission suggests that this will mean a much earlier indication of actual preference distributions on election nights. Previously preferences have not been distributed until the Tuesday or Wednesday following the election. As such, candidates and voters have relied on scrutineers' estimates as reported by media commentators on election night. Whilst trials by the Electoral Commission show that the new arrangements will take 15 to 30 minutes longer to count preferences, the results will be much more reliable. Indeed, one could say that the count will be slower to start but quicker to finish. Evidence given to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, whose recommendation initiated this change, suggests that the clause has been deliberately worded to be permissive and is not mandatory.

The Director of Public Prosecutions has advised that in the case of a misleading how-to-vote card which falsely represented that a candidate had endorsements from groups that had not endorsed him, it was not possible to bring criminal proceedings. This is because it could not be shown by admissible evidence that any particular person was responsible for publishing or distributing the cards. The cards bore the name of the printer and of the person who had authorised them, but the fact that the person was named on the card is not regarded as admissible evidence against that person; rather it is considered to be hearsay evidence. There is nothing in the current Act to facilitate proof that a person named in election material is familiar with that material. The legal issue lies in the difficulty of proving who was responsible for a misleading endorsement on a how-to-vote card.

If the Australian Electoral Commission investigations cannot find independent witnesses who saw the acts of distribution, the names of the printer and the authorising person listed on the card are not enough evidence to convict them of crimes against the Act. The proposed amendment will remedy this situation by providing that, where a person has been named on electoral material, this can be used as prima facie evidence in proceedings against that person for an offence against the principal Act.

Clause 26 of the Bill extends a legal privilege to enrolment documents. As the law stands, enrolment documents cannot be subpoenaed. The effect of this new clause is to give the Australian Electoral Commission a discretion as to whether or not the information is released to the Australian Federal Police. The current law makes the Electoral Commission liable to produce any documents demanded by the Federal Police under a proper warrant issued by a magistrate. However, section 390 of the Act has removed the requirement for the Electoral Commission to produce documents in any court. There is some obvious inconsistency here. The proposed amendment is designed to give the Electoral Commission the power to decide whether it will cooperate with a request for information from the police.

The coalition supports this amendment on the proviso that the Australian Electoral Commission's discretion should be exercised only in accordance with the information privacy principles under the Privacy Act, or with guidelines which are similar to those principles. My colleagues in the Senate have already indicated that the coalition will not be opposing this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating an omnibus Bill containing a range of amendments to implement some of the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, as well as a range of other reforms to the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act. Of themselves, the reforms are not particularly controversial. However, they are important reforms. In my contribution this afternoon I will speak briefly about some of them and I will speak in a little more depth about the changes concerning access to electoral rolls and to habitation indexes.

PARA.TAB: Some of the measures included in the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill are, in my mind, important. The Bill deals with the deletion of the requirement to provide candidate information booklets to all Australian households. This requirement formed part of the package which the Government introduced in relation to the controlling of electronic advertising of political broadcasts. As we all know, it is now part of history that that legislation was struck down in the High Court. As a result, since advertisements are now permissible, it is no longer necessary to send out these candidate information booklets which were to provide all electors with some basic policy information about their local candidates, as well as, I understand, Senate candidates.

Let me give honourable members an idea of what would have been involved here. The AEC did some preliminary work on putting this booklet together. It is an enormous booklet. It reminds me a little of the ballot paper that appeared in the first election for local government in the Australian Capital Territory, which was about the largest piece of paper I had seen. But this booklet would go somewhere near it. I do not know how effective it would have been in the end. I cannot imagine people wading through this in a great deal of detail to get all the information about their Senate and local candidates. Nonetheless, the intent behind it was probably sound in light of the measures which were being introduced at that time. Since that is no longer the case, there is no longer a need for the booklet. One of the measures contained in this Bill is to remove the need for that booklet to be produced.

A second matter which I think is extremely important deals with allowing on the night of the election an interim distribution of preferences in those divisions where preferences will be crucial to the result. The way in which this measure will work, according to clause 22 of the Bill, is that the State electoral officer will decide in which divisions it will be required to conduct a preliminary scrutiny of preferences. I assume that in practice that will not be seats like your own, Mr Deputy Speaker, where you will be returned with a thumping majority, but seats a bit like my own which are rather marginal and will probably, I concede, go to preferences.

TALK.START.PARA: —No!

—I welcome the confidence of my colleague, but it will occur in seats where the likelihood is that the results will be known only with preferences and it may be quite a close result. In the past it has taken many days for results in individual seats to be known. Even after the 1990 election it was some days before the result of the election was 100 per cent clear. It was not thought unlikely on the night of the election that the Government had been returned, but there were enough close seats that that position was in some doubt for a few days.

PARA.TAB: I remember my own experience after the 1987 election when the result in Fisher was, I think, the closest in Australia. Certainly, after the election I held the most marginal Government seat in Australia and it took three days of recounting and relying on advice from party scrutineers to be absolutely confident that I had won the seat. While that was rather unsettling and nerve-racking for me, I think it is not a particularly desirable outcome for this country that situations such as that should be allowed to exist.

This Bill allows a preliminary scrutiny of second and other preferences on the night of an election. That will be conducted by the polling officers in each individual polling booth. In the vast majority of cases it will allow a result to be pretty well determined on the night. There will still, I suppose, be a handful of cases which will be so close that postal and section votes will be necessary in order to be absolutely confident, but that will be a small number of cases. We will not have the ludicrous situation, as we did after the 1990 election, of going through the weekend not being 100 per cent certain whether the Government had been returned or whether a new government had been elected. I very much welcome that reform. I think it is a very positive one both for the candidates involved and, more importantly, for our system.

Another amendment concerns what I would describe as provisional enrolment for new citizens. I might describe this as the McLeay amendment because Mr Speaker, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), some years ago when I was a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters raised with me his view that a better system in relation to people taking out citizenship would be to include in that process an automatic way in which people could be added to the electoral roll so that when their citizenship actually went through they were added to the roll. At the moment new citizens are sent their little parcel of goodies together with their certificate of citizenship and an enrolment form to get on the roll. Obviously the vast majority of people do then go on to enrol, but it makes sense in terms of getting all the forms signed at one time that, when people are making their applications for citizenship, they can also at that stage choose to make an application to become enrolled and, if they proceed with the citizenship, that happens automatically.

It is similar, I suppose, to the current position where 17-year-olds can enrol and, if they turn 18, say, during the closing of the rolls if an election is called, be added to the roll. I find that a very worthwhile provision which currently operates, in my mind, very well. I think this is another one to be commended.

A measure contained in this Bill which I am not aware of having been heavily canvassed to date deals with the provision and use of the electoral roll itself, particularly in computer format. Australia has always had an open electoral system. I think we can take some pride in this country in the strength of our electoral system. Indeed, the term the `Australian ballot', which is essentially a secret ballot, still has some currency in parts of the United States as the description of the electoral system which was adopted. Certainly, we can take pride in the way in which we have run our Electoral Commission and the way in which we have conducted elections in this country.

Our rolls have always been freely available to people. They can go down to their local divisional returning office and check whether they are on the roll or whether other people are on the roll. Indeed, I think a system still exists whereby people may lodge an objection. If they lodge a $2 fee or something like that they can complain that somebody is wrongfully enrolled.

The information which has been generally available at a Commonwealth level in a public form has been a person's name and address. However, the Australian Electoral Commission has information beyond that. When people enrol, not only do they give their name and address, but they indicate, naturally enough, their gender and also, importantly, their date of birth and occupation. That information is contained in the Commission on its computer files, but is not made publicly available in terms of the printed roll.

The issues of who should have access to the Commission's information, how that information should be updated and to what use it should be put are important. They are particularly important in the context of the privacy debate, in which I am sure the House has taken some interest. It is a particular interest of mine, given that the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which I chair, is at present conducting an inquiry into the protections currently afforded to confidential Commonwealth information.

The real focus for this debate became evident following the release of the report of the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption on the misuse of confidential information in the State of New South Wales. That report revealed that there was within the State of New South Wales an extremely widespread network of people procuring and selling confidential information. This included a range of New South Wales public officials, including police officers, who were disclosing information either directly for money or in exchange for further information. Although Commissioner Roden in his report was not asked to look at the Commonwealth Government, he found in his inquiries that a range of Commonwealth Government employees from a range of Commonwealth Government agencies had been involved in this illicit trade of confidential information.

Employees in the Department of Social Security, the Health Insurance Commission, Telecom, Australia Post, the Customs department and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs were all involved, according to the ICAC report, in this information exchange network. As the Committee had already commenced its inquiry into these broad issues, we were also asked by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) to report to him and to the Parliament in relation to the appropriate Commonwealth response to the ICAC report and the implications for Commonwealth law.

Apart from the specific findings which Commissioner Roden made about corrupt conduct in New South Wales, he made three general rules, if you like, which were fundamental in terms of restricting the illicit trade in official information. He outlined several points that needed to be resolved. First, a clear line had to be drawn between information which is publicly available and that which is retained as confidential—which may seem very basic, but he found that often that clearly had not been determined. There was not a policy for what was to be regarded as confidential and what was to be available publicly. Secondly, when it is decided that information should be made available in a public sense, it should be provided readily, quickly and cheaply. Thirdly, if it is decided that a piece of information or a type of information is to be confidential, it must be properly protected with appropriate safeguards being put into place.

The Bill before us tonight addresses points one and two of those three general rules in relation to the provision of the electoral roll and habitation indexes. It goes some of the way towards deciding what information is to be publicly available and what is to be confidential. It also decides how information which is to be publicly available can be made available. Currently, the AEC holds extremely important information. I should add that there was no suggestion in the ICAC report of any wrongdoing on the part of the Australian Electoral Commission. No employees were named, and there was no inference at all in any of the evidence that there was any wrongdoing whatsoever occurring within the Australian Electoral Commission. I make that very clear. Nonetheless, these are issues which are important to the Electoral Commission.

The information that the Commission holds is currently made available to some 21 government agencies. It is made available to members of parliament and to political parties. There have been a number of problems with the general scheme of the way in which this information should go. Firstly, there was an apparent conflict between the operation of the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the Freedom of Information Act in relation to the availability in an electronic form or computer format of rolls and habitation indexes. The Commission does not make the roll publicly available in a computer form. People can go into an electoral office and buy a hard copy of a divisional roll, but not a computer tape of the roll. Yet the AEC had received a number of applications under the Freedom of Information Act for that very information. So we had the Freedom of Information Act apparently allowing access to this information but the Australian Commonwealth Electoral Act saying, `No, only a hard copy, a printed copy, is to be available'. This matter was raised by the Commission in public evidence given to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, and I am pleased to say that the matter has been resolved in this Bill.

I notice the Bill is also consistent with the advice given to Senator Bolkus, the Minister responsible for the Commission, by Kevin O'Connor, the Privacy Commissioner, that the Freedom of Information Act should not apply to this information; that the scheme regarding the control of the information and its dissemination should be contained purely within the Australian Electoral Act. This Bill resolves that point. I think it goes some of the way to resolving those three basic issues which Commissioner Roden posed as matters that have to be determined to be certain that information is being adequately protected.

There are some other issues which the Bill does not touch, nor would one expect it to, which are issues for the Australian Electoral Commission. One of those deals with its own staff and the information that it gains. For instance, the Commission has a responsibility to maintain the rolls in as accurate a state as possible. Regularly it does what is called a habitation review in order to maintain the rolls. It now has the power to go to other agencies to seek advice in furtherance of this aim of maintaining the rolls. For instance, it can go to Australia Post to look at its records to see who is living at various addresses and it can do a check for its own purposes. That is allowed for both in the guidelines under which Australia Post operates and also in the specific authority given to the Commission. It can gain information from other Commonwealth agencies and other sources in a like manner.

At the moment the Commission has no guidelines about the protection of the information it is gaining from third sources or when is the appropriate occasion that this information shall be sought. The ICAC report showed that it was not so much that information was leaking out directly but, rather, if people wanted to get some sort of Customs information, they might end up getting it out of an employee of a county council or an employee of the traffic authority in New South Wales because of this exchange of information between agencies. So it is important that we are aware of that and that the Commission is aware of that and is developing guidelines to make sure that this information, when sought from other agencies, is adequately protected. In evidence before the Committee, the Commission's witnesses advised us that they were aware of this problem, they were developing guidelines towards it, but were some way down the track from that.

Another issue which is important in terms of joint roles between the Commonwealth and the States is where information, which the Commonwealth gathers and is stringent in its own protection, is passed onto the States for the maintenance of State rolls, but where there is necessarily no equivalent of the Privacy Act applying in all States and no such control once the information leaves the immediate arm's length of the Commonwealth. What the States are doing with it and how they handle this information, particularly with occupation, date of birth and so on, is also an issue which I think the Commonwealth will have to raise with the States and, one hopes, will resolve. Certainly the Bill before us tonight is important. It makes a number of changes, it improves the law as it concerns the protection of information, and I commend it to the House. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill which is before the House, I wish to confine my remarks to those provisions which will repeal section 386A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Members may recall that section 386A of that Act was inserted last year following an amendment moved by the Democrats in the other place and agreed to by the Government.

PARA.TAB: I wish to take the time of the House to refresh honourable members' memories as to the effect of this section of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. It was simply to allow for a massive booklet giving the profile of candidates at a Federal election to be sent to every household. That would allow minority parties such as the Democrats or Independents to have massive taxpayer subsidies for their political purposes. In other words, the Democrats were trying to circumvent the usual political process, which is to garner support from the general public by way of physical contributions, by manning polling booths, handing out literature, or by contributing funds which are fully disclosable. So the Democrats, with the assistance of the Government, were trying to take a short cut and not do the hard, political slog.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a grubby deal.

—It was a grubby deal, as the shadow Minister reminds me. In fact, it was nothing more than a bribe. I will also refresh honourable members' memories as to the timing of this agreement, or unholy alliance, between the Government and the Democrats. That amendment to section 386A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act was inserted at the same time as there was debate on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill—in other words, the ban on political advertising—and that legislation was later struck out by the High Court.

PARA.TAB: I will put these events into sequence. Some 12 months ago the Government needed the Democrats' support to get through the Senate the ban on political advertising. It allowed this massive transfer of taxpayers' funds to the Democrats to allow for this mail out to all households of profiles of their candidates and others. The legislation goes through and then gets struck out, rightly—as we predicted—in the case before the High Court which the Opposition initiated. Now the Government reneges on the deal with the Democrats.

The booklet has gone now and I am still waiting for an apology from any Government member for, firstly, taking up the Parliament's time in the initial legislation and the subsequent legislation and, secondly, the money involved in changing the legislation some 12 months ago and now having to change it again—all because the Government has reneged on the Democrats. Talk about thieves falling out! The Government does a grubby deal with the Democrats to get its political ban legislation through by bribing them with this political propaganda booklet which it agrees to send to all households. Now that the High Court has struck out the legislation, which was the original reason for this agreement between the Government and the Democrats, the Government has reneged on it.

The Democrats do not have their booklet; they do not have their taxpayer-funded political campaign. As it is, taxpayers—without any recourse to a referendum, I hasten to add—have to pay some 40c or 50c for every vote a registered political party gains in the House of Representatives and about $1 for every vote it gains in the Senate. Of the order of $15m or $16m is devoted to publicly funded Federal campaigns. The Government wanted to add to that. Can honourable members imagine the cost of compiling, printing and distributing these booklets to each of the 148 House of Representatives electorates and for all of the Senate areas?

The Electoral Commission estimates, conservatively, that abandoning the idea of sending a booklet to every household will save $3m. On our equally conservative estimates, we believe that between $5m and $10m will be saved to taxpayers by the abandonment of this ludicrous idea that every household get a booklet with every candidate profiled. The message to the Democrats, the Independents and minor political parties, as it is to the major political parties—the Labor, Liberal and National parties—is to get out there and win support. Talk about accountability! Why should the Democrats, with their failing national support and disintegration in Victoria, turn to the taxpayer to maintain them as a political party and give some of those useless senators that they have representing them in the other place a job? The message is that they should get out there and be accountable for their policies, ideas and performance, and people will support them or they will not. They will give that support either by hands-on contributions or by funds—all of which we have to reveal.

No unholy deals should be done, as has happened between the Government and the Democrats. We do not hear much complaint from the Democrats about this. They have been caught out. What are they going to do? Will they go to the Australian public and say, `The Government has reneged on the deal that we struck a year ago and they are very bad people.'? To do so they would have to reveal the existence of the deal in the first place.

I wonder where the inquisitive media is at a time such as this. The media will always investigate anything surrounding the personalities in politics and so many of the irrelevancies, but when a really dishonest bribe occurs between the Government and the Democrats they are nowhere to be seen. What other explanation is there for the Government's agreeing to the funding of the booklet, which will so advantage the Democrats, and now, 12 months later, repealing it? It can only be because the Government no longer needs the Democrats' support to maintain the electronic advertising ban.

Members of the Government should hang their heads in shame. I wish more Australians knew what they are prepared to do to serve their own political purposes. Twelve months ago they thought that a ban on electronic advertising would suit them and benefit them, and they were prepared to pay any price—not out of their own pockets, Labor members never do, but out of the pockets of taxpayers. Now that that ban on political advertising cannot be enforced at law, they will abandon their deals with the Democrats. I think the Government and the Democrats stand equally condemned.

No wonder the Democrats are so desperate to get the taxpayer subsidised electoral advantages that the booklet would have given them. If the Party has its seven senators standing at the next Federal election, it would lose party status and could easily be wiped out, as the DLP was in the 1974 election. Sadly, only two of the Democrats are up for a vote this time, and honourable members can be sure that neither of them will be returned. I hasten to correct myself by saying that now that Senator Janet Powell from Victoria has left the Democrats, the Party is down to six.

We never hear of the Democrats. The last I heard of their Leader, Senator Coulter, was in a small paragraph in today's Daily Telegraph, in which he called on the Government to withdraw the sale of sea perch from the parliamentary dining room and to take it off the menu because sea perch, or orange roughy, is an endangered species.

TALK.START.PARA: —So is he.

—So are the Democrats. I know a great deal about orange roughy. Fishermen are engaged in orange roughy fishing from the port of Lakes Entrance. There is great controversy and debate in recent days on the scientific evidence about just what has been the depletion of orange roughy. We can debate whether or not a fish species has been depleted to the extent that it cannot maintain a sustainable fishery, but we can never argue that a fish species is extinct. There is no evidence that I am aware of—and I would be happy to be corrected—that fish species have become extinct. One cannot completely make a fish species extinct in the way that one can mammals or birds. Therefore, Senator Coulter is whipping up yet another environmental falsehood.

PARA.TAB: I will not labour the point, except again to draw to the attention of the House and the media at large that the Government is revealed for its grubby political behaviour. It has reneged on a deal with the Democrats to provide to all households a booklet containing all information as to their candidates. Honourable members can just imagine the political benefit that that would confer on the Democrats or on any individual.

It is not inconceivable to believe that somebody who wants a profile in a given area by way of some cheap advertising can just nominate. It would be the cheapest $200 lodgment fee anyone would ever spend. The nominee's name, occupation, background and family history would go to 75,000 or 76,000 households—marvellous! If I were setting up a new business in Gippsland and was not the Federal member, I would think this was a pretty good way to get into every household, regardless of the vote I might actually win at the next Federal election. The Government could have expected 20 to 30 candidates in every Federal electorate if it had offered household advertising on this scale.

The Democrats, with the assistance of the Government, were trying to cheat taxpayers. They cannot stand on their own feet as a political party to win public support and all that entails. It is despicable that the Government was ever a party to this very shoddy deal. It is not because the Government has had a change of heart, a burst of new morality or a new awakening; it is simply striking down the legislation with the High Court decision, which was the cause of this deal. The Government no longer needs the Democrats. The Labor Party and the Democrats deserve each other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last 12 minutes we discovered two things: the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) has a passionate interest in conspiracy theories and in orange roughy but, beyond that, very little else. I will make one observation about the conspiracy theory which seemed to so excite the passions of the honourable member for Gippsland. I wonder whether he holds the same view about the unions which expend union funds to ensure that every candidate in a union election has his message included in union journals at no cost to the candidate. Is that something which we should attack and bemoan?
—It's not taxpayers' funds.

—In that case it is union members' funds, but the same principle applies. Is the honourable member also concerned about the same practice followed by corporations, companies, credit unions and friendly societies? The people who contribute the money collectively elect to allocate some of that money to ensure that all candidates receive assistance to have their message put before those who cast a vote. I make that observation to the honourable member for Gippsland, who spent eight of his 12 minutes concerned about that conspiracy and the other four minutes talking about orange roughy.

PARA.TAB: My interest in the second reading debate on the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1992 is to address the clauses that relate to questions that have come before the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I am pleased to say that a number of matters in this Bill reflect concerns that have been raised in a couple of reports from the Standing Committee. At the outset, it is important to acknowledge in this place that Australia is well served by having an Electoral Act, an electoral system and a network of commissions at both Commonwealth and State levels that provide a high quality service, an impartial service and one which is regarded around the world as first rate.

We have a set of amendments before us which seek to improve on what is internationally recognised as a fair and proper system—a system which, by and large, is well administered. That is not to say that there are no problems and that there is no room for improvement. At the outset, though, it is worth acknowledging that we are debating amendments to what is a fine system.

Clause 15 of the Bill makes an alteration to provide easier access for new Australians to exercise their rights as new Australians in determining the government of this country. The amendment provides for a provisional claim for enrolment by applicants for citizenship so that at the time they become citizens they will automatically have an enrolment recorded in their favour. That will provide many new Australians with speedier access to exercising their votes as new Australians. As has been mentioned in this debate, that issue was raised by the Committee about three years ago. It is one in which a number of members of this Parliament have taken an interest. I am very pleased to see that the Government has picked up that issue and has sought to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 so that new Australians exercise their right to vote at the earliest opportunity after becoming Australian citizens.

There are a couple of other amendments which are probably of more direct interest to some honourable members in this place—most notably, the changes occurring in the scrutiny and counting of ballot papers. The Bill gives effect to some recommendations from the Committee on Electoral Matters on the counting of ballot papers that would require an indicative distribution of second and later preferences to the two candidates identified by the Electoral Commission as most likely to win. Proposed new subsection 274(2A) states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Australian Electoral Officer for the State or Territory that includes the Division must, in writing, direct the Assistant Returning Officer for the Division also to count such preference votes (other than first preference votes), on such of the ballot papers, as, in the opinion of the Australian Electoral Officer, will provide an indication of which candidate is most likely to be elected for the Division.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not possible always.

—I understand the concerns of the honourable member for Moncrieff. She raised this matter when the Committee delivered an interim report on this question. It is true that there will be some seats where it is not possible, with the best will in the world, to identify two candidates who might be considered most likely to win. There are a number of seats—we do not need to try to identify them here and now—where we would reasonably expect a three-cornered contest to occur.

PARA.TAB: In those situations, the Australian Electoral Officer will be put in the position of having to select two of those three. It may be that the Australian Electoral Officer will make an error. Going on the results of the 1990 election and the estimates provided to the Committee by the AEC and media observers, probably seven or eight errors occurred last time in exercising that judgment. However, the proposals taken as a whole will ensure that that difficulty is overcome on election night by extending the powers of scrutiny.

Clause 25 of the Bill extends the powers of scrutineers to ensure that scrutineers have access to every ballot paper and every preference. At the conclusion of the two-candidate preferred count—the indicative count which clause 26 provides for—I would think that, in the three-cornered contest seats, the scrutineers for the relevant parties would carefully scrutinise each of the other ballot papers. So they would leave the room with the very clear knowledge of the indicative count done by the AEC officers and, as scrutineers, they would also have a very clear indication in order to advise their candidates exactly where the preferences were falling on that night. That was the fundamental problem which the Standing Committee sought to address in its 1990 report. It looked at some of the problems associated with not knowing the result of the election on the evening of the 1990 general election.

Taken together, those two alterations will result in candidates—and the public through the media—being aware of the most likely outcome in every seat. In the great bulk of seats that information will be as a result of the indicative count which officers of the Australian Electoral Commission will perform under the supervision of scrutineers. For those seats where that two-candidate indicative count may not give the result, the Bill inserts quite clear rights for scrutineers to ensure that they know where the preferences have been allocated on all of the ballot papers and are able to provide the appropriate advice to the candidates.

In practical terms, that achieves the most desirable outcome. It provides the most authoritative account possible where most seats are concerned; that is, where it is a choice in the end between the two most likely candidates. That will be the case in the great bulk of seats. Most seats will be determined by that most authoritative count. The outcome of the other seats, which may well determine government, will be better known on election night 1993 than was the case in 1990, because in 1993, unlike 1990, the scrutineers will have quite clear and express authority to peruse every ballot paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —All your scrutineers must be schoolteachers.

—My scrutineers do a very good job. I guess I can fall back on the comments of the honourable member for Gippsland: it goes to the ability of the respective candidates and parties to enlist that public support which generates various benefits, some of which might be financial contributions, handing out literature or getting scrutineers who know what they are doing. In any event, if we are talking about three-horse races—
—That is insulting.

—It is not at all. The honourable member should talk to the honourable member for Gippsland. His comments could be regarded as an affront to many Independents and minor parties who would not take kindly to his suggestions. But the facts of the matter are that the major parties, and indeed candidates who are likely to succeed in a general election, will have scrutineers who are quite able to count the distribution of preferences. I suggest that that would be the case in all situations where there is a three-cornered contest if the candidates have done their work.

PARA.TAB: I see members of the Opposition shaking their heads in disagreement. Having spent I do not know how many evenings scrutineering for many candidates over the last 15 years or so, I can assure honourable members opposite—I am not sure how many polling places they have been in on election nights—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's illegal to go into them when you are a candidate.

—I am not talking about when one is a candidate. The honourable member should not get too concerned about it; there are other elections. Having been in those polling places when the scrutiny occurs, it is quite clear that members of all the major political parties are more than able to keep an accurate record of the preferences. In fact, it creates a problem on only a few rare occasions. That was the matter which the Committee sought to address in 1990.

PARA.TAB: A couple of other points are raised in the Bill which I want to mention quickly. Clause 27 of the Bill makes it an offence to encourage persons to mark their ballot papers otherwise than consecutively and fully if that advice is given during the election period. I think that is an important inclusion in the Act. There are provisions in the Act to ensure that people who cast a vote have every opportunity to have their intention recorded. Those provisions should not be used as loopholes for some sections of the community to seek to undermine the basic compulsory nature of voting or the preferential nature of the voting system. This clause seeks to address that problem. The Bill as a whole makes a number of significant improvements to the procedures followed by the AEC, both on election night and prior to election night in enrolling Australian citizens to vote.

I commend the Bill to the House. I think the work which has been undertaken by the Government in revising the current procedures and reviewing the work of the Committee has been fruitful. The end result is a system which is fairer and which will provide on election night 1993 a much speedier and, I suspect, more accurate final count for the evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to respond to a couple of points contained in the speech by the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis). When the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters was debated here, I sought the opportunity to speak briefly to it because it seemed to me that the recommendations which were being made overlooked the situation where three candidates had a genuine chance of winning a seat. I subsequently received a telephone call from the Deputy Electoral Commissioner. I have not yet had the opportunity to return that call, but I shall. He indicated that he wanted to discuss the matter further with me. I acknowledge that the Electoral Commission wants to do the right thing.

PARA.TAB: But I am concerned that the speech of the honourable member for Brisbane will be taken by the Electoral Commission as some sort of a solution to these difficult situations. He does not know what he is talking about in some cases and I really have to point these out. I have scrutineered many times. I have been in the Liberal Party for 32 years and I have certainly scrutineered many elections. Of course, I cannot scrutineer when I am a candidate, and that accounts for the last 18 1/2 elections. So I get counted out of a number. We have lot of Federal elections, as the honourable member is aware.

I suspect that the honourable member is not familiar with the situation in electorates where there is a multiplicity of country booths, for example. In the electorate of Moncrieff in the last election I think I had 49 booths, which ranged in numbers of voters from 100 to 6,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had 90.

—Those, like the honourable member for Forrest, who have rather larger rural areas than I would have many more polling booths. Our large rural electorates would have dozens and dozens of booths with just a handful of votes being cast at a number of them. There is nothing wrong with that; we must make that facility available to the public in order to assist their being able to vote. But certain things flow from it.

PARA.TAB: At one stage I said that the honourable member's remarks were insulting because he was referring to whether scrutineers were capable of doing this, that and the other. There are two issues involved. Firstly, at small booths parties sometimes have difficulty getting someone to scrutineer. It is always a case of having one person on the booth all day, with that person then going on to do the scrutineering. At the end of 12 hours hard work they are supposed to be mentally alert to do, in those cases where there are three possibilities, what is a really difficult job.

Secondly, I used to teach maths and I know about permutations and combinations. That is the reason why I said that the honourable member must have schoolteachers scrutineering all of his votes. It can be very tricky indeed. It is virtually impossible to explain it to some booth workers when they have to watch a multiplicity of situations. I will explain what I mean.

In 1984, the first time I stood for the electorate of Moncrieff, there were six candidates. There were the four major parties—Liberal, National, Labor and Democrat—and two Independents. There were three potential winners—Labor, Liberal and National. It really was not possible to tell in advance which party would win. Clearly, the full flow-through of preferences of all the minor candidates—the Democrats and the two Independents—had to be recorded in order to get the sort of result we are talking about here.

That is not quick or easy to do; it is very difficult when one thinks about it because one has to watch the full flow-through. Let us say one or a number of preferences go from one Independent to the next Independent to the Democrats and then to the National Party or the Liberal Party. Scrutineers have to watch the flow-through of five steps at once. If the returning officer in the booth with 100 votes, let us say, is good enough to turn over those votes one at a time and stand there while the scrutineers do their calculations, that is fine. But what do they do in the booths with 6000 votes?

I know that the votes are not all counted at one table; they are counted at a number of tables. But we are still talking about many hundreds of votes per table. I do not know of any training that we can give scrutineers which will enable them to perform the task. I tried it. I understand the complexities and I also understand the limitations of people who do not do this for a living. We love looking at ballot papers, preferences flows and doing the sums. We live it—and so we should; it is our bread and butter. But a lot of people out there do not really live this 365 days a year.

We try to give scrutineers a seminar two nights before election day. We say, `Here is the piece of paper. You have to watch four steps with each ballot paper. You have to know where each one of those Independent votes is going. Is it ultimately going to Liberal, Labor or National? If it goes to, let us say, Liberal before it goes to National, you have to make sure that it does not go on to Labor; you have to see whether it will go on to National or Labor'. That is a very difficult exercise for people who do not live and breathe ballot papers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be easier in 1993 than it was in 1990 because half of it will be done by the AEC in doing the two-party preferred.

—Well, okay. The objection that I raised initially related to the situations where the returning officer would simply have to say to the AEC, `I cannot say who the two candidates are. You will have to look at three'. Again, I instance Moncrieff in 1984 where no-one could anticipate how preferences would go. We cannot say, `So we will have to look at three'. There will have to be a let-out.

PARA.TAB: Let us take as examples the seat of North Sydney in the last election campaign or the by-election in Wills. I know that the by-election was not going to decide government, but it gets tricky where a strong Independent candidate goes against the odds and is elected.The essence of my point is that these are the seats that determine government.

It is all very well for the honourable member for Brisbane to say that in general terms that will not apply because the great bulk of seats will be determined fairly easily. The great bulk of seats are not the ones that determine government. The marginal seats, where it is very difficult to anticipate preferences, decide government. This whole exercise is supposed to be about telling the public as quickly as possible who the next government will be.

Whilst I am on my feet, I will throw in one for the ABC. I am not one who goes around bagging the ABC. I like to listen to its election commentary on car radio as I go to various venues on election night if it is a State election. If it is a Federal election and if I am in the one place, I watch the commentary on the television that night. I hope the ABC, with all of its little trinkets, playthings and gewgaws, will do a better job covering this Federal election than it did covering the last State election. I spent a great deal of the time after the close of polls on State election night in Queensland actually listening to results on the car radio. There were six State electorates within my Federal electorate and I wanted to visit all of the centres where party people were gathering to hear the results. I did not hear a single sensible set of figures given over the radio.

I had watched a bit of the coverage on television, so I knew what all of the commentators were doing. They had their noses glued to a screen which nobody in the television viewing audience could see. They were chatting to one another about what they could see on a computer screen, but nobody else could see it. The ABC probably would not show it on the television anyway because, like the scrutineers that the honourable member for Brisbane referred to, the commentators are highly trained people who can actually interpret what they are seeing on their screen. The general public cannot.

It appears that the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) has not been listening. I will not repeat it from the top. The honourable member for Brisbane said that we can train scrutineers to do these mental gymnastics and these mathematical feats. But we simply cannot do this in a particularly difficult or tricky situation—for example, if more than three parties are running against each other or if two parties are essentially running against one another.

I want to put this on the record. I hope somebody from the ABC or commercial radio or television is listening. It is very nice that the ABC is getting a computer analysis, but in the Queensland State election, which was the first exercise in this really sophisticated computer analysis, it was very difficult to know what was going on.

The party people go to election night gatherings and get the results phoned to where they are, and we can find out there what the results are. I did not get a single result for a single State seat in my electorate from either the radio broadcast or the television broadcast. All of the information I got came from my access to that gathering together of information at the candidates' post-election parties.

I reiterate to the honourable member for Brisbane the reason I was offended. What he said was insulting. He said that if scrutineers are any good, they should be able to learn all the steps. My scrutineers are very good, loyal people; I cannot criticise them for not being wizards at counting votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sure.

—That is easy to say, but I think the exercise is a bit harder. I have scrutineered plenty of Brisbane electorates. They have tended to involve the Liberal Party versus the Labor Party, and the National Party was a genuine third party in Brisbane electorates up until the last election. I do not think that situation will return. Brisbane and seats in the other major population centres will be contested essentially between the Liberal and Labor parties, the Democrats, who will be a major third force in terms of where their preferences go, and the occasional Independent. That leads to a fairly easy exercise but where we have three genuine contestants, whether they be from the major parties or outstanding Independent candidates, the exercise is a very difficult one. I reiterate that it is the difficult exercises that are the slow ones. They are usually the electorates that the attention is focused on days after the election campaign because they are the ones that determine the outcome.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, anything that speeds up the analysis of preferences is welcomed—not least because of the incredibly stupid comments one hears on the radio and television on election night from some of the commentators. They might say that so and so has won a seat, but do not take any account of the likely drift of preferences. That happens over and over again. Anyone sitting there, say, in the old days looking at DLP preferences and knowing that they went about 80 per cent anti-Labor, and these days looking at the Democrat preferences and knowing that in most metropolitan seats they go about 60 per cent pro-Labor, can start doing a bit of mental arithmetic, for those of us who dabble in that, and make a better guess. But it always amazes me that people who are paid to comment on election outcomes do not know the basics of politics in Australia. I am sure I have strained the patience of the House quite enough by making that intervention.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would never say that.

—The honourable member for Macarthur is too kind. But it is clear that an understanding of all the pitfalls has not got through. There is merely some selective understanding of it. There needs to be some pretty wide consultations between members, candidates and others before the Australian Electoral Commission settles on how it is finally going to handle the conduct of preference votes in the next Federal election.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Price) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health and Medical Research Council Bill 1992 is returned from the Senate with amendments relating to the ethics side of the NHMRC. The Opposition is opposed to the amendments inasmuch as they do not go far enough to address the major problems which we have raised in this place previously.

PARA.TAB: The essence of the problems is that it is inappropriate for the NHMRC, a body which has as one of its major functions the promotion of research, also to be responsible for the ethics considerations relating to that research which, by and large, would tend to slow down or inhibit aspects of that research. There is clearly a conflict of functions here between the two aspects of the NHMRC's responsibilities.

The view of the Opposition is and has been since the publication of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation in 1985, I believe, that there should be a separation of the ethics functions into a separate body, which may or may not be a statutory authority, so that the ethics considerations can be taken away from under the umbrella of the NHMRC and considered in complete separation and isolation, free of any influence which might encourage that ethics body to encourage research and, therefore, to dilute or water down any provisions to protect the subjects in particular of experimentation. One of the areas involved, of course, is the question of experimentation on embryos.

What the amendments do is to define the functions of the Australian Health Ethics Committee. It becomes a principal committee of the NHMRC. The members are defined, but the members are also principal committee members of other committees in the NHMRC. I am pleased to see that it does state that the recommendations of the AHEC must be accepted by the NHMRC—and we certainly support that as far as it goes—and also that the guidelines for medical research must be tabled, although not necessarily approved by both Houses.

As I say, however, the problem with the amendments as they relate to this piece of legislation is that there is still no separation, as such. We are talking about the same members wearing different hats and therefore having a conflict of responsibilities. We would prefer to see the guidelines for medical research not only tabled, but requiring the approval of both Houses.

There was an amendment foreshadowed by Senator Harradine in the other House relating to the issue of embryo experimentation. This was never put to the other place, mainly because the Government decided that it would not allow a conscience vote on an issue as important as this. The position of the coalition was that the question of embryo experimentation was such an important issue that we would allow a conscience vote, but this was blocked by Government members not being allowed that freedom and the usual rigidity which occurs in the Labor Party being imposed on its members in such an important issue.

I find it very sad that such an important issue should be decided on party lines when it is clearly a matter of conscience. I am disappointed that that particular issue was not able to be put in the other House. I reiterate that the amendments improve the Bill, but they do not go far enough for the Opposition. For that reason, we are unhappy about the current situation and we oppose the amendments as they stand.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.
