SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) I am pleased to present the latest in a series of initiatives to reduce tobacco consumption in Australia. The problems caused by tobacco consumption cannot be denied and the Government can see no justification for promoting tobacco sales in any way.

PARA.TAB: This Bill will establish a national prohibition on tobacco advertising, expanding the existing bans in the broadcasting and print media and complementing the action of those States and Territories which have introduced their own restrictions on tobacco promotion.

The facts about the impact of tobacco on health in Australia are clear and stark. Tobacco is the major preventable cause of death and disease in Australia. In 1990 over 18,000 people died before their time because they smoked. In addition, smoking was estimated to present an annual cost to the Australian economy of over $6.8 billion in 1988. Tobacco use is clearly a serious problem.

On the other hand, although smoking rates are declining from the extraordinary levels seen at the end of World War 2, some 28 per cent of adult Australians currently smoke. Thus, at least for the medium term future, it is not possible for the Government to simply make tobacco an illegal substance. Like powerful drugs, firearms and other legal, although dangerous, products, however, advertising of tobacco products should be severely limited. This is especially so when advertising has the effect, intended or otherwise, of persuading children to take up an addictive life-threatening habit.

To coordinate national action on the tobacco issue, the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments adopted the national health policy on tobacco in March 1991. This policy recognises the need for a diverse range of measures to reduce tobacco related harm. Marketing, availability, taxation, education, passive smoking and cessation services are each separately addressed.

This Bill is the latest in a series of initiatives by this Government to reduce tobacco consumption in Australia. Achievements to date include a ban on smoking in Commonwealth buildings, a ban on tobacco advertising in the print media to extend the established broadcast media ban, a ban on smoking during airline flights and a ban on the sale of chewing tobacco and oral snuff.

In addition, the Government increased tobacco excise by over 10 per cent in the last Budget, leading to increased prices and reduced consumption. Furthermore, significant funding has been provided for education programs including the very successful `Smoking. Who Needs It!' campaign.

It is important to understand that removing tobacco advertising is primarily a prevention activity intended to reduce the number of children taking up smoking. Although advertising may not directly cause children to smoke, it reinforces other influences such as peer and social pressures which cause children to smoke. Tobacco advertisements glamorise smoking, making it seem like a desirable activity.

We are reminded by the recent decision of the High Court that free speech is a value fundamental to Australia. Serious consideration must therefore be given to any restrictions on free speech, including commercial free speech. However, tobacco advertising is a clear case of where restrictions on speech are appropriate in light of the need to protect the community's health, especially the health of its children.

Even if we accept the claim of the tobacco companies that their advertising is directed towards increasing market share, not recruiting new smokers, it is stretching credibility beyond its bounds to claim that this advertising has no effect on total consumption. Tobacco advertising supports and reinforces pressures to take up smoking and increases the difficulties encountered in quitting.

There is plenty of evidence to indicate that tobacco advertising increases tobacco consumption. A recent draft discussion paper released by the United Kingdom Department of Health used a variety of methods to examine the effect of tobacco advertising and reviewed existing research. One of the conclusions of this paper was that `the balance of evidence thus supports the conclusion that advertising does have a positive effect on consumption'.

Research has also demonstrated the beneficial effects of tobacco advertising prohibitions such as those contained in this Bill. The same discussion paper examined the effect of advertising bans in several countries. On this matter, the paper concluded that `in each case the banning of advertising was followed by a fall in smoking on a scale which cannot reasonably be attributed to other factors'.

Tobacco advertising in association with sport is particularly insidious as it seeks to link an unhealthy product with a healthy activity. Sponsorship of sporting and cultural activities has been exploited as an effective form of tobacco advertising. For example, a sponsor's name or logo may be recognisable for up to one third of the broadcast time of a major sporting event. One estimate is that a tobacco sponsored team received the commercial equivalent of over $4.5m worth of advertising during this year's Bathurst 1000.

This Bill will break the nexus between tobacco and sport and between tobacco and cultural activities. There can hardly be a more bizarre association than that between a product which is known to be a killer and the health giving nature of sport. This is especially so in the Australian context where sport is a vital part of our culture and where elite sports people are idolised, particularly by the young.

The Government has recognised that sporting bodies may need some time to find alternative sources of funding. Hence, the Bill will allow phasing out of advertising associated with sponsorship. The elite sports can be expected to find alternative commercial sponsors readily. The fact that a range of minor sports and small scale events, including in rural areas, will also need to seek support is a measure of the degree to which the tobacco dollar has penetrated sport and culture.

The Government commends Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and the Australian Capital Territory governments for having established health promotion foundations to provide alternative funding and commends these examples to the other States and Territories. If, however, these smaller sports and events do genuinely find it impossible to replace lost tobacco funding, the Government will consider subsidising some events following the transition period.

In recognition of the effect of tobacco advertising, the Commonwealth has already banned direct advertising in the broadcast and print media. Several States and Territories have banned various other forms of advertising and marketing. In particular, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia, the Australian Capital Territory and New South Wales have all introduced legislation to limit tobacco advertising. This State and Territory legislation also addresses other marketing activities by, for example, banning tobacco related competitions and free samples.

Different regulations addressing tobacco advertising in each State and Territory have resulted in some difficulties with enforcement. For example, national activities have needed to be exempt and there have been ongoing problems with the venue for the 500cc motorcycle grand prix due to differences in the legislation between Victoria and New South Wales. Thus, a national advertising prohibition is required to ensure a comprehensive approach and one which minimises any disadvantage to a particular jurisdiction.

The international community is also increasingly introducing restrictions. Adoption of this Bill would move Australia from equal tenth to equal fifth in the OECD in terms of tobacco advertising restrictions.

The community expects the Government to act. The Government announced in April that it would ban tobacco advertising. Recently there have been a number of calls for the promised legislation to be introduced. Recently this call was renewed by the National Health and Medical Research Council, the principal medical advisory body to the Government.

The Bill will establish a complete ban on tobacco advertising to be phased in over the period 1 July 1993 to 31 December 1995. The major additional forms of tobacco advertising to be prohibited by this Bill are:

SPEECH.PARA: .advertising through sponsorship of sporting and cultural events—covering both naming of the event and publicity at the event;
.outdoor advertising such as on billboards or by illuminated signs; and
.the use of tobacco brand names, logos, et cetera on non-tobacco products.
The maximum penalty for breaching the ban is $12,000 for an individual or $60,000 for a corporation.

PARA.TAB: This Bill removes the potential for tobacco advertising but not to the extent that extreme measures are taken.

SPEECH.PARA: .Accidental or incidental advertising for which the broadcaster or publisher does not receive any benefit will be permitted. For example, broadcasts of tobacco sponsored sporting events held overseas will not be affected by this Bill.

.International events to be held in Australia will be able to apply for an exemption from the ban. Such an exemption would be granted if the event has international significance and Australia would be likely to lose the event if the exemption was not provided.

.Point of sale advertising will not be eliminated. In those jurisdictions with point of sale legislation, the State or Territory rules will apply. In other jurisdictions, point of sale advertising—as defined by Commonwealth regulations—will be permitted.
.Also, tobacco advertising in imported periodicals will be exempt so that these publications may continue to be available in the Australian market.

The Bill contains sections which, if proclaimed, would permit the Minister to specify periodicals excluded from this permission. Should it appear that tobacco companies are exploiting this exemption, these sections will be proclaimed.

PARA.TAB: The Bill, in essence, prohibits the broadcast or publication of a tobacco advertisement. It will have the effect of setting a national standard for bans on tobacco advertising. The Bill does not preclude or limit application of a State or Territory law which might apply a stricter ban.

A tobacco advertisement includes any image or audio message which publicises or otherwise promotes any words or designs closely associated with tobacco products. This includes logos, brand names and manufacturer's names. Some material is specifically excluded from the definition of tobacco advertisement, such as:

SPEECH.PARA: .labelling of cigarette packets; manufacturer's names on company letterhead;
.advertisements for specified non-tobacco products with tobacco brand names; and
.anti-smoking advertisements.

PARA.TAB: The act of publishing a tobacco advertisement, in addition to incorporating it in a printed document, is defined in a wide sense to include displaying or selling something containing the advertisement. A tobacco advertisement is published if it is brought to the attention of the public, or a section of the public, in some way.
The Bill creates an offence for a tobacco advertisement to be published, unless the advertisement:

SPEECH.PARA: .is at the point of sale of tobacco products and complies with the regulations;
.is contained in an imported periodical which is not principally intended for Australia;
.is associated with an exempt tobacco sponsored event of international significance and complies with any conditions attached to that exemption; or
.is accidental or incidental to the publication of other matter and where no benefit has been received by the publisher for publishing the tobacco advertisement.
In addition, an independent person is permitted to publish an advertisement on his or her own initiative—for example, a person may wear clothing which has a tobacco advertisement on it.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, persons publishing a tobacco advertisement in the following categories are exempt:

SPEECH.PARA: .advertising arising from sponsorship contracts established before 1 April 1992 which will be temporarily exempted until 31 December 1995; and
.billboard and other outdoor advertising established before 1 April 1992 which are provided for by a gradual phase-out period until 31 December 1995.

The publishing offence does not apply to Norfolk Island. The Norfolk Island Administration has indicated that it wishes to be excluded from the extension to the advertising bans. In accordance with the Commonwealth Government commitment to consult, given at the time of Norfolk Island independence, only the broadcasting offence will apply in Norfolk Island. The Bill has been constructed so that a person based in Norfolk Island will not be able to use this circumstance to publish a tobacco advertisement in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Should it be necessary to proclaim those sections of the Bill concerning specification of imported periodicals, it would be an offence to import a specified periodical which contains a non-incidental tobacco advertisement. However, importing for private use or exempt library use would be permitted.

Part 5 of the Bill amends the existing bans on tobacco advertising. The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 is amended so that it is consistent with the new bans. In addition, the Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Act 1989 is repealed, as the Bill incorporates the offences contained in that Act.

The ban on tobacco advertising will lead to reduced smoking rates. The effect on the tobacco industry—growers, manufacturers, importers, et cetera—is expected to be gradual as the major impact of the ban will be a reduction in the number of children taking up smoking rather than a sudden increase in smokers quitting.

The outdoor advertising industry is also likely to be affected by the ban. In New South Wales and Queensland in particular, tobacco advertising provides a significant proportion of the income for several businesses involved in billboard and illuminated sign advertising. However, a gradual phase-out of outdoor tobacco advertising in the Bill has been negotiated with the Outdoor Advertising Association of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: .Regulations will establish different deadlines for categories of signs—for example, small signs are to be removed by 1 July 1993—with all signs banned by 31 December 1995.
.Accordingly, the Outdoor Advertising Association has indicated that it does not oppose this Bill.

The time has come in Australia to end tobacco advertising. The passage of this legislation is among the most important health initiatives that can be taken by this Government. By supporting the trend away from smoking, it will make a major contribution to reducing illness and premature mortality amongst Australians.

PARA.TAB: On behalf of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples), I congratulate the Opposition on deciding to support this initiative. The Bill deserves the support of all members of this House. I commend this Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.
Debate (on motion by Mr Anderson) adjourned.
Bill—by leave—presented by Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to make racial vilification unlawful and also to make incitement to racial hatred a criminal offence. At the outset let me make it clear that the legislation is intended to show the Government's present intentions relating to this difficult area. The legislation is being introduced to allow for the widest possible public comment and discussion on the proposals. The Government does not have a finally established position on this Bill and I encourage all interested parties to provide comment on the legislation. To facilitate that comment the Bill will be left to lie in the Parliament over the summer recess. At present our intention would be that passage of the legislation would take place some time early in the next session of this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: This legislation will implement into Australian law the obligations contained in article 4 of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. Article 4(a) requires states which are parties to the Convention to declare an offence punishable by law all dissemination of ideas based on racial superiority or hatred, incitement to racial discrimination, as well as all acts of violence or incitement to such acts against any race or group of persons of another colour or ethnic origin and also the provision of any assistance to racist activities, including the financing thereof.

Australia ratified the Convention on 30 September 1975 and made a reservation on article 4(a). Australia declared that it was the Government's intention, at the first suitable moment, to seek from Parliament legislation specifically implementing the terms of article 4(a). Over 125 states have ratified the Convention. One of the great focuses of human rights initiatives since 1945 has been on efforts to have the right to be free from invidious discrimination on grounds of race, gender or religious belief irreversibly accepted in the world. There have been significant advances in the campaign. The ending of the system of apartheid in South Africa, a political system built on racist theory, has been one of the major and profound steps along the road to the elimination of racism.

The Convention has deeply influenced the domestic laws of most states which are parties to the Convention. It not only outlaws racist speech but also the practice of discrimination, among other things, in employment, housing, the provision of services and other fields. States, by virtue of article 2 of the Convention, are required to adopt a policy of positive action to eliminate racial discrimination, including measures which promote understanding among different racial groups and assist minorities in social, economic, cultural and other fields. The creation of a public opinion against racial discrimination is evidenced in the general acceptance of these norms, which limit the individual's contractual and property rights.

The pervasive recognition that racially motivated violence and racial vilification are on the rise led the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to conduct a national inquiry into racist violence. The inquiry opened in Sydney on 24 August 1989 and, during the next 12 months, held public hearings around Australia. The final report of the inquiry was published in 1991 and tabled in Parliament on 19 December 1991. The report concluded that racist violence, including intimidation and harassment, is an endemic problem for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders in all Australian States. It found that racist attitudes and practices pervade Australian institutions, both private and public. Racist violence also occurs on the basis of ethnic identity.

The report concluded that the existence of a threatening environment is the most prevalent form of racist violence confronting people of non-English speaking backgrounds. They are subjected to racist intimidation and harassment because they are visibly different. In public places, racist violence usually takes the form of unprovoked one-off incidents by strangers; on the other hand, the level of racist violence on the basis of ethnic identity in Australia is nowhere near that in many other countries. Nevertheless, it exists at a level that causes concern and could increase in intensity and extent unless firmly addressed.

The report made 67 recommendations directed to governments, police, public housing authorities, employer and employee organisations, education authorities, schools and higher education institutions and the media. The report recommended that civil remedies under the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 should be extended to cover, for example, racial harassment. It also recommended that the Crimes Act 1914 should be amended to create two new Federal offences of racist violence and intimidation; and an offence of incitement to racist violence and racial hatred. On 19 December 1991, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) tabled the Government's response to the report. The Government supported most of the recommendations in principle. The Australian Law Reform Commission in its report No. 57 on multiculturalism and the law made similar recommendations.

The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody recommended that governments which have not already done so legislate to proscribe racial vilification and provide a conciliation mechanism for dealing with complaints of racial vilification. The penalties for racial vilification should not involve criminal sanctions. In addition to enabling individuals to lodge complaints, the legislation should empower organisations which can demonstrate a special interest in opposing racial vilification to complain on behalf of any individual or group represented by that organisation.

The Australian Law Reform Commission in its report entitled Multiculturalism and the law, by majority, supported making racial vilification unlawful. The majority considered that making it a crime, however, restricts freedom of speech unduly. It was of the view that conciliation, backed up by civil remedies when conciliation fails, is the more appropriate way to deal with it and opposed the creation of a criminal offence.

The Bill amends the Crimes Act 1914 to make it a criminal offence for a person publicly to utter or publish words or engage in conduct which, having regard to all the circumstances, is likely to stir up hatred against a person or group of persons distinguished by race, colour, national or ethnic origin. It also makes it an offence for a person to inspire fear by a group of persons that violence is about to be applied to them. The law is intended to cover racist statements or propaganda of a serious and damaging kind. Examples would include the leaflets placed in letter boxes by extremist organisations nominating certain races as plotting to overthrow the government or public speeches calling for the forcible repatriation of certain ethnic groups or for violence to be perpetrated against certain ethnic groups.

The Bill also amends the Racial Discrimination Act to make it unlawful for a person to publicly utter or publish words or engage in conduct which, having regard to all the circumstances, is likely to stir up hatred, serious contempt or severe ridicule against a person or persons or a group of persons, distinguished by race, colour, national or ethnic origin. There is a provision in the Bill that ensures that certain valid activities are not brought within its scope—that is, the publication or performance of bona fide works of art, genuine academic discussion of any matter of public interest, making or publishing a fair report of any event or matter of public interest.

It may be helpful to give an example of where it is envisaged that the dividing line between lawful and unlawful behaviour might fall. Republication in full of a nineteenth century book on Australia with some racist passages concerning Chinese and Aborigines but with an introduction placing the work in its historical context certainly would not be covered. On the other hand, publication of a pamphlet consisting exclusively of a selection of those same racist passages with an accompanying text advocating that all Chinese persons in Australia should be deported would be covered. By inserting these provisions into the Racial Discrimination Act, it makes it possible to retain the very considerable advantage of adopting existing conciliation procedures and increases the educative role of the law.

Opponents of this legislation will say that the Government is seriously eroding the right to freedom of speech. Far from it. Australian defamation law has always recognised that words can seriously injure individuals and their social and economic well-being. Awareness of the damage which can be caused to individuals and groups through incitement to racial hatred or through racial vilification is only a recent development.

Proponents of the argument that freedom of expression is a value to be maintained at all costs would argue that the ethnic communities should bear the hurt of racial vilification until public education works its way through the ranks of society. However, the role of law as an educational force is often underestimated. The simple fact that an act is known to be unlawful will dissuade most citizens from performing that act unless they have a strong economic or personal interest in so doing. Laws can also change attitudes over time and it is not necessarily the case that an overall attitudinal change has to precede a change in the law.

One important group upon whom the law can be expected to have a very rapid educational effect is persons in official positions whose employment is dependent upon their observance of the law. It should be emphasised that one quarter of all complaints of racist statements which have been lodged with the then Human Rights Commission were statements made by people in official positions. Many of these people will have been unthinking in their statements but understandably members of ethnic groups whom they attack have little expectation of equal treatment when they hear such remarks.

Another argument put forward by proponents of free speech is that the Government is introducing further censorship into Australia. It is worth repeating what the then Attorney-General, Senator Lionel Murphy, said about free speech:

Free speech is only what is left after due weight has been accorded to the laws relating to defamation, blasphemy, copyright, sedition, obscenity, use of insulting words, official secrecy, contempt of court and of parliament, incitement and censorship . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, I could not have put it better myself. In my view, freedom of expression is just one of the values the law protects in a democratic society. In a tolerant society people are entitled to be protected against serious attempts to undermine tolerance by stirring up hatred between groups. Laws prohibiting incitement of racist hatred and hostility protect the inherent dignity of the human person. In a multicultural society, values such as equality of status, tolerance of a wide variety of beliefs, respect for cultural and group identity and equal opportunity for everyone to participate in social processes must be respected and protected.

PARA.TAB: Laws prohibiting incitement to racist hatred and hostility indicate a commitment to tolerance, help prevent the harm caused by the spread of racism and foster harmonious social relations. Australia is a multicultural society. Its survival as a multicultural society demands that the communities that make up the Australian society live in peace and harmony. Inciting hatred and hostility against sections of the community is an affront to the whole community and the whole community has an interest in ensuring that it does not happen.

The Government is of the view that no legislative action should be taken at this stage to make racist violence a Commonwealth crime but that existing State and Territory criminal law be relied upon. However, this matter has been left open and the Government invites further comment on this area as well. The Government is aware that certain sections of the community would like to see legislation on racist violence.

The Government's current Bill does not cover abuse of, or incitement to hatred of, religious groups or individuals that are attacked on the grounds of their membership of such groups. This is essentially because the Bill concerns amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, which is founded on the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. This Convention does not cover religious discrimination.

The Government believes that inciting religious hatred and vilification of religious groups should be unlawful but considers that the Racial Discrimination Act is not the appropriate place for such a provision. Australia fully supported the adoption of the Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination based on Religion or Belief. The Attorney-General will shortly be declaring that declaration to be an international instrument relating to human rights and freedoms for the purpose of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986. The Attorney has already consulted with the State and Territory Attorneys-General as required by that Act.

By declaring the religion declaration under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act, Australia will demonstrate that it is firmly committed to its principles. The move is also consistent with the Government's response to the report of the National Inquiry into Racist Violence, which supported, subject to the consideration of constitutional issues, the amendment of the Racial Discrimination Act to provide that discrimination against or harassment of a person on account of that person's religious belief be prohibited where the religious belief is commonly associated with persons of a particular race or ethnic group. The effect of declaring an instrument under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act is to extend the promotion, research, inquiry and reporting functions of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to the rights recognised in the instrument and to provide a mechanism for complaints to be lodged by persons claiming to have been discriminated against on the basis of their religious beliefs.

The Government is of the view that, as the Bill covers vilification on the ground of race, colour, national or ethnic origin, it covers everybody. These four characteristics are broad enough to cover characteristics imputed to a person even if those characteristics are untrue. For instance, if an Anglo-Saxon woman who has converted to Islam is more than likely attacked wearing the hijab or Muslim women's headscarf, she is attacked not because the attacker believes she is a Muslim but because the attacker thinks that she is an Arab woman. This legislation would pick such instances up.

For legislation prohibiting racial vilification to be of any long term benefit, it will be necessary for there to be an extensive public awareness and education campaign. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will be funded to conduct such a campaign.

In conclusion, let me again emphasise that the Government has introduced this legislation to encourage public discussion and debate on an issue which is relevant to us all. There needs to be balance struck between competing values that are central to our way of life. Where that balance is finally struck will depend very largely on the feedback the Government receives to this proposed legislation. I table the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.I commend the Bill to the House.

Bill—by leave—presented by Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Cabinet Notebooks (Access and Protection) Bill 1992 amends a number of Acts regulating access to Commonwealth documents and their use in court proceedings. The Acts to be amended are the Archives Act 1983, the Evidence Act 1905 and the Freedom of Information Act 1982. The Bill will, for the first time, provide access under the Archives Act to documents recording the content of Cabinet discussions and clarify the status of these documents in court proceedings. Cabinet notebooks will be excluded from the operation of the freedom of information legislation.

PARA.TAB: Before dealing with the current state of the law in relation to Cabinet notebooks, it may be helpful if I explain how the Cabinet note taking system works and the principles underlying the operation of the Cabinet system. Since 1951, a system has been in place to facilitate the formal recording of the outcome of Cabinet deliberations. It has developed at the behest of successive Prime Ministers solely to assist the Cabinet process by providing an effective link between the Government's private deliberations and the Public Service, which must give effect to the Government's decisions. The system allows Cabinet minutes—the formal record of Cabinet decisions—to be circulated to Ministers and departments as soon as possible for appropriate action.

The practice is to have three note takers at Cabinet meetings who are officers of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, one of whom is the Secretary to the Cabinet. At least one of the note takers attempts to take as full a record as possible of discussions. The form of the notes is entirely within the discretion of each note taker. Entries in the notebooks, while not a complete verbatim account of proceedings in Cabinet, do record the gist of the contributions of individual Ministers. Such notes are, however, simply memory joggers to aid the drafting of the Cabinet minute. Cabinet minutes, on the other hand, are a record of the collective decision of Ministers on particular items and do not record the contributions of individual Ministers to discussion on those items.In other words, the notes are not and do not purport to be a definitive record of proceedings, but merely a means to the end of preparing a definitive minute recording the collective decision.

Notebooks are issued to note takers for their exclusive use and only the individual note taker, the Secretary to Cabinet or the officer in charge of the Cabinet Office has access to a notebook. On only one occasion has it been known for the contents of a notebook to have been shown to a person outside the Cabinet system, and this was with the express agreement of the Prime Minister in the context of the Hope Royal Commission of 1983, which examined issues concerning the actions of a Cabinet Minister. I might emphasise that neither Ministers nor the Prime Minister have direct access to Cabinet notebooks, although note takers have, at the request of the Minister concerned, referred to their notebooks for the purpose of assisting Ministers to recall their individual contributions to earlier discussions. I have detailed these arrangements to demonstrate the unique place of these notebooks in the Cabinet system and the importance of the note taking system to the efficient working of the process.

The Cabinet system, as all members of the Parliament would be aware, was inherited from Westminster, and its successful operation depends upon the existence of certain conventions. One such convention is that of collective responsibility and solidarity with the concomitant obligations of confidentiality. The current Cabinet Handbook, which has evolved under successive governments, puts it this way:

SPEECH.PARA: Collective responsibility is supported by the strict confidentiality attaching to Cabinet documents and to discussions in the Cabinet room. Ministry, Cabinet and Cabinet committees are forums in which Ministers, while working towards a collective position, are able to discuss proposals and a variety of options and views with complete freedom.

The requirement that Cabinet proceedings be kept confidential is based on the vital practical consideration that the necessary frankness of discussion should not be inhibited. Whatever range of private views Ministers may put in Cabinet discussions, it is necessary that there be finality of decision making and that decisions, once arrived at and announced, are clear and unequivocal and supported by all Ministers. The frankness and freedom of expression in Cabinet proceedings would be seriously damaged if Cabinet confidentiality were not properly protected.

PARA.TAB: The issue of access by the courts to Cabinet notebooks has been considered by the Federal Court and the Full Court of the Federal Court in the Northern Land Council v. Commonwealth of Australia and Energy Resources of Australia—the NLC case. The issue has been argued before the High Court and the parties are awaiting the Court's decision. Both the Federal Court and the Full Court of the Federal Court rejected the Commonwealth's argument that the public interest in maintaining the confidentiality of Cabinet proceedings is such that Cabinet notebooks should be immune from production in court proceedings.

Subject to the views of the High Court—and it is not intended that this legislation apply to NLC notebooks should the High Court rule against the Commonwealth's public interest immunity argument—the present state of the common law would seem to be that, where the Commonwealth claims public interest immunity in response to an order to produce Cabinet notebooks, the question of whether they should be made available to courts for the purposes of litigation is ultimately one for the Court to determine, based on the Court's view about where the balance of the public interest lies in the particular case. The Government does not query the appropriateness of the common law position on public interest immunity so far as it relates to Cabinet material which does not disclose Cabinet debate, such as Cabinet minutes, memoranda and submissions. However, there are strong reasons of public policy in support of a different treatment for material which goes beyond recording outcomes and discloses the contributions of individual Ministers.

The Government's concern is that the common law cannot provide what the Government believes is the degree of confidentiality essential if the present Cabinet system is to continue. The release of notebooks would destroy the expectation on the part of Ministers that the expression of their views would remain confidential. More importantly, the freedom that Ministers feel to debate matters in complete privacy in the future would be seriously eroded, which could only harm the efficacy of the decision-making process.

On the other hand, the Government believes that the alternative of doing away with the current note taking system would be detrimental to the efficient operation of the Cabinet system. Indeed, it may not be a practical alternative at all, especially in an era of a large volume of Cabinet business on issues often of great complexity. The complete exclusion of officials as observers or a ban on their keeping any notes would be required, thus removing the very basis for accurate preparation of Cabinet decisions following discussions. Moreover, doing away with the system could not protect the notebooks already in existence. The Government is not prepared to destroy those records, which in due course would be of great interest to historians.

The Government has therefore decided to amend the Evidence Act 1905 to protect the confidentiality of Cabinet discussions by prohibiting the disclosure to courts of the notebooks and any other notes taken by officials present in the Cabinet room during Cabinet discussions and of oral evidence of officials about those discussions. I should emphasise that the common law of public interest immunity as it applies to the admission of Cabinet material other than these notes, such as minutes—that is, final decisions—and submissions, will not be affected by the proposed amendments. Use of this material in legal proceedings will remain a matter for the courts to determine, taking into account the sensitivities of the particular material and its relevance to the proceedings.

Further, the present law so far as it relates to evidence given by Ministers about Cabinet discussions will not be affected. Subject to the right of the Commonwealth to make a claim of public interest immunity in relation to particular evidence to be given by Ministers, they will not be prevented from giving evidence based on their recollections of discussions. It will remain a matter for the courts to determine whether the public interest in the administration of justice requires that the evidence be given by a Minister in a particular case. The alternative option of providing a statutory discretion to allow or prohibit Ministers giving evidence was considered, but the Government concluded that this would place governments in an invidious position of appearing to make political decisions in individual cases about whether or not particular evidence could be given.

Finally, I reiterate that the proposed provisions will not cover the notebooks, the subject of court action in the NLC case. Whatever the decision of the High Court and any subsequent consideration by the Federal Court on the issue, the Government will abide by the Court's decision. The Government believes that there are important reasons to protect the notebooks for as long as their use in court could have a detrimental effect on the Cabinet system. However, the Government has accepted that there comes a time when notebooks could only be of historical interest, and for this reason has decided to remove the provision of the Archives Act which excludes Cabinet notebooks from the operation of that Act. The Government has made the judgment that the period of 50 years will be sufficient to ensure that any sensitivities arising from the nature of the notebooks will have receded.

Given the nature of notebooks themselves as but individual and often incomplete interpretations of Cabinet discussions, they are an imperfect record and their use by historians in the future would no doubt reflect that fact. Even so, they may well provide insights into government decision making and be, to historians, a useful adjunct to Cabinet decisions which are now released after 30 years. The Government has decided that the informal records of the meeting of the War Cabinet during the World War II period will be released as soon as possible. These notebooks may well provide historians with a fascinating insight into government decision making during that period and convey a unique sense of the urgency of the crisis facing Australia at the time.

This Bill is intended to remove the uncertainty surrounding the status of Cabinet notebooks and the Cabinet note taking system. The Government believes that the proposed amendments reflect a realistic consideration of the public interest in the administration of justice and the rights of individuals and the public interest in ensuring that the operation of the Cabinet system is not impeded, together with—for the first time—a clear and sensible archival mechanism for handling these documents. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

Bill—by leave—presented by Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Copyright Amendment Bill 1992 is to make changes to the Copyright Act 1968 in three important areas and to correct a technical problem which has arisen from the operation of previous amendments to the Act. Because of the intense interest in the changes to copyright in sound recordings that were decided on by the Government and which are implemented by this Bill, I propose that the Bill lie on the table for three months to allow sufficient time for comments to be made and considered by the Government.

PARA.TAB: The first important change arises from the Government's response to the Prices Surveillance Authority's 1990 report on the prices of sound recordings. The most significant of the reforms the Government has decided to make following its consideration of the report is to permit the unrestricted commercial importation of non-pirate copies of foreign records appearing in the market after 1 July 1994. Other important reforms are designed to address the concern of sound recording copyright owners that the unrestricted importation of records may result in an influx of pirate records into Australia and affect their income from the sale of legitimate records.

Secondly, this Bill will introduce changes to prevent copyright in product packaging and labelling being used by distributors to create exclusive markets in relation to products. Such use of copyright in a label or package is an incidental and unintended use of copyright laws and has the potential effect of denying consumers access to goods at lower prices.

The final major change to be made by this Bill will be to remove the automatic right of a copyright owner, once a court has found in an action for infringement of copyright that an infringement has occurred, to damages amounting to the full value of the articles when sold by the defendant, even when the infringement relates to only part of the article. This remedy is known as conversion damages. I will now address each of these reforms in detail.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government's Response to the PSA Report on Record Prices

PARA.TAB: Under the Copyright Act, the owners of the copyright in a sound recording and any musical works performed in the recording can prevent the importation into Australia for commercial purposes of copies of that sound recording without their permission. The copyright owners can also prevent the sale of, and other commercial dealings with, copies so imported. For a number of years, there have been complaints from record sellers and consumer groups, among others, that this control by copyright owners has restricted record availability and inflated prices.

In 1983 this issue was referred by the Government to the Copyright Law Review Committee for examination. The CLRC reported in September 1988 and recommended that the importation provisions of the Copyright Act be relaxed so as to improve availability of foreign sound recordings. However, in making its recommendations, the CLRC made the comment that, in effect, there was insufficient evidence before it to determine the question of the effect of the present legislation on the prices of sound recordings in Australia. Subsequently, the question of record prices was referred to the PSA for consideration. As honourable members will be aware, amendments to the Copyright Act are now in place relaxing the importation provisions as they apply to books. In relation to records, the PSA reported its findings to the Minister for Consumer Affairs in December 1990.

The PSA found that the prices of sound recordings—that is, cassettes, CDs and LPs—were higher in Australia than in North America, Western Europe and even New Zealand. In the PSA's view, three factors underpinned these higher prices. Firstly, the demand for records was relatively inelastic compared with that for other products. Secondly, domestic price competition appeared to be absent. Thirdly, the importation provisions of the Copyright Act tended to restrict import competition.

Accordingly, the PSA recommended that the importation provisions of the Act be repealed in relation to parallel imports of records—that is, records made with the licence of the copyright owner—from countries providing levels of protection for musical works and sound recordings comparable to those in Australia. However, the PSA recognised that the Australian music industry operates on an established contractual framework which reflects the rights which copyright owners presently enjoy under the Act. Therefore, it also recommended that implementation of its recommendations be delayed for 12 months to allow the industry to readjust to the proposed new legal regime.

As announced earlier this year, the Government has decided to make a number of changes to the Copyright Act following the PSA's report. From 1 July 1994, the Australian market will be opened up to parallel imports from the United States, certain member countries of the EC, notably the UK, and New Zealand. These countries, which were identified as having lower record prices than Australia, presently provide adequate protection against record piracy. They will be included in a schedule to the Copyright Act, to which further countries may be added as appropriate. While these countries are few in number, they include the main sources of imported records.

Following the release of the PSA's report, extensive consultations were held by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) with all sectors of the music industry. It became apparent from submissions made on the PSA's report by music interests that adoption of its recommendations in full could have some adverse consequences for Australian performers whose works are marketed internationally. They expressed concern at the possibility of unfair competition for sales of their records from imported records which have been deleted from the catalogue of the overseas manufacturer of those imports and could be sold here at lower prices. In the US, for example, no copyright royalties are payable on deletions, nor are any contractual royalties payable to the recording artist. Although this is generally recognised to be a problem likely to affect only a very small percentage of the market, the potential damage to sales in individual cases may be significant.

Australian performers were concerned that overseas deletions of their locally released recordings would be imported and sold in Australia, thereby depriving them of the capacity to fully recoup the investment made to put their records on the Australian market. Accordingly, the Government has decided to take these concerns into account under the proposed reforms. Both the owner of copyright in the underlying musical work and the owner of copyright in the sound recording are to retain the right to control the importation of records where the recording is of a performer who is an Australian citizen or resident. In the case of recording by a group of performers, that control will apply if the majority of the featured artists are Australian citizens or residents.

This mechanism is consistent with Australia's obligations under the Berne Copyright Convention and the Rome Neighbouring Rights Convention because it does not discriminate on the basis of nationality amongst either musical composers or record producers as such. The right to control importation of recordings of Australian performers is to apply regardless of whether they were made in Australia or elsewhere. Thus, importers will only be able to freely import recordings of foreign performers from the countries included in the proposed schedule to the Copyright Act.
Aside from these far-reaching proposals, this Bill will also introduce other reforms which will have a significant impact on, and provide benefits for, both the music industry and consumers:

SPEECH.PARA: .The amendments will provide a better legal framework within which individual customer orders for records may be met quickly.
.The changes will ensure that, as from 1 July 1994, back catalogue imported sound recordings are available to consumers within a reasonable time.

.Copyright owner initiated customs seizure of infringing copyright articles under section 135 of the Act will be extended to include infringing copies of sound recordings. This will enhance the ability of copyright owners to control the importation of pirate products.
.For the benefit of copyright owners, the penalties for sound recording piracy offences will be brought into line with those applying to film piracy.

.The burden of proof in civil sound recording piracy proceedings, in relation to the subsistence and ownership of copyright, will be shifted from the plaintiff to the defendant where the plaintiff's claim of subsistence and ownership is established with appropriate evidentiary formality. This will facilitate infringement actions taken by copyright owners.

.Moreover, the knowledge requirement in civil actions under sections 37 and 102 of the Act for copyright infringement by importation of pirate articles will be removed, thus bringing such proceedings into line with those for locally made pirate articles.

The Government believes that the changes being introduced by this Bill to the sound recording importation provisions of the Copyright Act provide a sensible, fair and workable balance of competing interests. They will have the effect of providing greater protection for copyright owners in a number of important areas while, at the same time, ensuring greater accessibility to and price competitiveness of imported records for the benefit of Australian consumers.

PARA.TAB: Importation into, and distribution in, Australia of a variety of goods has been effectively controlled and exclusively licensed by manufacturers by relying on ownership of the copyright in the labelling or packaging of the goods. As with sound recordings, owners of copyright in works reproduced in product labelling and packaging can prevent importation of those materials without their permission. This has prevented importers from gaining and passing on to consumers the benefit of cheaper prices for the goods from alternative overseas suppliers.

For example, in the 1986 case of Bailey v. Boccacio, the defendant imported for sale in Australia bottles of Bailey's Irish cream otherwise than through the Australian distributor appointed by the manufacturer of the product and, as a result, at a lower cost. At the suit of the manufacturer, the New South Wales Supreme Court held that the importation infringed the copyright held by the manufacturer in the picture on the bottle label.

The CLRC in its 1988 report on the importation provisions of the Act criticised this use of copyright where the package or label in which the copyright subsisted was only an incidental part of the goods. The CLRC recommended changes to the law to restrict such control by a copyright owner to articles which are truly copyright articles, for example, books and films. Subsequently, complaints were made that copyright in instruction manuals and warrants accompanying goods has also been used to prevent parallel importation of goods in the same way as copyright in packaging and labelling.

The CLRC observed that the design of packages and labels to make them subject to copyright is a common practice in many industries such as those relating to liquor, tobacco, perfumes and cosmetic products. It was strongly of the opinion that distributors of imported goods should not be able to control the market in Australia by the simple expedient of enclosing them in a copyright label or package. Usually, buyers of such goods are primarily interested in the goods themselves, and the packaging or labelling is of no interest or only of incidental interest. The Government believes that the use of a copyright owner's exclusive importation rights over packaging or labelling to protect exclusive distribution arrangements for goods is an unintended use of copyright and is anti-competitive.

A change to the law to end this copyright control has attracted some criticism from those industries which rely on it to control the marketing of their goods in Australia. However, the Government regards it as indefensible to use copyright in this incidental way to deny consumers the possibility of lower prices and better access to goods. The amendments being introduced by the Bill in this area will remove the right to control the importation of products through the exercise of copyright in packaging or labelling associated with the products, where use of the copyright with the products was agreed to by the copyright owner.

The recently passed Copyright Amendment Act 1991 has allowed books to be parallel imported, without the copyright owner's licence, in certain circumstances. Occasionally, some books, such as a set of volumes by the same author, are sold in a container. To prevent any copyright in the container being used to frustrate the reforms made by the Act, the changes which the Government proposes by the present Bill will extend to containers in which copyright goods are sold and which are merely incidental to those goods.

Copyright instruction manuals, warranties, audio cassettes or videos that accompany goods are normally only incidental to goods to which they relate. Copyright in such explanatory or warranty material should similarly not be able to be used to control the importation of those goods and the current Bill will also end such control. The changes that are being introduced will not, however, extend to instruction manuals that accompany computer software. Those manuals were excluded from the reforms in the Copyright Amendment Act 1991 because all aspects of intellectual property protection of computer software are currently being examined by the CLRC, which is expected to issue a draft report soon. It would be inappropriate to change existing copyright rules in relation to software manuals pending the CLRC's report.

Also, the changes being introduced will not extend to copyright in, for example, pictures or patterns that are a permanent part of the goods themselves, for instance, cooking pots. In that case, the picture or design may be a reason for its selection by the purchaser, and thus may not be incidental like packaging or labelling. I must emphasise too that the reforms in this area will not affect a manufacturer's rights to control the distribution of goods through other avenues such as causes of action for passing off, breaches of the Trade Practices Act 1974 and trademark infringements under the Trade Marks Act 1955. These remedies are based on different policy considerations to copyright and will not be altered by the present Bill.

Moreover, the Government recognises that the reforms in this area, if introduced to apply immediately, may affect a manufacturer's or distributor's existing licensing arrangements in relation to products. With this in mind, the changes to product packaging and labelling will not commence until 1 July 1993. This will afford an opportunity for commercial adjustments to be made to take account of the new regime.

The Copyright Act presently provides that, where deliberate copyright infringement is established, the copyright owner has an automatic right to conversion damages, that is, damages amounting to the value of the infringing articles at the time of their disposal by the defendant. The remedy also extends to the delivery up of any infringing articles still held by the defendant. Both those remedies apply even if the infringement relates to only part of the article.

These two remedies were the subject of the CLRC's 1990 report on conversion damages which recommended changes to the Act to make the remedies available only at the discretion of the court, so as to avoid possible abuse by copyright owners and unfairness to defendants.

The main concern with regard to the remedy of conversion damages is the harshness with which it can operate. An extreme example is the 1981 case of W.H. Brine & Co. v. Whitton where the defendant was ordered to pay damages amounting to the whole value of imported soccer balls even though the copyright infringement related only to an emblem printed on the surface of the balls. Also, a plaintiff's alternative right to take possession of any infringing copies in the defendant's possession can provide a windfall gain.

The CLRC considered the position in other countries with similar legal systems to Australia's. The United Kingdom has abolished the remedy of conversion damages, although copyright owners may still be entitled to delivery up of any infringing copies in the defendant's possession in certain circumstances. Conversion damages and actions for detention are not available in the United States. Both countries are major exporters of copyright articles to Australia.

There are some cases where the award of conversion damages and the delivery up of infringing goods are merited, bearing in mind that conversion damages are available only in cases of knowing infringement. For instance, in the case of pirate copies of sound recordings and films, the plaintiff should be able to recover the value of the copies disposed of or, if the defendant still has them, to obtain their delivery up together with the copying equipment used to make them. However, these remedies should be available only at the court's discretion, exercisable according to appropriate criteria which the present Bill sets out.

The changes being introduced by the Bill may be opposed by some film and video interests who see the automatic right to conversion damages as having an important deterrent effect against piracy. However, the Government believes the amendments will provide for the fairer administration of justice, without depriving the courts of strong remedies for infringement of copyright where they are warranted, including relief in the form of damages which the courts may grant under the Act.

As I mentioned earlier, the Government will leave the Bill on the table for three months to allow adequate opportunity for consideration, the making of any comments to the Government and consideration of those comments by the Government.

The amendments effected by this Bill have no direct impact on Commonwealth expenditure. However, the Bill is likely to lead to a reduction in prices of some copyright materials supplied to Australian consumers. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Anderson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ARTS, SPORT, ENVIRONMENT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill—by leave—presented by Ms McHugh, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALKER.NAME: Ms McHUGH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of the Arts, Sport, Environment and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 is to make various minor improvements to the ACT self-government legislation, which are the result of a review of the legislation conducted by the ACT administration and the Department in 1992, three years after self-government. Possible more important changes are being examined and would be included in a separate Bill at a later date.

PARA.TAB: The Bill removes from the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 limitations on the powers of the Legislative Assembly and the Executive of the Territory that are no longer considered appropriate. For example, the Assembly will be given power to decide the number of its members; how frequently it will meet; how laws passed by it will be notified to the public; and the level of remuneration of its members and the Ministers and senior officers of the ACT Government. This brings the ACT's degree of self-government closer to that of the Northern Territory. The Bill also:

SPEECH.PARA: .Amends the ACT self-government legislation to ensure that, during the transitional period before the ACT establishes its own public service, the Commonwealth's Comcare system applies to the ACT Fire Brigade and to Legislative Assembly members' staff, as well as other ACT Government employees;
.Changes the name of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to `Australian Nature Conservation Agency', to reflect more accurately the agency's present functions;

.Ensures that an `eligible Judge', when exercising the power to issue search warrants under the enforcement provisions of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983, has the same immunity from legal action as a Justice of the High Court has in proceedings in that court; and
.Makes various minor corrections and drafting improvements in other legislation administered by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories.

PARA.TAB: I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGES (AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill—by leave—presented by Mr Robert Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ROBERT BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Road Transport Charges (Australian Capital Territory) Bill 1992 is to give effect to the National Road Transport Commission's first determination regarding annual registration charges for vehicles rated above 4.5 tonnes and permit charges for vehicles operating above 125 tonnes. The Bill is vital to the Government's national micro-economic reform agenda for land transport.

PARA.TAB: For too long the efficiency of Australia's interstate road transport operations has been impeded by a lack of uniformity in regulations and charging. Currently heavy vehicle operating conditions and registration charges vary considerably between nine different jurisdictions and bear little relation to the costs imposed on the road system by various types of vehicles.

The NRTC, which is an independent statutory authority, was established as a result of the heads of government agreement of July 1991 and set up under Commonwealth legislation passed in December 1991. Its purpose is to investigate and make recommendations regarding the establishment of a national registration scheme and uniform road use charges for heavy vehicles, and nationally consistent operating regulations for all vehicles.

The intergovernmental agreement, which forms a schedule to the National Road Transport Commission Act 1991, requires the NRTC to recommend charges for heavy vehicles which: achieve full cost recovery; achieve a reasonable balance between administrative simplicity, efficiency and equity; improve the link between pricing and investment decisions; and minimise the incentive for road transport operators to shop around for lower charges.

The ministerial council approved the NRTC charging determination on behalf of State and Territory governments. It is envisaged that each of the States and the Northern Territory will pass legislation in their respective parliaments which will adopt the legislation passed in respect of the Australian Capital Territory and any regulations made under it. This will ensure that there is uniform charging for heavy vehicles throughout Australia.

In accordance with the intergovernmental agreement, this Bill will require the Government of the Australian Capital Territory, from 1 July 1995 onwards, to fix annual registration charges for vehicles rated above 4.5 tonnes and to fix charges for the granting of permits to operate vehicles with a gross mass exceeding 125 tonnes. Those charges will be fixed in accordance with the schedule to the Bill. The Bill will not affect the existing registration scheme in the Australian Capital Territory other than to fix the charges to be collected when a heavy vehicle is registered. Responsibility for determining registration exemptions or concessional charges will continue to be a matter for the Australian Capital Territory. Revenue from the registration charges will be retained by the Territory.

The charges provided for in the schedule to the Bill may be increased or decreased by regulations under the proposed Act. The amount of increase or decrease is limited to a maximum of 5 per cent per annum. Heads of government have agreed that the matter of concessional registration charges for particular groups is for each State and Territory to address according to their own priorities, with the cost to revenue being met from their own budgets. In accordance with this decision, the NRTC charging determination does not make recommendations on the level and structure of concessions.

During the process of implementing national charges, the States and Territories will be reviewing the structure of registration concessions in their individual jurisdictions, including those which apply to the rural sector. The charges provided for in this Bill do not include, and the schedule does not preclude, the fixing of fees for administration and other services provided by the Australian Capital Territory.

In this context, it would be contrary to the spirit of the intergovernmental agreement for governments to impose administration or inspection fees that varied greatly across jurisdictions, as road transport operators would see these as part of the total cost of registering a vehicle. This would encourage operators to shop around between the States and Territories. A working group of officials is examining the issue of acceptable and uniform levels of administrative charges and inspection fees and is expected to complete its report by April 1993.

As in the Australian Capital Territory, revenues from national registration charges received by the States and Northern Territory will be retained by them and will be available for use on roads. The use of those funds, including distribution to local councils, and the determination of road funding needs, will be decided by each jurisdiction.

The passage of this Bill is testimony to the continuing commitment of the Federal Government to implementing the reforms in the road transport industry which have been needed for so long, and which were agreed to by heads of government. I expect that heads of government will honour their commitment made in the intergovernmental agreement and all administrations will implement the reforms by July 1995.

Road transport is an essential part of our land transport system, and approximately 70 per cent of freight which is moved in Australia travels by road at some stage. Australia cannot afford to squander opportunities to bring about workable and acceptable reforms in the road transport industry, and assist in enhancing Australia's international competitiveness. There will be no significant costs, revenues or savings to the Commonwealth arising from the Bill.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill 1992 forms part of a package of seven cognate Bills which are being introduced today. Taken together, these Bills will substantially increase the level of prudential protection provided to the superannuation industry, and represent a substantial strengthening of the security of superannuation savings and of the protection of the rights of superannuation fund members.

PARA.TAB: The Bills give effect to the most important of the new prudential arrangements for superannuation that were announced on behalf of the Government on 21 October 1992 in the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) Strengthening super security. The remaining measures will be introduced by way of amendments to these Bills before they are brought on for debate in the 1993 autumn sittings.

The Government is introducing this legislation in order to give added protection to superannuation savings and to promote a more efficient superannuation industry, while avoiding the imposition of unreasonable supervisory and compliance costs. The long term benefits of these carefully balanced measures will significantly outweigh the costs of their implementation.
The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill 1992 provides:

SPEECH.PARA: for effective supervisory arrangements involving direct enforcement powers for the Insurance and Superannuation Commission enabling effective enforcement of the prudential requirements and obligations placed on funds and trustees;

for trustees and investment managers to be made subject to adequate legislative sanctions for the proper performance of their fiduciary responsibilities and increasing their accountability to their members;
clear delineation of the basic duties and responsibilities of trustees, and indicating that trustees have primary responsibility for the operation of funds;
that trustees and investment managers must be suitable to act as fund trustees and to manage fund moneys respectively;
for financial assistance to be provided to funds that have suffered a loss owing to fraudulent conduct or theft; and
mechanisms for dealing with benefits in employer-sponsored funds in respect of members that have left employment or who are lost, and of unclaimed benefits.

PARA.TAB: The measures provided for in this Bill complement other measures being introduced today in the companion Occupational Superannuation Standards Amendment Bill 1992, Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1992, Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Bill 1992, Superannuation (Rolled Over Benefits) Levy Bill 1992, Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1992 and Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Consequential Amendments Bill 1992 to strengthen substantially the framework of prudential supervision of the industry. In developing this Bill, the provisions of the current Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 relating to prudential compliance standards have been taken up in order to consolidate superannuation industry prudential supervision arrangements. These provisions of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act will be repealed.

The measures contained in this Bill to provide added protection to superannuation savings and to promote a more efficient superannuation industry, together with the arrangements contained in the companion Bills, will result in additional supervisory costs being incurred by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The additional resources needed to give effect to this package of measures have been estimated at $4.155m in 1992-93, $4.831m in 1993-94, $4.591m in 1994-95 and $4.631m in 1995-96.

These additional costs will be recovered through the superannuation supervisory levy and the imposition of a new levy on certain superannuation funds and approved deposit funds as provided in the Superannuation (Rolled Over Benefits) Levy Bill 1992. I commend the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill 1992 to the House and present the related explanatory memorandum.

The Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1992 provides a mechanism through which members of superannuation funds can enforce their rights by way of statutory disputes resolution arrangements. There will be a statutorily appointed tribunal which will make determinations in respect of complaints. The full tribunal will consist of up to nine people; the chairperson will be a full time statutory officer, with the remaining tribunal members serving on a part time basis. The Treasurer will appoint the tribunal members on the basis of their knowledge and experience; two members of the full Tribunal will be appointed after consultation with the Minister for Consumer Affairs. In respect of each complaint, the chairperson will choose two other tribunal members to sit with the chairperson and determine the complaint. These arrangements will provide for continuity of decisions, while achieving a degree of balance, and will apply to all types of superannuation products, including those offered by life offices.
