SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It includes an amendment to the existing law to provide specifically for the assessability and deductibility of payments made in respect of accrued leave entitlements by one employer to another at the time an employee transfers to a new employer. This measure will operate where payments made are to facilitate the transfer of the employee pursuant to, or to accommodate the implementation of, an industrial award. Such payments will be called accrued leave transfer payments.

PARA.TAB: The Bill proposes a number of amendments to the provisions relating to the taxation of capital gains and losses. The Bill also contains measures to synchronise the capital gains tax and plant depreciation treatment of terminations of Crown leases. These measures were foreshadowed in the explanatory memorandum to the depreciation Crown lease amendments contained in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992.

Several technical amendments are to be made to various capital allowance provisions and to anti-avoidance rules relating to those provisions. The Bill will make two changes to depreciation cost price limit rules for luxury motor cars. One will exclude certain motor cars from the limit. The other will remove an anomaly under which some taxpayers gain earlier access to an indexed limit than others.

Other amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act proposed by the Bill relate to dividend streaming arrangements, PAYE, and the gift provisions. The Bill also includes minor amendments to fringe benefits tax provisions and the Taxation Administration Act. I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Assessability and deductibility of accrued leave transfer payments

PARA.TAB: In general, employees accrue leave entitlements based only on the period of employment with their current employer. However, in some industries, such as the waterfront industry, employees are likely to change employers so often that they could never take leave, but rather would be paid out the value of leave entitlements each time they transfer to a different employer.

In those industries, leave entitlements under the terms of an industrial agreement or award may be based on total service with a number of employers. Accordingly, employers may be required, or may as a matter of commercial reality decide, to pay one another on account of a transferring employee's accrued leave entitlements.

Under the existing law, an employer is not entitled to a deduction for a payment made in respect of leave entitlements that have accrued to an employee during the course of his or her employment with that employer unless it is made directly to the employee or, if the employee is dead, to a dependant or personal representative of the employee. Consequently, if a payment in respect of an employee's accrued leave entitlements is made by one employer to another upon the transfer of the employee, no tax deduction is available to the employer who makes the payment.

This amendment will allow the employer who makes the payment to claim a deduction for the amount of that payment. The amendment also will ensure that the amount of the payment will be assessable income of the employer who receives the payment.

The amendment is intended to facilitate structural reforms such as flexible employment practices, specifically where there are industry practices for the transfer of employment pursuant to, or to accommodate the implementation of, an industrial award. The amendment is not likely to have any effect on the revenue.

The Bill proposes a general anti-avoidance provision relating to the transfer of assets within company groups to which a CGT roll-over applies. The current CGT group roll-over anti-avoidance provisions will be repealed as a consequence.

The new anti-avoidance provision will deem the disposal and re-acquisition of an asset which has been rolled over within a company group if the company holding the asset ceases to remain part of the group in respect of which the roll-over was available. This will occur where, for example, the company is sold outside the group. Consequential amendments will be made to the record keeping requirements.

The Bill also proposes an amendment which will ensure that the capital gains provisions do not apply inappropriately to tax an amount, or part of an amount, which is concessionally taxed under another provision of the Act. This amendment will apply where the effect of that other provision is that all or part of the amount is not included in a person's assessable income.

A further amendment will ensure that a taxpayer holding a statutory licence which is cancelled by the issuing authority for no consideration will not be deemed to have received the amount that would have been the market value of the licence prior to its cancellation. Technical amendments are also proposed to the provisions relating to the principal residence exemption and the transfer of capital losses. The amendments to the CGT provisions are not expected to have any significant impact on revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Capital Gains Tax—Depreciable Property Installed On Crown Leases

PARA.TAB: Further amendments to the capital gains tax provisions are to be made so that disposals of interests in plant installed on crown leases of land are treated consistently with their treatment under the depreciation crown lease provisions. This amendment will prevent capital gains or losses from accruing in respect of plant installed on a crown lease where a lease is terminated but the lessee retains an interest in the plant. It will also prevent capital losses from accruing in respect of plant installed on a crown lease where the lease is terminated and an associate of the lessee obtains an interest in the plant.
These changes will apply to relevant disposals occurring after 26 February 1992. The purpose of the amendments is to prevent anomalous results and there is no direct impact on the revenue.

Five technical amendments are to be made in relation to provisions dealing with deductions for the capital cost of income-producing property. The first amendment relates to the broad banding of depreciation rates for plant acquired before 27 February 1992. The amendment will make it clear that rates of depreciation determined on effective life that match a broad banded rate cannot be increased to the next highest broad banded rate. The amendment will apply from the same time as the broad banding measures; that is, in relation to the 1991-92 and subsequent years of income. The second will amend the plant depreciation crown lease provisions in relation to disposals of pre-27 February 1992 plant, for which deductions have been allowed under the prime cost method, to prevent balancing loss deductions for that portion of the cost of plant notionally depreciated before 27 February 1992. It will also ensure that tax is imposed on the recoupment of previously allowed deductions. The amendment will apply to disposals occurring after 26 February 1992, the date from which the crown lease provisions applied.

A third amendment will replace an existing option taxpayers have to adopt annually a lesser rate of depreciation for an asset with a once-only option to adopt a lesser rate of depreciation that is not less than that based on effective life. This new option rule will apply in relation to current and subsequent years of income. Next, to correct an oversight, the petroleum mining roll-over relief provisions are to be amended so that they apply, as appropriate, to pre-18 September 1974 expenditure.

The final amendment in this series relates to anti-avoidance rules applicable to arrangements involving the use of property by tax-exempt bodies and the like. The amendment will make it certain that those rules can apply to arrangements where a person is entitled to deductions under a capital allowance provision in relation to property which he does not own. The amendment will apply to relevant arrangements entered into after today. These technical amendments are unlikely to have a significant effect on the revenue.

Two changes are to be made to depreciation cost price limit rules for motor cars. One will exempt motor cars specially fitted out for the carriage of disabled persons seated in wheelchairs from the limit. The cost of this concession is estimated to peak in seven years at about $1m per annum.

The other change is to remove a distortion arising from the annual indexation of the limit. At present, the limit is indexed in relation to each year of income. Taxpayers whose year of income commences earlier than others can obtain an advantage from earlier access to a new limit. This second change is expected to be revenue neutral. Both measures apply to motor cars acquired after today.

I announce today amendments to the dividend streaming provisions of the income tax law which will ensure their consistent application. The amendments contained in the Bill will ensure that dividend streaming arrangements using an interposed entity between shareholders and companies carrying out the arrangement are subject to the provisions.

Arrangements using an interposed entity are otherwise the same as arrangements already subject to the provisions in that they seek to stream franked dividends to those shareholders able to benefit most from the imputation credits attached to those dividends. The amendment will apply to dividends paid under these arrangements on or after the date of royal assent of the Bill and will prevent the loss of unquantifiable amounts of revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Pay as you earn or the PAYE provisions

PARA.TAB: The Bill will also amend the PAYE provisions in the income tax law. First, the definition of salary or wages will be expanded to include training allowances paid to participants in the land care and environment action program and remuneration and allowances paid to members of an eligible local governing body. Second, the current arrangements for variations of PAYE tax instalment deductions will be modified so that an employee with more than one employer may obtain a single variation in the amount of deductions to be made from his or her salary or wages.

This Bill will amend the gift provisions of the income tax laws to give effect to the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) of 25 November 1992. The announcement allows gifts of the value of $2 or more made to the Shrine and Remembrance Restoration and Development Trust to qualify as an income tax deduction if made on or after 25 November 1992 and on or before 30 June 1995. This measure is to assist with the restoration of the shrine as it is in a serious state of disrepair and needs urgent attention to avoid further deterioration. The impact of the amendment on revenue is not expected to be significant.

This Bill will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 to correct a technical error and to reflect a change in the name of the Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Access to Taxation information by the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission

PARA.TAB: The Bill also proposes to amend the Taxation Administration Act 1953 to include the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission within the definition of `law enforcement agency' for the purpose of gaining access to taxation information.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1992, which was introduced into this House on 4 November, implemented many of the measures outlined in the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), entitled Security in retirement, of 30 June 1992. Those measures introduce changes to both the voluntary and compulsory tiers of the Government's superannuation policies: changes which are designed to make the Government's policies fairer, simpler and more efficient.

PARA.TAB: This Bill now before us will introduce two of the remaining measures outlined in that statement: the treatment of death benefits and excessive components. The Bill also gives effect to the Treasurer's announcement of 4 September 1992 relating to the tax exemption available to continuously complying fixed interest approved deposit funds, ADFs.

Other amendments contained in the Bill change the notice requirements relating to personal superannuation contributions and allow ADFs to provide pensions. Lastly, the Bill will make a minor technical amendment to the reasonable benefit limit reporting requirements. I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.

The Bill introduces amendments to assess lump sum superannuation benefits received by a person, on the death of another person, against the deceased's pension reasonable benefit limits. The purpose of these amendments is to reduce the scope for estate planning and to ensure the retirement plans of non-dependants are not disrupted by a bequest of a superannuation benefit.

The Bill also changes the taxation treatment of death benefit eligible termination payments. Under the current arrangements the tax treatment of a death benefit varies considerably, depending upon the source of the benefit and whether it is received direct or through the deceased's estate. The new arrangements are both simpler and more equitable.

If a death benefit ETP is within the deceased's pension RBL and is paid to a dependant of the deceased the benefit will be exempt from tax. If the benefit is paid to a non-dependant the ETP will be broken into its ordinary components. However, the post-June 1983 component of the benefit will be taxed at a maximum rate of 15 per cent plus Medicare levy if paid from a taxed source and 30 per cent plus medicare levy if paid from an untaxed source.

Benefits in excess of the deceased's RBL entitlement will be taxed as an excessive component of an ETP whether paid to a dependant or a non-dependant of the deceased. These measures will apply from 1 July 1994 and are not expected to have any revenue implications.

At present, under the Income Tax Rates Act 1986, the excessive component of an ETP is taxed at the taxpayer's marginal rates of tax. In line with the Treasurer's statement, the Bill will amend that Act to ensure that the excessive component of an ETP, that is, the amount in excess of the RBL, is taxed at the top marginal rate of tax, currently 47 per cent, plus Medicare levy.

These amendments will apply from 1 July 1994. This measure, combined with the measures relating to limits on deductions for superannuation contributions and RBLs, is expected to increase revenue by $20m in 1995-96.

The Bill will amend the notice requirements relating to the tax treatment of personal superannuation contributions. Under the existing arrangements superannuation funds must treat all personal superannuation contributions as taxable contributions unless they are notified that a member is not going to claim a tax deduction for their contribution. As most personal superannuation contributions do not qualify for a deduction, the Bill proposes that personal superannuation contributions will not be treated as taxable contributions by a superannuation fund unless the fund has received a notice from the member stating that he is intending to claim a deduction for his contributions.

Consequently, taxpayers will be eligible for a deduction for personal superannuation contributions to a complying superannuation fund only if they give a notice to the fund advising the fund that they are intending to claim a tax deduction for their contributions and receive an acknowledgment of the notice from the fund. These new arrangements have been actively sought by the superannuation industry because they substantially reduce the administrative burden on superannuation funds.

These amendments will apply to contributions made to a fund on or after 1 July 1992, other than contributions made by a person who has ceased to be a member of the fund before the date of royal assent. These measures are not expected to have any revenue implications.

The Bill will make a technical amendment in relation to continuously complying fixed interest ADFs. Continuously complying fixed interest ADFs are exempt from tax on income that is referable to certain deposits held in ADFs as at 25 May 1988 when the tax arrangements applying to superannuation funds and ADFs were announced. The exemption applies only if an ADF receives at least 90 per cent of its investment income as interest or from amounts received in respect of the disposal of long term securities. Given that the disposal of securities is a normal activity of these investment bodies, the Bill will allow ADFs to take into account profits on the disposal of securities to determine whether they qualify as continuously complying fixed interest ADFs.

This measure will apply from 1 July 1988 as it is broadly consistent with the original policy intention of exempting continuously complying fixed interest ADFs. The measure is not expected to have any revenue implications.

The Bill proposes to amend the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 to allow ADFs to provide allocated pensions.At the moment ADFs act as repositories of ETP moneys and can only pay out lump sums. Depositors may not retain such moneys in an ADF after the age of 65.

Allowing ADFs to provided allocated pensions will enable ADF depositors to have the option of drawing down their accounts in the form of a pension benefit subject to the controls that will apply to allocated pensions generally, such as minimum and maximum payment rules. Pension payments will be subject to beneficiaries meeting tests similar to those applying to superannuation funds, for example, retirement. The measure will increase the choice available to people as to their pension providers.

The Bill also makes a number of technical amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act to recognise that ADFs can pay pensions. The measure will apply from 1 July 1994 and is not expected to have any revenue implications.

Lastly, the Bill makes a minor amendment to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act in relation to the reasonable benefit limit reporting requirements so that the exemption from reporting ETPs of small value is extended to all payers of ETPs, other than ADFs and deferred annuity funds. This measure applies from 24 December 1991. Full details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum being circulated to honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The Occupational Superannuation Standards Amendment Bill 1992 forms part of the package of seven cognate Bills which are being introduced today to give effect to the most important of the new prudential arrangements for superannuation announced by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on 21 October 1992. The Occupational Superannuation Standards Amendment Bill 1992 provides for the repeal of provisions relating to prudential compliance standards that have been taken up in the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill 1992; and new provisions setting out the arrangements for collection of levies to be imposed under the Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Bill 1992 and the Superannuation (Rolled-Over Benefits) Levy Bill 1992.

PARA.TAB: The measures provided for in this Bill complement other measures in the various companion Bills I am also introducing today which together will strengthen substantially the framework of prudential supervision of the industry. I commend the Occupational Superannuation Standards Amendment Bill 1992 to the House and present the related explanatory memorandum.

PARA.TAB: The amendments, as I have already suggested, follow a submission by the industry to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. This is another example of the hairy-chested approach by Labor to legislation in general but to taxation legislation in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean by that?

—What I mean is that the Government does not bother to consult. It does do not bother to get the opinions of either those likely to be affected or the professionals practising in the field. There has been this nonsense with not only this Bill but also four or five other Bills coming before the chamber tonight, as a result of the same stupid, inane practice which the honourable member supports so readily, and to his great shame.

—The honourable member interjects and seeks to interrupt these proceedings on the basis that he can support this arrogant, ignorant approach of his Government to legislation in general and to tax legislation in particular. The poor guy has got a dose of the talks. I will keep talking just as long as he does.

PARA.TAB: The improvements to this legislation, as a result of the Committee sitting and deliberating, are notable. We have amendments before us which would not have seen the light of day. We would have had defective legislation being enacted had it not been for the coalition doing what the Government itself should do; that is, give adequate and thorough consideration to its legislation. Of course it cannot do that unless it consults with people likely to be affected. The arrogance of our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) knows no bounds and those opposite follow him blindly.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We hear those opposite mouthing off. It does them no credit at all. TALK.START.PARA: —As entertaining as all this is, I repeat what I have said: this hairy-chested, arrogant approach of the Government has the support of back bench members. They blindly follow along. Given the Government's rhetoric about simplifying the tax Act, these amendments go no way towards that objective. It is a worthy objective but it is one which has not been, and shows no signs of being, realised by this Government, because we have a hotchpotch of amendments. The amendments themselves only make it more difficult for the people who have to live with the legislation ultimately to work with it and understand it.

PARA.TAB: The manner in which the legislation has been drawn up simply does not do anything to further the cause of simplicity in our tax legislation. The Government has been forced to reconsider. Labor, with its ad hoc approach to taxation generally, finds itself in this position so often and its back bench members are prepared to subordinate their views and the interests of their constituents to the Executive Government. This is just another example of it. They do not insist that the promised simplicity of taxation legislation is pursued. Instead, we have before us a piece of legislation to be amended this evening which is all part of a grand design some months ahead. It is all part of a tax on the business community in Australia which knows few equals.

A recent study of the OECD has shown that out of the OECD's 23 members, Australia has the fourth highest effective tax rates on business. Madam Deputy Chairman, you would have heard our learned Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) at Question Time today talking about the OECD and how much he relies on its good work. I am sure he would also be aware that the OECD has ruled that Australia has the fourth highest level of taxes on business of its 23 members.

On top of that, we have the added admonition of the Industry Commission which stated quite recently that a key component of the policy climate should be to improve competitiveness in the tax system. This legislation does not do that. It really ends up being another impost on business. We will let the Government stew in its own juices. We are not interested in opposing this legislation. TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments are pretty much in the same category as the amendments to an earlier Bill. It should not have been necessary for the Government to refer them back to the Senate; it could have dealt with them on the way through the House of Representatives. It is further evidence of what I term its hairy-chested approach to taxation legislation. It borders on the crash or crash through mentality. That is manifested in a fairly regular way by action simply to get the legislation through the House of Representatives as quickly as possible, in the hope that there is nothing wrong with it, and in the process avoid scrutiny by the House, either during second reading debates or in the Committee of the Whole, such as we have now.

PARA.TAB: These amendments represent a fair change to the Government's original approach. Special arrangements will now apply to any organisation which is a religious institution; a scientific, charitable or public educational institution other than an institution of the Commonwealth, a State or Territory; a public hospital, other than a hospital of the Commonwealth, a State or Territory; a hospital which is carried on by a non-profit society or a non-profit association; a trade union; an association of employers or employees registered under a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory relating to the settlement of industrial disputes; a non-profit society, non-profit association or non-profit club established for musical purposes or for the encouragement of music, art, science or literature; a non-profit society, non-profit association or non-profit club established for the encouragement or promotion of a game or sport; a non-profit society, non-profit association or non-profit club established for the encouragement or promotion of animal races; a non-profit society, non-profit association or non-profit club established for community service purposes, not being political purposes or lobbying purposes; a non-profit society or non-profit association established for the purpose of promoting the development of aviation; or a non-profit society or non-profit association established for the purpose of promoting the development of the agricultural, pastoral, horticultural, viticultural, manufacturing or industrial resources of Australia.

These amendments effect special arrangements applying to such organisations, that legislation having passed through the House of Representatives without the Government having the wit to know that it was deficient in this way. It has arrived at this conclusion now, finally, because it has been forced to consider the legislation once again in the Senate, not in the House of Representatives.

We continue to spit in the well, in the water from which we drink, in this place by making ourselves legislatively irrelevant because that hopeless bunch which sits behind the Ministers is not game and not prepared to insist that legislation get a proper airing in this place. This is another classic example of the Government's failure to consult prior to bringing down legislation. It is another outstanding stark example of a government not prepared to do the hard preparatory work and to get its legislation right in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That amendment No. 1 be disagreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: We are arguing that Senate amendment No. 1 is not acceptable because many of the benefits provided by the institutions mentioned in this amendment are exempt from fringe benefits tax. For example, benefits provided to religious practitioners in respect of their pastoral duties, benefits provided to employees of public benevolent institutions, live-in accommodation of and food benefits provided to employees of government, religious and non-profit organisations who care for elderly and disadvantaged persons, and live-in accommodation with food benefits provided to domestic workers employed by religious institutions or religious practitioners are exempt benefits.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, there is no reason in equity why those institutions mentioned in the amendment which are subject to fringe benefits tax should not pay fringe benefits tax on car parking benefits. The use of the term `educational institution' rather than `public educational institution' grants the exemption to profit making organisations who pay both income tax and fringe benefits tax. Finally, while the words `scientific, religious, charitable or educational' have a developed interpretation in the context of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, a different meaning may be given to these words under the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition proposed the amendment in the Senate and, naturally, we will pursue it. If I understood the reasons of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Johns) in opposing this amendment, they were in part that those bodies which would be affected by our amendment already have exemption from the fringe benefits tax. Presumably, that means that they will not be affected anyway if that is the case. I am not clear on that.

PARA.TAB: That aside, one could use the same argument for saying, `Why bother to knock back the amendment if it is not to have any effect in that context?'. I accept that the Parliamentary Secretary went on to give some other reasons, but if I heard him correctly, on behalf of the coalition, I simply do not accept the first part of his reasoning. We have before us a matter referred to in the Budget in virtually one sentence. The Budget reference to this legislation and the Government's intention to legislate in this way reads:

SPEECH.PARA: As part of the continuing task of making the tax system fairer, from 1 April 1993, Fringe Benefits Tax will be applied to valuable car parking facilities—mainly in central business districts—that are provided by employers to their employees.

So there was not a wealth of information contained in the Budget. Perhaps that is understandable; I am not being critical of that. What we do have subsequently is an indication of the financial impact of the proposal. It was said that these measures would raise $90m in 1993-94; $240m in 1994-95—although I understand that that is no longer the case and that the Government expects less than that, due to the grossing-up effect, as I understand it—and $190m in 1995-96, according to the information provided by the Government.

PARA.TAB: Whilst the Government has subsequently changed its estimates, it is still wildly underestimating, as far as we can tell. We can judge that by the fact that two companies alone will have to bear about $20m under these arrangements. This is another significant tax on business, another little impost which will probably see our position in the list of OECD countries with high business tax go up from fourth out of 23 into the first three. If this Government stays in office much longer, we will be top of the list.

The coalition set out, through the assiduous work of my colleague Senator Watson, to exclude educational institutions, amongst others, from the provisions of this Bill. Surely, people cannot find much wrong with that. In equity, we were trying to reduce the cost of education in this country. At present the Bill is worded in an all-embracing way to include educational institutions quite deliberately. For instance, we have the case of the University of Melbourne which will have to fork out under these provisions, as I understand it, but would not have to if the Government had been sensible enough to accept our amendment. Incidentally, the Government has recognised that its estimates of revenue to be gathered from these measures are wildly out. I believe that was confessed to in the Senate.

But getting back to educational institutions and adding religious, charitable and other such bodies to the list, this seems to us to be consistent with some tax law in this country already. Therefore, it is perfectly logical to extend it in this case. Indeed, the definitions for those categories which we believe should be included and which are enumerated in our amendment are already defined in various taxation Acts.

The other point is that this Bill, as amended—plus the proposed Government amendment which we will not be opposing—but without our amendment, will still be a very dicey piece of tax law. There are very strong reasons to believe that the Bill will tax more than fringe benefits. This would be brought about by arbitrary devices, such as the one-kilometre rule or the four-hour rule, because they remain the basis for determining whether the fringe benefit tax liability exists.

Above all, the Bill remains inconsistent with the treatment of other fringe benefits. The Building Owners and Managers Association of Australia has some very strong concerns about and objections to the provisions in this legislation. It would prefer to see the Bill subjected to a technical review and there is some merit in what it seeks to achieve by doing that.

However, it seems that the Government is hell-bent on pressing ahead and, once again, increasing business taxes in this country to the detriment of not only profitability but also employability. This tax will increase the host of businesses and operations which are now being driven offshore. There is good reason to believe that our total tax burden contributes to that situation, but this Bill, as amended, will certainly add to it once again.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). He made some points in his contribution which should be answered. While he was talking, I was thinking that we have come a long way in this country as regards the fringe benefits tax. Some of us will remember, when the fringe benefits tax legislation was first introduced, the vehemence with which the Opposition opposed it not only here but also in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Members of the Opposition spoke against the legislation. They talked about all the evils that were associated with a fringe benefits tax, even though the working people in this country always paid the full amount of tax on their income—their only form of income, in cash—whereas those people who were able to manipulate their income through receiving some in cash and some in benefits skated through the system without paying any tax at all on that part of their income which was not cash. Those of us who were here at the time would recognise the equity of the Government's original stance on the fringe benefits tax legislation.
The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN (Mrs Sullivan)—I hope we are not going to re-canvass the Government's legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are being very hard on me, Mrs Sullivan. Let me say this: you have allowed—

—No, the honourable member for Canning will let me say something. The amendments deal with a fringe benefits tax on car parking. You have given a general preamble, so perhaps you had better get on with your comments on car parking now.
—In the general debate in this chamber, I think you would agree, Mrs Sullivan, that one minute out of 10 is not a lot of time to spend on a preamble.
—Order! I have not objected to your preamble. I am suggesting that you cease the preamble and get on with the debate.

—I am. I am getting onto the legislation. All I am doing is setting the background for the legislation by talking about the fringe benefits tax in general. I am announcing in this chamber the principles of the fringe benefits tax so that I can—

—Order! The honourable member for Canning will resume his seat for a moment. The previous Bill was on fringe benefits. The Committee is now dealing with the Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill. I do not want to be told by the honourable member for Canning what I may or may not tell him. There is a relevance issue, and in committee we debate clauses. In this particular Committee we are very specifically on a very particular amendment. I suggest that, having been allowed to give his preamble, the honourable member now get on with the actual amendment.

—Thank you, Mrs Sullivan. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Johns) announced, the Senate amendment is not acceptable to the Government because many of the benefits provided by the institutions mentioned in this amendment are already exempt from the fringe benefits tax which I was mentioning. For example, benefits provided to religious practitioners in respect of their pastoral duties; benefits provided to employees of public benevolent institutions; live-in accommodation and food benefits of employees of government, religious and non-government organisations who care for elderly and disadvantaged persons; and live-in accommodation and food benefits of domestic workers employed by religious institutions or religious practitioners, are all exempt.

PARA.TAB: There is also no reason in equity why those institutions mentioned in the amendment which are subject to fringe benefits tax should not pay fringe benefits tax on car parking benefits. Why should they not? If those institutions are in business to make a profit and if they employ people and pay part of their salaries in fringe benefits in the form of car parking, why should they not pay tax on that? If it is a benefit taken in kind instead of cash, why should they not pay a tax on that? I have not heard an argument in this place tonight why they should not. The point I was making before holds true: where fringe benefits are taken as a benefit instead of a payment in cash, those benefits should be taxed, and particularly in this case. That is why the Government is saying that the amendment moved in the Senate is not acceptable to it.

We honestly believe that, where income is taken in cash or in benefits, fringe benefits should be taxed. That is why we oppose this amendment. I agree with the Parliamentary Secretary: we will not accept the amendment, and neither should we.

Motion (by Mr Johns) agreed to:
That Dr Bob Woods, Mr Gear, and the mover be appointed a committee to draw up reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to amendment No. 1 of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the committee appointed to draw up reasons for the House disagreeing to amendment No. 1 of the Senate, I bring up such reasons, which have been circulated to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: Senate amendment No. 1 is not acceptable because:

(1)Many of the benefits provided by the institutions mentioned in this amendment are exempt from fringe benefits tax. For example, benefits provided to religious practitioners in respect of their pastoral duties, benefits provided to employees of public benevolent institutions, live-in accommodation and food benefits of employees of government/religious non-profit organisations who care for elderly and disadvantaged persons and live-in accommodation and food benefits of domestic workers employed by religious institutions or religious practitioners are exempt benefits.
(2)There is no reason in equity why those institutions mentioned in the amendment which are subject to fringe benefits tax should not pay fringe benefits tax on car parking benefits.
(3)The use of the term "educational institution" rather than "public educational institution" grants the exemption to profit making organisations who pay both income tax and fringe benefits tax.

(4)While the words "scientific, religious, charitable or educational" have a developed interpretation in the context of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, a different meaning may be given to these words under the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Johns) agreed to:
That the reasons be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill is supported by the coalition. The only complaint we have about this Bill is that it has taken such a long time to reach fruition. We were given indications that it would have been presented to this House something like 18 months ago. It has taken a long time to reach this state because of the wheelings and dealings inside the Labor Party. Nonetheless, it is a Bill which is appropriate and long overdue.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) will be well aware that I asked him for the Bill something like 18 months ago. I asked him for support; I asked him for indications; I asked him for briefings. He was unable or unwilling to provide any of those things. There was no sense of bipartisan approach to the Bill, which is a vital health issue. The Minister can smugly smile about the whole thing. Clearly he does not care about the fact that this Bill is going to save lives; he cares only about his internal party politics.

There are a few points here which are vitally important. The first issue to assess is whether in fact there is a health issue involved in smoking. I think this is now beyond all doubt. The second is whether advertising, in whatever form, actually increases the likelihood of people, particularly the young, taking up smoking. The third issue is whether there are any reasons why we should not put this Bill through. One of the important things to note is that this Bill closes a loophole in the original prohibition of broadcasting of tobacco advertising legislation, which was brought in by the Fraser Government—a Liberal Government—in, I believe, 1976. I am delighted that the loopholes are now being closed because they have been ruthlessly exploited by a number of tobacco companies.

Let us look at the first issue: is tobacco smoking harmful? I think there is no doubt about it. It is the largest single preventable cause of disease in Australia today. It is estimated to have caused between 19,000 and 20,000 deaths in Australia in the last year. Seventy-five per cent of drug caused deaths are due to tobacco—not, as other people would indicate, opiates. Opiates probably cause something like 2 or 3 per cent of deaths; 20 or 25 per cent are due to alcohol, including road crashes. Something like a third of all cancer deaths in Australia are attributable to smoking. Between one in five and one in three smokers will die of a tobacco caused illness, depending on how heavily they smoke. A person who smokes roughly one packet of cigarettes a day increases his or her chances of getting lung cancer by about eight times; with two packets it goes up to 25 times. There is no doubt at all about the association between tobacco smoking and a number of diseases.

It is not just the people who smoke who are affected; passive smoking clearly also has adverse health effects for adults, but more importantly perhaps for children. It is the cause of lung cancer and heart disease in adult non-smokers—unequivocally. One of the questions which this Bill has to address is whether there has been encouragement to the youth in our society to smoke. The main development period for the uptake of smoking is usually between the ages of 12 and 16. Sadly, in those age groups there is a particular prevalence of smoking amongst girls rather than boys. Advertising by tobacco companies in its various forms, including sponsorship of sporting and cultural events, has undoubtedly been a factor in encouraging the uptake of smoking, particularly by these young people. Again I think the evidence for that is overwhelming.

If one asks the children themselves they will say just that. Something like 65 per cent of children aged 10 and 11 indicate that tobacco sponsorship is simply another form of advertising. So, contrary to what various tobacco authorities tell us, there is good evidence that tobacco sponsorship is simply advertising. There is good evidence about market share. One of the arguments sometimes put forward by tobacco companies is that all they are doing is changing brands, rather than increasing smoking per se. In fact, tobacco advertising of any sort does both. It not only moves people into a company's own brand but also encourages individuals to take up smoking—particularly when it is associated with clean, healthy activities such as the various sports.

There is no doubt at all that children see sponsorship of sports as equivalent to a personal endorsement of smoking by the athletes and other players involved in those sports. According to the AMA study in 1991, 61 per cent of Western Australian teenagers believed that the sponsorship of cricket by Benson and Hedges would encourage children to smoke. There is evidence from around the world that this is the case. There is good evidence about the impact of smoking. Some cigarette companies say that it really does not have a major impact. The simple answer to that is: if that is the case, why do they spend millions of dollars on it? Beyond that, there is good evidence about the brands. For example, why is it that far more children in New South Wales and Queensland smoke Winfield than in other States—something like 44.5 per cent in New South Wales and 48 per cent in Queensland compared with 4 or 5 per cent in South Australia and 18 or 19 per cent in Victoria? There is good evidence that in New South Wales and Queensland, where Winfield achieves enormous visibility by sponsoring the major winter sport, rugby league, that is the underlying reason.

Escort dominated the young adolescent market in South Australia, and Escort sponsored the Australian rules Escort Cup. In Victoria, Peter Jackson dominated, followed by Winfield, and, although there is not such an overwhelming predominance of Peter Jackson advertisements, that brand is heavily advertised through the AFL. There is no doubt at all about the impact of smoking upon the young. Those age groups related to smokers between the ages of 12 and 14. We are talking about young school children.

There really is, I think, no doubt, first of all, that tobacco is harmful and, secondly, that advertising increases the likelihood of taking up smoking and does impact upon the brand. Tobacco brand names are clearly identifiable for at least a third of the time during broadcasts of many major sporting events. I watched some of the cricket match last night and it was difficult to watch the cricket, there were so many ads around the place for Benson and Hedges in one form or other.

There are a couple of issues relating to this which we need to address. There are some arguments to say that this legislation should not go through. The arguments mainly focus on the question of being able to advertise a legal product, that companies should be free to advertise those legal products, that it is a restraint of some sort of freedom if they are not able to do so. I guess the first argument against that is that in many regards, particularly in regard to young children, cigarettes are not a legal product. In all States in Australia, there are constraints upon the age at which cigarettes can be sold to minors and clearly, for that group, the target group for many of these sponsorships, there is no legality about buying them.

Secondly, I think that there is an argument which says that, if we start with tobacco, where do we stop? We might go on to alcohol next. We might even go on to Mars bars, because those things are also, in one way or another, potentially unhealthy in various forms. The argument, of course, for tobacco is unique. There is no safe level of smoking. One cigarette is bad. It is as simple as that. It is not as bad as 20 and it is not as bad, again, as 100, but it is certainly bad.

The problem with, say, alcohol is not use; the problem with alcohol is misuse or abuse or overuse. It is therefore a completely different kettle of fish, and it is very clearly appropriate in that situation to direct education and target campaigns at misuse and overuse and responsible use of alcohol. I will not enter into the debate about Mars bars. I think that is a somewhat facetious argument sometimes put up which really has no particular merit.

Other arguments put on the other side of this debate include the fact that there is an important influx of money into various sporting events and that, without that influx of money, there would not be the ability to hold those sporting events. Overseas experience, of course, shows that that is not, in fact, the case. Even in these recessionary times, it has been possible overseas to find alternative sponsors for virtually every major tobacco sponsored event which has been removed from sponsorship by various legislative bodies. I do not think that is an argument either. The provisions in the legislation allow for particular consideration to be given to minor, small sporting and similar events, should they face difficulties, and that is something which I think we should certainly support.

I have a couple of concerns which are relatively minor concerns. I am not quite sure about the importance of introducing the exemption for clothing and I hope that it will not be possible to exploit it as some sort of loophole. I am not sure about the importance of Norfolk Island. I think the loophole there has been potentially closed inasmuch as I do not think, for example, we will start seeing test matches televised to the mainland from Norfolk island. I think that is not a problem, but it is something which was raised with me.

In essence, the bottom line is that we will save thousands of lives, but we will also save thousands, in fact, millions of dollars. I want to refer to one of the arguments put forward by the tobacco companies. In relation to the amount of money—which is about $2.5 billion—which flows into government coffers through various excise charges and licensing fees, a corporate relations manager for W.D. and H.O. Wills, Mr George Symmes, was quoted in the Australian Financial Review in January last year. The article said:

SPEECH.PARA: There's going to come a day when, if it's not careful, the Government is going to kill the golden goose.

One of the problems is that he has missed out on a whole side of the balance sheet. On the other side of the balance sheet are billions of dollars worth of expense in looking after people affected by tobacco, looking after the health expenses, the hospitalisation, the time lost from work which, in relation to tobacco and a few related drugs, is estimated to be well over $12 billion by some authorities, and even higher by others.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, this legislation will result in an overwhelming benefit in health terms. There is an overwhelming benefit in preventing our kids from taking up smoking. There is also an overwhelming benefit in economic terms in this sort of legislation. I congratulate the Government on finally producing the legislation. I am sad that it took so long. I am happy it is here, and the coalition will support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill. I think we have been seeing far too much of this sort of legislation in Australia in recent times. After listening to some of the hyperbole from honourable members opposite, I might remind the last speaker, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods), that many years ago in France there was a national strike of doctors, the main consequence of which was that the death rate dropped dramatically. It may have been coincidental, but it is a fact that it did.

PARA.TAB: In the paper put out by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) we are told that $6.8 billion is the cost of cigarette smoking in Australia. This is a figure that cannot be substantiated, and any honest academic—and heaven help us, there are a few of those in Australia today—could blow holes as big as Queensland in any supporting arguments. The honourable member for Lowe now tells me that the cost is $12 billion. Obviously what we do is pick a figure out of the air and square it and use that as evidence. Such arguments, I believe, should be treated with contempt.

We are told that tobacco related diseases are the biggest and most preventable diseases in Australia. If we do our calculations on the basis of relating deaths as a result of heart attacks, strokes and other illnesses to tobacco, yes, we can probably arrive at that figure. However, I suspect that there are often contributory or other causes for these deaths. I suspect that, if the real figures were done, we would find that diabetes causes more deaths than any other single factor in Australia. If we took all the ramifications of diabetes control and if we were to put into diabetes research some of the money that we squander in other areas, I am sure we could dramatically reduce the number of related deaths.

Hepatitis B is another one, of course. It is a disease introduced as a result of the lack of care of governments in the past; a disease which has only recently come to Australia and is now endemic and kills very many people. It is a disease which is highly curable and totally preventable, but what do we hear about that? What do we hear about the people in Australia who die as a result of their use of analgesics? We have not counted them, but I will bet there are thousands. Fortunately for us, they are nearly all middle-aged women screaming for themselves in suburbia. They are obliging enough to die quietly, so we do not do much about that. I think we have to look into these claims much more deeply than is done in this Bill.

I speak as a non-smoker. I gave up smoking when I left school. While I had the occasional OP when Brian Burke went on his fascist anti-smoking campaign, generally I would have to call myself a non-smoker; I would be in the half a packet a year league.

In relation to another problem that I see here, I have a regard for history. In the early 1950s cannabis was not illegal in Australia; it was widely prescribed pharmaceutically. Then, at the behest of the American drug authorities, we decided it was a wicked substance that had to be dramatically controlled. We have gone full circle and States in Australia are now realising that the dangers of marijuana are grossly overstated. Some of the more enlightened States have actually taken steps to play down marijuana smoking as a crime. Yet we are still staining the records of very many people for the heinous crime of having a smoke of marijuana.

I think we are heading down the road of making cigarette smoking the same sort of crime. When we get that far, what we will do, of course, is drive cigarette smoking into the hands of organised crime. That will be another great success for society. I might add that we have done that with hard drugs. The honourable member for Lowe mentioned that hard drugs represent a very small percentage, just over 2 per cent, of all drug deaths in Australia. I very strongly subscribe to the view that hard drugs should be available on prescription from chemists to take organised crime out of the supply of these drugs. I believe that we would then have far fewer problems. I note that in civilised countries elsewhere in the world—in the UK, for instance—heroin is prescribed for terminally ill cancer patients. Not so in Australia. I suppose our medical friends are frightened that the people might become addicted, despite the comfort it gives them.

Parallels have been drawn with the dangers posed by asbestos. This is probably right, because here again we have seen a grossly overstated consequence of asbestos. We spent $300m in the ACT removing asbestos from buildings, but none in Queanbeyan where the workers live—all that money in Canberra and other capital cities throughout Australia. Yet the Neville report just brought down in Western Australia for the first time documents the real consequences of asbestos and for the first time puts forward the relative risks of asbestos. I commend the reading of that report to every member of this House, particularly the medicos. It puts that matter into a perspective which would result in the people of Australia, when they grasp it, becoming very angry about the money that is spent.

I am also concerned about the suffering of people. If people choose to smoke and know the consequences, it ill behoves society to legislate. I worry about a society that believes that it is the sole arbiter of what is good for people; it must take the great father role and direct people. I believe people should have a much greater freedom of choice. Remember that the people who die as a consequence of tobacco are invariably people in their late middle age—it is a sad fact that everybody dies of something or other—and I think research would bear that out.

For instance, my brother had a father-in-law who started smoking at 13 and died of lung cancer at the age of 78. He is down as a cancer, cigarette-induced statistic. Right up until his death he maintained that it was only nicotine that made his life bearable with the pain he used to suffer from congenital rheumatoid arthritis. It was a view he held, and in the respect that he believed it that was all that mattered.

I value freedom of speech. It is part of our culture and has been for a thousand years. People have fought and died for it. Freedom of speech is not divisible. We either have it or we do not have it. To argue, as the asinine High Court does, that free speech is inviolate in respect of political advertising but—shock horror—that a legally available product cannot be advertised is bizarre in the extreme. Anyone who puts forward that argument is at least intellectually bereft.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin), on behalf of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples), in his second reading speech, suggested that tobacco consumption was dropping. Later on in the speech we were told that advertising promotes tobacco consumption. It is a little hard to have it both ways. But that sort of thing really does not seem to bother people these days. They could argue, of course, that tobacco consumption would fall quicker if it were not for cigarette advertising, and that would be a respectable argument, but that is not what they are saying.

I now want to go to specific elements in this Bill. We are told that the Government would set up a fund to compensate those people who used to get sponsorship from tobacco companies but no longer do. The Government should have a responsibility to place this additional burden on the taxpayers. But the reality, as we have seen in Western Australia—a State that has the same sort of fascist legislation and set up the same sort of mechanism to support sport—is that what gets supported is politically correct sports. What gets supported overwhelmingly is sports in the city areas—country areas get neglected. That will be the consequence of this legislation. We will find that numerous small golf clubs in some country areas will not get the compensation and sports such as rifle shooting—not politically correct—will be neglected by the bureaucrats making these sorts of decisions. I only hope, after the strenuous efforts made by the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls), that rodeos will be funded, particularly the rodeo in his area, although I can see now the animal liberationists rallying to deny aid to this honourable sport.

It seems rather odd to me: I have not heard of very many cases where people have a few cigarettes and then go home and bash up the kids and the missus. I do not think that generally occurs. Clearly, tobacco does not have the social consequences of alcohol. Alcohol is a drug that is so imbued in our society that we will not move to act against it. Yet it is quite clear that the social consequences of alcohol are far worse, far more pernicious and affect more people than tobacco. At least tobacco smokers make a mature, adult choice about the risks they run and the consequences that they inflict upon themselves.

I find that in society generally we are deregulating the economy like mad but trying to regulate people's lives to an extreme degree. It reminds me of when I was in China a couple of years ago. I was in a department store in this most communist of countries. By the stairs on the fifth floor were numerous extension cords running across the floor, taped down with bits of tape. It looked to me to be a very dangerous situation.

I said to the Chinese Government officials who were with us, `What would be the consequences of people falling over these cables and breaking their leg?'. The official said to me, `Their employer's insurance would look after them until they were able to go back to work'. The Chinese health system has a great similarity with the American health system. I said, `But what about the store? Doesn't it have a responsibility for having these cables lying on the floor?'. `Good heavens no', he said, `people have a responsibility to look after themselves. People should look where they are walking'.

If a communist country can realise that one cannot legislate people's responsibility out of existence and that people must take the consequence of their own actions, surely we can at least give that some consideration in this country. But we are going down the road of complete control, where members of the public do not know what is good for them and the state must legislate for their welfare. It is not the Australia I want and it is not the Australia of our history, which is a history of independence. I therefore abhor this sort of legislation.

The problem does not just rest with tobacco. We find the same situation in other areas. We are going to bring into this House legislation against racial vilification. We are going to make it illegal to say nasty things about other people when there are already remedies under common law for the things to which we will give additional penalties and sanctions.

We already have precedents. The State of Western Australia has similar legislation in respect of equal rights. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission there operates virtually on the same basis as the frauds who run the Commonwealth Commission.

I know of a fellow working in the State Public Service who was recently charged with sexual harassment. He was arraigned before this Commission, deemed to be guilty and fined. It was not until, at great personal expense, he took his case to the Supreme Court that he found out what he was charged with. Once he was able to establish that, the case was thrown out of court. He was fortunate in that he was able to hock his house to the tune of $30,000 and have costs awarded against the State. It was very fortunate, because most people simply would not have the resources to do that or could not take those sorts of risks.

I have also seen this happen in respect of Aboriginals who claim to have been victimised. It is quite clear that, in many of these cases, people have simply set up the situation. They have gone into a pub and acted in a totally unsocial and unacceptable way and, when thrown out, have resorted to this legislation and have succeeded under the rules of the tribunals, which totally ignore the much stronger need for truth which exists in the law courts.

My opposition to this legislation will have very little effect, because the Opposition wants to be even holier than us. Opposition speakers say that we have not gone far enough. I think that we have gone far too far. It is about time we started getting people to take responsibility for their own actions, to lift from the state the taxation burden that is caused by legislation such as this and to look to doing things in society that are real and need doing.

I am fairly close to the diabetes scene. I am absolutely sure that if we put money in for the research of hepatitis we could make some improvements. If we put the money we have squandered on AIDS into hepatitis B, a disease which is entirely preventable and will kill more people than AIDS, we would be doing something useful, but we do not do that. We go down the road of giving more power to institutions and more power to bureaucrats to rule the lives of people.

I know we are saying that we are only banning the advertising. That, I think, is a first step. There is also a more sinister implication: the social engineers who infest society today and infest institutions such as the High Court know that if they can socially engineer people out of smoking, they can socially engineer us into doing virtually anything that they want. I find that a frightening prospect. I already see a lot of evidence to support the view that this process is well in train.

I resent this Bill very strongly. I believe it is ill-advised. I think that the arguments which will be put forward by speakers who follow me, with the greatest sincerity, simply have no basis in fact. In years to come, I fear that we will look back on this legislation with the same bemusement as we are now starting to look back on making marijuana an illegal substance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill 1992 is an extension of the Television Amendment Bill 1976 and the Tobacco and Smoking Products Advertisement Prohibition Act 1989, which together banned the advertising of tobacco in print, on TV and on radio. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) and the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) have covered very clearly what is in this Bill, and I shall not go into it in detail.

PARA.TAB: Briefly, though, from 1 July 1993, tobacco companies will not be able to advertise at cultural or sporting events or use billboards or other outdoor displays. Tobacco will not be able to be associated with non-tobacco products. Penalties for breaching the Act will be $12,000 for individuals and $60,000 for corporations. I am sorry to see the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) leaving the chamber, because he made some very interesting, if not somewhat curious, points on the Bill. I will refer to those later since he has left the chamber.

Tobacco sponsorships entered into before 1 April this year will be allowed to continue until the end of 1995. For cricket matches this extension will continue until April 1996. The exclusions have already been listed by the honourable member for Macarthur and the honourable member for Lowe. At this stage, I give my support for this Bill.

Cigarette smoking causes 99 per cent of emphysema and 98 per cent of lung cancers. A total of 20,000 people die each year from cigarette smoking related diseases, and the cost to the Australian economy is $6.8 billion.That does not take into account the social costs of smoking. The father of a friend of my son died in his mid-40s solely from the results of smoking. The effect that has had on his young family and his wife has been devastating. This is one instance which is repeated over and over again in the country.

The honourable member for Kalgoorlie made light of the fact that people die in their 50s and 60s from smoking. I point out to him that they also die in their 40s. He said it was their own choice whether they smoked or not. This is not quite the truth. People take up smoking at an early age and become addicted. It is then no longer a choice. A number of our colleagues regularly try to give up smoking without any success at all. People are influenced to take up smoking when they are young. Undoubtedly advertising is one of these influences.

Studies which have been conducted show a correlation between advertising and the rate of smoking and the effect when advertising has been removed. A study in Canada showed that, after advertising was removed from sporting clubs, the drop in the incidence of smoking in one year was 8 per cent, which is quite an effective drop.

It is the effects on children with which we are most concerned and this is why the advertising has been directed to sporting clubs where children are likely to be influenced. I believe there is a correlation between the popularity of a cigarette brand and its association with a local football club. Children at the ages of 12, 13, 14 and 15 are not in a good position to make a judgment about whether they should smoke. They perhaps believe that they are immortal and they discount the warnings they get. By the time they are of an age to realise the hazards, it is too late and they are already addicted to smoking.

It is argued by the tobacco companies that they are advertising not to gain new smokers—that is, not to gain the young smokers—but I think this is a somewhat spurious argument. How does one make a product attractive enough to get somebody to switch to that product without at the same time making that product so attractive that somebody will take it up? I am not claiming that advertising is the only reason why people smoke—obviously, peer pressure and other pressures do contribute—but it is certainly one of the pressures.

Young people are one of the biggest growing groups of smokers. A study that I carried out five years ago indicated a mounting incidence amongst children and, although this study was done locally in South Australia, it was one of the first studies to show a greater incidence of smoking amongst young women than young men. A study by the Medical Journal of Australia in 1989 entitled `Cigarette smoking in Australian schoolchildren' found that by the age of 15 years, 33 per cent of the girls and 26 per cent of the boys in the study sample had smoked at least one cigarette. That seems to be the start of what becomes a life-long habit which can lead to death in the mid-40s, early 50s and later, in addition to that enormous economic cost that I mentioned earlier.

One of the arguments put forward is that if we are going to ban advertising, why not ban cigarette smoking itself? I think everybody is aware of the problems with that. With 28 per cent of the population smoking, it becomes an extremely difficult thing to ban it and make something that is legal one day illegal the next. That 28 per cent of adults have to be dealt with and what happens then when they are smoking an illegal substance? However, the major argument—and I want to make this brief tonight because I would like to get home at some reasonable hour—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha, ha!

—There is laughter. I will make it very fast. One of the major arguments brought against the banning of advertising in this form is that it is a denial of freedom of speech. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie brought this forward very strongly. It is a very powerful argument that in this society we do not want to see a plethora of restrictions; we do not want to get to the stage where every single thing is regulated by government and we are told what we can and cannot do. I do have sympathy for that argument. But I think the honourable member for Kalgoorlie would have to acknowledge that in many things in life there is more than one principle at stake. In this case there are two principles at stake and the principle of freedom of speech is one of them. The principle of saving the lives of young people, albeit it when they become older, is another, and the weight is certainly with that one.

PARA.TAB: Finally, on the freedom of speech referred to by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, we are not totally free in our freedom of speech. For instance, we would not allow someone the freedom to publicly encourage suicide by advertising, which is exactly what we are doing when we encourage them to smoke.

I would like to comment that the people in this chamber would be fairly sophisticated in their appreciation of advertising, but this is not true for everyone. I was in the position of actually being faced by one of my constituents who, when I asked her about smoking, said, `It really is all right, because if it was bad for me the Government would ban it'. There is the belief that once it is allowed to be advertised, then somehow it is all right. That may be one of the messages that is getting through to our children. I commend this Bill to the House in its present form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hulls Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill. Before I get to the main text of my speech, I wish to say that I find it somewhat astounding that the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) has come into this House and said that whilst he supports the Bill, the only concern he has is that the Government has taken so long to introduce it into the House. A headline in the Australian newspaper of Friday, 27 November 1992 reads, `Coalition backs ban on tobacco sponsorship'. The article reads as follows:

PARA.TAB: Coalition backbenchers have overturned a shadow ministry decision by lobbying the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, to support a ban on tobacco sponsorship of sport.
The shadow ministers voted earlier yesterday by a narrow margin to reject the Federal Government's anti-tobacco legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In fairness to the honourable member for Lowe, the article goes on to state:

PARA.TAB: They ignored the recommendation of the Opposition spokesman on health, Dr Bob Woods, who wanted to ban sponsorship on health grounds.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me a touch hypocritical for the honourable member for Lowe to come into this House and say that he supports the Bill but the Government has been far too slow to implement this legislation, when his own Party has rejected this legislation. This legislation would not have been implemented by the Opposition had it been in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Forced into it.

—As the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, who is at the table, said, the Opposition has been forced into supporting this Bill. Members of the Opposition agree with what I am saying; they have finally been forced into agreeing with this particular Bill.

PARA.TAB: It is fair to say that nobody would deny that the basic objective of this Bill is to improve public health. Other speakers have already said that there is irrefutable evidence that smoking causes all sorts of diseases that lead to death and it would be difficult to argue against the proposition that tobacco consumption is one of the largest preventable causes of death and disease in Australia.

This legislation, which I understand finally has cross-party support, will have the effect of setting a minimum standard for bans on tobacco advertising. While I support the thrust of this Bill and applaud its stated objectives, there are a number of comments I want to make about tobacco growers and Cabinet's commitment to ensuring that small sporting and cultural events in rural Australia are not adversely affected by the ban. I also want to make some comments about the anomalies associated with the ban already referred to by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell).

As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, I represent the most significant tobacco growing area in Australia. The townships of Mareeba, Dimbulah and Mutchilba are totally dependent on tobacco for their viability. Not only are there more than 300 growers in this area of the Atherton Tableland, but also the service industries associated with tobacco make it a huge employer and the lifeblood of these towns. Hard-working farmers have been growing a legal product for many years. Unfortunately for them, but perhaps fortunately for the health of the nation, public policy in Australia dictates that fewer people consume tobacco products.

As I have said in this House many times before, there is currently a quota system in operation for tobacco growers. That quota system—the amount that growers can grow in a given year—is based on the previous year's consumption. As domestic consumption decreases, the amount of tobacco that local growers can grow also decreases, thus adversely impacting on their livelihoods. This is a human cost not often thought about when discussing the tobacco issue.

The ban on tobacco advertising, if the manufacturers' arguments are to be believed, should not have any impact at all on growers. The manufacturers argue that advertising does not get more people to smoke. They argue that it is simply used as brand identification—that is, getting people to change from one brand to another. Therefore, growers should not be adversely affected at all by this particular ad ban.

I think it is fair to say that growers have to develop a strategy to ensure their future long term viability. Unless such a strategy, involving value adding and exporting, is embarked upon, growers and their families, and towns such as Mareeba and Dimbulah, will be doomed.

I am pleased that growers have agreed, along with manufacturers and union representatives, to take part in a national tobacco task force to look at impediments to sustainable growth, investment and competitiveness in the industry, and to look at the means of overcoming these impediments in order to develop a national growth strategy for the industry. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) will shortly be announcing the make-up of this task force. I believe such a task force will be the catalyst for putting confidence back into the tobacco industry in Australia.

Whilst I have stated that the ad ban on tobacco products should not affect growers, I have always been concerned about the effects such a ban would have on small sporting and cultural events in rural and remote Australia. One of the anomalies in this legislation is that it allows the Minister to exempt certain events from the ban if the Minister deems such events to be of national or international significance and if those events would be lost to Australia if the ad ban applied to them.

It is very difficult—indeed impossible—to explain to people in Mareeba, Dimbulah or other parts of my electorate that the Minister can exempt specific events that are of international significance and which might fold if the ban applied to them, but there will be no such exemption for events such as the Mareeba Rodeo, the Dimbulah Festival or the rugby league in Mount Isa. The Mareeba Rodeo is just as important to the people in that town as the Adelaide grand prix is to the people in South Australia. Whilst this is an anomaly in the legislation—and one I am prepared to wear because the legislation is a giant step in the right direction—it should not be at the expense of these very important sporting and cultural events in rural Australia that are currently sponsored by tobacco companies.

It is important to note that the legislation allows a lead-in time of some three years, until 31 December 1995, to allow sponsored organisations to locate alternative funding. Whilst it may be all well and good for major events such as the Winfield Cup or the Benson and Hedges World Series Cricket, which I am sure will have sponsors queuing up to fund them, it does not help specific events in my electorate; for example, the very well, and now nationally, publicised Mareeba Rodeo, which is actually called the Peter Jackson Mareeba Rodeo, or the Dimbulah Festival, which is actually called the Dimbulah Tobacco Festival. I do not think it would matter much if there were a 20-year lead-in time; sponsors will not be lining up to fund these events.

If these events were to fold, it would be devastating for rural and remote Australia. These events are bigger than Ben Hur in their specific towns. They attract a lot of tourists and are part of the social fabric of these towns. It is for this reason that I have pushed Cabinet, specifically the Minister at the table and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly), to give a commitment to ensure that these events survive.
