I am pleased that Cabinet has decided that the Government will re-examine the effects the ban is having on small sporting and cultural groups after the ban has been in operation for a short time and that, whilst the States have the prime governmental responsibility for alternative sponsorships, especially through health promotion funds, if there is evidence that the ban is causing genuine hardship for small sporting and cultural groups, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories is to bring back to Cabinet a proposal to relieve the groups so affected.

Already the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has indicated that she wants to ensure the survival of these events. I am quite sure the Minister at the table also wants to ensure their survival. He is nodding to indicate that that is the case. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has decided to set up a Government committee to monitor the effect a ban may have on such events in rural Australia. She also went on the public record. She was questioned about this matter on ABC Radio 2CN on Friday, 13 November, by Matthew Abraham, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: What about these small sporting events that seem to worry the back bench?
Mrs Kelly said:

That's always been a concern to me and to many of the backbenchers. Primarily this is only a problem in Queensland and New South Wales because they do not have health promotion funds. So last night the Cabinet had a talk about that and we said, `Look, we would want the State Governments in those States to be responsible and take the sort of same action as Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria have taken'. If, after the implementation of this legislation, which remember it does not come into effect until 1996 in fact, if there are still some problems, I could then go back to Cabinet with a proposal if they were desperate and if the States wouldn't respond in a positive way.
The next question was:
So if Rob Hulls' rodeo was threatened, you'll throw some money at it?
Mrs Kelly's answer was:
In 1996 if, by then the State Governments haven't come to their senses . . .

The Minister then went on to say that she believes the State governments will come to their senses. I think it is fair to say that the States do have primary responsibility for the establishment of a health promotion fund. I have already written to the Queensland State health Minister, the Hon. Ken Hayward, about setting up a health fund in that State. I have received a letter from him dated 1 December this year stating that he is having the matter examined and he will advise me when further information becomes available.

PARA.TAB: It is fair to say that the commitment is there. The Cabinet, Minister Kelly and Minister Staples are to be congratulated for their conciliatory and understanding attitude to the plight of rural Australians and the importance that rural Australians place on these extremely significant sporting and cultural events. These events will not only survive but also thrive as a result of the commitment that has been given by the Ministers and Cabinet.

The attitude of the relevant Ministers is in stark contrast to that of Mr David Hill, the General Manager of the ABC. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you will probably recall, when this Bill first came to Caucus it was deferred so that concerns, such as mine and others, could be appropriately addressed. Those concerns were genuine and I believe—despite what the honourable member for Kalgoorlie had to say—they have now been appropriately addressed.

On the World at Noon on ABC television on 11 November, Mr Hill was interviewed—on his own station—by John Lombard and he made the outrageous accusation that the tobacco industry had nobbled Caucus to stop this legislation going through before the election. I will quote from a transcript of that interview dated 11 November 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: DAVID HILL: I think enough Caucus members have clearly been got at by the awesome tobacco industry who made it clear when Cabinet made a decision earlier this year to ban tobacco sponsorship—but they've fought it every inch of the way. The only surprise for me is that we've seen such a large scale capitulation of Caucus so early in the piece.
LOMBARD: Nobbled?
HILL: I think so. I think that the members of Parliament in those marginal electorates that grow tobacco have been got at directly . . .
Mr Deputy Speaker, there is no need for me to tell you whom he is referring to there. He continues:

I think the tobacco industry has been working the lobby machine overtime, and I think they will have got the sporting bodies who have had their pockets lined for years by the tobacco industry to do a lot of their pressuring and dirty work as well.
Later in the interview, Lombard said this:

But you'd understand most of the rural members are concerned that their sports in country electorates which would be affected by this and yet major events can get exemption by being declared international.
Hill said this:

It's to prop up South Australia with the Grand Prix. Most of the sporting dollars from the tobacco industry go to the mass sports—not the farmer's sports in the bush electorates, and they go there because that's where the television coverage is—that big money goes to the cricket from B and H and to Winfield Rugby league and that's where the industry is fighting the rearguard action. Really, whether or not there's a rodeo in a tobacco growing electorate in North Queensland is frankly irrelevant.

In conclusion, it appears to me that David Hill has used the TV station of which he is the General Manager to peddle his own views and to maliciously and falsely make accusations. These have been shown to be false by the fact that this Bill is in this House tonight. Mr Hill should be ashamed of himself.

PARA.TAB: Whilst I fully support this Bill, I wonder whether Mr Hill's actions have the full support of his board. I only hope that Mr Hill will now use his obvious influence with the ABC to ensure that the Mareeba rodeo is telecast live throughout Australia next year and that he personally undertakes to ride the bucking bull on this particular occasion. He has been speaking plenty of it. It would be a pleasant change to see him ride it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard some pretty harsh criticism of David Hill. I must say that there is not much love lost between David Hill, members of the Opposition or the organisation that he heads up, but I ought to say on the public record how much I respected the stand that he took as Chairman of the North Sydney Rugby League Club. The club incurred the considerable wrath of the New South Wales Rugby League. At one stage it looked as though it might even be thrown out of the competition. Obviously, Mr Hill—and I have never spoken to him about this—believes very strongly in this cause, as I and others do, and was prepared to take considerable risks. I believe he deserves to be congratulated. I suspect that what he said had a considerable element of truth in it.

PARA.TAB: The sensitivity that the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls) has shown tonight lends credence to that. The honourable member is concerned about the Mareeba Rodeo and the Dimbulah Festival, and with some justification. But he cannot have it both ways. He has gone to considerable lengths in this speech tonight to lock the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) in to looking after those two events which may need to have international significance if they are to survive. That might be his remedy under the Broadcasting Services Act. It seems to me that the honourable member needs to create international interest in the Mareeba Rodeo and the Dimbulah festival. That will be their salvation. But that would seem to be their only salvation within this legislation. The Minister stated in his second reading speech:

The time has come in Australia to end tobacco advertising. The passage of this legislation is among the most important health initiatives that can be taken by this Government. By supporting the trend away from smoking, it will make a major contribution to reducing illness and premature mortality amongst Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I totally agree with that statement and I congratulate the Government, although I am disappointed that in some respects this Bill has stopped short of what I believe could have been a more comprehensive ban. I presume that the reason for the Bill stopping short is the sort of pressure that was being applied by honourable members, such as the honourable member for Kennedy, who obviously have a considerable vested interest in softening the legislation to the extent that they have. The one to which I alluded is one considerable exemption that has been granted. The second reading speech states:

PARA.TAB: The Bill removes the potential for tobacco advertising but not to the extent that extreme measures are taken.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister said in his speech:
International events to be held in Australia will be able to apply for an exemption from the ban.

We might well expect—although I hope we do not—a plethora of applications for so-called international events to be held in Australia. I am not seriously suggesting that the Mareeba Rodeo or the Dimbulah Festival might qualify in that regard, but there might be some hope.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased that the Opposition is supporting this legislation, deficient though it is in some respects. Most of the issues have been adequately canvassed, but it needs to be clearly understood that this legislation is intended to deal with inconsistencies and loopholes within the existing law. It is for that reason that this legislation was necessary. The existing laws are clear but they have been consistently flouted over the years, and that needed to be fixed.

I need to say, because from my point of view it is relevant, that I come to this debate with a long personal involvement in sport, as a participant, a supporter and a spectator. I have always believed that tobacco promotion and sport were diametrically opposed. Smoking is clearly and unequivocally unhealthy.

We could spend all night debating the extent to which smoking is unhealthy. In the end that would be pointless. As the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) correctly pointed out, many deaths are indirectly attributable to cigarette smoking. But I do not think there is any doubt in anybody's mind—and the speaker after me may well clarify this—that smoking is unhealthy.

Sport, of course, is quite the reverse, both for participants and, to some extent, even for spectators. Sport is a healthy activity. Connecting sport and smoking in any way at all is completely hypocritical. In his second reading speech, the Minister actually described the connection as bizarre. That is a slightly stronger description but I agree that it is bizarre to in some way connect these two activities.

In some way tobacco use has always been legitimised, enhanced or otherwise made respectable by its connection to sport. One does not have to be too sharp to realise that this is clever marketing. Every day we see evidence of clever marketing; it is effective. But, ultimately, in this particular case it is misleading, fraudulent or even deceptive.

Our concern on a political level—as we found in the recent Queensland election with car stickers stating, `Voters are Smokers'—is that in supporting this legislation we may run the risk of offending people who smoke. I suppose that is a risk that many of us in this place have been prepared to take, for obvious reasons.

I want to make it clear that I have no particular criticism of tobacco users. I am not happy about people smoking near me or lighting up in a restaurant when I am at the table next to them. But, by and large, I do not have any criticism of their choice to smoke. It is, after all, as speakers in this debate have said, a legal product. For that reason, of course, people are free to choose to smoke if they want to, and rightly so. Actually, I suspect that it would not be legal if we had known years ago what we now know about the effect of tobacco not only on the health of those who use it but also, as we found out more recently, on the health of those who are exposed to it involuntarily—or passively, as it is more frequently known.

Unfortunately, it is not possible to ban it now. The argument that we have heard in the debate on both sides to some extent—if not in the Parliament, certainly behind the scenes—is that if we are really serious about this problem we ought to ban the product. That might well appeal to a lot of people but it is clearly impractical or impossible to do it now. Prohibition will not work.

However, we can discourage the use of tobacco. Indeed, as members of Parliament, we have an absolute responsibility to do that. Comprehensively banning advertising, which is a further step that this Bill takes, will achieve this. It will not prevent people from making a choice to use a legal product.

But let us be quite clear about one thing, because this is really the fundamental lie in the whole of this debate: advertising has only one purpose and that is to sell a product. This is so whether the advertising is incidental or not. Any argument to the contrary is clearly flawed. It is even difficult to take such an argument seriously.

Yet the argument that has been run before us by the tobacco companies time after time is that their largesse in the sponsorship of sporting activities is not to encourage people to take up smoking; not to encourage children who are exposed to the advertising to take up smoking. Those companies tell us that is not the reason at all. It is for some other obscure reason—for example, promoting brand awareness or encouraging people to change brands. That argument is absurd; it is not the case at all.

Others have spoken about the effect of cigarette smoking, and I am prepared to concede that there may be some doubt about the full extent of the statistics, but I am prepared to accept that since 1965 half a million Australians have died prematurely from diseases due to smoking. The cost to the nation of this has been incalculable, in my view. Clearly, tobacco smoking is the largest single preventable—and that is probably the operative word—cause of death and disease in Australia today.

We have been reminded about the number of deaths that have occurred in Australia in recent years. Significantly, most people who take up smoking adopt the habit before they reach the age of 20. I think that is a very telling statistic. My father, who smoked most of his life—and died, incidentally, prematurely—took up smoking during the war, when a lot of young men of his era did, and he could never stop smoking. I think it still is the case today that people who take up smoking do so at a very young age. I believe that we have a very real responsibility to make sure that children are protected from the advertising of tobacco products, incidental or otherwise.

I have that responsibility, not only as a member of Parliament doing my work in this place, but also for my own young children. I have never doubted that the tobacco industry's ultimate objective was to convince my children to take up smoking. I resolved long ago to resist that at all costs. Children, as others in this debate have said, are most easily influenced and they certainly are influenced, as the research has shown, by the association of certain sports and certain sports people with tobacco brands.

Fortunately, in this so-called enlightened age, we are becoming much more aware of the damage caused to children by what they see and hear on television. Recently, I am pleased to see, concerns have even been expressed, for the first time, about the advertising of certain products—particularly junk food products—during children's programs on television. I share those concerns and I expect that we are going to hear more about that issue in this place before too long.

The tobacco industry, as the honourable member for Kennedy pointed out, has campaigned strongly against this legislation. Some of its tactics, in my view, have been a little bit over the top. To some extent, because of this it has been successful. Fortunately, and the result of that is evident tonight, most members of this Parliament have not fallen for its propaganda. Clearly, in response to the overall declines in tobacco consumption in Australia, the tobacco companies are concerned. The tobacco industry has also enlisted the support of some of the sports which have accepted its sponsorship.

I want to say in closing that I received a copy of a letter—just one of many—that the Queensland Rugby Football League had written to Dr Hewson. I will not read the letter because I am quite sure I would embarrass Mr Livermore, the Managing Director of the QRFL, but the letter is quite threatening in its tone. It makes the point, at least in its final paragraph, that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the sport and racing lobby is much stronger and more powerful than the anti-groups and will prove it in future elections.

I was not asked to respond to Mr Livermore's letter, but he challenges, in this particular letter to Dr Hewson, that those who are going to vote in favour of this ban should be prepared to stand up and be counted. So I said to Mr Livermore:

I am sure, in due course, Dr Hewson will respond to your letter but I wanted to tell you, for my own part, that I strongly support the move to extend the ban on the advertising of tobacco products to incidental advertising and I am quite prepared to stand up and be counted on this matter at any time. There is no doubt in my mind that the cost of treating those who become ill through smoking is enormous. I am also quite sure my young children, one of whom plays Junior League, are influenced, however subtly, by incidental advertising.
I said a bit more and then I put in a PS to hopefully cheer him up a bit:
I hope the Gold Coast does better in `93. I will be there to encourage them.

I am pleased that the Opposition has chosen to support this legislation. I congratulate the Government for bringing it forward. Albeit that it is, in my view, deficient in some respects, it is certainly a step in the right direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of speakers have supported this legislation and the arguments that have been put forward are convincing and assuring. I think that, speaking at the end of the debate, one wonders what else there is that one can say. What I would like to do is comment briefly on some of the things that have been said by speakers in the debate and to make some personal observations.

PARA.TAB: I have been involved in anti-smoking campaigning since my days as a medical student. Indeed, as a student, my epidemiological study, which was undertaken back in 1975, was into the smoking habits of school children. That was undertaken with one of my colleagues, Dr Paul Magnus, who is now one of the principals of the National Heart Foundation and who has been a very strong advocate of this legislation and, of course, many anti-smoking measures. Then, during the 1970s, as a Sheffield Shield cricketer for Western Australia, I came under the influence of the cigarette companies in the sense that pressure was applied to endorse their products, to carry their bag, to wear the badges. I feel very proud that I resisted that pressure during that time.

I would like to make one or two comments about the contribution of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I think that he is right when he says that the figures are probably inflated. As in all of these arguments, there are hyperbolic figures put forward on both sides. I understand that these figures have been derived with the very best intentions by people, but my view would be that there is a cost and a benefit obtained from cigarette smoking. My view is that, clearly, the costs to our society are substantial, but I support the honourable member for Kalgoorlie in the sense that I think that sometimes the figures are used a little too zealously.

I would also put the view that, in respect of passive smoking, the evidence is not as convincing as it is in other areas. My view would be that the argument for restrictions on smoking in confined areas is a clear cut one which goes along the lines of, `If I do not want to have to inhale other people's smoke or the products of their smoking, then I should not have to'. Indeed, the rights of those who wish to breathe fresh air should be paramount.

So, in a restaurant, in a government building, in an airliner, or whatever the circumstance, the initiatives that have been taken by this Government have my wholehearted support. But in respect of the evidence regarding passive smoking, I would like to see more research. I remain to be thoroughly convinced as to some of the assertions that are made in that area. I have no doubt that it causes problems for people, but I think that perhaps some of the claims are hyperbolic.

In respect of the argument put by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie with regard to the fact that consumption of tobacco products was falling and yet advertising was still out there, I think there is a very good reason why that is the case. The reason is that for some time now, for almost 20 years, there have been substantial anti-smoking campaigns, anti-smoking education and anti-smoking measures taken by governments of various persuasions in this country and by various health bodies. So, that very well justifies the fact that, in spite of the advertising, there are now counter measures operating and so, it is not surprising that consumption has fallen.

In regard to his arguments about free speech, I would use exactly the same arguments in this debate as I used in the electoral advertising debate. It is quite clear that, when it comes to advertising, there is no such thing as freedom to advertise. Advertising is incredibly expensive and only people with large amounts of money have the opportunity to advertise on television and other media. There is no such thing as the freedom for me to put advertisements on those media, because I just do not have the resources. It is necessary for governments to look very closely at the sorts of advertisements, the sorts of measures that are being advertised, and for there to be a degree of regulation.

This legislation is perfectly consistent with the right and the role of Government in taking those moves. I will also comment on the remarks of the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls) who was perhaps unfairly critical of David Hill. David Hill's position on cigarette smoking has been a very consistent one and, I believe, a laudable one. While the rodeo is of great importance to the honourable member for Kennedy, I think it is clear that the advertisers, the cigarette companies, are really interested in the high profile sports, the sports that have massive media coverage, and the sports that have large numbers of spectators going through the gate. I think David Hill was right when he made those comments and the stance he took on his Rugby League Club was one of great principle.

The legislation is about reducing tobacco consumption. It is not about prohibition and it is not about banning these substances. As has been rightly pointed out by many honourable members in the chamber, more than three million Australians are addicted to these substances and the proposition of prohibition or banning the availability of these substances would be absurd. I would argue—and the shadow spokesman opposite has said—that if we look at deaths related to smoking, alcohol and other substance abuse, then the opiates, for instance, and substances such as marijuana which are illegal in our society have a very small impact. If we were to be internally consistent in our arguments, then it is very clear that we would not allow any of these substances to be advertised, but they would be freely available.

I know that is a very contentious view and I know that it is liable to be expanded on and `hyperbolised'—if that is a word that one can use—by the Opposition. There is great hypocrisy in respect of our position on substance abuse. There are very dangerous substances which are legal and available and substances which, I think one could fairly argue, are less dangerous and certainly have less effect on our community that are not available. That brings with it all of the difficulties of the criminal justice system, policing and imprisonment, and enormous costs to our society which relate to offences regarding those substances.

We have legislation in this country about whether or not we wear seat belts, we have legislation on gun laws and we have legislation about censorship. They are matters which are appropriate for governments to consider and there should be a degree of regulation. Exactly the same argument can be made in respect of the advertising of these products.

There are a mosaic of measures that we need to undertake in order to have an effect on tobacco consumption. Increasing taxation and increasing the price have been shown to have a very direct effect on consumption. It is necessary for us to have worthwhile and wide ranging education programs for our young people on the effects and dangers that relate to the use of these substances.

It is important for us to have regulation and control over the marketing of these substances. A range of measures have been introduced under this Government. Great credit goes to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples), who is at the table, for his enthusiasm and consistent pushing of these issues. We have had the banning of smoking on airlines and in government buildings, we have had legislation in respect of print advertising and we have had increases in excise. All these things will have, and have had, an effect on consumption. It is important for us to consider that we need to keep pushing and pushing on these things.

I believe that there are a number of reasons why people choose to smoke. As long as our society remains a liberal society, as I believe it is, we will have people who make the choice to smoke. It seems to me a very strange thing to want to do, but there are forces such as peer pressure, the example of parents and elders and of course advertising. As was rightly pointed out by the honourable member opposite, the whole ethos of advertising is that it increases the sale of products. By increasing the sale of products, the price can be dropped; so advertising justifies itself.

The suggestion that advertising is all about shifting brands—we have heard it time and time again in this debate—is completely absurd. The suggestion is that only the people who are already smokers see the advertisements and shift brands accordingly and the other 60 per cent of the population who are not already smokers are not influenced one jot by the advertising. I find that very hard to believe. I find it very hard to accept that cigarette companies spend large amounts of money on advertising and sponsorship without believing that they are in some way increasing the market. That is what underpins the whole ethos behind advertising.

One thing that has been brought into the argument many times is that sport will suffer. One of the loopholes following the 1976 legislation was that incidental advertising via sponsorship in sport was a way of getting products on television which were not legally able to be advertised on television any more. This represented an opportunity.

A lobbyist rang me this afternoon—I assumed that is who he was; after I had spoken to him for a few minutes he was not interested in talking any more—and suggested that the International Cricket Conference would isolate Australia, that it would be supported by tobacco companies to sponsor cricket overseas and Australia would suffer as a result. This is a great national game that has survived a couple of world wars, Kerry Packer, bodyline—you name it; it has got through it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Underarm bowling.
—Underarm bowling; I could go on and on.

PARA.TAB: An honourable member—Ric Charlesworth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I was very dull. When I played they found me very dull and boring. The suggestion that cricket will suffer is a red herring. It is a different argument. If this is worth doing, it is worth doing for its own merit. The argument about what will happen to sports is a separate argument that we have to deal with. That is the position that the Government, the Minister and sensible people have taken in respect of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I well remember the pressures that were applied to me when I went to receive my Benson and Hedges Sheffield Shield medal after Western Australia had won yet again, as we usually did and still do. The association with Benson and Hedges was not anything to do with altruism, with trying to change brands or with the cigarette company's love of cricket; it was a commercial enterprise. It was there and it was undertaken because the company was hopeful of increasing its market size.

I am delighted with this legislation. It may well be that this is the second last day I spend in this place. If that is the case, the passing of this legislation and the opportunity to speak on this Bill is something of which I can be proud. I hope that members of this House will all support this legislation, as I believe the majority will.

I said at the beginning of the debate that some of the figures that are quoted are perhaps a little over the top. But in my time of practising medicine, particularly in the first years, I spent two 10-week sessions in the chest ward of the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital. One did not need to look at the large picture to get an impression when working in that environment of the effects of cigarette smoking. The common factor amongst all the patients in that chest ward—or maybe 90 per cent of them—was cigarette smoking. Irrespective of whether they were being treated for emphysema, chronic obstructive airways disease, lung cancer, asthma or some other condition, the common factor amongst those patients whose condition was serious enough for them to be in hospital and to incur the expense that related to their being there was cigarette smoking.

One only has to see people who are immobilised by oxygen debt to the extent that they cannot laugh at one's jokes because they become short of breath; that going to the bathroom, which may be only five metres away, causes them to be short of breath; or that they cannot pick up one of their children because it causes them to be short of breath, to know that cigarette smoking has been a pernicious killer in our society. This is good legislation and it deserves our support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Governments have an essential role in creating a just and equitable society. I believe in government regulation and intervention, for without it the inequities inherent in our society will continue to flourish. Governments are elected to govern, not to sit back and be spectators.

PARA.TAB: I am delighted to support the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill 1992. This legislation is in the public interest. Tobacco companies are merchants of death. They promote cancer sticks, which lead to people dying before their time. Just as random breath testing has been hailed as a progressive move that has led to the saving of lives in Australia, time will see this legislation heralded as legislation that leads to Australian citizens and others leading better lives and living longer.

This is important legislation and it is important that it receive bipartisan support, as it has. It is an absolute delight to be able to get up and support this sort of legislation in this Parliament. My only regret is that I would like it to go even further.

Recently I received a letter from Stephen Leeder, Professor of Public Health and Community Medicine in the Department of Public Health at the University of Sydney, dated 2 December 1992. It is worth reading:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Melham,
The recent Caucus decision to support the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill is good news for Australian children.
Please find enclosed a study of childhood smoking which my colleagues and I conducted in Newcastle some years ago.
Several factors emerged in the uptake, maintenance and quitting of smoking by 10-12 year old children.

Those children who approved of cigarette advertising at even this young age, were more likely to take up smoking during the following year or continue smoking if they were smoking already, or less likely to quit if they were smokers, than children who did not approve of cigarette advertising. That cigarette advertising does influence children's smoking behaviour has been confirmed by other Australian and international studies.
In a letter to the Medical Journal of Australia this year, we have estimated that tobacco advertising might be responsible for as much as 14% of the uptake of smoking by children.
Smoking by Australian schoolchildren in the future will, I am sure, be reduced because of your action. Congratulations on being part of this historic decision.

Stephen Leeder was the co-author of a study called Cigarette smoking and drug use in schoolchildren: IV—factors associated with changes in smoking behaviour, which was published in 1983. The study involved approximately 6,000 school children between 10 and 12 years of age. In their study, the authors describe changes which occurred in smoking behaviour over the one-year period of a randomised control trial. They discovered that children who approved of cigarette advertising were twice as likely to become smokers as children who disapproved. Children who disapproved of cigarette advertising were more likely to quit than those who approved of it.

PARA.TAB: In a subsequent letter to a medical journal in 1992, they pointed out—admittedly it was only an estimate—that some 14 per cent of young children would take up smoking as a result of advertising. They extrapolated the figures from the New South Wales Cancer Council, which estimated that in 1990 almost 74,000 New South Wales school children between 12 and 17 years of age had smoked in a particular week. The authors of the letter found that about 10,000 of those children would have taken up smoking as a result of advertising, and that is pretty worrying.

There is another interesting article that I commend to members, and it was printed in the Journal of Drug Issues in June 1992. The article is headed `Tobacco in Australia: An Overview'. It goes through the history of tobacco in Australia. The article commences with the following:

SPEECH.PARA: Tobacco smoking is the largest single preventable cause of death and disease in Australia today. Smoking is estimated to have caused 19,899 deaths in Australia in 1991, nearly six times the number of road crash fatalities. Of drug-caused deaths, 75 per cent are due to tobacco, 23 per cent are due to alcohol (including road crash fatalities) and 2 per cent are due to opiates.
The authors go on to give a short history. They say:

In 1972, for the first time, a mandatory health warning was required on cigarette packages and paid cigarette advertising on radio and television was phased out between 1973 and 1976. These restrictions were anticipated by the tobacco industry, and it developed strategies to circumvent the effect of such proposals. The minutes of a Rothmans management meeting held in November of 1970 give a clear indication of their thinking at that time.
The minutes of that meeting state:

Discussing smoking and health, Mr Watson [then general manager] advised that we can expect more severe attacks on the industry in the near future. In Canada and the USA, advertising restrictions are pending, and in the UK, there is no cigarette advertising other than press. We can expect similar restrictions here within the next few years. This is the reason for the existence of the Rothmans National Sport Foundations and our sponsorships which are being developed in anticipation of restrictive advertising action in Australia (Rothmans of Pall Mall Australia Pty Ltd 1970).
The article continues:

The continued broadcast exposure for tobacco companies gained through sport and cultural sponsorship, and the relative ineffectiveness of the early health warning legislation, made these initial controls little more than an inconvenience to the industry . . .
That is why there is a need for this legislation before the Parliament this evening. As for future directions, the authors conclude by saying:
Removal of vestigial tobacco advertising from television screens via sponsored sporting events is an obvious priority.

That is what we are doing here tonight and why we should be applauded. That is why current surveys show that this measure is popular in the community. It is popular because the people out there in the real world know that the tobacco companies have been peddling lies for years and living on borrowed time.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) made a number of pertinent points in his second reading speech that are worth repeating. He said basically that advertising has the effect of persuading children to take up an addictive, life-threatening habit. He continues:

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to understand that removing tobacco advertising is primarily a prevention activity intended to reduce the number of children taking up smoking. Although advertising may not directly cause children to smoke, it reinforces other influences such as peer and social pressures which cause children to smoke. Tobacco advertisements glamorise smoking, making it seem like a desirable activity.
Further on in his speech he states:
Tobacco advertising in association with sport is particularly insidious as it seeks to link an unhealthy product with a healthy activity.
Here is the nub of it:
Sponsorship of sporting and cultural activities has been exploited as an effective form of tobacco advertising.
The Minister says:
This Bill will break the nexus between tobacco and sport and between tobacco and cultural activities.
Hear, hear!

PARA.TAB: A sponsor's name or logo may be recognised for up to one-third of the broadcast time of a major sporting event. In 1983 Winfield was identifiable during 33 per cent of the broadcast of the New South Wales rugby league grand final; in 1987 Benson and Hedges was identifiable during 32 per cent of a one-day cricket broadcast; and in 1989 Marlboro was identifiable during 35 per cent of the Adelaide grand prix broadcast. What a joke! What an absolute joke! The most significant study, in my view, was undertaken in 1984. The most popular brands of cigarettes amongst 12- to 14-year-old children coincided with the major sponsor of the State football code.

In New South Wales, Winfield had the giant market share; in Victoria, it was Peter Jackson; and in South Australia, it was Escort. The tobacco companies were not doing this out of the goodness of their hearts; they were doing this to peddle and promote their product which, in my opinion, resulted in people dying before their time and young children taking up smoking in unacceptable numbers.

Who can forget the launching of Winfield onto the Australian market, the linking of that product with Paul Hogan, who was reasonably popular back then, and the market share that Winfield enjoyed at the time? The promotion of Winfield, and the taking up of Winfield by young children at that time, is testament to the impact of advertising. The tobacco companies were not doing it out of the goodness of their hearts, but their time has come. This legislation is historic legislation. Unfortunately, it does not go far enough; it should go further.

In time, the community will demand that we as politicians respond and go further. It is interesting that if it were left to the Opposition, whilst there is bipartisan support here this evening, this sort of legislation would not be introduced into the Parliament. The reason there is bipartisan support is not because of the shadow ministry—to his great credit, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) has championed this legislation from the very beginning—but because the shadow Cabinet got rolled by the back bench. It was exposed by Michelle Grattan in the Age of 27 November 1992. The article was headed, `Hewson rolled over tobacco ad sponsorship' and stated:

The Opposition leader, Dr Hewson, and the shadow ministry were rolled in the coalition party room last night over a recommendation to oppose legislation to ban tobacco advertising and sport sponsorship.

The shadow ministry, which was deeply divided, decided by a narrow margin to propose to the party room that the legislation—which was already assured of passing because of Democrat support—should be opposed.
But at the meeting, about 16 of 26 speakers spoke in favour of the legislation.

The shadow cabinet then met. After discussion, Dr Hewson told the party room the numbers were close, and people held strong views on both sides. He said neither view was more valid than the other. The shadow cabinet had, on balance, decided to reconsider its position and recommend that the legislation should be supported.

SPEECH.PARA: Further on, the article states:
Party sources said that four or five parliamentarians would have crossed the floor if the decision had been to oppose the legislation.

It is relevant to put that on the public record, just as it is relevant that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) is here during this debate. If the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) had not done a U-turn on his Fightback package, which he is announcing in its full detail on Friday, there would have been another party room revolt and the honourable member for Bennelong would have been leading the Opposition at the next Federal election.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition has been done over by the back bench on this legislation, he has been done over by the party room in relation to Fightback and that is why he has rolled over. He still holds his ideological position, but he has rolled over. At the next election the people will judge him accordingly. I much prefer the honourable member for Wentworth as the Leader of the Opposition than the honourable member for Bennelong. I do not want him around a second time.

This legislation is worthy of support. It has been a long time coming but we can be proud of it. We should not allow tobacco companies to hold the sword of Damocles over our head and hide behind sporting advertisements, as they have done for so long. This legislation is in the public interest and it is great to be able to get up here tonight and support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to participate in this debate, but I should declare to the House that I am a consultant in a Sydney law firm that has amongst its clients the Tobacco Institute of Australia and one or two of the very large tobacco companies. That has not in any way influenced my attitude on this issue. I have personally not done any work for those organisations, but I think, in the interests of more abundant disclosure, the House should be aware of that fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the lead of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), I also declare my interest in this debate. My family has been selling tobacco and cigarettes since 1897 and continues to do so. For the record, we are still in there selling them, but I am voting with the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls) summed up much of what I wanted to say in response to the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods), and I will leave it at that. The Government does not claim that tobacco advertising is the only factor influencing people to smoke. There are many reasons, such as parental example, sibling and peer smoking behaviour and attitudes, price, disposable income and age.

PARA.TAB: By this legislation the Government is signalling clearly to the community that it is taking further positive action to reduce tobacco consumption by reducing its appeal or limiting the opportunity for exposing so-called appeal, particularly to younger people. Most smokers at different times would prefer to give up smoking. Most smokers certainly do not want younger people and kids to be

SPEECH.PARA: influenced to take it up. I think it is important to recognise that this legislation does not in any way penalise smokers. In fact, I am sure it will help many of them.

PARA.TAB: The tobacco industry and its advocates—some in the community and some in the media—have been very quick to criticise the Government, alleging hypocrisy in cracking down on tobacco consumption on the one hand and levying excise on tobacco on the other. I think that was part of what the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) and others were referring to.

I think most people are now aware of the economic study by two Sydney economists, David Collins and Helen Lapsley. They conservatively estimated the net economic cost of tobacco use and abuse in Australia at about $6.8 billion in 1988. There is also a net cost to the Federal Budget, as there is to State Budgets. What has to be understood by John Laws, Terry Vine and a few of the others who seem to make a welter of this for some unknown reason is that there are great economic, social and personal costs to the Australian community in net terms of anything that governments may try to regain through taxation excise of the real costs of this industry to Australia.

When we look at this issue in a very broad sense—and if we listen to what the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, for one, was saying—we see that there are many issues of great health importance to Australia, and tobacco is one of them. By this legislation we do not deny that other things have to be done, whether it be with alcohol abuse, asbestos, hepatitis B, diabetes or analgesics.

One of the things the honourable member for Kalgoorlie spoke about was freedom of speech. The whole process this Parliament has as part of our heritage and democracy means that people like the honourable member for Kalgoorlie can get up and rave on, as he did, using any form of words or any sort of argument or abuse that he cared to pour out and still have that freedom of speech. This legislation does not take that away from anyone. I hope that he makes himself a bit more aware of what this Government and other governments in Australia are trying to do in a lot of those other areas that he mentioned. As I said, this legislation does not take away from any of those other issues.

Probably the most perennial furphy promoted by tobacco apologists and interests is that, if tobacco is a legal product, then it should be legal to advertise it for sale. It is not legal to sell tobacco to children. It is not a legal product for children, yet children have been exposed to what is effectively tobacco advertising through so-called accidental and incidental advertising.

We all know what a fraudulent activity that had become. Other products which are also legally available for sale in Australia have been banned from being advertised, notably guns and prescription drugs, amongst the probably many hundreds of different items on the market in Australia. Given the detrimental effects of tobacco, which are now well recognised internationally, it is highly unlikely that any government in the world would permit its sale if it were a new product on the market. Tobacco is simply an accident of history and a very bad accident. Some have advocated that if the Government were serious it should ban tobacco outright. We recognise in this country and in many other countries today that the prohibition of social drugs such as tobacco is not practical and really does not work in itself; but allowing it to be promoted through advertising is a very different issue.

Another furphy promoted by the tobacco industry is that tobacco ads are aimed solely at adults. They would have us believe that some barrier exists which prevents children from digesting a smoking advertisement of whatever form. Whereas adults are magically vulnerable and should be able to be appealed to through tobacco advertising, children are somehow not influenced. That is absolute rubbish, as any advertising person would know.

It has been estimated that about three-quarters of current adult smokers began smoking during or before their teenage years. In Australia, children are the future of the tobacco industry as it would see the future. They are one of the major targets of its advertising; it is nothing short of that. Learning to smoke occurs in childhood and in adolescence. If a person is still a non-smoker by the age of 20, he or she is very unlikely to take it up.

It is also said that tobacco advertising does not encourage people to start smoking but rather encourages people to change brands. That is arrant nonsense as well. Tobacco interests would have us believe that cigarettes run contrary to all other products when it comes to advertising. In the words of an Australian advertising agency executive:

SPEECH.PARA: As an argument (that tobacco advertising is only aimed at brand switching and not attracting new consumers) it is so preposterous it is insulting . . . To claim that cigarette advertising does not encourage smoking flies in the face of all advertising knowledge and experience.
This view was supported by Emerson Foote, former Chairman of one of the world's leading advertising agencies, who said:

This is the public position of the tobacco industry but I don't think anyone really believes this. I am not even convinced that competition among brands is the most important purpose of such advertising. I suspect that creating a positive climate of social acceptability for smoking, which encourages new smokers to join the market, is of greater importance to the industry.

The Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Bill 1992 is regarded as one of the most significant pieces of public health legislation introduced in many a year. I now turn to the point raised by the honourable member for Kennedy in his contribution to this debate. The State governments which do not have organisations such as health promotion foundations and still receive benefits from tobacco excise need to take the lead of the former Victorian Government which started not only a national but also an international trend when it set up a health promotion foundation to support the encouragement of good health practices in Australia by the use of tobacco excise and also to support sport and arts which are currently hooked on tobacco sponsorship to enable them to prosper and improve.

PARA.TAB: Another point I wish to raise at this stage concerns alcohol. Alcohol abuse is a major problem in this country; one which in terms of cost to the Australian community rivals tobacco abuse. It has many other implications for our society beyond the 6,000 or so deaths that are caused directly through alcohol abuse in Australia every year. The consultative and advisory processes that I have set up with the alcohol industry are recognised as unique in the world. I hope that the industry understands the importance of those consultative mechanisms. Quite frankly, the Australian community—I know that many honourable members view the matter exactly as I do and that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) is very keenly attuned to this—is very concerned about the problems of alcohol abuse.

It will do the alcohol industry no good if sections of it adopt a dog in a manger attitude, an opportunistic attitude, when it comes to alcohol advertising and labelling. Those sections are currently under scrutiny by the community and by people in governments right around Australia to make sure that they keep their side of the bargain when it comes to alcohol advertising and labelling. In particular, I commend one section of the alcohol industry—that is, the wine industry—which has shown itself to be a little different from the brewers and distillers side of the industry. At this stage the wine industry has been far more cooperative when it comes to the issue of standard drink labelling than those other two sections.

The alcohol industry has to understand that public opinion is very concerned about alcohol abuse, particularly among young people. People expect the alcohol industry not to take the attitude of the tobacco industry, but to recognise that it needs to be far more responsible than it has been recently in response to community concerns expressed through government. I hope that the industry recognises that.

In closing, I thank my colleague the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) for her support and involvement in this process, which in many regards has been a difficult one for her. I appreciate it very much. I would also like to thank the following people: Steve Woodward from ASH; Dr Robert Marr; people from medical associations around Australia such as the AMA, the RACGP and others; Rhonda Galbaly; Ron Casey; Nigel Gray; and also members of anti-cancer councils around Australia. I would also like to thank David Hill and other people involved in sport, including Lindsay Gaze and many other sports men and women of Australia, who have stood up for a long time on this issue. Sports men and women in basketball, soccer, surfing, hockey and AFL and other people such as Bob Jane have gone a long way towards breaking that nexus between tobacco and sport.

I also want to recognise the work of Senator Janet Powell for the way she approached this issue when she was in the Australian Democrats and Leader of the Australian Democrats. I sincerely commend her for the work that she has done over many years. Likewise, I recognise the work of the Australian Democrats in the Senate, particularly Senator Meg Lees.

As we have seen in the debate, this issue crosses political barriers. It also raises other debates. But I want to close by thanking the other members who have contributed, particularly the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth)—not only a great Australian olympian and sportsman but also someone who, as a doctor, has contributed to debates on sport—the honourable member for Kennedy and the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham). With regard to those on the other side, the contributions by the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus) and the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) were excellent and very much appreciated. I commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Staples) read a third time.
Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration in Committee of the Whole House forthwith.
Senate's amendments—

PROCTEXT.PARA: No. 1—Clause 6, page 4, after proposed subsection 25(4), insert the following subsection:

TAB.TAB: "`(4A) The Agreement must provide for the amount of hospital bonus payment payable to a State under the hospital bonus component to be reviewed each time the percentage of the national population who, at 30 June 1993, are covered by a supplementary hospital table falls by at least 2 percentage points or a multiple thereof.

Note 1:If the percentage of the national population at 30 June 1993 who are covered by a supplementary hospital table is x%, then a review would be triggered under this section if the rate drops to (x-2)%.

Note 2:Subsequent review during the life of the Agreement would be triggered by additional drops of 2 percentage points over the base established at 30 June 1993. That is, if the percentage of the national population at 30 June 1993 who are covered by a supplementary hospital table subsequently drops to (x-4)%, this would trigger another review. Similarly, drops to (x-6)%, (x-8)% etc. would trigger further reviews.".

PROCTEXT.PARA: No. 2—Clause 6, page 4, at end of proposed section 25, add the following subsection:

TAB.TAB: "`(6) In calculating the percentage of the national population who are covered by a supplementary hospital table at any time, regard must be had to the data published by the Private Health Insurance Administration Council.".

PROCTEXT.PARA: No. 3—Clause 8, page 9, proposed Schedule 2A, after Head of Agreement 7, insert the following Head of Agreement:

TAB.TAB: "7A.The Agreement is to provide for the Commonwealth and the State to agree, during the first year of the Agreement, on national health goals and targets and a timetable for their continuing development and implementation over the life of the Agreement.".

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Howe) proposed:
That the amendments be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed amendments relate to the Medicare Agreements Bill. That Bill has been debated in this chamber in some detail before. I will not take the time of the Committee by going through yet again the details of our various points of view. Those views are recorded in Hansard. In essence, those views are that the Medicare Agreements Bill is a nonsense.

PARA.TAB: It is a Bill which will reduce funding to the two most populous States, New South Wales and Victoria, where 60 per cent of the population resides, by a total of something like $1.2 billion over the next five years. Recently, the Government made some minor financial gestures in bringing forward some of the funding to those States. They are, however, minor gestures. They do not resolve any of the problems. They do not address any of the underlying reforms that are needed by Medicare. They do not resolve the problems facing our great public hospital system.

Medicare is still in crisis and will remain in crisis in relation to the public hospital system as a result of this Bill. These amendments are simply a way of trying to get this piece of legislation through the Parliament as quickly as possible. It does not need to be completed until 1 July next year. The amendments change the situation only very slightly.

In essence, the amendments require a review of the funding of public hospitals whenever there is a fall in the private health insurance rates by some 2 per cent. They provide for a definition of how to assess that 2 per cent. They also insist upon a setting of national goals and targets for the health arena over the next year or two.

The latter is something that we have supported for some time. We have been critical of the Government for not having a decent set of national goals and targets—a realistic, worthwhile set of targets which really mean something. I am delighted to see that the Government has now been dragged screaming towards agreeing to set those targets, and I congratulate the Democrats for their initiative in this regard.

In terms of the provision relating to the 2 per cent fall in private health insurance, clearly whenever the incidence of private health insurance falls those people who were previously covered under the private health insurance schemes will move into the public system. That is one of the reasons why Medicare is creaking and groaning at the edges as it is now, in as much as something like 25 per cent of the population who, prior to this Government taking over, used to provide for themselves now rely on the public system, and yet the funding for the public system has not increased significantly at all. That is the reason why there are waiting lists and why the system is creaking and groaning at the edges.

But these changes address those problems only very slightly. The Bill itself is still fatally flawed. We are opposed to the whole Bill, as indeed remain the governments of New South Wales and Victoria where, as I said, some 60 per cent of the population resides. However, I will not take up more of the Committee's time in going through the details of the problems of the Bill. They have all been enumerated very clearly and carefully on a previous occasion and, sadly, the Government has chosen not to address them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill that has been amended has, as the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) indicated, been amended only quite slightly. The issue of national goals and targets had indeed been canvassed and it was agreed that they would form an important part of the Medicare agreement. The course of this agreement will see those national goals and targets developed so that we can move to a situation where we will be able to measure performance in terms of the impact of measures that we take, whether it is in the health system or in terms of public health with respect to the well-being of the population. That is a very significant move forward.

PARA.TAB: Of course, in regard to Medicare agreements, this legislation represents a setting out of issues of principle that are spelled out and will be reflected in reciprocal legislation. The agreements with the States will provide an opportunity to particularly address issues of access but also to provide funds for a number of incentive payments which will do a great deal to improve the health system in this country, particularly the hospital system.

A great deal has been said about the issue of health insurance and private health insurance. It was implicit in the introduction of Medicare that there would be a significant fall in private insurance. That occurred. Over recent years there has been a rather slower but nevertheless appreciable drop in the numbers of people who have private insurance. That is inevitable, given the fact that we have universal health insurance that not only goes to primary health care but also is a foundation of a great deal of the funding that we provide for the hospital system in this country. Since the introduction of Medicare the Government has provided very significant funds at the national level—something of the order of $4 billion—but in this legislation we are indicating that over the next five years there will be a significant increase in public funding. That is on top of indexation. That was negotiated as part of the 1988 agreement. It is a special index that reflects factors in the hospital system and also the ageing of the population.

The additional funds that are being provided represent a significant real increase in funds from the Commonwealth to the States over the life of the agreement. Notwithstanding the remarks of the honourable member for Lowe, the reality is that no State will lose as a result of the new Medicare agreement. The bonus system will operate in a way in keeping with the understanding that I think was very much present in the meeting of health Ministers in April, and in subsequent discussions with health Ministers; that is, that the Commonwealth will seek to ensure that, where there was a need for additional public patients to be cared for, no State would be disadvantaged by that trend. That is the way that the bonus system will operate to provide additional assistance to States where they incur additional costs because of an increase in the number of public patients within the public hospital system.

There is no intention in terms of this legislation to move away from the situation where people have the choice to opt, within the public hospital system, to be private patients or public patients. But there is certainly made explicit in this legislation what has always been implicit within Medicare, and that is that people should be admitted to a hospital system essentially on the basis of clinical need, not on the basis of their insurance status or their financial status.

That is the reason why we have introduced into this Bill the concept of a hospital charter, so that it is made much more explicit, much more clear what people's rights are within the public hospital system in this country. I think that by that mechanism, we are pointing to not only the need to provide additional resources, which we are certainly doing this year to reduce waiting times, but also to ensure that, when people do need to wait for hospital treatment, the rules are made transparent, that people are clear as to how the system is operating, who controls the system and, indeed, that we get some national consistency in terms of the way that we describe waiting lists, the way that they are calculated.

We have asked the Institute of Health and Welfare Data, in its capacity as a body that operates with the cooperation of the States and State health departments, to develop an approach to defining and measuring waiting lists. A great deal is said about the numbers waiting, but the reality is that we have very little hard information. I think that is regrettable. At a national level, that information should be collected by a body such as the Institute of Health and Welfare Data.

As I indicated, the changes were to pick up something which we had canvassed with Health Ministers and agreed would be part of this new health agreement in terms of goals and targets. It picks up the concept of a review, where there is a movement of the order of 2 per cent in terms of fall in private insurance. That was also something that had essentially been canvassed with the States in terms of the agreements that flow out of this legislation. For that reason the Government had no difficulty in picking up these amendments. I commend the amendments and the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration in Committee of the Whole House forthwith.
Senate's amendments—

No. 2—Clause 3, page 2, proposed paragraph 106J(2)(b), line 14, after "protecting", insert "certain".
No. 3—Clause 3, page 3, proposed subsection 106K(1), definition of "quality assurance activity", subparagraph (a)(ii), line 7, omit "2", substitute "3".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill 1992, which has come back from the Senate, relates to quality assurance and giving provisions for freedom from immunity for people participating in that particular process. This particular issue was canvassed in some detail in this chamber on a previous occasion, so I do not propose to go into any great details.

PARA.TAB: The amendments, in essence, have watered down the Minister's discretion in regard to the information that should be disclosed during a QA investigation. The Opposition's view was that the discretion should not be watered down but should be completely removed, because we were fearful that as it remains, perhaps not quite as seriously as it was originally but still even as it remains, it will undermine the whole aim of the legislation. Moss Cass has put it very well. He said that health care professionals have been encouraged, under the protection of the legislation, to openly and fully discuss the care they have provided to various patients, even admitting deficiencies which can be recognised with the wisdom of hindsight. In that way, it is hoped that the quality assurance process can improve the quality of care which always has a mixture of both science and art.

If the ministerial discretion remains in the Bill and doctors are treated in the way that patients expect to be treated—by being fully informed of all the implications of a course of action or treatment, with failures; or statutory immunity with its possible retrospective removal—how many doctors are likely to participate in the quality assurance process for which statutory immunity has been provided? I guess the answer is, sadly, all too few. If, through fear, doctors and other health care professionals decline to participate—and they cannot be forced to—then I guess the answer to the question of where we are is exactly where we are now, and that is, in many regards, nowhere.

So if there is suspicion that a misjudgment might have occurred, everyone closes ranks and no-one knows anything about what might have happened. This is seen over and over again in court cases where patients endeavour to gain compensation for what they consider to be medical mistakes. Mistakes are made and it can only help to be able to discuss them and to learn rather than bury them and hope no-one finds out. Sadly, the situation as presented back to the House from the other place is not going to resolve this particular problem. If we do not understand how the mistakes are made, we are doomed to continue to repeat them.

This legislation as it stands will prevail over all the States, and quality assurance process with statutory immunity—which is very slow getting under way because of the nervousness of doctors being allayed—will grind to a halt all over the country. Future patients will sadly be the most significant losers as inappropriate treatment is undertaken without the benefit of peer review.

I appreciate of course that for the large part of this legislation there will be a very sensible Minister for health making those decisions, so hopefully the problem will not arise. But for a short time, at least, we will be under the aegis of the current Minister, the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe), and the problem is that the ministerial discretion may not be used appropriately or, more importantly, it may be feared that it will not be used appropriately. It is the fear rather than the actual use which is important in this situation.

So sadly again we are of the view that this is inadequate legislation. It will not actually meet the aims which it tries to, aims which are very laudable, aims which we support. It has been undermined by that particular clause 106N and the amendments to that particular clause water down and improve the situation only slightly; they do not resolve the underlying problems.
