SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill makes changes to provisions of division 4B of the Migration Act, which deals with the custody of people who come to Australia by boat without prior authorisation. The changes proposed are interim measures until the commencement of the relevant provisions of the proposed Migration Reform Act 1992 in November 1993, which establishes a new and simplified regime for dealing with all unlawful persons, irrespective of their mode of entry to Australia.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members may recall that in May this year I presented a Bill to the House designed to ensure that people who arrive in Australia by boat without prior authorisation remain in custody until they leave Australia or are granted an entry permit. I believed then, and I continue to believe, that only those granted authority to enter should be permitted to move into the general community, and that a clear signal be sent that entry into the Australian community cannot be achieved simply by arriving here.

Aspects of division 4B were challenged in the High Court, which recently handed down its judgment validating the custody regime it sets out. I applaud this very valuable decision, which clearly affirms the Government's right to maintain control over Australia's borders for the protection of the community as a whole.

The High Court decision did, however, uncover doubts as to the validity of custody under section 88 of the Migration Act, in which most boat people were held before the commencement of the amended legislation on 6 May 1992. Section 88, which formed part of the major 1989 amendments to the Migration Act, replicates a longstanding provision in the earlier legislation. A majority of the judges held that detention ceased to be lawful under section 88 after the destruction of the boat on which the person arrived or in other circumstances making the boat unavailable for the person's departure. While most of the boats on which the people in section 88 custody arrived remain in existence, including the two boats on which the 37 plaintiffs before the High Court travelled to Australia, there is nonetheless considerable uncertainty now surrounding the lawfulness of section 88 custody.

This uncertainty turns not on the central issue of unauthorised arrival, but on the haphazard fate of the boat on which the people travelled. Should custody have become unlawful, it is as a result of a technical breach. This has created an artificial situation when the fact of the matter is that the boat people arrived in Australia unlawfully and their detention was based on our understanding of the provisions of section 88 at the time.

Lawyers for the boat people are now publicly discussing compensation for unlawful detention, and already applications have been lodged in the High Court on behalf of some of the detainees. While our assumptions about the operation of section 88 may have been misplaced, and the High Court has offered important guidance on this, the issue still remains to be tested in numerous cases. In the case of one boat, for example, the people were rescued at sea by the Royal Australian Navy as their boat foundered. They were brought into Darwin on HMAS Townsville. One passenger who was rescued described their relief at being rescued in last Saturday's Weekend Australian. There must now be serious doubt about the custody of this group. It would be ironic if those rescued could now sue the Commonwealth for the privilege. Some 300 boat people in all are potentially affected. It is possible that, were a court to find for these people, the Commonwealth could be ordered to pay a very considerable sum by way of compensation.

I believe that it is essential to counter the possibility of significant damages claims. It would be absurd for the Australian taxpayer to be expected to underwrite compensation payments to people who had arrived here without authority and who had been detained on reasonable grounds while their claims to remain were exhaustively examined. This Bill, therefore, introduces a provision which limits any compensation payable to an amount of $1 per day for any period of detention which a court of competent jurisdiction finds to have been unlawful. This will apply to all designated persons under division 4B of the Migration Act, including those who have already commenced proceedings against the Commonwealth for damages in relation to claimed unlawful custody.

In addition, this Bill seeks to put beyond doubt certain aspects of the custody scheme that are embodied in division 4B of the Migration Act, in line with the guiding philosophy of that scheme—namely, that designated persons remain in custody until granted an entry permit or removed, subject only to the proviso that the processing of entry applications must be completed within the time frame set down in the legislation.

Specifically, the Bill introduces a provision to put it beyond doubt that custody is to continue between the negative determination of an entry application and the removal of the applicant. While removal must be effected as soon as practicable after the entry application is refused and all appeals against, or reviews of, the refusal have been finalised, there are inevitable lead times in procuring travel documents and making associated arrangements. It is essential that there be legislative authority for continued custody through this period.

The Bill also introduces a provision to extend the permissible period of custody where an entry application decision is reopened by an unfavourable ruling of the courts. This Bill provides that the period known as `application custody', which is limited to 273 days and which is intended to ensure that a decision is taken by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs within that period, excludes any period of reconsideration following an adverse court ruling. The Bill provides an additional 90 days for each such reconsideration.

The Bill also provides that the institution of proceedings in relation to unlawful custody does not prevent the Government from detaining or removing designated persons during the course of such proceedings. This Bill makes it plain that a stay order against removal may not be issued to allow an applicant to remain in Australia during the course of such proceedings.

Finally, this Bill extends the coverage of the existing provisions under division 4B to include people arriving by boat on or after 1 December 1992 until the commencement of the new measures contained in the proposed Migration Reform Act 1992, which was passed recently by this Parliament. When division 4B was enacted in May this year, it was envisaged that the planned Migration Reform Act would commence on 1 December 1992 and, therefore, the amendments related only to boat people arriving before that date. As the relevant provisions of the proposed Migration Reform Act will not now commence until 1 November 1993, it is essential to extend the existing custody provisions to cover people arriving on or after 1 December 1992, but before 1 November 1993. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992, the passage of which is being facilitated by the Opposition, is an important piece of legislation designed to ensure that the provisions of the Migration Act, which were enacted last May, are valid. These deal with asylum seekers and their continued detention until claims for refugee status have been considered and an entry permit granted as a result of that, or their removal from Australia is effected. The legislation that was enacted at that time had the cooperation of the Opposition. This legislation has the cooperation of the Opposition and has been the subject of certain comment in the courts.

PARA.TAB: I take the opportunity tonight to deal with certain matters that have arisen in relation to the case of Chu Kheng Lim and others and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand). In this case, the Full Court of the High Court of Australia has determined that the sections of the Migration Act in division 2, namely sections 54L and 54N, dealing with the continued detention of certain asylum seekers were valid. The Court thus accepted that the legislative power bestowed by section 51(xix) of the Australian Constitution confers upon the Executive authority to detain an alien in custody for the purposes of expulsion or deportation, together with incidental authority to detain aliens to investigate and determine an application for an entry permit and, after determination, to admit or deport such an alien.

That overall schema that we approved of in the previous legislation was obviously upheld in that landmark case. Even though other aspects of the provisions were brought into question, the fact is that the basic framework of law for dealing with aliens was upheld in this particular legislation.

As I have mentioned, it will be recalled that division 4B was incorporated into the Act as a result of amendments enacted on 5 May shortly before Federal Court proceedings were brought by a number of Khmer asylum seekers who were seeking release from detention. While it is now clear that the legislation was effective in validating ongoing detention, a number of other questions have arisen. Some of these are a result of comment by members of the Bench in what I would think is obiter because it was not necessary that these matters be determined other than for the purposes of dismissing their relevance in determining the ongoing custody. Nevertheless, the court offered some guidance.

It appears that a number of the asylum seekers may have been unlawfully in custody under section 88 of the Act from the time they first entered Australia until the amendment that we enacted in May was put in place. It is also possible, as the Minister has alluded to tonight, that if they were held unlawfully, a claim for damages could arise.

The defect in section 88, which has given rise to this possibility, was discussed by a number of the judges in the judgments. I note that in the joint judgment of Justices Brennan, Deane and Dawson at pages 15 and 16 the question of the unlawful custody under section 88 is discussed. Mr Justice Toohey raised that matter again at pages 38 to 40, and Mr Justice McHugh at pages 61 to 63 dealt with the same matter.

It was clear that each of the judges came to the view that the detention initially is authorised only until the departure of a vessel carrying an alien from Australia or until such earlier time as an authorised officer directs. The fact is that, as a result of these comments by members of the bench, a number of particular issues have now been raised in relation to a number of the asylum seekers. I must say it is the first time that I have seen reference to the possibility that some 300 of the 400 or 500 detained may be affected by this decision.

For the purposes of elucidating the important principles involved, I shall read some sections of what Mr Justice McHugh had to say in his judgment dealing with the detention of asylum seekers. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Before dealing with the validity of Div. 4B, it is convenient to refer to the detention of the plaintiffs before the Amendment Act was passed.

PARA.TAB: The source of power to detain the plaintiffs in custody before the Amendment Act was passed is unclear. Absent a statutory power of detention, no public official has any power to detain an alien who has entered the country whether or not that person's entry constituted an illegal entry.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to quote a United States immigration case and states:
Jackson J. reminded us that:

`Executive imprisonment has been considered oppressive and lawless since John, at Runnymede, pledged that no free many should be imprisoned, dispossessed, outlawed, or exiled save by the judgment of his peers or by the law of the land.'
In Re Bolton; Ex parte Deane, Deane J. echoed these sentiments when he said:

`The common law of Australia knows no lettre de cachet or executive warrant pursuant to which either citizen or alien can be deprived of his freedom by mere administrative decision or action. Any officer of the Commonwealth Executive who, without judicial warrant, purports to authorize or enforce the detention in custody of another person is acing lawfully only to the extent that his conduct is justified by clear statutory mandate.'

One suggested source of power to detain the plaintiffs is in s.88(114) of the Act. However, the provisions of s.88 are only activated by the arrival of the vessel at `a port' which by s.4(1) of the Act means `a proclaimed port'. While the case stated does not make clear where the plaintiffs' boats were intercepted, it is unlikely that the interception occurred before the arrival of the boats `at a port'. Furthermore at the time of the plaintiffs' arrival in Australia, a person could only be detained under s.88 `until the departure of the vessel from its last port of call in Australia or until such earlier time as an authorised officer directs'. The Court was informed during argument that the boats on which the plaintiffs came to Australia had been burned. It is difficult to see how s.88 could justify the detention of the plaintiffs when the boats upon which they arrived had been destroyed. The period of detention authorised by s.88 was clearly intended to be no longer than the period of the temporary stay of the vessel in Australia.

It is clear when one reads section 88 that it was a provision that was intended to deal largely with seamen who might be absconding in Australia or perhaps stowaways. The expectation was that such people might be taken into custody when they left the ship or vessel and, of course, put back on the ship when it sailed and that there would be no need for custody afterwards.

PARA.TAB: I must say that that seemed fairly logical when one read the provisions. But, when one recognises that there were no other general provisions in the Act authorising the detention, it is hard to imagine how it was ever viewed that this particular section could authorise the continued detention of people when there was no longer any vessel.

I am not trying to challenge the bona fides of the officers involved. But when we have the judgment before us and when we read the section it becomes clear that there was no mandate for detaining people in these circumstances in this way, even though quite properly my view and the view of my colleagues on this side of the House is that nobody should be allowed to arrive at our door without a visa or entry permit. They should not be able to arrive without the opportunity for Australia to see those persons and their documents of identity to clearly establish who they are, to test whether or not they have a criminal record, whether they are of suitable character to enter Australia, whether they meet our health requirements or whether they have a disease which may affect Australia. In other words, all of the matters which are relevant to determining people's entry for permanent residence are matters which we ought to be able to examine before people present in Australia. The schema is there for that to happen.

If people simply get in a boat and seek to land on our shores and often deprive themselves of their documents of identity for the purposes of limiting further inquiry as to their bona fides, it is appropriate and proper in our view that they should be held in detention. That is why we supported the legislation that was brought into the Parliament in May and that is why we have continued to support the new framework of legislation that was introduced in the Migration Reform Bill, recently carried through this House and the Senate.

The reform Bill, the earlier legislation, was a long time coming. This is not the first occasion on which the taking of people into detention in these circumstances has arisen. A matter of concern to me is the large number of vessels, some of which may have sunk before people arrived—as the Minister described, those who were picked up at sea en route to Australia. I understand that another has been burnt and destroyed. That was presumably done by quarantine officials, not by immigration officials.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not covered; that doesn't apply.
—But the situation is germane. It may not have applied in relation to whether or not these people—
—It doesn't apply to people who are affected by the need to make those changes.

—I understand that. That may be the case, but vessels have been destroyed properly for quarantine reasons. That is the only point I am making. Vessels also may have been sold or otherwise decommissioned in a way which would not permit them to be taken to sea again. A whole variety of situations could arise.

PARA.TAB: There is the potential for substantial claims for compensation. In his second reading speech, the Minister alluded to the fact that it is ironic that those rescued could now sue the Commonwealth for the privilege of being rescued. He makes the point that some 300 boat people are potentially affected—that is, it is possible that were a court to find for these people the Commonwealth could be ordered to pay a very considerable sum by way of compensation. You nod somewhat disapprovingly, Mr Deputy Speaker.

In the case of Lindy Chamberlain there has been a settlement—she was subjected to unlawful detention over a long period—approaching $1m. I do not know the nature of other claims settled by the Department in relation to unlawful detention, but I believe there have been some claims settled by the Department. Figures have been suggested of $200,000 each. If that were the case and there were some 300 boat people who were paid $200,000 each—ignoring the Lindy Chamberlain example, in which case $300m would be involved—the figure could be as high as $60m in compensation for people who may well find that their claims for asylum are rejected; in other words, they were illegal entrants to Australia. That finding might well be clear as well.

Because of the circumstances that the Minister has described and a court has found, it may be possible that these people were unlawfully held for a time. The amount of time for which they could be held could vary considerably. Some of these people have been held for upwards of three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have to use the word `may'.
—I understand. They may have been held for three years.
—May have been held unlawfully.

—I accept that they may have been held unlawfully, but I assert that some people have been held for upwards of three years. If decisions were made in some of those cases—and I am not trying to suggest that the Parliament has formed a view in relation to these matters; it is not for us to do that, it is part of the judicial power—very substantial claims could arise. This legislation is designed to deal with that. It has our support, but I want to make it very clear that it does not in any way seek to validate any unlawful detention that may have occurred.

PARA.TAB: The Bill, in its three relevant sections, prescribes a schema which is designed to ensure that no action lies, and no action is taken, in any court against the Commonwealth or any officer or any other person for damages other than as provided in the second section, which says that the designated person has a right of action in a court of competent jurisdiction for compensation in respect of unlawful custody. The Bill also provides that the compensation that may be awarded to a designated person in an action under the second section is to be $1 for each day of the person's unlawful custody.

If people are found to be non-bona fide asylum seekers and voluntarily agree to leave Australia or are deported from Australia, being unwilling to move, any other moneys that might be paid to them could be used to offset any compensation that is paid or payable, depending upon any further decisions that might be taken. We take the view that for more abundant precaution this provision should be enacted. I want to make it clear that we would not support, and have not supported, any proposals for validating unlawful detention because we think that would be an inappropriate course.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not in the Bill.

—It is not in the Bill; the Minister is right. I am making it very clear that that is our position. The Bill also seeks to put beyond doubt, as the Minister has termed it, custody that may arise in line with other potential difficulties.

PARA.TAB: Each of those provisions is prospective in its effect and is designed to ensure that, in the event that there is a negative determination of an entry application and arrangements for removal, custody can continue until that removal is effected. I would have thought the legislation was clearly designed to cover that situation and, if it does not, that provision has our full support.

The Bill introduces a provision to extend the permissible period of custody where an entry application decision is reopened by other legal proceedings. That is to ensure that, where the permissible time for decisions to be taken is reopened because of a decision of the courts, any further time necessary to deliberate on those matters is time that the person will remain in custody. The Bill also provides that the institution of proceedings in relation to unlawful custody does not prevent the Government from detaining or removing designated persons during such proceedings. We agree to that provision.

Finally, the Bill is now extended to ensure that, if there are any further boat arrivals after the passage of this legislation, after 1 December 1992—which was the date for which the Bill we passed in May was intended to operate—up to the passage of the Migration Reform Bill, which is now enacted but will not be proclaimed until 1 November 1993, detention during that period is also validated. That particular provision also has our support. In that regard we give the legislation speedy passage.

I wish to make a number of points about this matter generally in the time I have left. It is clear that we have had to enact legislation in quite unusual circumstances. The legislation in May was enacted in unusual circumstances. The legislation in the reform Bill was important legislation but it did not cure these defects. So we are now dealing with legislation as a result of a decision in the High Court. The fact is that we have been dealing with these asylum seekers for some three years and a number of them have been held in detention for that length of time. I do regard the fact that we have had people held in detention for that length of time awaiting determination of claims to be unconscionable.

I know there has been a good deal of comment about where the blame for that should lie. I make it very clear that, in my view, it is not appropriate to blame individual judges, the legal profession or voluntary agencies for that. Voluntary agencies, the legal profession and judges seek to uphold the law as they see it. They seek to exercise rights that they believe they have. Often agencies, for the most honourable reasons, seek to assist those people with counselling and advice. The fact that people are making a lot of comments is a symptom of the greater problem that does exist in this area. It is the failure of the Government to be able to get it right that is involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are getting boring.

—I have said these things before, and I do not resile from them one iota. The honourable member may make comments of that sort, but what we are trying to do is close the door after the proverbial horse has bolted. We cannot hold as scapegoats in these matters the individuals who have commented adversely in relation to the Government and its record. It is as a result of Government decisions over a long period that we now face this difficulty.

PARA.TAB: The reason for the large number of asylum seekers is the expectations held out by the Government's failure properly to administer the sale of education into China, as well as the fact that after the Tiananmen Square massacre we allowed a large number of people to remain in this country without testing their claims. Those matters still remain unresolved today. It is as a result of those failures on the part of the Government that a number of people have sought to explore their rights within our courts to the greatest extent possible when in other circumstances and at other times that has not been the case.

If we go back to first principles and look at the way in which the courts have behaved in these matters, it has always been clear that our principal problem has been the unduly legalistic approach that has had to be adopted because of the Government's view that we ought to provide ready access to judicial review of administrative decisions in so many of the areas affecting immigration. When we look at the provisions in the Migration Act dealing with humanitarian and compassionate cases and the way in which those provisions were interpreted by the courts using the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 and its application to migration decisions, we can see why these problems have arisen.

When we look at the creative way in which the High Court of Australia got into the business of determining refugee claims, when it was always intended that these should be administrative matters dealt with by the government of the day, we can appreciate that the Government by allowing the ADJR Act to continue to apply in this area without review was creating a rod for its own back. It has always seemed very clear to me, and I have argued this strongly, that the role of the courts collectively in this area has brought about a very significant problem for the government of the day. That problem remains of the Government's own making, because it could have commenced undertaking the reform to limit judicial involvement in this area well in advance of the Migration Reform Bill 1992 that we dealt with only a matter of weeks ago.

The potential to take decisions and to challenge decisions in the way in which the Khmer and a number of other asylum seekers have challenged them is something that has remained in the legislation. It was known to the Government three years ago and could have been dealt with then. The fact that these people have been detained for this length of time is a result of the failure to grapple with these decisions at the time when it was relevant. That is a matter of deep concern to me, particularly as we see the effect that the internment has had on a number of the asylum seekers. Of course, those matters have yet to be fully resolved. I hope that there will not be any tragedy as a result of the time that it has taken to deal with numbers of these cases.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I place on record my appreciation of the cooperation I have received today and over the past couple of days from the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), concerning the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 4). I am grateful to him and to the Opposition for their speedy response during the day.

PARA.TAB: This is an important issue, and there are many things I could say. I am constantly being cautioned about saying them because, as the shadow Minister knows, these cases are not concluded yet. But let me just say this in response to him: I, too, am appalled by the length of time this matter has taken. I, too, get no joy out of people being kept in custody. I am sure I speak on behalf of every officer of my Department when I say that they get no joy from it, either. I become quite distressed by the fact that people are held in custody for such lengths of time.

I become bewildered, daily, by the things that are occurring. Who is it that is throwing the Panadol and other drugs over the fence for people to use when they are in a depressed state? Who are the people encouraging some of these activities? Who are the people in the detention centre who, in the last 24 hours, have promised that the High Court would be ruling these people refugees and giving them a large sum of money? Who are the people who, following the first set of decisions which were handed down a week or so ago in Port Hedland, met on the Sunday afternoon with those claiming to be refugees and said, `Ignore the Department; don't take any notice of the Department when they come in and talk about a resettlement sum of money given that you are going to be rejected, because the High Court will let you out next Wednesday.'? But the High Court did not let them out, so these people were depressed again. Officers of my Department, officers of the UNHCR, officers of the Australian Red Cross, and others engaged in the area have counselled people. It was a very frustrating matter to be dealing with.

The shadow Minister mentioned section 88, and the fact that we should have known about the problem that would arise. That section arose out of the old section 36, which I understand came into play in about 1958. The shadow Minister talked about taking action after the horse had bolted. That is a good racing term, and I know a bit about that. I have been on a horse that has bolted, but on this occasion I was not holding the horse when it bolted, if that is the way he wants to describe it. We can all be clever afterwards.

As I have said before, maybe I was too generous in the early days. I thought I was being fair; I thought I was doing the right thing. At the time, most people applauded me—but that applause very quickly turned to criticism because it all got spun out. I did not for one minute think that people would want to spin it out for so long. I repeat: I very much doubt that some of the clients have any idea of what has been done on their behalf. In the courts recently a set of applications was made to stay the return of people to China. The fact that 12 people on that list had made application to the Chinese Embassy saying that they wanted travel documents so they could return home was completely ignored by the legal people. The fact that five were leaving the next day was again ignored by the legal people.

So we have to ask ourselves what sort of dialogue goes on between some people in the legal profession—not all of them—and their clients. It stands to reason that one has to ask that question. These people want to go home and they are going home and some joker goes into the court and says, `I demand that the court stop these people leaving'—in the name of civil liberties, for God's sake! Then we have the situation of a person who wants to die and who has made up her mind to do so. We introduce a regulation that says that we ought to try to stop this and the medical profession comes down on me like a ton of bricks as though we were going to, at gunpoint, march its members in there to do it when that was not the intent. The intent was that this provided an opportunity for someone to do that. Secondly, we had no intention of interfering in the medical arrangements. This person is perfectly sane at that point. However, when she decides that she wants to go home and start eating, people approach us with a psychiatrist to say that suddenly she is not sane. The lawyer says, `Don't sign it; don't go home', and then they work on her a few days later and again she changes her mind. How confused is that woman?

These are the sorts of things that are going on daily. Drugs are being thrown over fences for people to take, and we have to cope with that. I have to question some of the actions being taken by some people—although I suspect they are well-meaning. It is very difficult to deal with these things.

I am told that I have to be brief tonight and that I cannot talk about this. I just hope that one day we are able to talk about this exercise. But I do not want to do anything to jeopardise the rights of any of these people who are seeking refugee status and, as far as possible, I will not do anything to jeopardise the fairness of their processing. So I have kept quiet. But honourable members will have to forgive me every now and again when a judge or a set of lawyers, drinking their nice flash red wine, sitting around casually in Port Hedland and photographed in the Australian or whatever it was on the weekend—all very nice and, I point out for the record, all being paid for by the Australian taxpayer, something which is never mentioned—throwing brick after brick at everybody else. Maybe some of those bricks will come back at the right time, when this matter is looked at in the coolness of another day.

So, without going on, this is a very frustrating area of policy. I reject some of the comments made by the shadow Minister, and no doubt there will be another day to debate them. He knows the history of section 88. He knows that this is a matter that has never been tested in the High Court before. It now has and the Government has responded as quickly as humanly possible. I regret that it is this time of night. I would have loved it to have been prime time television and radio time so that everybody could have seen this debate because I think this is something that the Australian taxpayer really is quite interested in, contrary to the comments some people make. I think they are very interested in it. When the crew of an Australian naval vessel picks up someone drowning at sea and brings that person ashore and then finds that, for its trouble, because somebody spots a loophole in the legislation, we are to be sued, I think the Australian taxpayer will be very interested.

I commend the Bill to the House and I again thank the Opposition for its cooperation. Ignoring some of the comments that the shadow Minister made, I do appreciate the speed with which honourable members opposite responded to our requests today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fatin The Hon W.F.

TALKER.NAME: Ms FATIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill follows on from the Territories Law Reform Act, which introduced major reforms to the legal regimes of the Indian Ocean Territories, Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands, with effect from 1 July 1992. The Commonwealth's plans for the effective and efficient administration of the new legal regime depend in large measure on the continued cooperation of the Western Australian Government. It is pleasing to note the passage of an Indian Ocean Territories (Administration of Laws) Bill through the Western Australian Parliament on 2 December 1992 which corresponds to the Territories Law Reform Act and provides for appropriate intergovernmental arrangements.

PARA.TAB: This Bill makes minor technical amendments to the Christmas Island Act and Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act, which have been requested by Western Australia in the above context. One particular amendment relates to the manner of application of Western Australian laws. The Christmas Island Act and Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act currently provide that the provisions of the law of Western Australia are in force in each Territory, so far as they are capable of applying in the Territory. Western Australia has expressed concern about possible undesirable and unintended restrictions on the applicability of some Western Australian laws, arising from this formulation. This Bill will remove references to the applicability of Western Australia law. This will not substantially affect the laws currently in force in the Territory, but removes a possible doubt as to the validity of actions under applied laws.

Another group of amendments concerns the exercise of judicial and related powers under applied laws by Territory or State courts and court officers. The Christmas Island Act and Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act currently deal differently with powers under applied laws which are vested in the courts and judicial officers of the Territories, and other powers, which are vested initially in the Commonwealth Minister administering those Acts.

Provisions dealing with exercise of jurisdiction by the existing Territory courts will be repealed and replaced—by the Territories Law Reform Act—when jurisdiction in respect of the Territories is conferred on the courts of Western Australia, given suitable intergovernmental agreement.

Western Australia has sought a range of amendments of these provisions, to refer to `court officers' rather than `judicial officers', encompassing officers with primarily administrative functions, but possibly some judicial attributes, and to be able to deal more comprehensively and consistently with the full range of courts and tribunals of the State. The Bill will have no impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 makes minor technical amendments to the Christmas Island Act 1958 and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act 1955. This legislation has been requested by the Western Australian Government in the context of the Western Australian Government's decision to move forward with its own legislation. The Indian Ocean Territories (Administration of Laws) Bill was introduced into the Western Australian Parliament on 11 November this year. It passed through the Legislative Assembly on 26 November and the Legislative Council without amendment on 2 December this year.

PARA.TAB: The two amendments are not controversial, with one amendment relating to the technical manner of application of Western Australian laws. The Christmas Island Act and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act currently provide that the provisions of the law of Western Australia are in force in each Territory so far as they are capable of applying to the Territory. The Bill removes the reference in both the Christmas Island Act and Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act to the applicability of Western Australian law. This will remove any doubt. Provisions incapable of application will still not have any real effect, but will be described as part of the law in force in the Territory.

The other amendment concerns the exercise of judicial and related powers that are applied to laws by Territory or State courts and court officers. Western Australia has sought a range of amendments of these provisions to refer to court officers rather than judicial officers as currently applies. This will enable officers to be able to deal more comprehensively and consistently with the full range of courts and tribunals of the State.

Honourable members will recall that earlier this year this Parliament passed the Territories Law Reform Bill 1992, an important piece of constitutional legislation. Essentially, it replaced the Singaporean based regime with a Western Australian based body of law. Some 700 pieces of Western Australian Acts of Parliament were transferred in their administration of these Indian Ocean islands as a result of this legislation. The Western Australian laws are subject to modification by ordinance under the Christmas Island Act and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act. We have already seen a number of pieces of legislation which have been repealed or their operations suspended, or modification of the legislation for application on the islands.

I have noted with interest the comments made by the Western Australian member for Kingsley, Mrs Cheryl Edwardes, who is the shadow Minister in this area, regarding the Indian Ocean territories becoming part of the Western Australian State electorate. She says of Christmas and Cocos (Keeling) Islands that they:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . could become part of our electorate—
meaning her electorate—

at some time in the future. That has already been recommended, although it has not been taken up in this legislation. However, I am sure that within the next couple of years that series of islands could become part of Western Australia.

In the long term, this is a very valid point. My colleague in the Senate, Senator Tambling, has voiced his concern at the present situation with regard to the Indian Ocean Territories and their lack of representation in the Western Australian Parliament. Currently, the laws of Western Australia apply to the Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands. However, the residents of these islands have no representation in the Parliament of Western Australia where the bulk of their laws will now be made. These islands are, coincidentally, part of Senator Tambling's electorate for voting purposes in this Federal Parliament.

PARA.TAB: A very formal community of interest, particularly in the provision of education and health services, has been built up with Western Australia. The community of interest of many of the families is now with the communities in Perth and with those in Port Hedland. Looking to the future, the application of Western Australian law will inevitably lead to the incorporation of those islands into the State of Western Australia. I know that Senator Tambling is looking at initiating discussions on behalf of the Federal Opposition with the respective representative bodies on both of those islands to ensure that constitutional progress can be made in that regard in the long term.

I would also like to comment on the operation of the Christmas Island casino. The member for Kingsley in Western Australia, who is the shadow Minister responsible for the legislation in that House, made further comments about the operation of casinos in Western Australia. The application of this legislation applies very much to that casino. In her speech, Mrs Edwardes said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Commonwealth Government must bring the infrastructure of the islands up to mainland standards. The establishment of the casino complex may mean that the Island achieves financial independence from Australia. The casino is expected to bring around 40,000 people to the islands mainly from Indonesia. It is important that this Bill be passed to ensure that the Christmas Island casino will provide the same level of operation and service that is provided by the Burswood Casino. From a Western Australian point of view any competitor to the Burswood Casino should be operated under the same conditions.

The casino on Christmas Island is intended to be operational at some stage in this financial year. In the recent Estimates and Appropriations debates, Senator Tambling was able to ascertain from officers of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) that that particular program has been slowed because of problems with the construction details and the construction program. However, the coalition believes that it is important that laws are in place and applicable when the casino is up and running—and hopefully the target date of March 1993 will be achieved—to ensure that there is an appropriate checking of those operations.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling has recently placed questions on the Senate Notice Paper to both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the senior portfolio Minister regarding the appointment of Mr Read, a former Cabinet Secretary to the Western Australian Premier, Mr Brian Burke, to the position of Administrator of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. We on this side of the House await with interest the answers to those questions.

I was pleased to note that last week there was an election for a new shire council on Christmas Island and a number of new councillors have taken office. It is important that under the Territories law reform legislation the new council exercise a proper and full consultative role in implementing all of the legislation and any changes necessary.

Although the Opposition supports this legislation, it is concerned that such a small piece of legislation, albeit important, could have and should have been dealt with through the correct process of the Territories Law Reform Act earlier in the year. We believe that if the Department had consulted more completely with the relevant authorities in Western Australia instead of rushing the original legislation through the Parliament—and honourable members will recall that that took place only in June of this year—perhaps this legislation would not have been necessary. Perhaps the island communities or the Western Australian Government needed that added consultation. However, we support this legislation, and I conclude on that note.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Ms Fatin) read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Further to the answer to Question No. 882 (Hansard, 26 February 1992, page 278), did the advice of the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) state the allegations against Mr Geoffrey Manners but omit to state that all the allegations were withdrawn because there was no evidence to support them; if so, why.

(2) During committal proceedings instituted by the DPP, did a magistrate, in response to a newspaper having printed that Mr Manners was a defendant, state to the court that Mr Manners was definitely not a defendant; if so, were DPP officers present when that statement was made.

(3) Did Mr Manners request him, in a facsimile message on 11 February 1991 and a further facsimile message on 26 February 1991, to correct a false impression given to Parliament by the DPP, in his annual report for 1989-90, that Mr Manners was a defendant; if so, did he (a) respond to the messages and (b) ensure that Parliament was correctly informed; if not, why not.
(4) Did the Associate DPP, Mr Coghlan, state that Mr Manners' wanting Parliament to be correctly informed was frivolous; if so, was it proper for Mr Coghlan to make that statement.
(5) Is the DPP's office trying to silence and discredit Mr Manners because of allegations he has made to the Attorney-General and the DPP's office about DPP officers.
(6) Has the DPP's office been vague and contradictory about (a) the number of warrants it has issued against Mr Manners, (b) the current status of the warrants and (c) the location of the warrants.
(7) Has Mr Manners requested clarification from the DPP regarding arrest warrants repeatedly since 15 August 1990.

(8) In response to the requests referred to in part (7), did Mr Coghlan admit on 21 August 1991 the existence of only one Victorian warrant; if so, why does the answer to question No. 882 state that Mr Manners was advised in August 1990 that two Victorian warrants were withdrawn.

(9) Did the DPP's office try to conceal the 1984 origins of allegations against Mr Manners from a UK court; if so, (a) did Mr Coghlan know and (b) was he therefore tardy in mentioning the existence of the second warrant.

(10) Did Mr Coghlan write a letter to Mr Manners on 12 March 1991; if so, (a) was the letter not sent until 21 June 1991 when it was sent by facsimile message, (b) did not the letter contain the first admission to Mr Manners that the three Queensland warrants existed and (c) did Mr Coghlan state that (i) the warrants remained technically alive, (ii) he had discovered a procedure for withdrawing them and (iii) he would have them withdrawn as soon as possible.
(11) Is it a fact that the three Queensland warrants cannot be located.
(12) Does the DPP's office have the custody of, and legal responsibility for following up matters in relation to, the records of the former Special Prosecutor's Office.
(13) Did the DPP decide that the three Queensland warrants had no foundation in law and that he would not proceed with them; if so, why were the warrants not withdrawn.
(14) Was any arrest warrant against Mr Manners made inactive instead of being withdrawn; if so, why.

(15) Has Mr Manners alleged to the DPP that (a) the sole purpose of maintaining inactive arrest warrants against him was to dissuade him from returning to Australia and (b) the DPP had failed to supply any other reason for the warrants being inactive rather than withdrawn.

(16) Will he ensure that the DPP issues Mr Manners with an indemnity, binding all law enforcement officers, with respect to (a) the three Queensland warrants in case of their reappearance and (b) any other warrants which the DPP is unable to locate.
(17) Is the DPP's office aware that Mr Manners has no solicitors; if so, why is it stated in part (1) of the answer to question No. 882 that Mr Manners had been advised through his solicitors.
(18) Has Mr Manners been denied the financial means, or ability through legal aid, to be legally represented in Australia; if so, is this action supported by the DPP's office.

(19) Did Mr Manners begin to report details of actions by officers of the DPP through the Australian High Commission in London on 10 May 1990; if so, why does part (2) of the answer to question No. 882 state that Mr Manners has been corresponding on a broad range of matters with the Commonwealth since August 1990.
(20) Does a letter from Mr Manners, dated 10 May 1990, to the DPP contain serious allegations and evidence.
(21) Will he ensure that the allegations referred to in part (20) are promptly and properly investigated.
(22) Is it a fact as stated in part (2) of the answer to question No. 882 that Mr Manners has not provided any evidence.

(23) If so, why has Mr Manners requested the DPP, since 10 May 1990, to (a) explain why the DPP has not examined the evidence referred to in part (20) or (b) provide Mr Manners with the name of an official authorised to do so; if not, will he ensure that the DPP explains why he has not met the requests.

(24) Was Mr Weinberg, QC, before his appointment as DPP, involved in actions concerning the Australian Taxation Office taken by the DPP's office but later found to be unsubstantiated in law; if so, did the involvement enable Mr Weinberg to disclaim responsibility for the conduct of the DPP's office in relation to Mr Manners.

(25) Was the former Chairman of the National Crime Authority (NCA), Mr Justice Phillips, involved in a previous capacity in actions taken by the Commissioner of Taxation and some of his officials against Mr Manners.
(26) Was Justice Phillips requested, as Chairman of the NCA, to place facts concerning the wrongdoing of officials in regard to Mr Manners before the NCA.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is that I am advised as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The matters against Manners were not withdrawn on the basis that there was no evidence but because a number of his co-conspirators had been acquitted. In those circumstances it was decided that it was inappropriate to proceed further against Manners.

(2) The DPP's office has no knowledge of the matter referred to. If the matter refers to the committal proceedings against Forsyth and others then it is acknowledged that Manners was not a defendant in those proceedings.

(3) Manners accused the former Director of misleading Parliament without direct reference to stating that it was in relation to him being referred to as a "defendant". In that context there was nothing to correct. The informations and warrants for arrest described Manners as a defendant.

(4) The reference in the annual report to proceedings against Manners being withdrawn against him as a "defendant" was accurate, since there were in existence at the time referred to valid and current warrants to which Manners was a defendant.

The then Associate Director stood by the view that it was frivolous to claim that the reference amounted to parliament being misled. It was never intended to mean that "wanting Parliament to correctly be informed was frivolous".

(6) There was some initial confusion about the number and place of the warrants. The misunderstanding arose mainly because of the age of the matters and the fact that Mr Manners left the jurisdiction in June 1983 and did not take the matter up with the authorities until some 6 years after the issue of the warrants.
(7) Mr Manners has made persistent requests from the DPP about the warrants and has sought assurances which the office is not in a position to give.

(8) It is so that Mr Manners was advised by letter dated 21 August 1991 that a Victorian warrant had been withdrawn. There were two Victorian warrants. It is also the case that the answer to question No. 882 said that two Victorian warrants were withdrawn. The situation is that an arrest warrant issued on 11 September 1984 upon the information of the Special Prosecutor was formally withdrawn before the Melbourne Magistrates Court by the Office of the DPP in June 1990. Another arrest warrant was issued on 11 March 1986 and included in the extradition brief forwarded to the Crown Prosecution Service in the United Kingdom in late 1989 but has since been requested to be destroyed with all other papers in that brief. The reference to only one Victorian warrant is quite inadvertent and not intended to mislead. Notwithstanding that, it has been made quite clear as early as September 1990 and on subsequent occasions that the proceedings against Mr Manners are at an end.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Commonwealth policy requires that all programs have regard to the cultural diversity of Australian society. On this basis, it is possible to identify Commonwealth expenditure on multicultural programs as being $94.9m in 1991-92, while estimated expenditure for 1992-93 is $94.7m.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 17 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have individual consumer groups received sitting fees on Government bodies since 1987; if so, in each case (a) what sum was paid to the group, (b) what are the (i) names and (ii) titles of group representatives and (c) what organisations did they represent.
(2) What are the selection criteria for selecting consumer representatives.
(3) Who selects the representatives.

(4) What measures are taken by the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs and her office to ensure that Commonwealth funds received by the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, and like bodies, are used efficiently and appropriately.
(5) What action is proposed should Commonwealth funds be used in a way which contravened the organisation's objectives or constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I provide the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No consumer groups have received sitting fees for providing representatives to sit on government bodies within the consumer affairs portfolio since 1987.

(2) It has been the practice of my predecessors to consult with the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO), as the peak body for the consumer movement, when seeking nominations for individual consumer representatives, as distinct from individual consumer groups. My intention is to continue this process.

When seeking nominations through AFCO, the normal process is that AFCO consults with its member organisations on possible appropriate nominees. AFCO then forwards a list of nominees to the Minister for Consumer Affairs for his/her consideration and selection of the consumer representative. Ministers have also considered other persons from the community sector as representatives for particular bodies, depending on the backgrounds required or the subject matter with which the body is dealing.

In selecting an appropriate consumer representative, it has been my predecessors' desire, and one which I intend to continue, to ensure that consumer representatives on industry and government bodies are acceptable to interested groups and capable of representing the broad interests of consumers rather than themselves, industry or some fringe interest.
(3) Following on from my answer above, the final selection of the consumer representatives is the responsibility of the Minister for Consumer Affairs.

(4) I am advised that the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs is responsible for administering the grant-in-aid to AFCO and ensuring that the grant is acquitted properly. The Bureau examines the proposed budget for AFCO each financial year when its grant-in-aid application is submitted to ensure that the proposal is in accordance with its constitutional aims and objectives. In accordance with usual practices, an advance on funding for the coming financial year is provided to AFCO on the basis of five twelfths of the previous year's funding. It is a condition of the grant that it is expended in accordance with the objects and powers of AFCO's constitution. This condition and the receipt of funds has to be acknowledged by AFCO. The Federal Government then requires an audited statement of expenditure for the previous financial year to be received by the Bureau before the balance of any funding for the coming year will be paid in order to be satisfied that expenditure has been in accordance with the grant condition.
(5) The Government would seek legal advice on the matter to ascertain whether there are any implications for the future funding of the organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I provide the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, my attention has been drawn to the article you refer to.

(2) Following the receipt of Dr Frank Peters' allegations, legal advice was sought by my Office from the Office of General Counsel in the Attorney-General's Department of any implications for future funding of AFCO. The advice generally suggests that the issues raised are internal to AFCO and generally technical rather than of substance. For the most part, the allegations by Dr Peters concern the internal workings of AFCO. It would have been open to a member of AFCO to raise these matters in appropriate court proceedings and seek intervention by the court. None, however, did so.
In summary, Dr Peters' allegations were that:
notice of AFCO's biennial general meeting was not given to members in accordance with AFCO's constitution;
there were irregularities in the election of State and Territory representatives;
moneys were expended contrary to the requirements of the constitution;
there were breaches of the constitution in admitting unqualified organisations;
the Executive Committee usurped the powers of the Council;
meetings of the Council were not held in accordance with the constitution; and
there were irregularities in the preparation of the annual report.

The advice from Counsel points out that there is no real suggestion that AFCO is not devoting its funds primarily to its purposes and in accordance with the objects and powers set out in clause 2 of its constitution.

I am advised that since approximately 1985, Dr Peters has been making allegations and insinuations about various individual Council or staff members of AFCO or of the organisation itself. I understand that the latest allegations that AFCO had acted unconstitutionally first came to notice at around the beginning of 1992.

(3) I am advised that Counsel's advice concerning the constitutional irregularities referred to here by the honourable member was that they involved technicalities rather than matters of substance. These technicalities included that the holding of the Biennial General Meeting was unconstitutional because notices were not given to members in accordance with AFCO's constitution and, that there were irregularities in the election of State and Territory representatives such as in the sending of nomination and ballot forms. There is no suggestion to date that AFCO will be involved in extensive litigation because of those irregularities. For example, members of AFCO, having been advised of the problems associated with the calling of the 1992 Biennial General Meeting, nevertheless, instructed the Chair to proceed with the conduct of the meeting.

(4) I am aware that the AFCO executive did obtain legal advice on the matter. For the honourable member's information, the address of AFCO is Level 1, 40 Mort St, Braddon, ACT, 2601, and the phone number is (06) 2576311.
(5) to (16) The matters raised here are internal to AFCO, and it is more appropriate for them to be raised by the honourable member directly with AFCO.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the site of the Swan Brewery on the shores of the Swan River in Western Australia a sacred site of extreme importance to Aboriginal people.
(2) Did his predecessor make a declaration in 1989 under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 to protect the site.
(3) Was the declaration reversed after discussions with the Western Australian Government.

(4) Is he able to say whether the Western Australian Government (a) has allowed or (b) will allow legislation to override other Acts relating to the protection of Aboriginal sacred sites thereby leaving the sacred sites without protection; if so, will he act to protect sacred sites affected by the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information in response to the honourable member's questions:

PARA.TAB: (1) The old Swan Brewery site has been registered under the Western Australian Aboriginal Heritage Act 1972 as an "Aboriginal site". My predecessor, the Honourable Gerry Hand MP, was advised in 1989 by Dr Clive Senior, whom he appointed to prepare a report on the area under s.10(4) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 (the Commonwealth Act), that the area contains an Aboriginal mythological site which is significant to Aboriginal people.
(2) My predecessor did make a declaration over the old Swan Brewery site in June 1989.

(3) In July 1989 he withdrew the declaration on the undertaking that the State would be bound by its own legislation in respect of the site. This action followed consultations between the then Prime Minister, the Honourable Bob Hawke and the then Premier of WA, the Honourable Peter Dowding.

(4) On 11 August 1992 the Western Australian Government sought, by the gazettal of a notice made pursuant to the Heritage of Western Australia Act 1990 to avoid the procedures for Aboriginal site protection provided by its own Aboriginal Heritage Act 1972.
The Order was disallowed by the Western Australian Legislative Council on 22 September 1992.
Thereafter I am advised that the procedures set out in its Aboriginal Heritage Act 1972 have been implemented.
The Commonwealth Act is not intended to replace State-based processes but is used only as an Act of last resort when these State or Territory procedures have not been observed.
I am continuing to monitor developments closely in liaison with the Government of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 7 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: Is it a fact that under the Closer Economic Relations agreement between Australia and New Zealand it would be appropriate for goods made in either New Zealand or Australia to use the `Made in Australia' or `Made in New Zealand' labels; if so, why; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: No. I have been advised that the CER agreement and associated documents do not imply that goods made in Australia could legitimately be labelled `Made in New Zealand' and goods made in New Zealand could legitimately be labelled `Made in Australia'. This would be misleading.

The rules of origin contained in Article 3 of the CER agreement do not relate to country of origin labelling. The application of the CER rules of origin determines whether or not a good is entitled to the free trade benefits of the CER agreement, that is, whether or not it is entitled to duty-free entry into Australia or New Zealand.

For example, to be an `Australian' good for the purpose of duty-free entry into New Zealand, the good must have had at least 50% of its value added in Australia or New Zealand and the last process of manufacture must have been in Australia. The same applies to New Zealand goods seeking duty-free entry into Australia.

On the wider issue of accurate country of origin labelling, I believe the present uncertainty about the criteria for determining country of origin makes it difficult for suppliers to accurately label their goods.

The Government announced on 19 October 1992 its intention to establish two working groups `to conduct an urgent study into the legislative and other developments that need to be set in train so that country of origin labelling will be more comprehensive, accurate and informative'.
The working groups met for the first time on 28 October 1992 and have subsequently written to industry, consumer and other organisations seeking their views on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 8 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the number of single voyage permits issued to foreign flag vessels increased from 48 in 1988-89 to 203 in 1991-92; if so, has the increase affected the viability of planned investment in interstate rail freight links by the National Rail Corporation between (a) Melbourne and Adelaide, (b) Adelaide and Perth and (c) Sydney and Adelaide.
(2) What is the expected pay back period of each link referred to in part (1).

(3) What percentage of freight tonnage carried by (a) V/Line, (b) Australian National, (c) Westrail and (d) the State Rail Authority of New South Wales from (i) Melbourne to Adelaide, (ii) Adelaide to Melbourne, (iii) Adelaide to Perth, having originated in Sydney or Melbourne, (iv) Perth to Adelaide, bound for either Sydney or Melbourne, (v) Sydney to Melbourne and (vi) Adelaide to Sydney does the National Rail Corporation consider to be vulnerable to competition from coastal shipping.
(4) Is a decision to standardise the Melbourne to Adelaide rail route contingent upon an expected minimum annual freight tonnage in either direction; if so, what are the figures.
(5) Does the Sydney to Adelaide route via Sunshine, Victoria, afford an advantage of at least four hours over the superfreighter route through Broken Hill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a)—(c) Yes. However, this is the number of single voyage permits issued for all sectors of the coasting trade, not just those issued for routes and cargoes which might represent competition for interstate rail services.

In 1991-92 only 30,203 tonnes of containerised cargo (ie that cargo capable of carriage by rail) between the eastern ports of Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide and Fremantle was carried under these permits. Most of the 1.32 million tonnes carried consisted of petroleum products (841,129 tonnes) and iron ore (331,224 tonnes).

Rail freight operates in a competitive market which has experienced declining real freight rates over a number of years, reflecting the competitiveness of the trucking industry. An increase in single voyage permits will reflect new trades, not previously able to be serviced by existing transport services, or the attraction of cargoes to sea from road or rail transport. In the case of the latter, there will be an effect on National Rail's revenues and hence potential profitability.
(2) National Rail has advised that investment programs in the corridors mentioned will comprise many discrete projects. Pay back periods vary depending on project type.

(3) (a)—(d) (i)—(vi) National Rail has advised that, while it is not possible to define percentages accurately, it considers that corridors to and from Perth are most vulnerable. National Rail consider that the Brisbane-Sydney-Melbourne corridors are not highly exposed to this competition.
(5) Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 12 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Commonwealth Government decide, in agreement with State and Territory health ministers, to accept no more than 200 candidates per year to sit for the Australian Medical Council's clinical examinations for overseas-trained doctors; if so, why.

(2) Is he able to say whether Sir William Keys, the Chairman of the National Advisory Committee on Skills Recognition, stated in a letter dated 12 August 1992 that (a) the Government's decision to limit the number of overseas-trained doctors who can apply to sit the necessary examinations for registration to 200 had compounded difficulties and (b) the whole protectionist edifice should be dismantled.
(3) Does the decision to restrict the number of candidates amount to protectionism; if so, how is it justified.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I, as the Commonwealth Health Minister, along with all State and Territory Health Ministers, determined at our meeting in April 1992, to accept no more than 200 candidates per year to sit for the Australian Medical Council's (AMC) clinical examinations for overseas trained doctors (OTDs).

Ministers adopted a national medical workforce supply target of one doctor per 500 people or 1:500 (currently 1:430) and agreed that in order to address the oversupply a quota on the number of OTDs entering the workforce was unavoidable. As quoted in the Australian Health Ministers' Conference Communique (14 April 1992):

ANSWER.PARA: `In 1990-91 over 500 doctors from overseas settled in Australia, a figure which is equivalent to about 40% of the graduates from Australian medical schools.'

PARA.TAB: Ministers noted that Australian medical schools have reduced intakes by 12.5% since 1985.
In line with this decision, the Commonwealth Government announced in May 1992 that from 1 July a 10 points sub-skills factor would be applied to intending medical migrants.

Ministers also determined that, on the grounds of equity, the number of OTDs allowed to join the medical workforce each year should be linked to the number of graduates from local medical schools. A ratio of 1:6 has been agreed on the basis:
that Australian medical school graduates in 1991-92 were approximately 1,200; and
the annual average since 1983 of OTDs successfully completing the AMC multiple choice examination is approximately 200.
Approximately 800 OTDs who had completed the first (Multiple Choice Questionnaire) part of the AMC examination by July 1992 have been exempted from the quota.

(2) Sir William Keys, Chairman of the National Advisory Committee on Skills Recognition wrote to a Professor H. Schaupp of Everton, Queensland, on 12 August 1992. Mr Moore has attributed Sir William correctly.

(3) No. The medical profession is the only profession that has automatic access to an open-ended Government funded payment system upon registration. In a situation where there is already an oversupply of medical practitioners in Australia, the rapid entry of large numbers of doctors into the workforce would have a significant effect on health outlays. Health Ministers agree that a quota system limiting the number allowed to sit the final part of the AMC examination is the only sensible means of addressing the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 12 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is he able to say whether the National Specialist Qualifications Advisory Committee (NSQAC), since it was established, has automatically accepted qualifications obtained in the United Kingdom and New Zealand, and in some cases from South Africa and the USA, but not qualifications from Western European countries.
(2) Does he hold portfolio responsibility for the NSQAC.
(3) Does the NSQAC receive Commonwealth funding for (a) assessing overseas qualifications or (b) any other purpose.
(4) Is he able to say whether the NSQAC has denied professional recognition on the grounds that it has not assessed the qualifications of the country in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1), (3) and (4) The role of the National Specialist Qualification Advisory Committee (NSQAC) is to draw up a list of recognised specialties and sectional specialties and a list of acceptable postgraduate medical qualifications. The NSQAC does not accept overseas qualifications automatically.

NSQAC receives Government funding only in relation to sitting fees and travel and accommodation of members. Secretariat support services to the Committee are provided by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.

The Specialist Recognition Advisory Committees and the Specialist Recognition Appeal Committee are responsible for assessing applications for specialist recognition based on the applicant's primary qualifications, experience and standing in the medical profession, and the nature of practice of the medical practitioner.
(2) Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 4 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council considering uniform regulations for smoke emission.
(2) Does the Council propose to support a uniform smoke emission standards of 5.5 grams of smoke per kilogram of fuel; if so, when will the standard come into force.
(3) How will fuel emission standards be monitored.
(4) What categories of fuel will be tested.
(5) Will anthracite coal, a smokeless fuel, be among the categories to be tested; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC) resolved on 6 November 1992 to introduce uniform legislation in all jurisdictions to ensure that domestic solid fuel heaters sold in Australia will comply with the April 1992 Australian Standards that refer to aspects of the performance of such appliances.

(2) Yes. Smoke is only one visible form of particulate matter. For compliance, an appliance without a catalytic combustor must have a maximum average rate of particulate emissions no greater than 5.5 grams per kilogram of fuel when tested as specified. Where an appliance is fitted with a catalytic combustor (which ensures more efficient combustion) the equivalent figure is no more than 3.0 grams per kilogram of fuel. The ANZECC resolution does not specify the date from which the legislation shall apply but the intention is that each jurisdiction will introduce legislation as quickly as practicable.
(3) Each model of new domestic solid fuel heater will have to successfully pass a series of tests in one of two authorised laboratories before being granted a certificate of compliance.
(4) Hardwood, softwood, lignite briquettes and sub-bituminous coal, each with characteristics within a limited allowable range, are specified as the test fuels to be used in determining performance.

(5) No, anthracite is not one of the specified test fuels because it is not a widely available or commonly used fuel for the types of domestic heaters covered by the Standards and proposed legislation.

Of the $8 million available in 1992-93, $2.5 million is for specific grants for remote and isolated general practitioners (GPs). The remaining funds provide a capacity to relocate and train between 50 and 100 GPs this financial year with further funding available from 1993-94 onwards.
