(2) Given the period of time over which the treaties listed in (1) have been open for adherence, and the variety of subject matters dealt with under them, it is not possible to detail what consideration has been given to each of them by successive Australian Governments. However, from information recorded by my Department, it is known that Australia was party to the European Convention on the International Classification of Patents for Invention (No. 6 on the list) from 1958 to 1975 and that on 18 October 1988 the Government announced that Australia would not become a party to the Convention on Mutual Administrative Assistance in Tax Matters (No. 81). More recently, the Convention on Laundering, Search, Seizure and Confiscation of the Proceeds from Crime (No. 89) was signed for Australia, subject to ratification, on 28 September 1992 and a copy of the Convention was tabled in both Houses on 5 November 1992.

Most of the treaties focus on exclusively European concerns. Council of Europe listings indicate that only ten non-European states are currently parties to eleven different Council of Europe treaties and the maximum number of non-European parties to any one treaty is three. The Government is always prepared to consider becoming a party to such treaties when it is clearly in the national interest to do so. Indeed, in relation to the Money Laundering Convention mentioned above, Australia actively participated in the negotiation of the final text.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 10 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: Since the submission of the Industry Commission report on energy generation and distribution on 17 May 1991, what steps have the States and Territories taken to (a) allow unrestricted interstate supply and movement of gas and (b) achieve a transcontinental gas pipeline.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) The 1991 Industry Commission report on energy generation and distribution recommended that "government policies that restrict the use of gas or its sale interstate or overseas he abolished", and that "the Commonwealth should consider using its powers, where relevant, to facilitate abolition of these restrictions." These issues were addressed in the National Gas Strategy, which I announced in Parliament on 28 November 1991.

In relation to interstate gas trade, I have sought, through the Australia and New Zealand Minerals and Energy Council (ANZMEC), the commitment of all State and Territory Governments to the removal of impediments to free and fair interstate gas trade in order to ensure no constraints on gas finding new commercial markets.

Ministers attending the ANZMEC Meeting of 6 November 1992 agreed to continue working through ANZMEC, towards removing remaining impediments to interstate trade to provide a more open and competitive market place for natural gas, taking into account differences in structure of the gas industry in individual States. Ministers noted that the removal of impediments should provide incentives for the further development of Australia's natural gas industry.
The next step will be to identify the barriers and to consider appropriate action for their removal.

(b) The Industry Commission report on energy generation and distribution indicated that new gas pipeline developments are best left to the private sector. The National Gas Strategy does not support a prescriptive approach to the development of gas infrastructure. Rather Federal Government policy is to remove impediments to gas trade, allowing market forces to determine the nature and timing of gas supply development and associated infrastructure requirements.

A recent supply/demand study by the Australian Gas Association has provided a timely warning of the costs involved if the States and Territories prevent future free and fair interstate trade in gas. The study estimates that the cost to Australians of higher prices due to restricted interstate gas trade could, over the period until 2030, be as much as $4 billion, in current dollar terms. This study highlights the need for governments to take action now to remove impediments to free and fair interstate trade in gas.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Cave, Private Adrian: Inquiry into Death

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) When will the Minister respond to my letter of 22 October 1992 seeking advice on when the Army board of inquiry into the death of Private Adrian Stephen Cave, Army Number: 556941, killed at Cultana Range, SA, on 26 May 1992, will report.
(2) When will the Minister respond to the letters from Pte Cave's father, Mr Geoffrey Cave, dated 22 October and 6 November 1992.
(3) When will the results of the board of inquiry be made known to Mr Geoffrey Cave.
(4) Why has the board of inquiry not reported sooner.
(5) Has the SA coroner's inquest into the death been delayed until February 1993; if so, is this a result of a delay in the board of inquiry findings; if so, why.
(6) If there has been a delay, is the delay warranted.
(7) Did three months elapse before an official explanation of Pte Cave's death was made known to his father; if so, why.
(8) What was the cause of Pte Cave's death.
(9) Did Pte Cave die during a live-firing exercise; if so, was he wearing a protective vest; if not, (a) why was it permitted and (b) is it permitted as a general rule.
(10) What is the incidence of injuries incurred from live-firing exercises at Cultana Range.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) 11 November 1992.
(2) 11 November 1992.
(3) 28 November 1992.
(4) The Board of Inquiry has submitted its report. It took longer to report than originally estimated due to the amount of evidence and the overall complexity of the task.

(5) The inquest has been set for 2 February 1993. Sufficient time was required to allow for an independent legal check of the Board of Inquiry report to ensure that it was legally complete and correct and also to provide advice to the military commander responsible to facilitate subsequent action based upon the Board's recommendations. It also provides sufficient time for the Coroner to prepare for the inquest.
(6) Given the complexity of matters dealt with by the Board, it was proper that its report was independently checked.

(7) An official explanation cannot precede the findings of the Board of Inquiry. However, Private Cave's father received notification of his son's death on 26 May 1992 including a very brief description of how he died and the type of activity. A more detailed account was provided by the Chief of the General Staff in a letter dated 25 August 1992 and by the Minister in a letter dated 11 September 1992. It is acknowledged that the system needs to be improved to deal with sensitive situations such as these. Accordingly Army is investigating ways of improving the provision of information to the next of kin without prejudicing any subsequent proceedings.

(8) The official cause of death will be determined by the Coroner. The Board of Inquiry determined that Private Cave died as a result of a gunshot wound and it also addressed the events and circumstances leading to the tragedy.

(9) Private Cave died during a live firing exercise. He was not wearing a protective vest. They are not worn during this particular type of live firing exercise. The Board of Inquiry has addressed this matter.
(10) As far as can be ascertained, no other injuries resulting from weapons or explosives have occurred during live firing exercises at Cultana Range.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 12 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) recently issued a report on cyclodeine insecticide use in Australia; if so, (a) did the report refer to an evaluation of the insecticides heptachlor and chlordane carried out by the World Health Organization's International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) in 1990-91, (b) did the IARC evaluation find that heptachlor and chlordane are animal carcinogens and possible human carcinogens and (c) did the NHMRC report accept the IARC finding; if not, why not.
(2) Have high levels of chlordane been found in fish from Sydney waters.
(3) Does the NHMRC report refer to high levels of chlordane found in fish from Sydney waters; if not, why not.

(4) Has his attention been drawn to measurements made by the NSW WorkCover Authority of pesticide levels in air in homes which found that following application of insecticides in accordance with the appropriate Australian standard the combined indoor heptachlor levels did not fall below the American National Academy of Science emergency evacuation guideline level until six months after the application.
(5) What steps is the Government taking to review its policy towards cyclodeine insecticide use in Australia in the light of the NHMRC report and the findings of the NSW WorkCover Authority.
(6) Has he sought legal advice on the liabilities of Government agencies which advise the public on the use of cyclodeine insecticides.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. A report on cyclodiene insecticide use in Australia was adopted by the Council at its 114th Session in November 1992.
(1)(a) Yes.

(1)(b) As recorded in volume 53 of its monograph series, IARC concluded that, on the basis of the epidemiological data and case reports, there is inadequate evidence in humans for the carcinogenicity of chlordane and of heptachlor. On the basis of the animal toxicology data, it was concluded that there is sufficient evidence in experimental animals for the carcinogenicity of chlordane and heptachlor. The overall evaluation according to the criteria of the IARC classification scheme, was that both chlordane and heptachlor are classified as possible human carcinogens.

(1)(c) The NHMRC report concluded that there was evidence that these chemicals caused liver tumours in mice and that there was no strong epidemiological evidence in humans of an excess cancer risk due to occupational exposure to chlordane and heptachlor.

(2)&(3) The NHMRC report, citing information from the NSW Environment Management Unit, Water Board and the NSW State Pollution Control Commission, notes that residue levels of chlordane in the Red Morwong fish (Cheilodactylus fuscus) found in the coastal waters of Sydney were in excess of maximum limits recommended by the NHMRC.

(4) I am aware of an unpublished report which describes findings from indoor air monitoring studies conducted in conjunction with the NSW WorkCover Authority and the NSW Department of Agriculture. The significance of these findings has yet to be assessed.

(5) Decisions on the registration of these chemicals for specified uses are the responsibility of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council (AAVCC) while controls on their availability are regulated by the States and Territories through poisons scheduling on the basis of recommendations of the NHMRC Drugs and Poisons Schedule Standing Committee (DPSSC). The findings of the NHMRC Report will be communicated both to AAVCC and DPSSC for consideration.

(6) No. Legal advice has not been obtained through or from my Department in respect of any actual or possible liability arising from the provision of advice by Government agencies to the public on the use of cyclodiene insecticides. The common law duty of care which generally may apply where advice is given to the public has, of course, often been the subject of legal advice within the portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister's Department entered into consultancies by contract, subcontract or other means during 1991 and 1992 with Turnbull Fox Phillips; if so in each case:
(a) what sum was paid for the consultancy,
(b) what was the purpose of the consultancy,
(c) were any delegations exercised in respect of the consultancy; if so, (i) what were they, (ii) who exercised them and (iii) when were they exercised,
(d) what duties and functions were to be performed by the consultant,
(e) when were the duties and functions performed,
(f) what advice did the Department receive from the consultant,
(g) did the advice conform with the objectives which were the basis of the advice,
(h) was the advice accepted; if so, why; if not, why not,
(i) what criteria were used to establish the objectives which were the basis of the advice,
(j) how were the objectives derived,
(k) how was the conformity of the advice to the criteria of the objectives monitored and evaluated,
(l) who established the objectives and criteria,
(m) what were the qualifications of those who established the objectives and criteria,
(n) how did the objectives and criteria relate to the delegations exercised by the officers who authorised or recommended that the advice be obtained,
(o) did the Department get value for money from the consultancy, and
(p) did any firm of which Turnbull Fox Phillips is a member, shareholder, employee or subcontractor receive payment; if so, what sum.
(2) Is the Minister able to say whether consultants as individuals or as firms are making donations to the ALP for election campaign or other purposes.
(3) Is the Minister able to say whether any portion of the sums paid for the consultancies referred to in part (1) was subsequently donated to the ALP for election campaign or other purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Social Security did not enter into consultancies by contract, subcontract or other means during 1991 or 1992 with Turnbull Fox Phillips.
Questions (1) (a) to (p) are not applicable.

(2) The Department holds no information on consultants engaged by it during 1991 and 1992 which indicates that consultants as individuals or as firms are making donations to the ALP for election campaign or other purposes.
(3) Not applicable.
